headline: Hand-Held Unit and Keyboard Part Ways, Linked by Infrared
abstract: Most keyboards for hand-held organizers require that the organizer be carefully placed in the flimsy data bracket at the top of the unit -- a delicate process somewhat akin to slipping the Oxford English Dictionary onto a music stand: it should work, but you get the feeling it wasn't meant to.      In this context, the Wireless Link from Micro-Innovations (www.mi-products.com) might more aptly be called bracketless. Rather than a fragile data port, the keyboard uses an infrared transmitter to send letters and numbers to a freestanding organizer inches away.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Oil Refiner Cuts Output
abstract: Idemitsn

headline: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Wildblue Raises $158 Million In New Capital
abstract: WildBlue Communications, which aims to provide high-speed Internet service via satellite starting in 2004, says it raised $158 million in new venture capital from five investors (S)

headline: New Hostage Toll in Russian Siege Feeds Rumors
abstract: Rumors continue to swirl in Moscow around death roll from deadly commando raid that freed hostages being held by Chechen terrorists; authorities now report 128 hostages died, five from gunshot wounds rather than from gas pumped into theater (S)

headline: COMPANIES FOUND LIABLE IN ASBESTOS LAWSUIT
abstract: Florida jury rules that Union Carbide and other building-products makers are responsible for lung ailments of construction worker who was exposed to asbestos; awards $1.8 million to worker, Yves Lagueux (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Nortel Reports 11th Quarterly Net Loss
abstract: Nortel Networks Corp says third-quarter loss narrowed to $1.80 billion from $3.47 billion loss year earlier; sales fell to $2.36 billion from $3.69 billion (S)

headline: Racism Up After 9/11, European Monitor Says
abstract: European Union's racism monitor Bob Purkiss warns bias against Muslims and Jews has increased in Europe since Sept 11 terrorism and subsequent escalation of Israeli-Palestinian conflict, report to European Union leaders; cites danger that racism has embedded itself; calls on union to deal with social and economic factors fueling prejudice; blames news media and politicians for fomenting racism; French National Assembly unanimously adopts bill toughening penalties against racist and anti-Semitic acts and putting greater pressure on local officials to prosecute such acts (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Bank In Stock Buyback
abstract: Standard Chartered hires UBS Warburg to help it repurchase up to $1 billion of preferred stock in attempt to increase returns to shareholders (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: CARGILL, Wayzata, Minn., agreed to acquire Peter's Chocolates, a unit of Nestlé, Vevey, Switzerland. Cargill plans to keep the Peter's brand and sales force but shift production to its Wilbur Chocolate subsidiary.    SYNERGY FINANCIAL GROUP, Cranford, N.J., said it would buy First Bank of Central Jersey, North Brunswick, N.J., for $2.1 million.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Finland: Worrying Statistics
abstract: Haaga Center for Neurological Research and Rehabilitation in Helsinki, Finland, reports unusual sleep patterns in population that could be attributed to national tendency of internalizing problems instead of talking about them; survey finds one-third of Finns suffer from sleep disorders, which is higher than any other European country (S)

headline: U.S. to Seek To Abolish Many Tariffs
abstract: Bush administration will propose plan to eliminate all tariffs on industrial and consumer goods by 2015, eliminating about $18 billion in tariffs that American consumers pay each year; proposal plays to US strengths and will require most other countries to cut their tariffs more drastically and more rapidly than US; trade experts say administration may be trying to regain credibility on free-trade issues after giving in to demands for protectionist measures from steel industry and from American farmers earlier in year; proposal is almost certain to run into objections from many countries in Latin America and Asia, which are likely to argue that their domestic industries will have to endure severe competitive jolts on industrial side while still facing steep barriers to American markets for agriculture (M)

headline: Flinging Billions to Acquire Assets That No One Else Would Touch
abstract: Analysis of criminal complaint filed against Enron's former chief financial officer Andrew S Fastow says complaint describes instances of Enron's entering into huge acquisitions demanding billions of dollars in cash, only to find shortly afterward that deals were disasters that had to be sold to avoid damaging its financial performance; holds some of acquired assets were so unattractive that no independent buyer would ever consider purchasing them; says questionable deals included Enron's ownership of 65 percent of company that was building power plant in Cuiaba, Brazil, that was over budget and did not look promising, Enron's ownership of three electricity-generating power barges off coast of Nigeria that no one wanted to buy, and Enron's ownership of 1.09 million shares of Avici Systems that company could not sell because it had received them as part of initial public offering; chart (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Blackberry Maker Lays Off 10% Of Work Force
abstract: Research in Motion, maker of BlackBerry e-mail pager, will lay off about 10 percent of its Canadian work force, or 220 employees, in cost-reduction effort; graph (S)

abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   4.25   4.25   5.00       Discount rate   0.75   0.75   1.50       Federal funds   1.25   1.20   1.52       3-month T-bills   1.18   1.13   1.71       6-month T-bills   1.22   1.20   1.80       10-yr. headline: Wired, Yes, but Drawing the Line
abstract: Many people are drawing the line on how much information and communications technology to allow in their lives, and many of them have high-level jobs in high-tech industries; they are aware, perhaps more than most, that personal choices they make about cellphones, handheld computers, laptops and other technology are reflection not only of way they perceive themselves but also of way they would like to be perceived by others; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: UKRAINE: New Prime Minister; ITALY: Archbishop, Unmarried, Returns To Duties; MONACO: Trial In Billionaire'S Death Starts; TURKEY: Head Scarf Furor;.

headline: Warring Afghan Factions Fire on Green Berets, but They Pay a Price
abstract: United States Army reports American bombers hit positions held by two factions that had been fighting each other in Western Afghanistan after American Special Forces came under fire near Shindand; move seen warning to rival Afghan factions to quell their fighting; Hajji Muhammad says planes bombed his positions and those of Ismail Khan, phone interview; fighting between Khan's group and faction led by Amanullah Khan seems to be over control of Shindand air base and nearby border crossing to Iran; map (M)

headline: 3 Big Advertisers Seeking New Agencies
abstract: Three large advertisers said yesterday that they were beginning account reviews, after unexpectedly parting ways with their agencies.    The Timex Corporation and the Minneapolis office of Fallon Worldwide, part of the Publicis Groupe, are ending a 16-year relationship as of Dec. 31.

headline: NORTHWEST AIRLINES ASKS FOR RELIEF ON PENSIONS
abstract: Northwest Airlines expects pension-related expense of more than $700 million at end of 2002; asks federal regulators to ease conditions of its required pension fund contributions (S)

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: GERMANY: Can Marital Strife Turn Hair Gray?; FRANCE: Ski Resort Doctors Stage Strike; RUSSIA: Appeal To Reopen Kursk Inquiry; SWEDEN: Violent End For Red-Nosed Elk;.

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Health Care Report
abstract: Canada must increase spending on health care by 15.3 billion Canadian dollars ($9.7 billion) in three years or risk abandoning its system of universal access to free medical treatment, a report commissioned by the government concluded. Roy Romanow, a former premier of Saskatchewan who conducted an 18-month review of Canadian health care, said the 34-year-old Medicare system is cracking under the strain of underfinancing and rising costs. He urged the government to spend 8.5 billion Canadian dollars ($5.4 billion) more in the next two years to fix shortcomings that may be leading to early deaths, like long waiting lists for diagnostic services and shortages of doctors and equipment in rural areas.

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY  None

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Agilent Posts 4th-Quarter Loss
abstract: Agilent Technologies reports fourth-quarter loss of $236 million (S)

headline: Mexico's Amber Miners Find Risk, Not Riches
abstract: Deep in the earth, surrounded by the pale light of a single candle, Juan Gutiérrez Guzmán is laboring with a sledgehammer and a spike, looking for the ancient sparkle of amber.    Buried in darkness, bathed in sweat and dust, he searches through the rubble for a tiny nugget that might bring him a dollar or two.

headline: Brazil's Presidential Election Reflects Power of São Paulo
abstract: Brazil's presidential election between two candidates from Sao Paulo reflects growing political power of country's most important economic center; photos; map; Rio de Janeiro is better known outside Brazil, but Sao Paulo state, with 38 million people, is nation's 'true center of gravity,' accounting for third of gross domestic product; engine is metropolitan Sao Paulo, which has grown from 31,000 people in 1870 to more than 18 million, third-largest urban area in world (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: China: Yangtze Closed For Huge Dam Project
abstract: Engineers close off Yangtze River, China; $25-billion hydroelectric project to build Three Gorges Dam displaces over a million people (S)

headline: Growing Poverty Is Shrinking Mexico's Rain Forest
abstract: Mexico's remaining rain forests are disappearing as peasants slash and burn jungle to create little patches of land on which to farm; crops will soon fail because of thin topsoil, and then land will be grazed by cattle until rains wash earth away; Zapatista rebel movement is starting to turn against ecologists who want to save remains of forest, accusing them of waging 'war of extermination' against indigenous communities; photo; map (M)

headline: Mutual Funds Report; The Bright Side of Losses: Years of Tax Savings
abstract: Big losses for mutual funds could become boon when markets rise; funds' capital gains would then be sheltered from taxes, offset by losses incurred earlier; photo; table (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: 5 Abducted By North Korea To Stay In Japan
abstract: Five Japanese returned to Japan after lengthy stay in North Korea after being abducted hold joint press conference announcing their decision to stay in homeland and express wish for their families to join them; Hitomi Soga, American soldier Robert Charles Jenkins' wife, declares intent to visit mother-in-law in US; Jenkins, still in North Korea, has been listed as deserter since 1965 when he disappeared near demilitarized zone; photo (S)

headline: World Briefing | Ecology: Japan Rebuffed On Whaling
abstract: Meeting of 160 nations adhering to Convention on Trade in Endangered Species, Santiago, Chile, rejects bids by Japan to allow limited trade in meat and blubber from minke and Bryde's whales (S)

headline: Broadcom Cuts Work Force by 16%
abstract: The Broadcom Corporation today laid off more than 500 workers, or 16 percent of its work force, and consolidated units to reduce costs amid slumping sales of some lines of computer chips.    In an interview, the company's chief executive, Henry Nicholas, declined to say precisely how many jobs were cut. Broadcom combined groups that develop chips for big telecommunications networks and that make chips for office networks because of slow growth in the former business, he said. The company did not eliminate any product lines, he added.

headline: The Gifts So Nice They're Given Twice
abstract: Martha Crotty letter comments on Nov 17 article about gifts given twice

headline: Kenyans Cast Ballots and Wait, Mostly Peacefully
abstract: Kenyans, offered their first true choice in 24 years, line up to cast ballots in presidential election; candidates are 42-year-old businessman Uhuru Kenyatta, who is choice of outgoing Pres Daniel arap Moi, veteran politician and opposition leader Mwai Kibaki and three others representing minor parties; some voters, mostly those who are opposition backers, discover they have been left off voting rolls; some violence and vote rigging is reported; polls indicate that Kibaki is likely to win; photo (M)

headline: Sarsen Is Retiring As Association Head
abstract: John J Sarsen Jr, president and chief exec of Association of National Advertisers in New York for almost nine years, will retire next month (S)

headline: Mexican Oil Contract Is Victory for President
abstract: President Vicente Fox has won a major political battle with old Mexico, forcing the powerful union at the state-run oil giant, Pemex, to call off a strike that would have sent the nation reeling.     Now comes the larger struggle to make Pemex work. Hundreds of billions of dollars, not to mention Mr. Fox's political fortunes, are at stake.

headline: Nuclear Study Raises Fears About Weapon
abstract: National Nuclear Security Administration is authorized to spend $15 million to study modifying nuclear weapons so they can be used to destroy underground factories and laboratories, such as ones that are thought to be used by some countries, including Iraq and North Korea, for producing and storing nuclear, chemical and biological weapons (M)

headline: Executive Quits As Bayer Wins Patent Case
abstract: Frank Morich, chief executive of Bayer AG's health care division, resigns; will be immediately replaced by Rolf Classon, head of diagnostic products unit; Bayer agrees to sell its insecticide and fungicide business to BASF for $1.16 billion, fulfilling commitment it made last year to win European regulatory approval to buy Aventis CropSciences; federal appeals court in Washington upholds Bayer's American patent for Cipro, antibiotic used to fight systematic infections that respond to few other drugs; declines to allow Bayer's rivals to begin making equivalents to Cipro before patent expires in December 2003; photo (M)

headline: No Calipers or Cringing: A Discreet Gauge of Body Fat
abstract: Fat analysis scale looks like traditional bathroom scale, but by sending small electrical current through body is able calculate body fat composition using bioelectric impedance analysis; works on principle that muscle is good electrical conductor and fat is not; however, several variables can throw off measurement; illustration; photos (M)

headline: A Computing Pioneer Joins Hewlett-Packard
abstract: Dr Alan Kay, personal computing innovator who was leader of Xerox's pioneering Palo Alto Research Center in 1970's, joins Hewlett-Packard as senior researcher; discusses plans, interview (M)

headline: With West Bank Stones and Gunfire, Another Child Dies
abstract: Ten-year-old Palestinian boy is shot and killed by Israeli gunfire; Israeli military says troops patrolling Palestinian town of Tulkarm, West Bank, had responded to a riot with weapons not intended to cause death; photo; map (M)

headline: Foster's Beer Is Up for Review
abstract: Miller Brewing division of SABMiller says it has placed in review assignment to create campaigns for Foster's beer, which has been handled by Chicago office of J Walter Thompson (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: India: Interest In Russian Weapons
abstract: Indian and Russian officials discussed a proposal for India to build advanced fighter jets under license and with Russian help, and for India to buy a 15-year-old Russian aircraft carrier. Indian military officials have been increasingly nervous as China has bought large amounts of the latest Russian  weaponry.   Keith Bradsher (NYT)

headline: Guilty Plea Is Expected From Trader
abstract: John M Rusnak, Baltimore currency trader who is accused of hiding losses of $691 million at Allfirst Financial for five years, will plead guilty to bank fraud charges; office of US attorney for Maryland says it will announce guilty plea 'in a significant financial fraud case involving Allfirst Bank'; statement does not name Rusnak but no one else has been indicted in case; photo (M)

headline: Biggest Fish in a Big Pond
abstract: Globalization has had little effect on United States monetary policy decisions because foreign events rarely have a major influence on the economy, said Robert Parry, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco.    ''Globalization has not changed the goals or conduct of U.S. monetary policy to any great extent,'' Mr. Parry said at a Philadelphia conference on policy making. While Fed officials do take developments in other countries into account, ''for the most part, the effects on policy making are at the margin,'' he said.

headline: A NORTHWEST UNIT INCREASES ITS SMALL-JET ORDER
abstract: The Northwest Airlines Corporation's Pinnacle Airlines unit plans to more than double its fleet of small jets made by Bombardier Inc. as declining air travel leaves larger planes unfilled. Pinnacle serves cities such as Detroit, Minneapolis and Memphis, where it is based. It plans to add 52 Bombardier jets to its fleet of 43 by the end of 2004, 12 more than it initially planned, Pinnacle said in a regulatory filing. The jets, which carry about 50 passengers, are valued at about $20 million each.

headline: Advertisers Association Names a President
abstract: Association of National Advertisers names Robert D Liodice acting president and chief executive, replacing retiring John J Sarsen Jr (S)

headline: Russian Lawmakers Reject Plans to Investigate Hostage Horror
abstract: Lower house of Russian parliament rejects proposals for independent commission to investigate siege of Moscow theater that ended with death of at least 128 hostages and 41 Chechen hostage-takers; vote underscores government's apparent aversion to answering troubling questions, such as daring but ultimately deadly rescue by commandos (M)

headline: 11 Million Voters Say the Iraqi President Is Perfect
abstract: Iraq says Saddam Hussein has scored perfect 100 percent of 11.4 million votes cast in presidential referendum, winning further seven years as leader; Iraqi Vice Pres Izzat Ibrahim, in announcing results, seeks to deliver warning to US of popular resistance it would face if it stages military invasion; says American troops would be 'no match' for Iraqis in ground war; among ordinary Iraqis, threat of war is momentarily set aside for street demonstrations celebrating Hussein's triumph; photos (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Natural gas futures fall; gas for December delivery loses 12.1 cents, or 2.8 percent, to trade at $4.14 per million BTU's; graph (S)

headline: Indonesian Human Rights Court Acquits 4 in East Timor Killings
abstract: A P J Abdul Kalam, India's Muslim president, pays visit to Sri Sathya Sai Baba, Hindu holy man at ashram in Puttaparthy, who preaches unusual mixture of faiths and encourages nonviolence; photo; map (M)

headline: The Collections / Paris : Ungaro and Lagerfeld get the right mix
abstract: PARIS—  What is the essence of glamour? Is it John Galliano in snow white suit and fedora descending from the heavens at the Paris Lido — to land among befeathered showgirls at the launch of Dior's Addict fragrance?

headline: World Briefing | Arctic Ocean: Dilution Could Cut Off Europe's Heat
abstract: Science journal reports that flow of major rivers into Arctic Ocean has increased 7 percent since 1936; rise in river water contribution reduces salt content, which appears to be linked to changes in atmospheric pressure; continued increases in flow of rivers and consequent changing ocean currents could impact Western European weather patterns and keep warmer air from moving north; map (S)

headline: U.S. Aide Touring Europe to Cut Qaeda Finances
abstract: Treasury Under Sec Jimmy Gurule is in Europe to press financial regulators and bankers there to make more determined effort to shut down Al Qaeda's financial network (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Dell Offers Discount
abstract: Dell Computer is offerø

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Speak Gaelic Or Hit the High Road
abstract: West Ireland Galway County Council institutes ban on new residents who do not speak fluent Gaelic in effort to preserve Gaeltacht region's language; Gaelic usage is declining and supporters feel insular community will keep extinction of their culture at bay; critics call ban discriminatory (S)

headline: Kibbutz Attack Threatens Ties to Arab Neighbors
abstract: Palestinian gunman infiltrates Kibbutz Metzer near West Bank, shooting to death five people, including two children, before escaping; incident shatters calm of bucolic farming community and threatens close ties it has formed over decades with neighboring Arab villages; their representatives come to pay their respects to the dead; photo; map (M)

headline: Dutch Shut IKEA Stores After Bombs Are Found
abstract: Investigators close aÿ

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Accounting Firm Disputes Webster Claim on Company  One of the nation's biggest accounting firms has accused William H. Webster, the head of the new accounting oversight board, of making ''false and misleading statements'' about what he knew of the financial problems of a company whose audit committee he headed.    Mr. Webster denied the accusation by the accounting firm, BDO Seidman, and defended his work for the company, U.S. Technologies, which has been accused of fraud. But he said that he was considering whether to step down from the oversight board, a decision that he plans to make after the elections. [Page A1.]

headline: Does Schröder Have Political Capital to Reform Economy?
abstract: German Chancellor Gerhard Schroder, who has long promised economic reforms, faces questions about whether he has courage and political capital to tackle woes with his popularity falling and economy tipping toward second recession in year; pressure to address problems is coming from within Germany and from nation's European Union partners; labor unions and other vested interests that form base of Schoder's support have stymied reform and upcoming elections in two states make it hard for Schroder or opposition to propose unpopular measures; graph; photo (M)

headline: Chicago's Block 37 Finally Becomes a Contender
abstract: Chicago is days away from repurchasing Block 37, parcel of land in prime location, 13 years after it sold land and development rights to group of renowned local real estate minds; succession of mayors and developers failed to develop parcel; city now hopes to develop major mixed-use project; photo; map (M)

headline: Anti-American Feeling Rises in Pakistan as U.S. Confronts Iraq
abstract: Suspicion of and disenchantment with US is spreading in Pakistan, fed by anger at US policies toward Iraq and Israel, new American immigration policies, anti-Muslim statements by conservative American religious leaders and misleading accounts in some Pakistani newspapers; there is also fear that Pakistan could be next US target after Iraq; photos (M)

headline: Weblogs and Gender
abstract: Karen Feng letter disputes contention that more than women are writing Weblogs

headline: Kenya's Ruling Party Is Defeated After 39 Years
abstract: Kenyans elect opposition leader Mwai Kibaki as their new president, in resounding defeat for party that has ruled over country for nearly four decades; result leaves no doubt about voters' opinion of 24-year rule of retiring president Daniel arap Moi, whose chosen successor Uhuru Kenyatta is rejected throughout country; this is first election governing party has lost since independence in 1963; election officials declare Kibaki winner as ballots are still being tabulated; say margin is so great that none of his four rivals stand chance; independent election watchers give Kibaki 63 percent of vote, compared with 20 percent for Kenyatta, second-place finisher; Kibaki is former finance minister and vice president to Moi who broke with him decade ago; has vowed to change Kenya's fortunes by turning tide on corruption, poverty and authoritarian rule; Moi's decision to retire, as required by country's Constitution, and to allow bitter rival to replace him is seen as milestone in development of Kenya's democracy; photos; map; brief recap of country's history since 1963 (L)

headline: Big Investors Push for Disclosure Of How Venture Firms Are Faring
abstract: Institutional investors in several states, stung by accounting scandals, are pushing for greater transparency and disclosure not just from public companies, but from private equity and venture capital firms, which have long operated outside public eye; University of Texas publishes financial performance of all its investments, including venture capital funds; disclosure comes over fierce objection of some of venture capitalists, with whom university signed confidentiality agreements promising not to disclose figures; University of Texas Investment Management Co chief executive Bob Bardt says fund came under pressure from elected officials and local media; proponents relied on state law that requires disclosure of returns for public investments; Massachusetts Pension Reserves Investment Management Board has received requests to disclose its private equity investment performance; University of Texas system chancellor Mark G Yudof says university's investments should be 'publicly accountable' (M)

headline: Market Place; Talk in Capital Of Easing Taxes On Dividends
abstract: Pres Bush and members of Congress are considering ending 'double taxation' on dividends; under current law, company pays corporate income taxes on its profits, and receives no deduction for dividends it pays to shareholders; shareholders then pay taxes at ordinary income-tax rates on dividends they receive; companies have sometimes talked about ending this taxation of dividends, but there has been little lobbying on it; tend to prefer specific proposals that would benefit them, rather than generalized idea that would help their shareholders, and everyone else's; Pres Bush backs reform (Market Place column) (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Questions For Fiat
abstract: Italian stock market regulator asks ailing conglomerate Fiat to report whether it has replaced plans to overhaul its unprofitable auto division with other proposals (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Wireless Service Planned
abstract: NTT DoCoMo will begin offering its third-generation wireless service in United States in 2004; DoCoMo and AT&T Wireless Services, its partner in United States, will begin service in San Francisco (S)

headline: Turkish Media Executive Is Sentenced
abstract: Cem Uzan, a Turkish media executive, was sentenced to 15 months in prison today for contempt of court for failing to give testimony related to charges that he and family members owe billions of dollars to Nokia and Motorola.    Mr. Uzan's sister, Aysegul Akay, was also sentenced, to six months in prison, for contempt after failing to appear at hearings over the last two months.

headline: More Young Victims Falling On Front Lines in the Mideast
abstract: Current Palestinian uprising enters its third year with Israeli forces reoccupying most West Bank cities; children are often on front line as soldiers use live ammunition to enforce curfews and break up violent street protests, sometimes with deadly results; in most recent incident, soldiers open fire during stone-throwing clash at village near Jenin, killing 15-year-old boy; photo (M)

headline: TICKETMASTER TO ACQUIRE DANISH TICKETING BUSINESS
abstract: Ticketmaster To Acquire Danish Ticketing Business*

headline: Telling All Online: It's a Man's World (Isn't It?)
abstract: Weblogs, commonly called blogs, personal Web sites where people spout their thoughts for all to read, are fairly evenly divided between men and women, but subject matter is vastly different; men's blogs generally comment on news and politics and women's tend to be more inwardly focused; cursory inspection can lead surfer to think men are more prolific because they are linked more to each other's blogs, while women's blogs can be found in directories like Blog Sisters; there are signs that tables are turning, as more men's blogs contain personal tidbits and women are surveying the body politic; drawing; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Road Panel Resignation
abstract: Takashi Imai, head of panel charged with privatizing Japan's road-building operations, resigns because his committee cannot agree on how to spin off state-held orgns; photo (S)

headline: Investing; FedEx Has Hit the Ground Running, but Will Its Legs Tire?
abstract: FedEx shares rise 29.9 percent over last 12 months -- even as Standard & Poor's 500-stock index loses 23.9 percent; company tries to insulate itself from vagaries of national economy; investment professionals differ on outlook for company's future earnings and stock price; photo; graph (M)

headline: U.S. WARNING IRAQ OVER NEW ATTACKS ON PATROL PLANES
abstract: Bush administration warns Iraq it breached UN resolution by firing on American and British planes patrolling southern no-flight zones but stops short of casting violation as sufficient reason to go to war; leaves seriousness of incidents deliberately ambiguous; underscores seriousness of threat to American and British pilots while reserving idea that attacks on allied warplanes are part of pattern of intransigence that ultimately could be used to make case for war; decides against bringing issue before UN Security Council, faced with lack of support by council members; will focus primarily on pressing Pres Saddam Hussein to cooperate in giving up arsenal of weapons of mass destruction; UN weapons inspectors arrive in Baghdad to begin search for evidence of chemical, biological and nuclear weapons and programs to produce them; photos (M)

headline: A High-Tech Fix for One Corner of India
abstract: N Chandrababu Naidu, chief minister of state of Andhra Pradesh, India, has moved decisively to move turn his state, one of poorest in India, into high-tech region; city of Hyderabad has been transformed from quiet administrative center of agricultural state into computer programming and pharmaceuticals hub that is trying to rival Bangladore, nearly 300 miles to south; Naidu, with a businesslike, long-term approach to public policy in country long bedeviled by populists pursuing short-term fixes, had become darling of Western governments and corporations; photos (L)

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: RUSSIA: Population And Politics In Chechnya; EUROPEAN UNION DEFINES CHILD PORNOGRAPHY; GREECE: Electoral Gains By The Right; VATICAN: More Tensions With Russia;.

headline: World Business Briefing: Europe
abstract: BRITAIN: Bid For Retailer; ITALY: Protests Over Fiat Cuts;.

headline: Global Trade Looking Glass: Can U.S. Have It Both Ways?
abstract: New Bush administration farm subsidies and other barriers to American marketplace cause some US trading partners to doubt America's commitment to free trade; US pursuit of trade agreements outside World Trade Organization diminishes pre-eminence of WTO and may impede crucial round of global trade negotiations; US trade representative, Robert B Zoellick, says that all countries' negotiators have to balance domestic self-interests with those of their trading partners; poorer members of WTO fear being marginalized in negotiations; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Zany Brainy To Stop Selling Video Games
abstract: Zany Brainy toy stores' owner FAO Inc will stop selling video games at its 170 locations because there are not enough video games for children below age ten (S)

headline: Calpers Wears a Party, or Union, Label
abstract: Board of California Public Employees' Retirement System, which is responsible for growth and safety of $136 billion in retirement funds of 1.3 million public employees whose pensions it guarantees, is criticized for being too activist, too eager to promote social change through investing; all 13 board members represent either labor or Democratic Party and have ability to steer huge blocks of capital toward investments favorable to labor; Calpers officials say that their top priority continues to be seeking maximum returns and that fund has not abandoned its mission of pressuring companies on behalf of investors, but outsiders say these assertions mast important shift toward interests of organized labor, one that has prompted at least some of recent series of high-level resignations; photos; graphs; list of members (M)

headline: WAL-MART SAYS SAME-STORE SALES MET FORECAST
abstract: Wal-Mart Stores says sales at stores open at least year met forecast of 2 percent to 4 percent gain (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Dollar weakens against Japanese yen, which settles at 120.44 to the dollar; yen exchange rate graph; table of other currency conversions (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Ruling On Insurance Stakes
abstract: Italy's stock market regulator rules Societa Assicuratrice Industriale and Mediobanca, companies that have purchased minority stakes in insurer La Fondiaria Assicurazioni, will not have to bid for remaining Fondiaria shares, reversing August 2001 ruling; says two companies will have to reduce their combined holdings to less than 30 percent of Fondiaria by Feb 18; they now own 43 percent; upset minority shareholders prepare legal action as stock tumbles (S)

headline: Oil Prize, Past and Present, Ties Russia to Iraq
abstract: Russian diplomats participating in United Nations debate on Iraq are ever mindful of Russian oil companies' extensive interests in Iraqi oil; about 10 Russian companies have development agreements with Iraq; very little oil is being produced now at fields because of UN embargo; Russian companies worry that if military action by United States topples Saddam Hussein, it will also break their own hold on potentially lucrative oil fields (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Ukraine: New Prime Minister
abstract: Viktor F Yanukovich, Ukranian President Leonid D Kuchma's nominee for prime minister, is approved by parliament (S)

headline: Unions Bristle at United's Proposed Cuts
abstract: Union officials at United Airlines say they are shocked and angered by size of concessions company is demanding of them to meet cost-cutting stipulations set by lenders; Assn of Flight Attendants posts message on its Web site telling members that United wants to cut $2.4 billion a year from labor costs and that company needs to reach agreements with its unions by mid-February to continue to obtain financing; photo (M)

headline: New Kind of Dam Rises in Switzerland: To Hold Back the Land
abstract: Construction workers in village of Pontresina, Switzerland, put finishing touches on giant earth dam designed to keep residents safe from cliff that scientists say is in danger of crumbling because permafrost that anchors it is melting; village official calls structure a precaution against warming Alpine climate; he says permafrost will not be here in 20 years because of global warming (S)

headline: Tenet Hospital In California Is Searched By U.S. Agents
abstract: Tenet Healthcare says its California-based Redding Medical Center was raided by FBI agents seeking information for investigation into unnecessary surgeries, including open-heart surgery, and possible Medicare billing fraud; Federal officials say there is reason to believe 'many known and unknown patients' have been victims of scheme to cause patients to undergo unnecessary invasive coronary procedures, including artery bypass surgery, and heart value replacement surgery; Tenet says it has no reason to believe accusations are true; agents search offices of Dr Chae Hyun Moon, director of cardiology, and Dr Fidel Realyvasquez Jr, hospital's chairman of cardiac surgery; photo (M)

headline: Business; Stepping Up in TV, Without Stepping on Toes
abstract: Profile of Michael Tollin and Brian Robbins and their Tollin/Robbins Productions, producer of mainstream films and prime-time television series; Clear Channel Communications now owns company and uses it as beachhead into film and television; photos (M)

headline: F.T.C. Opens Inquiry Into Hospital Merger
abstract: FTC will investigate 1999 merger of two hospitals in Poplar Bluff, Miss, owned by Tenet Healthcare in effort to assess both potential anti-competitive effects and synergies and efficiencies that hospital systems have realized; sought to block merger, but was rebuffed by court; Tenet say its Palm Beach Gardens Medical Center in Florida is taking corrective action on problems with infection control (M)

headline: Navy Hospital Ship Is Activated for Duty
abstract: In another major sign of preparations for a possible war against Iraq, the Navy has activated one of its two 1,000-bed hospital ships, the Comfort, to be sent for possible duty in the Persian Gulf.    Activating the Comfort signals that the Bush administration is preparing for large numbers of American casualties, and is ready to take the risk to back up its threat to use military force to disarm Iraq. The Comfort has 12 operating rooms and is equipped to deal with major trauma cases and casualties from chemical and biological weapons.

headline: Bush Intervenes to Halt West Coast Port Dispute
abstract: President Bush announced he would seek a court injunction to end the 11-day shutdown of 29 West Coast ports.

headline: Kenya's Ruling Party Picks Kenyatta Son to Succeed President
abstract: Long-ruling Kenya Africa National Union (KANU) picks Uhuru Kenyatta, son of Kenya's patriarch Jomo Kenyatta, as candidate to replace retiring President Daniel arap Moi, who has led country since independence in 1978; is chosen as successor in move engineered by Moi, upsetting many in party who favor more open and democratic process; move prompts resignation by dissident party members, who vow campaign against Kenyatta; photo (M)

headline: Personal Business; Divide and Conquer: Duplexes May Ease the Way Into a Home
abstract: Article on advantages and disadvantages of purchasing duplex house and renting out half in order to make home ownership more affordable; in many cases home buyers may have easier time qualifying for mortgages on two-family homes than on single-family homes; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Jobless Rate Falls
abstract: Hong Kong's seasonally adjusted unemployment rate fell to 7.4 percent in period from July to September, compared with 7.6 percent in three-month period through August and 7.8 percent in three-month period through July; personal bankruptcies more than tripled in September compared with year earlier, to 2,580 (S)

headline: Consuls Lax In Screening For Visas, Report Says
abstract: State Department inspector general reports that system for issuing nonimmigrant visas remains too lax and poorly financed to screen out determined terrorists; reports that many consular officials are inexperienced or inadequately trained, that visa review procedures vary from embassy to embassy and that program to identify terrorism suspects needs more money (M)

headline: Regulators Sue Ernst & Young In the Collapse Of an S.& L.
abstract: Federal regulators filed suit today against Ernst & Young, one of the nation's largest accounting firms, seeking more than $2 billion in damages for what they say was the firm's role in the collapse of a savings and loan last year.    Regulators accused Ernst & Young of committing fraud in its audit of Superior Bank, which regulators seized last year in one of the largest banking failures in a decade, by misrepresenting the bank's poor finances and hiding its mounting problems.

headline: Pressure Is Building On Banks In Japan
abstract: Largest Japanese banks sense political and market pressures to deal with mountain of bad loans; major banks sharply reduce profit forecasts and hasten disposal of non-performing loans; government wants banks to liquidate indebted companies with little prospect of repaying; some politicians fear liquidations would cause widespread layoffs and cost political contributions from foreclosed businesses; Japan's five largest banks intend to write off nearly 3 trillion yen ($24.5 billion) this fiscal year; graph (M)

headline: Some Anxiety in Russia As Monopoly Nears End
abstract: Russia got new start last week on one of its boldest economic reforms in years: breaking up its vast electricity monopoly; many questions remain about how plan will be implemented and investors and some lawmakers have warned that process risks repeating flaws and mistakes of privatization in Russia in mid-1990's; central concern that critics have about breakup of monopoly, Unified Energy Systems, is that it is being driven by company's chief executive Anatoly B Chubais, who was principal architect of earlier privatization program; breakup plan clears early legal hurdle on Sept 10 when package of bills that will set plan into motion was passed in first of three required votes in lower house of Parliament; photo (M)

headline: Auto Workers and Daimler In Tentative Deal in Canada
abstract: Canadian Auto Workers union reaches tentative agreement with DaimlerChrysler on new three-year contract covering 13,000 workers; tentative agreement is announced 25 minutes before union's strike deadline of midnight; photo (M)

headline: Hartland Molson, Hockey Owner, 95, Dies
abstract: Hartland deM Molson, former owner of Montreal Canadiens hockey team and heir of one of Canada's oldest business families, dies at age of 95; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Gives U.N. an Iraq Measure, Seeking a Council Vote Tomorrow
abstract: United States presents United Nations Security Council with proposal for resolution, revised to draw support of France, that would give Iraq last chance to accept rigorous weapons inspections and disarm or face American-led war; France does not immediately accept draft, but Amb Jean-David Levitte acknowledges that 'very important progress has been achieved' and Pres Jacques Chirac reportedly consults with Russian Pres Vladimir Putin about removing 'certain ambiguities' about use of force; proposal, which is also sponsored by Great Britain, preserves United States prerogative to attack if Iraq fails to comply with United Nations inspections and also allows for second round of Council decision-making sought by France; would set up far more intrusive program than in past, including inspections of Saddam Hussein's palaces and other presidential sites; if resolution is adopted, Iraq would have seven days to declare whether it intends to comply and 30 days to present comprehensive declaration of all its weapons of mass destruction; photos (M)

headline: UNOCAL TO BUY REMAINING SHARES OF PURE RESOURCES
abstract: Pure Resources senior managers agree to sell their shares in company after Unocal Corp raises its bid for 35 percent of company it does not already own; revised offers if for $376.9 million (S)

headline: Market Place; S.E.C. Puts Data Disclosure In the Spotlight
abstract: SEC files first three cases against companies that it says violated new regulation barring selective release of important information, obtaining cease-and-desist orders against Siebel Systems, Raytheon and Secure Computing; fines Siebel $250,000 as well; lets Motorola off with only a report because it secured legal advice, even though that advice was wrong; appears to be trying to lay out clearly just what behavior is prohibited while trying to reassure companies that they will not be penalized if they act in good faith (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Volkswagen's Profit Slides
abstract: Volkswagen AG's third-quarter profit fell 51 percent, to 439 million euros ($432 million), while sales increased 2 percent, to 21 billion euros (S)

headline: Blair Warns Troops to Be Prepared For a War
abstract: British Prime Min Tony Blair, in Christmas radio message, warns troops to prepare for action against Iraq if Saddam Hussein fails to comply with UN weapons inspections; Britain reportedly is preparing to send up to 20,000 troops along with tanks and other supplies to region in coming weeks (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Télécom Debt Refinancing
abstract: France Telecom will sell at least 1.5 billion euros ($1.5 billion) of bonds to refinance its debt, which is about 70 billion euros; also plans to sell 250 million pounds of ($392.6 million) of bonds (S)

headline: For Retailers, a Halloween That's Not Too Scary
abstract: National Retail Federation estimates sales of Halloween items will total $6.9 billion, or $44 a household, $1 less than in 2001; graphs (M)

headline: Technology Briefing: Hardware
abstract: FASTER MICROCHIP PROTOTYPES DEVELOPED; HARRIS LOWERS PROFIT FORECAST; SUN MICROSYSTEMS' CREDIT RATING LOWERED;.

headline: European Union Acts to Admit 10 Nations
abstract: European Union, in biggest expansion in its history, adds Poland, Czech Republic, Hungary, Slovakia, Lithuania, Latvia, Estonia, Slovenia, Cyprus and Malta to its membership, effective in May 2004; expansion will create mega-Europe of 450 million people in 25 countries and with economy of more than $9 trillion; photo (M)

headline: Brazilian Meets Bush and Vows to Cooperate on Freer Trade
abstract: Brazilian Pres-elect Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva, who campaigned against global reach of American power, meets with Pres Bush, Washington, pledging to work with him to open both nations' markets to freer trade; aides say they established working rapport despite their broad ideological differences; da Silva lauds Bush and says he can count on Bush as ally (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Deflationary Trend Ends
abstract: Singapore's five-month deflationary trend ends with 0.2 percent rise in consumer prices in November (S)

headline: Europe Pushes for Renewable Energy
abstract: European Commission president Romano Prodi is leading drive for less reliance on fossil fuels and more use of energy from wind or sun; commission has earmarked more than 2.1 billion euros ($2 billion) for research over next five years into sustainable energy projects, 20-fold increase in last five years; central focus will be hydrogen fuel cells, field where European Union has lagged US and Japan in publicly financed research; commission convenes meeting of panel of senior executives from European companies with stakes in matter, like Royal Dutch/Shell, DaimlerChrysler and Rolls-Royce, aircraft engine maker; panel will advise union on developemnt of hydrogen fuel cells; photo (M)

headline: Italian Premier Names Rising Apprentice as Foreign Minister
abstract: italian premier names rising appreni

headline: Swedes Drop Hijacking Charge Against Armed Man at Airport
abstract: Swedish prosecutor drops hijacking charges against Kerim Chatty, who was arrested at Swedish airport in Aug when he tried to board flight to Britain with gun in his toiletry kit; case attracted international attention after Swedish investigators were said to think Chatty intended to crash plane into American embassy in Europe; Chatty denies this; he admits gun is his but says he took it to airport accidentally; Swedish prosecutor says he has been unable to refute Chatty's account of events (M)

headline: An Afterlife on Disc For That Fading Video
abstract: Adaptec sells kits for converting analog video tapes to DVD at affordable prices; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Worldcom Network Problem
abstract: WorldCom, leading Internet carrier, suffers software problem with its Internet network, slowing access to Web sites hosted on its systems; problem emerged around 8 am and was fixed by 4 pm (S)

headline: Arafat Group Drops the Idea Of a Premier
abstract: Yasir Arafat's Fatah movement drops idea of creating post of prime minister to take over Arafat's governing tasks; step had been discussed before 10-day Israeli siege of his headquarters; siege was criticized by Bush administration on grounds that it would hinder drive for democratic reform of Palestinian institutions; some Fatah officials argue that appointing prime minister would only serve American and Israeli efforts to have Arafat replaced (M)

headline: U.N. Official Won't Reveal Iraq Suppliers To the Public
abstract: Chief United Nations arms inspector Hans Blix tells Security Council that he will not release names of foreign arms suppliers that Iraq listed in its weapons declaration because they could be valuable to inspectors as sources of data about Iraq's programs; confirms that declaration detailing Iraq's deactivated secret nuclear program apparently contains bomb recipes; says he will quickly identify passages that must be screened out before document can be distributed to full Council; asks US and other permanent Council members, who have already been given copies, to quickly assess data to be filtered out (M)

headline: Panel Is Set to Prescribe Japan's Economic Medicine
abstract: Japanese Prime Min Junichiro Koizumi's Council on Economic and Fiscal Policy is set to announce series of measures aimed at supporting economy that is likely to be hurt in near term by government's plan to speed up write-off of bad loans by nation's banks; experts say with tax revenue falling and national debt exploding, such measures may, at best, only prevent another recession instead of spurring growth; council favors tax cuts and other support worth no more than 5 trillion yen ($40.2 billion), or about 1 percent of gross domestic product; council report is expected to include calls for tax cuts of 2.5 trillion yen ($20.1 billion), mostly aimed at companies (M)

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: Bending On Death Sentence
abstract: Iranian judicial lawyer Ali Mi-Mohammad Sadeghi reports reformist scholar Hashem Aghajari's death sentence will be commuted on appeal; trial of four students who were protesting Aghajari's sentence is postponed (S)

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: U.S. Journalists To Be Fingerprinted
abstract: Iranian government, responding to American policy of fingerprinting and photographing Iranians entering US, asks airport security to fingerprint and thoroughly document American journalists entering country (S)

headline: Filmmaker to Look at Racy Magazine for Ideas
abstract: New Line Cinema, in search of synergy between print and film and maybe touch of sex appeal, has turned to Maxim magazine, bawdy runaway newsstand success from Dennis Publishing US; so-called first-look deal means that New Line will have option of turning content from Maxim into film project; films would be produced under 'Maxim Presents' banner (M)

headline: World Business Briefing: Europe
abstract: BRITAIN: Rate Debate; FRANCE: Aluminum Unit Acquired; GERMANY: Bank Names Chief; THE NETHERLANDS: Layoffs At Drug Concern;.

headline: World Briefing | The Environment: Warmer Oceans Kill Reefs
abstract: Scientists say coral reefs see worst damage since 1998 as result of warming ocean temperatures; Australia's Great Barrier Reef is hardest hit (S)

headline: Protesters Shot Dead in Venezuela; Oil Deliveries Slowed
abstract: Gunman identified as Portuguese-born Joao Goveia opens fire in crowded plaza in Caracas, Venezuela, killing three antigovernment demonstrators and wounding nearly 30 others; is arrested and six other men are detained; five-day-old nationwide strike against Pres Hugo Chavez brings oil industry close to full-scale shutdown; photo; maps; graph; chart (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Bond Sale Limit May Change
abstract: Japan's Finance Min Masajuro Shiokawa says government might reconsider its 30 trillion yen ($240 billion) limit on new bond sales this year if government continues efforts to restrict spending and stem growth of state debt; photo (S)

headline: Under Fire for Sept. 11, C.I.A. Chief Gains From His Bond With Bush
abstract: CIA Director George J Tenet, who has faced bitter public criticism over intelligence failures thnat preceded Sept 11 attacks, has nonetheless survived in his job because of his close bond with Pres Bush; has been strenghthened by ongoing campaign against terrorism and crisis over Iraq; personally briefs Bush daily on intelligence issues; photo (M)

headline: Adelphia Asks Judge to Block Asset Sales
abstract: Adelphia Communications seeks temporary restraining order to block Rigas family and their entities from selling or transferring any assets; says it has uncovered evidence that some family members are selling assets (S)

headline: More Pace Plus Less Tedium Equals a Better Sequel
abstract: Charles Herold Game Theory column reviews computer games Shenmue 2 and Onimusha 2: Samurai's Destiny; photos (M)

headline: Stocks Climb on Hopes That Fed Will Cut Rates Next Week
abstract: Stocks rallied today after weak data on October employment and manufacturing seemed to confirm investors' expectations that the Federal Reserve's policy makers will cut interest rates.

headline: STOCKS SHRUG OFF RECENT BATTERING WITH A BIG SURGE
abstract: Stocks surge almost 5 percent on major exchanges on October 15 as investors celebrate upbeat earnings reports from Citigroup and Bank of America; Dow Jones industrial average jumps 378.28 points, closing at 8,255.68; has risen almost 1,000 points, or 13.3 percent, in past four trading sessions in biggest four-day gain in almost 70 years; Standard & Poor's 500 index rises 39.83 points, or 4.73 percent, to 881.27; Nasdaq composite gains 61.91 points, or 5.07 percent, to 1,282.44; charts; graph (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Leftists Accused Of Terrorism Arrested
abstract: Spanish police hold seven people suspected to be members of far-left group Grapo, which has been labeled terrorist organization by US and European Union (S)

headline: Expectations Trimmed In a Year of Grim News
abstract: Airline business travelers give their assessments of airline performance this year (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Porsche Profit Zooms
abstract: German auto manufacturer Porsche AG increases pretax profit by 40 percent, to $817.7 million, for fiscal year 2001-02, far exceeding preliminary figures and market expectations (M)

headline: Learning Can Be Fun, At Least for the Makers Of Electronic Toys
abstract: Market for electronic learning toys for young children has grown 77 percent since January and is now fastest-growing segment of toy industry; is powered by parents scrambling to give their children an edge well before they enter preschool; LeapFrog Enterprises accounts for much of growth, thanks to its LeapPad learning products, but other companies are joining in, including Mattel's Fisher-Price, whose Kasey the Kinderbot teaches foreign languages and math, Hasbro's Playskool and Tiger Electronics units and several niche marketers like Learning Resources; photos; chart (M)

headline: EUROPE ALLOWS G.E. TO BUY UNIT OF ABB FOR $2.3 BILLION
abstract: European Commission gives clearance to General Electric to buy business loans division of ABB Ltd, which employs of 500 people in 11 countries, for $2.3 billion; Swiss industrial giant ABB is reducing its debt (S)

headline: A Hong Kong Rally For Tough New Laws Pushed by Beijing
abstract: Large crowd demonstrates in Hong Kong in favor local government's plan for strict internal security laws, including long prison terms for sedition and broad police discretion for searches without warrants in security cases (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Stagecoach Restructures Unit
abstract: Stagecoach Group will write down value of its businesses in United States by $903 million and sell some of units as it restructures operation, known as Coach USA; is discussing sale of parts of Coach USA (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Vivendi Moves Up Deadline On Bids for Publishing Unit  Vivendi Universal is rushing suitors of its publishing business, which includes Houghton Mifflin, to submit final bids by today, executives involved in the discussions said.    Vivendi, which is trying to sell assets to cut its enormous debt, moved up the bidding deadline so that it could negotiate a higher bid, or possibly counter, an offer by the Vodafone Group for Vivendi's stake in Cegetel, the large French phone company. [Page C2.]

headline: Doctor's Procedures Were Monitored by Rival Hospital
abstract: Hospital in Redding, Calif, took action six years ago to monitor cardiologist who is now target of federal investigation into possible use of unnecessary medical procedures; Dr Chae Hyun Moon, then and now chief of cardiology at Redding Medical Center, was told by Mercy Hospital Center that any catheter procedures he performed at Mercy would have to be monitored by Mercy staff; Dr Moon filed 1999 lawsuit seeking to have restrictions lifted; he is also being investigated to determine whether he recommended unnecessary open-heart surgery by Redding Medical's cardiac surgeon, Dr Fidel Realyvasquez Jr; cardiac program is major profit source for Redding Medical Center and its owner, Tenet Healthcare (M)

headline: Kenya's Democracy Prepares for an Important Test
abstract: Kenyan leader Daniel arap Moi is ceding power after 24-year rule in Dec election that many see as test of democracy's viability across Africa; election will be first for most voters in which winner is not preordained; Moi's favorite, Uhuru Kenyatta, vies for presidency with opposition coalition leader Mwai Kibaki; Kibaki benefits from voter ire at corruption and crime under Moi's rule; photos (M)

headline: Italian Lawmakers Pass 'Reform' Seen as Rescuing Its Premier
abstract: Italian Parliament approves legal 'reform bill' that opponents contend is devised and prompted largely to help Prime Min Silvio Berlusconi wriggle out of his continuing legal travails; bill allows defendants in criminal trials to appeal for change of venue on grounds of 'legitimate suspicion' that judge hearing case is biased; Berlusconi, Italy's richest man, is currently on trial on charges of false accounting and bribery in connection with his past business dealings; his lawyers want trial moved from Milan, contending prosecutors there are politically motivated against him (M)

headline: Kenyans Vote in Presidential Elections
abstract: Kenyans of all ages and tribal affiliations lined up by the millions today to vote in the first presidential elections that they were offered a true choice.

headline: Troops Disrupt Protest as Caracas Oil Workers Join Strike
abstract: Venezuelan soldiers firing tear gas scatter striking oil industry workers, prompting dissident managers to extend walkout against Pres Hugo Chavez's government; workers from Petroleos de Venezuela, key US supplier, join national strike by business leaders and politicians demanding Chavez hold referendum on his rule (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Porsche Drops Listing Plan
abstract: Porsche decides against listing shares on New York Stock Exchange to avoid 'considerable extra costs' resulting from new financial oversight law (S)

headline: Patents; Dress up the usual gifts with some invented impishness. Or just hang the tree from the ceiling.
abstract: Survey of some holiday gifts for which patents have been obtained (M)

headline: In a Twist, High Dividends Are Now a Predictor of Growth
abstract: Research by Robert D Arnott of First Quadrant and Clifford S Asness of AQR Capital Management finds corporate profits grew fastest during years following highest average shareholder dividend payout ratios and slowest after years of lowest dividend payouts; finding contradicts current theories; graph (M)

headline: Blair Presses Call for Action on Iraq With Laborite Delegates
abstract: Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain today took his case for U.N. action on Iraq to his own Labor Party convention.

headline: Technology Briefing: Hardware
abstract: NETWORK APPLIANCE POSTS PROFIT AS SALES RISE; BLACKBERRY MAKER LAYS OFF 10% OF WORK FORCE; MICROSOFT AND SAMSUNG TO SELL DESIGN FOR PC'S;.

headline: United Goes Back to Court As It Seeks More Union Cuts
abstract: United Airlines asks federal bankruptcy court judge to begin process that would allow company to void its contracts with its unions if they do not agree to deep cost cuts; but United also says it will delay its request until March 15 if unions agree by Jan 8 to interim cuts that would equal $70 million a month in concessions (M)

headline: Fidelity Leads in Net Cash Flow
abstract: Report compiled by Strategic Insights indicates that Fidelity Investments led all mutual fund families in net cash flowing into defined-contribution retirement plans, such as 401(k)'s (S)

abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate 4.75   4.75   5.50        Discount rate   1.25   1.25   2.00        Federal funds   1.75   1.72   2.42        3-month T-bills   1.52   1.57   2.21        6-month T-bills   1.48   1.52   2.18        10-yr. T-infl.   2.26   2.16   3.19        10-yr. T-note   3.57   3.63   4.66        30-yr. headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Scansoft To Buy Royal Philips Business
abstract: ScanSoft, maker of document- and photo-scanning software, acquires speech-recognition unit of Royal Philips Electronics for $35.4 million (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Crude oil for December delivery falls 39 cents, or 1.5 percent, to $25.38 a barrel; graphs (S)

headline: The Mystery of the Missing Gift Certificate
abstract: Michelle Slatalla Online Shopper column examines online gift certificates; finds that recipients who have stringent junk mail filters might not receive them, depending on level of filter setting; drawing (M)

headline: For Microsoft, Ruling Will Sting But Not Really Hurt
abstract: When the federal government and 20 states filed their sweeping antitrust suit against Microsoft in May 1998, the company dominated the personal computer business and was aggressively moving into the markets for software for hand-held computers, cellphones, television set-top boxes and data-serving computers.    More than four years later, little has changed. And there is little in yesterday's ruling on sanctions in the case by Judge Colleen Kollar-Kotelly of Federal District Court in Washington that will slow down the big software maker.

headline: World Briefing: Asia
abstract: JAPAN: Kidnapping Victims Can Go Home Again; SINGAPORE: Jail Terms For Opposition Politicians; CHINA: Finance Official Sentenced;.

headline: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: G.I. Found Not Guilty
abstract: United States Army Sergeant Fernando Nino is acquitted of negligent homicide; stood trial for deaths of two local teenage girls struck by his vehicle during military excercise (S)

headline: Japan's Executives Fear Economy Is Slipping Again
abstract: Bank of Japan quarterly survey shows Japanese executives say country's fragile nine-month old recovery is losing its momentum; suggests that without new impetus from country's main sources of growth--exports to US and Asia--Japanese economy could slip back into recession soon; report's main confidence index of managers rose four points to reading of minus 14, meaning that pessimists outnumber optimists by 14 percentage points; another slowdown will add to political pressure on Prime Min Junichiro Koizumi to abandon his austerity program and prop up economy with flood of public spending; Koizumi has been trying to reduce country's budget deficit by cutting public works projects; photo (M)

headline: The big winner in the EU expansion:Washington
abstract: PARIS:—  The European Union's coming enlargement to 25 members, including many former Soviet bloc countries now entering NATO, seems sure to increase the United States' overall influence in Europe and within the EU — while putting aside for the time being the idea of an emergent Germany leading the continent from Berlin.

headline: White Extremists May Seek 'Race War,' South Africans Say
abstract: South African Defense Min Mosiuoa Lekota says government is searching for white extremists within military and police force who could be trying to start 'race war' (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Ford Appeals for Patience As It Attempts Turnaround  With Ford stock in rapid retreat, senior executives plan to meet with major investors to appeal for patience as the company attempts a turnaround. Ford's shares have fallen 25 percent in the last two weeks and 60 percent since May.    But Ford should not expect a warm reception from Wall Street; analysts said they did not sense much urgency in Ford's overhaul efforts. To battle back, critics contend, Ford must send clearer signals about its condition and demonstrate how it intends to deal with its potential problems. [Page C5.]

headline: Mexico City Journal; Uproar Over a Movie Priest Going His Own Way
abstract: Low-budget movie about romance between priest and young girl is denounced so vehemently by Mexico's powerful Catholic Church that it has become biggest box office hit in history of Mexican film; movie, The Crime of Father Amaro, portrays priests as predators, drunk with power and lust; it was directed by Carlos Carrera and based on 19th-century novel; church pressure has kept several other movies from being shown in Mexican theaters; Pres Vicente Fox, most openly Catholic president since Mexican Revolution, says he will not allow personal morals to overrule freedom of expression; photos (M)

headline: No Time for TiVo
abstract: Craig Bradley letter objects to being characterized as technophobe, preferring term technoramus (Nov 14 article)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   4.25   4.75   5.00       Discount rate   0.75   0.75   1.50       Federal funds   1.25   1.35   2.01       3-month T-bills   1.20   1.20   1.90       6-month T-bills   1.24   1.23   1.96       10-yr. T-infl.   2.43   2.45   3.26       10-yr. T-note   3.99   4.03   4.78       30-yr. headline: Economy Grows At 3.1% Rate, But Shows Strain
abstract: Commerce Department estimates economy grew at moderate 3.1 percent in third quarter, but says there are indications that growth may be slowing as year comes to end; consumer spending accounted for vitually all growth during summer months; trade deficit continued to hamper growth, ballooning to $437.3 billion at seasonally adjusted annual rate, or 4.2 percent of entire economy; wages rose by 0.5 percent in quarter, compared with 1 percent in second; Labor Department reports initial claims for unemployment benefits stayed high last week, at 410,000; graph (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Club Med Executive Resigns
abstract: Philippe Bourguignon steps aside as chief executive of Club Mediterranee after company announces its second consecutive annual net loss; photo (S)

headline: F.D.A. WILL RECONSIDER CORIXA'S LYMPHOMA TREATMENT
abstract: Corixa Corp says Food and Drug Administration will again consider approving company's Bexxar radiation-drug treatment for lymphoma, setting off 21 percent increase in its share price; FDA rejected Bexxar in March (S)

headline: In Germany, Banks Mirror Wide Malaise In Economy
abstract: Germany's banking system has come to symbolize country's broader economic distress with plummeting share prices, faltering credit ratings and bad loans that keep piling up; Rolf E Breuer, chairman of supervisory board of Deutsche Bank and president of Germany banking association, says problems in banking system have more to do with profitability than liquidity crisis; Salomon Smith Barney report shows Commerzbank and HVB Bank are likely to lose money this year in core banking business; Deutsche Bank is expected to report modest profit; Dresdner Bank, which was acquired for $20 billion last year by Allianz, had heavy losses in second quarter; photo (M)

headline: Citigroup Seen Cutting 1,000 Jobs
abstract: Citigroup is planning job cuts in its investment banking and corporate banking businesses, with more than 1,000 employees to be dismissed; analysts say additional layoffs are not surprising given continued weak demand for banking services like advice on mergers, as well as for offerings of stocks and bonds (M)

headline: Statement by S.E.C. Nominee
abstract: Following is a transcript of the statement by President Bush's nominee for chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, William H. Donaldson, at a news conference today in Washington, as recorded by The New York Times.

headline: It's Cranberry Season, On Table and in Court
abstract: Cranberry growers are felling financial strains; price of 100-pound barrel of cranberries fell from high of $66 in 1996 to low of $17 in 2000; Ocean Spray Cranberries plans to pay its growers $21 to $24 per barrel; many growers, particularly in Massachusetts, say dry weather contributed to below-average yield this year, giving them fewer barrels to sell; Northland Cranberries and defunct cranberry processor from Duxbury, Mass, named Clermont, have files lawsuit contending they suffered as Ocean Spray engaged in systematic scheme to violate antitrust laws by participating in payments in restraint of trade and by exploiting its extraordinary market power; Ocean Spray says it will defend itself vigorously against complaint; photos (M)

headline: E-Commerce Report; The pet supply business is finding that a site may serve mostly to guide shoppers to stores and catalogs.
abstract: Petsmart, industry leader among traditional pet supply retailers, discovers that its Web site brings people to its stores and exposes them to its catalog; photos (M)

headline: Jobless Claims Fall a Bit More Than Expected
abstract: Labor Department reports unemployment applications declined 25,000, to 389,000, for week ended Oct 19; economists had expected claims to fall to 405,000; graph (M)

headline: Nonalcoholic brew is shedding its flat image : A lush market for near beer
abstract: FRANKFURT:—  As professor emeritus of brewing sciences, Anton Piendl knows more than the average barstool philosopher about beer aroma, flavor and foam. But when Piendl, author of a seven-volume beer encyclopedia, swills a cold Pilsener, it's an alkoholfrei Clausthaler Premium.

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY  None    TUESDAY  None

headline: KPMG CONSULTING CHANGES ITS NAME TO BEARINGPOINT
abstract: KPMG Consulting Inc, which was spun off from accounting firm KPMG LLP in $2 billion initial public offering in February 2001, changes its name to BearingPoint Inc to emphasize its independence (S)

headline: CLOROX AND P.&G. PLAN JOINT VENTURE FOR GLAD PRODUCTS
abstract: Clorox Co and Procter & Gamble Co will undertake joint venture to develop more products for Glad bags, wraps and containers; P&G will have initial 10 percent ownership in venture and contribute some patents and technology; Clorox will administer joint venture (S)

headline: NRG SAYS CHAPTER 11 BANKRUPTCY FILING IS POSSIBLE
abstract: Power-generation division of Xcel Energy Inc, NRG Energy Inc, says that it could seek Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection as part of plan to restructure finances and settle with creditors; defaulted on $850 million of bonds recently and began discussions on restructuring $10.2 billion of debt (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Economic Growth
abstract: Japan's economy grew at annual rate of 3.2 percent in July-to-September quarter, slightly higher than original estimate of 3 percent; machinery orders fell 4.1 percent in October from September (S)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of Sept 29 profile of Ford Motor chief executive, William Clay Ford Jr

headline: No Decision Yet on Letting U.S. Use Bases, Saudi Says
abstract: Prince Saud al-Faisal, Saudi foreign minister, says that kingdom has not yet decided whether it would make its airspace and air bases available to United States in event of war with Iraq; seeks to amend remarks he made in CNN interview over weekend, in which he appeared to state that Saudi Arabia would not allow American-led coalition to use Saudi air bases and airspace to attack Iraq; photo (M)

headline: Grades Are In: NBC Reigns, ABC Surges, Fox Lags
abstract: First ratings sweep of television season suggests that ABC may be pulling out of its two-year-long slide, that Fox is falling sharply and that NBC has clearest claim to superiority, winning contest for viewers in 18-to-49-year-old category and cutting into lead CBS had a year ago amaong total viewers; WB netwok has largest percentage increase of any network; networks announce schedule changes; photos (M)

headline: As Turkey Votes Today, Religious Issue Dogs the Leading Party
abstract: Much uncertainty continues to surround Islamic Justice and Development party of Turkey, which is expected to win most seats in Parliament in voting on Nov 3, and its leader, Recep Tayyip Erdogan; he vigorously rejects Islamic label and says he would not change Turkey's secular state, but chief rival, Deniz Baykal of Republican People's Party, says vote for Erdogan could led to political instability (M)

headline: Some Working Moms Can't Have It All
abstract: Nancy McCallister letter responds to Oct 27 Executive Life column about executive's special child care arrangements while she attends to her work responsibilities

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Faster Microchip Prototypes Developed
abstract: Lucent Technologies says its research arm Bell Labs has developed compact, energy-efficient prototypes of microchips that receive data and interactive services on cellphones and laptop computers up to eight times speed of most advanced mobile consumer devices (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Austria: Suit Over Seized Klimt Paintings Continues
abstract: Ninth Circuit US Court of Appeals in California dismisses Austrian arguments that American court has no legal jurisdiction over paintings seized during Holocaust; suit filed by Maria V Altmann against Austria and Austrian Gallery claims paintings seized from her uncle by Nazis in 1938 were wrongfully handed over to gallery at end of World War II (S)

headline: Standards for Over-the-Counter Drugs
abstract: Article on how Food and Drug Administration assesses whether medicine is safe enough for patients to use without doctor's supervision in light of FDA's approval to let Schering-Plough's allergy medication Claritin be sold without prescription (M)

headline: New Group Will Lobby For Change In Iraqi Rule
abstract: Independent bipartisan group is formed with White House's tacit approval to press for ouster of Saddam Hussein; hawkish group, Committee for Liberation of Iraq, seeks to increase domestic and international support for new government in Iraq; members of group include former State Sec George P Shultz, former House Speaker Newt Gingrich and Sens John McCain and Joseph I Lieberman (M)

headline: This TV Fills a Void on Your Wall But Puts One in Your Wallet
abstract: With sufficient wall space and indifference to sticker shock, consumers can now hang a 63-inch flat-panel plasma television on the wall of the family room. Samsung is shipping what the company says is the largest flat-panel plasma screen available for consumers. The HPM6315 has a very wide screen, but is only three and a half inches deep. It has a resolution of 1366 by 768 pixels and can display 15 million colors.     It can be viewed within a 160-degree angle so that people sitting off to the side of the set still see a bright picture. It can be used as a display for a wide range of digital devices like camcorders, DVD players and game consoles, and it is HDTV-ready.

headline: Eni of Italy Buying Finnish Energy Assets
abstract: Eni of Italy Buying F

headline: House Passes Bill to Combat Internet Gambling in the U.S.
abstract: House approves legislation that would prohibit Internet casinos from taking payments from Americans and would require banks to prevent use of their credit cards for such gambling; bill could also require Internet access providers to block entry to gambling on Web sites; Rep James A Leach sponsored bill (M)

headline: Article 2002112193605121059 -- No Title
abstract: function pop_me_up(pURL, features) { new_window = window.open(pURL, "popup_window", features); new_window.focus(); } Let 1,000 Desktops Bloom From Home Networks to Screen Wipes to Internet Connections, a Season for Sharing Convenience and Power

headline: U.S., Citing Maoist Threats, Warns Against Visits to Nepal
abstract: US State Dept urges Americans to defer nonessential travel to Nepal because of written threat from Maoist rebels to attack American diplomats (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Northeast Quietly Becomes A Health Care Corridor  With little of the fame that can be claimed by Silicon Valley, the Northeast's urban corridor has quietly built its own economic powerhouse by becoming the nation's health-care epicenter. Roughly following the line of Amtrak's Metroliner and stretching from Boston to Bethesda, Md., this medical megalopolis encompasses a vast array of health care facilities.    The region is anchored by urban complexes serving as homes for many influential teaching hospitals and includes big suburban campuses of most of the world's major drug companies. It also stretches to clusters of research outfits in the Boston area and around the National Institutes of Health outside of Washington. Economic Pulse. [Page A1.]

headline: Japanese Growth Falls to 0.7%; Slower Pace Expected This Winter
abstract: Japan's economic recovery slowed during summer, with third-quarter growth dropping to 0.7 percent from 1 percent in spring; economists predict that summer's annual growth rate of 3 percent will evaporate this winter because growth in exports is falling and consumer spending looks weak for coming holiday season; value of yen has risen 5 percent against dollar over last three weeks making matters more difficult for exporters; unemployment is near postwar high at 5.4 percent; graph; photo (M)

headline: Lionel Poilâne, Parisian Baker, Missing in Helicopter Crash
abstract: Lionel Poilane, famed Parisian bread baker, and wife Irena are missing and presumed dead after helicopter he pilots crashes off Breton coast; photo (M)

headline: Finding Wrongs, Through the Prism of Silicon Valley
