abstract: Justice Department is putting new focus on Silicon Valley managers who are suspected of crossing the line into securities fraud and insider trading; Valley executives say effort may be more political than practical, and they expect that government will not find extensive fraud at most well-known companies and will instead make examples of smaller extrepreneurs; some executives and lawyers representing shareholder groups say peculiarities of high-tech business, especially its emphasis on selling software and reliance on stock options, may provide fertile ground for aggressive prosecution; photo (M)

headline: Disney Details Affiliations Of Directors
abstract: Walt Disney Co, one day after saying it is cooperating with inquiry by securities regulators into timing of disclosure of board members' affiliations, discloses more financial relationships between some directors and companies that do business with Disney; disclosures involving Eugene Bay, father-in-law of Robert A Iger, Disney president, noted; Disney also discloses that company paid $623,782 to Air Shamrock, small fleet of aircraft owned by Shamrock Holidings, investment vehicle for family and associates of Roy Disney (M)

headline: As Deficits Climb, Some Investors Fear Rates Will Follow
abstract: Now that President Bush has chosen a new Treasury Secretary when do investors start to worry about the federal budget deficit and its potential effect on interest rates?

headline: Act Two: An 'American Idol' Tops the CD Charts
abstract: Kelly Clarkson, who captured America's fancy on television show American Idol, wins radio listeners and huge record sales with her new CD that includes song written for TV series; photo (M)

headline: CIGNA TO PAY $24.5 MILLION TO SETTLE FRAUD ACCUSATIONS
abstract: Cigna Corp agrees to pay $24.5 million to resolve charges that its Lovelace Health Systems unit filed fraudulent Medicare reports from 1988 to 1998 for its New Mexico hospital (S)

headline: In North Korea and Pakistan, Deep Roots of Nuclear Barter
abstract: North Korea has provided Pakistan with missile parts it needs to build its nuclear arsenal in exchange for many of designs for gas centrifuges and much of machinery it needs to make highly enriched uranium for its latest nuclear weapons project; relationship between North Korea and Pakistan appears much deeper and more dangerous than US and its Asian allies first suspected and raises disturbing questions about nature of uneasy American alliance with Pakistani government, ally in ousting Taliban from Afghanistan; Bush administration says Gen Pervez Musharraf, after first denying Pakistani involvement in North Korea's nuclear effort, has assured Sec of State Colin L Powell that no such trade will occur in future, but American and Asian officials are far from certain that Pakistan has cut off relationship, or even if Musharraf is in control of transactions; photos (L)

headline: World Briefing: Americas
abstract: MEXICO: Ex-Oil Chief Arrested; TRINIDAD AND TOBAGO: Governing Party Wins;.

headline: Work at Last: Marketing Themselves
abstract: Home Front column focuses on three out-of-work marketers who have developed campaign to find jobs for themselves and about 40 other jobless New Yorkers using guerilla marketing tactics, which emphasize direct contact like handing out fliers; photo (9M)

headline: Inspectors Urge Iraq to Document Arms Claims
abstract: United Nations arms inspectors, meeting with senior Iraqi officials, Baghdad, urge them to reconsider and document their repeated claims that they are not hiding weapons of mass destruction; chief inspector Hans Blix comments; Min Naji Sabri says Iraq will submit declaration to inspectors on Dec 8 covering biological, nuclear and chemical arms; Bush administration holds Iraq violated Security Council resolution by firing on US and British aircraft over no-flight zones in northern and southern Iraq; UN Sec Gen Kofi Annan disagrees moves contravene resolution (M)

headline: Europeans treading in land of lawsuits : Trans-Atlantic legal cultures clash
abstract: LONDON:—  When a group of New York teenagers sued McDonald's last month, contending that eating its hamburgers had made them obese, many Europeans enjoyed the apparent confirmation of two of their favorite stereotypes about Americans: that they are fat and that they like to sue each other.

headline: Pre-emptive Diplomatic Strike
abstract: Iraq's decision to readmit United Nations inspectors has complicated President Bush's effort to win Security Council approval for a tough resolution. News analysis, Page A16.

headline: Technology Briefing: E-Commerce
abstract: CERTEGY BUYS NETZEE ASSETS FOR $10.4 MILLION; CHINESE AND GERMAN CHIP MAKERS SIGN DEAL; INFOSYS BOARD APPROVES SHARE CONVERSION; EBAY AND AUTOTRADER WILL END PARTNERSHIP EARLY;.

headline: Earnings at Merck Decline For 3rd Consecutive Quarter
abstract: Merck & Co reports third-quarter profit drop of 3.3 percent, its third consecutive quarterly decline; says net income fell to $1.88 billion, or 83 cents a share; sales rose 8.2 percent, to $12.9 billion (M)

headline: Corporations Revise Wish Lists; Republican Victory Sets Stage for Pro-Business Agenda
abstract: Corporations are revising wish lists as Republican Party captures majorities in both houses of Congress in midterm elections sets stage for pro-business agenda; issues facing Washington include brand-name drugs, fuel-economy standards, energy and taxes; many executives and business leaders stress that Republicans' majorities are slender and that they are not sure American business will achieve its most important goals; photos (M)

headline: Credit Offerings Planned This Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week includes today's regular weekly auction of new three-  and six-month bills and a four-week bill tomorrow.    According to traders, at the close of the New York cash market on Friday the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 1.20 percent, on the six-month bill 1.25 percent and on the four-week issue 1.20 percent.

headline: ONLINE DIARY
abstract: Online Diary column offers survey of Halloween related Web sites; top celebrities not often seen hawking products in US do just that in Japan and sites like Japander.com offer video clips or still images of ads; organizers of laughlab.co.uk announce results of contest for world's funniest joke; miscellaneous Web sites noted; drawings (M)

headline: Compressed Data; Bhopal Critics in Web Hoax Against Dow Chemical
abstract: Yes Men sends out hoax e-mail press release purporting to be from Dow Chemical, which now owns Union Carbide, directing journalists to Web site supposedly explaining why Dow refuses to clean up site of lethal gas spill at Union Carbide plant in Bhopal, India, 18 years ago or help people who remain sick from spill (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: UBS Closes Trading Floor That It Acquired From Enron  Less than a year after acquiring Enron's energy trading operation, UBS Warburg said that it would reduce the size of the unit and shut down the trading floor in Houston. The operation, which had about 630 employees when UBS acquired it, is expected to be reduced to fewer than 100 employees, all of whom will be moved to Stamford, Conn.    The decision comes during a sharp downturn in the energy trading business and after some large trading companies have announced plans to scale back their operations or exit the business. [Page C4.]    Making a BMW a Conversation Piece  Christopher E. Bangle, BMW's first non-German design chief, wants each BMW to be a conversation piece known as much for design as precision engineering. He is trying to make the yuppie dream car as idiosyncratic as it once was predictable. And a lot of longtime BMW lovers hate him for it. [A1.]

headline: Slow September Sales Lead to New Auto Incentives
abstract: Robust pace of auto sales slows in September, causing fresh round of big incentives from Ford Motor Co and General Motors and debate from Wall Street about industry's outlook; industry sales rise 3.2 percent compared with September 2001, but fall sharply from strong pace this year; General Motors, where sales fall 12.8 percent, says it will offer no-interest 60-month loans on most of its 2003 passenger cars and minivans; Ford, whose sales are up 3.2 percent, also announces new incentives; DaimlerChrysler's sales rise 18 perent from year earlier; company is weighing its own incentive package; graph (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: India: Peace Gesture To Rebels
abstract: India repeals ban on Nagaland rebel group; hopes action will encourage peace talks (S)

headline: Ad Spending Rises In First 3 Quarters
abstract: CMR reports that advertising spending in major media rose 2.2 percent for first three quarters of 2002, to $84.4 billion, compared with period year earlier (S)

headline: Defiant S.E.C. Chief Exhorts Wall Street And Assails Critics
abstract: Harvey L Pitt, who resigned as Securities and Exchange Commission chairman, calls on Wall Street executives to restore investor confidence, speech to Securities Industry Association, Boca Raton, Fla; says he hopes his successor will be spared personal and political attacks he says contributed to his downfall; gets warm reception; Robert Herdman, who had worked closely with Pitt on establishing accounting board and checking William H Webster's background, resigns as SEC chief accountant; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Economy Expands
abstract: Surge in exports to China and weaker American dollar lead to economic growth in Hong Kong in third quarter, spurring government to upgrade its full-year economic growth forecast to 2 percent (S)

headline: Ford to Review How Chairman Got 400,000 Goldman Shares
abstract: Ford Motor Co board forms committee to probe allocation of 400,000 shares of Goldman Sachs to chairman and chief executive William Clay Ford Jr in 1999; Goldman Sachs has received about $90 million in banking fees from Ford Motor since 1996; board responds to letter from corporate governance advocate Robert E Curry on behalf of Ford stockholder; Mr Ford defends actions, email to company employees (M) (M)

headline: U.S. Tells Sri Lanka Rebels To Renounce Terror Tactics
abstract: United States Deputy State Sec Richard Armitage, in unusual direct appeal, urges Sri Lanka's rebel Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam to renounce violence publicly and permanently and recognize government's sovereignty over whole nation, donor conference, Oslo, attended by Sri Lanka Prime Min Ranil Wickremesinghe, Tamil Tiger negotiator Anton Balasingham and representatives of over three dozen nations; Balasingham says rebels have pledged not to resort to war or violence as part of cease-fire; does not permanently renounce violence (M)

headline: Bush Picks Prominent Banker to Head Securities Commission
abstract: William H. Donaldson, a wealthy and powerful Wall Street executive, was nominated today by President Bush to be chairman of the S.E.C.

headline: Mystery Man At the Helm Hu Jintao
abstract: Man in the News profile of Hu Jintao, new leader of China; he is veteran Communist Party insider who never strays from party's prescribed oratory; his past suggests that he values power over vision; photo (M)

headline: Baghdad Envoys Pitch 'Buy Iraq' Campaign in Russia
abstract: Iraqi officials visit Moscow to appeal to Russian business people and officials to resist pressure from Bush administration for Russia and other veto-bearing members of Security Council to agree to new resolution on Iraq; Iraqi delegation lists benefits for Russia by cooperating with Iraq; Kremlin has not yet expressed publicly its thinking on new Security Council resolution; there is little enthusaism in Moscow for regime of Saddam Hussein, but economic ties with Iraq run deep (M)

headline: Kenyans Suffer Again In Anti-U.S. Violence
abstract: Attack on Israeli-owned Mombasa hotel is eerily reminiscent of even deadlier 1998 attack on United States Embassy in Nairobi; Kenyans made up bulk of casualties in both cases and both attacks were driven by international politics having little to do with East Africa; Mombasa is home to most of Kenya's Muslims, who generally mix easily with majority Christians; latest bombing is sure to increase calls among some Kenyans for nation, staunch US military ally, to distance itself from some US policies (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: I.B.M. Plans To Increase Sales To Small Businesses
abstract: IBM starts campaign to increase its sales to small and medium-sized businesses with several new product offerings and $100 million marketing budget; graph shows IBM stock price (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Gemstar Dismisses Its Accountant
abstract: Gemstar-TV Guide International, which plans to restate its financial results for last two and a half years, dismisses its accounting firm, KPMG, and hires Ernst & Young to replace it (S)

headline: President Seems to Gain an Asian Ally
abstract: Pres Bush and leader of Brunei, Sultan Sir Bolkiah Hassanal, meet at White House; they agree to expand intelligence-sharing as part of Washington's campaign against terrorism; photo (S)

headline: Seeking Names for Bali's Anonymous Dead
abstract: Most of dead remain anonymous two days after bombing of popular tourist discotheques on Bali, Indonesia; official tally lists just 38 identified, from 11 countries; many remain missing; clues provided by friends and family are only proof of identity for many badly burned; terrorists seemed to pick target and moment for nighttime attack for maximum effect; powerful explosives packed inside small white truck on narrow street where clubs faced each other were so devastating that officials have not determined whether suicide bomber remained behind wheel; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: ASML Holding Will Lay Off 22% Of Work Force
abstract: ASML Holding, manufacturer of semiconductor equipment, will lay off 22 percent of its work force worldwide; graph (S)

headline: AETNA REPORTS BETTER-THAN-EXPECTED PROFIT IN QUARTER
abstract: Aetna says third-quarter profit was higher than expected as it controlled medical expenses and increased premiums (S)

headline: Pushing Accounting Rules To the Edge of the Envelope
abstract: Kurt Eichenwald analysis of how companies like Tyco International can inflate their profits while still adhering to generally accepted accounting principles; says financial statements are far from precise things that investors suppose, being infused with management judgments and estimates that can drastically transform a company's financial picture, all depending on how aggressive that management wants to be in application of accounting principles; graph (M)

headline: Fire in Vietnam Office-Building Kills at Least 54
abstract: A huge fire in Ho Chi Minh City trapped hundreds of people inside a six-story office building, killing at least 54.

headline: Ukraine's Leader Loses NATO Alphabet Shuffle
abstract: Ukraine's embattled president, Leonid Kuchma, was ritually humiliated at the tail end of this week's expanded summit meeting of NATO, in a deft exercise in diplomatic etiquette.     Facing strong criticism from the United States and other alliance members over suspicions that he had personally approved the sale of sophisticated radars to Iraq, and over growing unrest about his strong-arm rule, NATO publicly refused to invite Mr. Kuchma to the summit meeting here.

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Concern Grows Over Bird Flu
abstract: Hong Kong officials close chicken markets one day for cleaning and increase inoculations in effort to arrest spread of H5 avain influenza which has killed dozens of chickens; tests are in progress to determine if birds carry rare H5N1 strain, which killed six people in Hong Kong in 1997 (S)

headline: ICT, A CALL CENTER OPERATOR, PLANS TO CUT JOBS
abstract: ICT Group, operator of call centers for large companies, says it plans to lay off workers and expects fourth-quarter loss of 46 cents to 59 cents a share (S)

headline: Bank of America Chooses Interpublic
abstract: Bank of America, concluding unusual review of its estimated $170 million advertising account, awards bulk of business to agencies owned by Interpublic Group of Companies; decision boosts hard-pressed agency company (M)

headline: Acquisitions and New Clothing Give a Lift to Burberry's Profits
abstract: An expansion strategy based on acquisitions, new stores and new offerings like sleek handbags and children's clothing bearing its signature plaid pattern seem to be working for the Burberry Group. The company reported results for the first half of its fiscal year today that exceeded market expectations.    So far at least, Burberry has managed to keep sales and profits growing in a year when many rival fashion companies are suffering from economic sluggishness and from tourists' staying home because of the threat of terror attacks.

headline: ARMS  INSPECTORS BACK TOUGH TERMS TO PRESSURE IRAQ
abstract: Leaders of UN weapons inspections teams ask Security Council for aggressive new mandate backed up with threat of enforcement action, giving US boost in negotiations over its draft resolution to disarm Iraq; Hans Blix and Dr Mohamed Elbaradei question some details of inspection regime proposed by Washington, but appeal strongly to Council to overcome disputes and reach consensus on clear mandate for inspectors' work; say it is important for Iraq to understand any lack of cooperation will call for reaction on part of Council on continuous basis; note Iraq has openly violated past resolutions by barring arms inspectors for past four years; indicate for first time that they accepted inspection terms in draft resolution proposed by US and Britain; appeal seemingly clears way for broad agreement on inspections regime, leaving negotiators to focus on vexing question of if and when to authorize military force (M)

headline: Jet Purchase Splits Brazil: New Leader Wants Voice
abstract: Five aircraft companies compete to sell Brazil fleet of jet fighters as Pres-elect Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva, who ran on platform of buying locally whenever possible, seeks voice in awarding nearly $700 million contract; Pres Fernado Henrique Cardoso has been cool to bid; National Defense Council expects to choose winner soon, but not let da Silva make decision; Embraer, Brazilian company competing for contract, operates from Sao Paulo, da Silva's main political base (M)d

headline: World Business Briefing: Europe
abstract: GERMANY: Chairman Of Allianz Resigns; GERMANY: Business Confidence Falls; BRITAIN: Caterer Sells Unit;.

headline: China's Party Talks Near End, and Jiang Looks Set to Step Down
abstract: Some delegates to the 16th Communist Party Congress told reporters that Jiang Zemin was not on the list of candidates for the Central Committee that will be elected on Thursday.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Strong Forecast At Honda
abstract: Honda Motor Co expects global auto sales to rise 10 percent in 2003, helped by growing demand in US and other foreign markets; plans to sell 3.1 million cars worldwide in 2003; sales are expected to rise 12.5 percent overseas and 4.4 percent in Japan; Honda also plans to double its capacity in China to 240,000 cars (S)

headline: Why Consumers Should Keep Spending
abstract: Elisabeth DeMarse letter responds to Oct 6 Economic View column concerning continued consumer spending in current economic climate

headline: Administration Said to Weigh New Choices for Top Latin Post
abstract: Sec Colin Powell and other State Department officials are talking with lawmakers about possible replacements for Otto J Reich as assistant secretary for Latin America; recess appointee is Cuban exile who is opposed by liberal Democrats and farm-state Republicans who see him as obstacle to lifting trade embargo (S)

headline: Amazon's Loss in Quarter Shows a Sharp Decrease
abstract: Amazon.com reports third-quarter loss of $35 million compared with loss of $170 million year ago; posts sales of $851 million, up 33 percent from year earlier; chairman Jeff Bezos comments (M)

headline: Eli Ginzberg, 91, Economist at Columbia And Adviser to Eight Presidents, Is Dead
abstract: Eli Ginzberg, economist who taught at Columbia University, advised eight American presidents and led research efforts in employment and health care, dies at age 91; photo (M)

headline: Text Messaging Takes Off
abstract: Telephia reports users of text-messaging services on cellular telephones rose to 20 percent of United States subscribers in 2002 from 12 percent in 2001; photo; graphs (S)

headline: Biztech: E-tailers are primed for happier holidays
abstract: From the U.S. bellwether Amazon.com to the German catalog retailer Neckermann.de to HK.Yahoo.com in Hong Kong, online shops around the world are hoping for a holiday season of double-digit sales growth — a small beacon of light amid stock downturns, flagging tech spending and stagnant corporate sales.

headline: E-Commerce Report; Retail executives are uniting to fight credit-card fraud in the online bazaar.
abstract: Hewlett-Packard risk management and customer privacy manager George Redenbaugh has helped largest e-commerce companies to form group tentatively called Internet Merchant Fraud Roundtable to counter credit card fraud that costs Web merchants over $1 billion annually; group hopes to develop database tha merchants can use to block potentially fraudulent sales and help snare people who commit credit card fraud; photo (M)

headline: I.B.M. Will Move Faster to Fill Its Pension Fund Gap
abstract: International Business Machines shifts its approach and announces plans to put $3 billion in cash and stock into its United States pension fund in 2002; speed-up in resolution of pension fund shortfall is seen as sign of company's balance sheet strength and ample cash flow (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Gateway's Results Meet Expectations
abstract: Gateway Inc reports third-quarter loss of $50 million on revenue of $1.12 billion (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Daiei To Sell Restaurants
abstract: Japanese company Daiei Inc will sell two fast food restaurant divisions and its part-ownership of third fast food chain; share price graph (S)

headline: NEWMONT INCREASES STAKE IN AUSTRALIAN MAGNESIUM
abstract: Newï

headline: Long To-Do List for New Economic Team
abstract: Analysis of challenges awaiting John W Snow, nominee for Treasury secretary, and Stephen Friedman, leading candidate to be Bush's economic point man; says Snow and Friedman will have to meld Bush administration's preference for tax cuts that affect economy primarily over long term with its desire to jump-start growth before 2004 election; says they will continue administration's push for lower trade barriers in other countries while confronting foreign executives and policy makers angered by recent tariffs enacted in this country; holds they will be faced with near collapse of large parts of some crucial industries each of which could provide tempting if vexing possibilities for government intervention; photo (M)

headline: Report Tracks Terror Trail of an Islamic Group
abstract: Comprehensive report finds that terrorist attack on nightclub in Bali that killed nearly 200 people in October was work of radical Islamic orgn, Jemaah Islamiyah, that carried out series of bombings of churches across Indonesia two years ago; orgn, which has links to Al Qaeda, bombed churches as revenge for killings of Muslims by Christians during communal conflict in Maluku Islands and Central Sulawesi in 1999 and 2000; report says group later turned its sights on United States (M)

headline: Senate's Foreign Policy Man Could Buttress Powell
abstract: Sen Richard G Lugar prepares to take over chairmanship of Foreign Relations Committee, saying he is determined to set tone of independence and bipartisanship and is willing to prod Bush administration on key issues; views, far cry from outgoing chairman Jesse Helms, could make him ally for Sec Colin Powell in efforts to exhaust diplomatic alternatives before using force in Iraq; moderate Republican, 70, has had setbacks within his party and long interest in international affairs; Democratic counterpart Joseph Biden says there is not much that he and Lugar disagree on (M)

headline: Thais Impose Wide Ban on Smoking and, Surprise, It Works
abstract: Thailand's stringent new antismoking law, which makes it illegal to light cigarette in just about any indoor public place, seems to be taking hold; there are warning signs in restaurants, in hotel elevators and in malls; the air is suddenly and surprisingly free of smoke (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Sales Drop At Advanced Micro
abstract: Advanced Micro Devices says it had 'substantial operating loss' on sales of about $500 million in third quarter (S)

headline: MediaTalk; A New Vocabulary at Headline News
abstract: CNN Headline News injects slang and hip-hop phrases into its coverage; continues aggressive attempt to make network hipper for its increasingly younger audience; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing: Europe
abstract: BRITAIN: Gus Buying Homebase; GERMANY: Deutsche Bank May Sell Equities; THE NETHERLANDS: Ing Cuts Forecast; SWITZERLAND: Progress In Tax Talks;.

headline: But elsewhere interest is muted : Davis Cup final captivates France
abstract: PARIS:—  Every ticket has been sold to the Davis Cup tennis final between France and Russia that begins here Friday on the clay court that was very deliberately laid down inside the 15,000-seat Palais Omnisports de Bercy. It has been so difficult to procure tickets to the three-day event that even the French soccer stars Thierry Henry and Sylvain Wiltord had to scramble for les places this week. Perhaps they would not have had such problems if they had done better in the World Cup. The French president, Jacques Chirac, and the former Russian president, Boris Yeltsin, did not suffer the same indignity.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Italian Phone Profit
abstract: Telecom Italia reports third-quarter net income of $477 million, compared with loss of more than $800 million in same period in 2001 (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Kashmir: New Lawmaker Shot To Death
abstract: Abdul Aziz Mir, new state legislator from ruling coalition, is fatally shot after leaving mosque south of Srinagar, Kashmir; assault, claimed by Save Kashmir Movement, may signal stepped-up assault by anti-Indian Islamic militants (S)

headline: Bond Offerings Scheduled for the Coming Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week includes today's regular weekly auction of new 3-  and 6-month bills; a 4-week bill and a 5-year note tomorrow; and a 10-year note on Wednesday.    At the close of the New York cash market on Friday, the rate on the outstanding 3-month bill was 1.40 percent; the 6-month, 1.38 percent; and the 4-week, 1.42 percent. In when-issued trading, the 5-year note was offered at a price to yield 2.91 percent; the 10-year note, 4.03 percent.

headline: A Glut of Sept. 11 Books Cuts Into Sales
abstract: Flood of books published in connection with anniversary of Sept 11 attacks quickly sates consumers' appetites; also shaves month of September off book industry's all-important fall season, leaving it in grip of post-anniversary sales letdown just when pre-Christmas momentum usually kicks in; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Adams Linked To I.R.A. Killers
abstract: Irish journalist Ed Moloney charges in new book, A Secret History of the IRA, that Gerry Adams led Belfast paramilitaries in early 1970's and set up unit to kill informers; Adams, leader of IRA's political wing, denies accusation; photo; book also says Adams knew of killing of Jean McConville, widowed mother of ten who disappeared in 1972 after comforting wounded British soldier (S)

headline: Vivendi Spurns Offer for Entertainment Units; Stock Rises
abstract: Vivendi Universal shrugs off overture for its American entertainment business from Marvin Davis, investor and oilman; executives in Paris are increasingly inclined to hold onto entertainment assets (M)

headline: Marketers Try to Turn Web Pirates Into Customers
abstract: Some online marketers are beginning to promote their wares on file-trading services like KaZaA, which are typically used to obtain unauthorized copies of music, movies or software; marketers, ranging from independent bands to Microsoft Corp, hope to turn these 'hackers, thieves and pirates' into into customers; ertertainment industry officials say marketers are only giving support to services that encourage theft of other people's intellectual property; organizations promoting file-traders see this kind of marketing as way to lure people away from piracy by providing them with authorized material to download--and, in some cases, asking them to pay for it; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Prices Rise
abstract: Consumer prices in Korea were 3.1 percent higher in September than they were in September of last year, according to the National Statistical Office. The consumer price index rose 0.6 percent from August and 2.4 percent from September 2001. The biggest increase was in vegetable prices, which surged 19.8 percent from September 2001 because of a typhoon that damaged crops.   Don Kirk (NYT)

headline: International Briefs | Europe: France: Economic Growth Slows
abstract: The French economy grew at an annual rate of 0.8 percent, compared with the second- quarter pace of 1 percent, the government said, as cutbacks by companies in investment and inventories offset gains in consumption and exports. ''Without consumption, G.D.P. would have shrunk,'' Emmanuel Ferry, an economist with the brokerage firm of Exane in Paris, told Bloomberg News. ''If consumers lose heart in November and December, the economy could shrink in the fourth quarter.'' France's report came a day after Germany reported growth of 0.4 percent in the quarter; last week, Italy reported growth of 0.5 percent.

headline: Ivory Coast's Raging Conflict Draws France In
abstract: France is becoming more deeply enmeshed in fighting in Ivory Coast, former French colony where rebels have tried to overthrow government; more than 2,500 French troops are deployed along cease-fire line until multinational West African force takes over, but French are being drawn into what may be long war that could spiral into anarchy; photos; map (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Isuzu To Post Loss
abstract: Isuzu Motors expects to lose money for fourth consecutive year in fiscal 2002; anticipates $1.4 billion loss; General Motors owns 49 percent of Isuzu; graph (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Motorola Selects A Technology Officer
abstract: Motorola Inc promotes Padmasree Warrior to chief technology officer, making her company's highest-ranking woman (S)

headline: One-Word Shoppers' Lexicon: Price
abstract: Shoppers at every income level are increasingly making decisions about what to buy, where to buy and even when to buy based solely on price; attitude helps explain why traditional department stores lost ground this holiday to discounters and online merchants; certain products, particularly in electronics and housewares, have become commodities that play into retail strategies of discounters; some department stores, including Macy's, are trying to play by new price rules, offering deep discounts and coupons; photos; graph (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Nintendo Introduces Device For Game Boy
abstract: Nintendo, world's No. 2 maker of video games, will start selling device that allows users to play its software for Game Boy series on its GameCube console to bolster flagging sales; graph (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Hungary: Pro-Europe Vote
abstract: Leftist parties dominate local elections lending support to Hungary's bid to join European Union; election results solidify new government, led by Socialist Party Prime Min Peter Medgyessy (S)

headline: Citigroup Picks A Former Star Of Research For a New Unit
abstract: Citigroup hires Sallie L Krawcheck, chief executive of Sanford C Bernstein, to lead separate division for its stock research and brokerage businesses, even before reaching agreement with regulators on how its analysts will operate; announcement is latest in series of appointments and other steps taken by Citigroup chief executive Sanford I Weill over last few weeks that demonstrate his determination to quickly resolve multiple investigations into its investment bank Salomon Smith Barney; analysts and investors praise hiring of Krawcheck, whose former firm Bernstein is known for its independent research; new division, which will be known as Smith Barney, will technically be part of Salomon Smith Barney but will function separately from investment bank; Krawcheck will report to Weill; photos (M)

headline: UNITED AIRLINES OPENS TALKS WITH ATTENDANTS
abstract: Association of Flight Attendants begins talks with UAL, parent company of United Airlines, over labor concessions (S)

headline: Indonesia Arrests a Top Suspect in Southeast Asia Terror Network
abstract: Ali Ghufron is suspected of being a senior leader of a terror group linked to Al Qaeda and the planner of the Bali bombing.

headline: World Briefing: Africa
abstract: BURUNDI: Thousands Flee Fighting; RWANDA: Ex-Governor Denies Genocide Charge;.

headline: U.S. Assesses Afghans' Needs
abstract: Health and Human Services Sec Tommy G Thompson arrives in Kabul with pledge that United States will not abandon Afghanistan now that Taliban are gone; signs agreement with health ministry to help rebuild county's medical services and improve delivery of health care (S)

headline: Technology Briefing: Telecommunications
abstract: FURUKAWA TO DECREASE PRODUCTION OF CABLES; GLOBAL CROSSING REPORTS $157 MILLION LOSS;.

headline: Chinese Court Voids Death Sentences on 5 Christian Leaders
abstract: A Chinese appeals court has overturned the death sentences given last December to five leaders of a defiant evangelical Christian group.

headline: Nonprofit to Create Open Source Software
abstract: Mitch Kapor, software industry pioneer, starts nonprofit organization to create software applications in manner of 'open source' movement, in which underlying code is freely shared with public; Open Source Applications Foundation will share with those who will, in turn, share freely; photo (M)

headline: UAL and Its Backers Scramble for Support and Financing
abstract: United Airlines moves to firm up financing in advance of bankruptcy filing, even as it continues talks with its unions and suppliers to secure concessions that would help stem its mounting losses; United's supporters in Washington renew their scramble to win aid, with some lawmakers suggesting that Congress should overturn decision by federal panel that voted to deny airline $1.8 billion in loan guarantees; Pres Bush, through spokesman, says he 'respects' panel's decision but holds back from enthusiatically endorsing ruling; United is in final stages of negotiating commitments from Citigroup, J P Morgan Chase, Bank One and financial arm of General Electric for $1.5 billion in financing needed to keep operating in bankruptcy protection; chart; photos (M)

headline: Europe Votes To Overhaul Antitrust Regulations
abstract: European Union overhauls its antitrust laws in hopes of channeling its energy into uncovering price-fixing arrangements and breaking up cartels; new laws, adopted by vote of economics ministers of union's 15 member nations, will shift much of responsibility for regulating ties between companies away from European Commission and back to individual countries and their courts (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Philippines: Brewer Considers Taiwan
abstract: Philippines beer and food conglomerate San Miguel is considering investment in Taiwan as part of drive to expand in Asia (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Dole Food Co chief executive David H Murdock extends $2.5 billion takeover offer for 76 percent of company not already owned by him or his family (S)

headline: US Airways and Pilots in Agreement on Concessions
abstract: Bankrupt US Airways reaches tentative accord with its pilots' union on added concessions that would save carrier $101 million annually; photo (M)

headline: Jittery Britain to Advise Public How to React to Terror Attacks
abstract: Britain will start a campaign to advise the public about how to respond to a biological or chemical attack.

headline: South Of Border, Prospects And Pitfalls
abstract: Kenneth N Gilpin interviews Paul H Rogers, portfolio manager of Scudder Latin America fund, on prospects for economies and markets of that region; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: University Chiefs Quit Over Budget
abstract: About fifty Italian university chancellors resign to protest national budget cuts planned for 2003; Finance Ministry spokesman Fabrizio Ravoni discounts resignations as publicity stunt and assures research funds will be forthcoming (S)

headline: France Télécom Names a Chief
abstract: France Telecom reshuffles its board, naming Thierry Breton to be chairman and chief executive; board members representing labor unions and employees say that Breton told them he has received assurances that French government will play major role in any financial overhaul; state owns 56 percent of France Telecom; photo (M)

headline: Corporate Leaders Are More Pessimistic Than the Fed
abstract: Most chief executives of large companies plan to reduce work forces in 2003 in face of what they predict will be meager economic growth; several Federal Reserve officials disagree, stating publicly that United States economy is slowly gaining strength; majority of chief executives say their 2003 capital-spending budgets will be unchanged (M)

headline: Norway Tries to Resolve A Lasting Nazi Legacy
abstract: Norway's Parliament is expected to vote to endorse compensating some 12,000 children born to Norwegian mothers and occupying German soldiers during World War II for abuse they suffered at hands of their countrymen after war; such births were encouraged by Nazis and children were pampered during war as torchbearers of new master race; Norway deported thousands of mothers after war, some of whom left without children, or interned them as collaborators (M)

headline: Israeli Forces Take Positions Near Arafat's Compound
abstract: Israeli forces took up positions in buildings near Yasir Arafat's compound in Ramallah today.

headline: Chief Weapons Inspector Urges Iraq to Accept New Rules as Team Awaits Resolution
abstract: Chief UN weapons inspector Hans Blix appeals to Iraq to agree to arrangements for new inspections but says his weapons teams will only return to Iraq if Security Council adopts resolution giving them new mandate; say he still has no agreement with Iraq on several inspection issues; Sec of State Colin L Powell meets British Foreign Sec Jack Straw; both seek to link Pres Saddam Hussein to global campaign against terrorism; Sec Gen Kofi Annan meets with in Beijing with Chinese Pres Jiang Zemin, who says UN weapons inspectors should return to Iraq as soon as possible to report on weapons programs; photo (M)

headline: Plans for an Independent Janus
abstract: Mark Whiston, who will become president of Janus Capital Management on Dec 31 when it separates from parent Stilwell Financial and becomes publicly traded company, says Janus will offer more risk-managed funds and value-oriented funds (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Andreotti Trial Resumes
abstract: Trial of former Prime Min Giulio Andreotti on charges of colluding with Mafia during his many years in office resumes in Palermo's appeals court after summer recess (S)

headline: Optimism Among Midsize Manufacturers
abstract: A new survey of chief financial officers at midsize manufacturing companies found substantial optimism about business prospects in 2003, corroborating a recent spate of positive data on the economy but differing with the views of America's top chief executives.    Fleet Capital collected 673 responses from a survey of financial executives at randomly selected manufacturers with annual revenue of $25 million to $1 billion. Almost 7 in 10 of the executives expected the economy to expand next year. A roughly equal portion predicted that their own revenue would increase in 2003, compared with just half in the survey a year ago.

headline: When Life's Watermarks Become Visible
abstract: Lisa Belkin Life's Work column comments on how regular rituals, such as changing clocks twice a year, can help mark life's changes; drawings (M)

headline: Private Sector; A Mild-Mannered Mr. Fix-It
abstract: Profile of Knight Trading Group chief executive Thomas Joyce; discusses his efforts to fix problems of troubled stock and options trading firm; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Shares In 2 Video Game Companies Fall
abstract: Technology

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Credit Union Investigation
abstract: South Korean government agency suspends nearly 10 percent of country's 1,242 credit unions for 6 months while it investigates their finances; investors in 115 credit unions will not have access to their assets, totaling nearly $2 billion, during that period; government has already closed 410 credit unions (S)

headline: Opposition Headed for Landslide Win in Kenyan Election
abstract: Incomplete election results in Kenya indicate that Mwai Kibaki will become next president, winning by landslide over Uhuru Kenyatta, Pres Daniel arap Moi's chosen successor; Moi's party seems to be facing crucial losses in other contests as well (M)

headline: Some questions on 'The Sopranos,' an 'American Beauty' star and a Donald. And some answers.
abstract: Stuart Elliott, in first column in occasional series, answers questions submitted to weekly e-mail newsletter In Advertising; photo (M)

headline: Some Working Moms Can't Have It All
abstract: Helen Feit letter responds to Oct 27 Executive Life column about executive's special child care arrangements while she attends to her work responsibilities

headline: Kurdish Agents Play Spy Games With Iraqis on Arms Tips
abstract: Kurdish security officials evaluate stream of tips about where Saddam Husein 's chemical weapons and illegal missiles are said to be hidden, and there is lively internal debate about whether tips are authentic or part of deliberte counterintelligence campaign by Iraqi security forces; photo (M)

headline: Private Sector; How Did That Ice Cream Get Its Start?
abstract: John Robbins, son of founder of Baskin-Robbins ice-cream chain, joins People for Ethical Treatment of Animals in seeking court order to make California Milk Advisory Board halt its 'Happy Cows' campaign, which shows cows and calves leisurely grazing in idyllic pastures; says truth is entirely opposite from what is portrayed (S)

headline: In South Africa, Leaders Face Blacks' Ire
abstract: Black protesters march through Johannesburg, accusing black government of losing touch with the poor and charging that privatization is 'born-again apartheid'; photo (M)

headline: In Vast Expansion of the European Union, Pluses but Also Perils Lie Ahead
abstract: Uncertain outlook for European Union discussed, as vast expansion of EU approaches; trouble is that few people--either in 15 nations already in European Union or in 10 others being invited to join by 2004--are entirely sure it is a good thing for all of Europe to be fused into single entity in name of peace and prosperity; current, relatively wealthy members of European Union face fears of being overwhelmed by new members in east that are far poorer, and that may send waves of immigrants westward, taking jobs and creating new pressures on economies that are, at the moment, far from robust; map; charts compare growth in gross domestic products of France and Britain with 10 newest members (L)

headline: Article 2002112191885448982 -- No Title
abstract: function pop_me_up(pURL, features) { new_window = window.open(pURL, "popup_window", features); new_window.focus(); } For Road Warriors, Tools to Ease the Way When Mobility Counts, Small Is Beautiful

headline: South Korea May Allow a Rise In Stock Held by Pension Funds
abstract: South Korean government announces sweeping plan for injecting new life into its sagging stock market by allowing increased stock market investments by National Pension Fund and other government pension plans (M)

headline: Al Qaeda Arrest in Kuwait
abstract: A Qaeda member who has confessed to planning the attack on French tanker in Yemen is in custody, a Kuwaiti official said. Page 20.

headline: Economic Scene; Sticks and stones can break bones, but the wrong name can make a job hard to find.
abstract: Professor Alan B Krueger Economic Scene article on recent study that found job applicants with common black first names on their resumes were less likely to be called for interview than applicants with common white names and identical qualifications; table of names (M)

headline: U.S., Counting on France, Will Submit Iraq Plan to U.N.
abstract: United States decides to submit its final proposal for resolution on Iraq to Security Council after Secretary of State Colin L Powell concludes draft would receive crucial support of France; French diplomats say Paris would not make final decision until French Foreign Min Dominique de Villepin and Pres Jacques Chirac study complete text of revised draft (M)

headline: TECHNOLOGY: Gazing Into 2003: Economy Intrudes on Dreams of New Services -- Cellular; Making a Statement In Tunes and Pictures
abstract: Outlook for technology in 2003 notes that cellular phone carries are moving to create range of new consumer services; new phones from Nokia and others allow consumers to download games and melodious ring tones, browse the Web and send and receive e-mail; photo (S)

headline: The Craving Man takes his lumps in a new campaign for a patch to control smoking.
abstract: Pharmacia Corp has begun $50 million marketing campaign developed by BBDO Worldwide for its Nicotrol 16-hour nicotine-replacement patch; Pharmacia faces daunting task because sales of over-the-counter products to help people stop smoking have been stagnantg over last five years; market is dominated by GlaxoSmithKline, which has top brands in Nicorette gum and Nicoderm CQ patch; photo (M)

headline: René Thom, 79, Inventor of Catastrophe Theory, Dies
abstract: Dr Rene Thom, French mathematician who invented catastrophe theory, dies at age 79; photo (M)

headline: Times Co. to Buy Washington Post's Stake in Herald Tribune
abstract: The New York Times Company said today that it had signed a letter of intent to become the sole owner of the Paris-based newspaper.

headline: Quarterly Loss Widens at Reader's Digest
abstract: Reader's Digest Association Inc reports widened fiscal first-quarter loss of $5.2 million, or 5 cents a diluted share; sales rise 3.9 percent; spending on promotions and marketing increases (M)

headline: Court Rules for Cameroon In Oil Dispute With Nigeria
abstract: World Court rules at Hague that Cameroon is rightful owner of oil-rich Bakassi Peninsula in Gulf of Guinea that has long been claimed by Nigeria; decision in longstanding dispute could shuffle some of oil wealth in area thought to hold huge offshore deposits; dispute has limited exploration, but peninsula's proximity to other abundant fields holds promise of deposits of hundreds of millions of barrels; this would be timely boost for Cameroon, whose production has been steadily declining; map (M)

headline: Private Sector; When There's Smoke at the Firehouse
abstract: DaimlerChrysler again rents historic firehouse near Detroit's Cobo convention center for use as hospitality suite during automobile show in January 2003; photo (S)

headline: A Friend in India to All the World
abstract: Amber miners of Simojovel, Mexico, earn very little for their backbreaking and dangerous work: salary of no more than $2 or $3 a day, plus as little as $2.50 a week for amber that they might hack from earth; they work hand-hewn, hundred-foot tunnels without benefit of safety standards, rules and regulations; Simojovel has one of world's few known mother lodes of amber, and its amber is reputed to be best; photos; map (M)

headline: Two Magazines Are Shut And Red Herring Is Sold
abstract: Mutual Funds magazine, personal finance magazine owned by AOL Time Warner, and Upside magazine, owned by MCG Capital Corp, say they are shutting down; November issue of Mutual Funds will be last, while October issue of Upside, which is in production, will not be published; Red Herring magazine says it is selling itself to majority investor RHC Media Inc in effort to restructure financially; photo (M)

headline: Havel Denies Telephoning U.S. On Iraq Meeting
abstract: Czech Pres Vaclav Havel's spokesman denies The New York Times report that Havel called senior Bush administration officials to explain that Czech authorities have no proof that Sept 11 hijacker Mohamed Atta met in Prague with Iraqi spy in April 2001 (S)

headline: Private Sector; How to Score a Best Seller
abstract: High-powered associates of Arthur Levitt attend party to celebrate publication of his book Take on the Street (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: CenturyTel Bid For Digital Teleport Assets
abstract: CenturyTel Inc offers $38 million in cash for bankrupt Digital Teleport Inc's fiber optic network and Midwest business (S)3

headline: Haitian Industry Sees Hope in U.S. Trade Bill
abstract: Haiti's manufacturers lobby US Congress to pass trade act that would allow Haitian clothing factories, which now receive duty exemptions only if they use American fabrics, to use fabrics from other cuntries, where they might cost less; say such a measure could triple number of factory jobs in Haiti and spur other industries to invest in Haiti, whose advantage as hemisphere's least expensive labor market has been outweighed by infrastructure that has deteriorated, party because of freeze on foreing aid; photo (M)

headline: Digital-Generation Gifts for Radio-Generation Parents
abstract: Roundup of electronic holiday gift ideas for people to give aging parents and grandparents; user-friendly items with good design are important when buying gadgets for older people who often have sight or dexterity problems (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Telecom System Set Up
abstract: China's No. 2 mobile phone operator meets its state-set goal of creating rival phone network based on communications system most widely used in United States; operator, China United Telecommunications, signs up seven million users this year for its code-division multiple access system (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Explosives Linked To White Group
abstract: South African police unearth supply of explosives while investigating white militant group Boeremag; group claims responsibility for October bombing in Soweto (S)

headline: World Business Briefing: Europe
abstract: THE NETHERLANDS: Nutrition Write-Off; GERMAN: Chip Maker Posts Loss; BELGIUM: Telecom Executive Dies; BRITAIN: Bid For Retailer Altered;.

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: RUSSIA: Protests On Revolution'S Anniversary; NORTHERN IRELAND: Official Arrested In Spy Inquiry; IRELAND: Outrage Over Proposed Smoking Ban; ITALY: Protesters Gather In Florence; DENMARK: One Killed In Commuter Train Crash;.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Plan To Trade Foreign Stocks
abstract: Indian government drafts plan to allow trading of non-Indian stocks on country's exchanges in form of depository receipts, the way many foreign shares are traded in US (S)

headline: G.E. TO BUILD LAB IN GERMANY FOR $52 MILLION
abstract: General Electric Co will invest $52 million over next five years to build its first European research laboratory in Garching, Germany; laboratory is expected to employ 150 scientists by 2005; will focus on technology development in areas like renewable energy, medical imaging and materials science rather than on fundamental research (S)

headline: Private Sector; Edsel Ford, Consultant With a Bankroll
abstract: Marketing Associates reveals in routine news release that Edsel B Ford II is its principal owner (M)

headline: A Personal Tech Feedback Forum
abstract: Usually, you find a "P.S." only at the bottom of a full-fledged letter. This week, however, my e-mail note to you consists of nothing but postscripts. Here are my follow-ups to previous columns:

headline: J.P. Morgan's Thorny Dilemma on Troubled Loans
abstract: Loans made to telecommunications and cable television industries and deal linked to Enron Corp weigh down JP Morgan Chase balance sheet, causing Moody's Investors Service and Standard & Poor's Corp to reduce ratings on bank's debt; chief executive William B Harrison, who insists that economic recovery will revive Morgan's profitability, faces dilemma in that by staying the course he would fail to address investors' anxieties but by discount selling of bank's loan portfolio he could incur further lowering of credit ratings and attendant increased operating costs; most recent quarterly report shows 91 percent earnings drop compared with year earlier; Morgan's management could change if results do not improve soon; photos; graph (M)

headline: U.S. Officials Will Try to Help Tame Afghanistan Border Trade
abstract: Treasury officials say they will send customs officials to assess chaotic and largely unregulated system at Afghanistan's main border crossings to help nation gain control of customs revenues; respond to request Pres Hamid Karzai and Min Ashraf Ghani Ahmedzai made of visiting Sec Paul H O'Neill (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Manugistics Shares Drop On Report Of Loss
abstract: Manugistics Group warns third-quarter loss will exceed analysts' expectations; stock price falls sharply; stock price graph (S)

headline: One Down, 31,999 to Go: Surrendering to a Solitary Obsession
abstract: FreeCell has become addiction for many computer users because, unlike most versions of solitaire, all cards are made visible in tableau of eight columns at onset, making it more game of strategy and one of luck (M)

headline: Miramax Blinks, and a Double DiCaprio Vanishes
abstract: Miramax Films decides to release Martin Scorsese's film Gangs of New York, starring Leonardo DiCaprio, in early December to prevent it from going head-to-head with Dec 25 release of Dreamworks' film Catch Me if You Can, directed by Steven Spielberg and starring DiCaprio; Miramax's decision to change release date for Gangs of New York shows how concerned studio is about whether film will prevail in all-important opening days; Miramax has three other big movies opening on or near Christmas Day, Pinocchio, starring Roberto Benigni, Chicago and Confessions of a Dangerous Mind, directed by George Clooney about Gong Show creator Chuck Barris, who claimed to be spy; photos (M)

headline: HERSHEY FOODS WILL BUY BACK $500 MILLION IN STOCK
abstract: Hershey Foods Corp will repurchase as much as $500 million of common stock; adds $150 million to its pension plans (S)

headline: Iraqi City Seen as Powder Keg If Hussein Were to Be Ousted
abstract: Iraqi government has displaced or relocated nearly million Iraqis in last three decades, majority of them Kurds; report by Brookings Institution says this has created deep regional and ethnic fractures that could erupt into civil war if Pres Saddam Hussein is deposed; says Kurds whose villages were razed or mined by Iraqi military are living in ramshackle communities, and any effort by them to regain control of fertile, oil-rich northern city of Kirkuk could set off conflict; report underscores rising tide of concern among Iraq's neighbors, international aid groups and foreign policy experts about chaos that could be unleashed if US forcefully deposes Hussein (M)

headline: World Business Briefing: Europe
abstract: SWITZERLAND: Insurer Chooses Chairman; RUSSIA: Airline Drops Logo; BRITAIN: Bank Names Chief; BELGIUM: Brewer Selects Leader; GERMANY: Steel Maker Forecasts Profit;.

headline: Iceland Joins Whale Panel, Giving Whalers Stronger Say
abstract: Vote allowing Iceland to join International Whaling Commisssion shows shift in power toward defiant whaling nations; for two decades antiwhaling nations led by United States have safeguarded commission's moratorium on commercial whale hunting; Iceland, which quit commission in 1992, has now been readmitted despite its declared intent to resume commercial whaling in 2006; Norway currently conducts only annual commercial hunt in defiance of commission majority, although Japan takes hundreds of whales each year for what it says is scientific research; Greenpeace International, environmental group, attributes surge in pro-whaling sentiment to promises by Japan to give aid to countries that support its quest to legitimize whaling (M)

headline: WESTAR ENERGY REPORTS IT LOST MORE THAN IT SAID
abstract: Westar Energy, the owner of Kansas' biggest utility, will restate first-half results, widening its net loss for the period by $98.4 million, or $1.37 a share, after discovering accounting errors. The company said it made mistakes in accounting for good will at its security business and for liabilities from a call option on Westar's debt. It had reported a net loss of $639.6 million, or $8.94 a share, for the first six months of 2002. The restatement comes after a federal grand jury last month subpoenaed documents and testimony about Westar's chief executive, David Wittig, and the use of corporate aircraft.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Bank's Income Is Down
abstract: Societe Generale reports 63 percent decline in third-quarter profit, to 146 million euros ($147 million); will eliminate about 200 employees to reduce operating costs (S)

headline: A Word of the Day Keeps Banality at Bay
abstract: Anu Garg's e-mailed word-of-the-day is indispensable to many on his subscriber list, which comprises 527,850 people from 206 countries; photo; sampling of words from companion book A Word a Day: A Romp Through Some of the Most Unusual and Intriguing Words in English, coauthored by Garg's wife Stuti (M)

headline: Security Council Votes, 15-0, for Tough Iraq Resolution
abstract: The Security Council unanimously adopted a resolution on Friday that President Bush called a "final test" of Saddam Hussein's willingness to disarm.

headline: Mutual Funds Report; Fund Firm Weathers A Year of Big Losses
abstract: Alliance Capital Management, which held very large positions in most of biggest companies involved in financial scandals over past year, loses tremendous amounts of money for its individual and institutional clients; its own share price has declined 42.6 percent this year through September; firm has close to $400 billion under management; photo; graph (M)

headline: Private Sector; The Elephant's Dance Teacher Decides to Go Back to School . . .
abstract: Former International Business Machines chief executive Louis V Gerstner Jr begins promotional tour for his book Who Says Elephants Can't Dance?; plans to start national commission dedicated to improving education; will study Chinese history at Cambridge University; photo (S)

headline: Israeli Ex-Army Chief Accepts Defense Post
abstract: Shaul Mofaz, who has advocated aggressive measures against Palestinians, including exiling Yasir Arafat, has agreed to become Israel's next defense minister.

headline: World Business Briefing: Asia
abstract: SOUTH KOREA: Bank Takeover Advances; JAPAN: Telecom Profit Soars;.

headline: Agencies to Create Sports Venture
abstract: Publicis Groupe, Dentsu and Sports Mondial agree to form venture for international sports marketing called International Sports and Entertainment, or iSe; venture will be financed with $10.3 million from its founders; Publicis and Dentsu will each control 45 percent, and Sports Mondial will control 10 percent; Haruyuki Takahashi is named chairman, Bertrand Siguier is named vice chairman and George Taylor is named chief executive (S)

headline: Capturing a Vote in Athens After Catching Its Eye
abstract: OVER the two decades since Yvette Jarvis came here from the United States, she has been called many things.    ''The Black Diamond'' was a nickname that Greeks bestowed on her when she was playing women's basketball here and becoming an immediate standout in a country that was almost entirely ethnically and racially homogenous at the time.

headline: Terrorism Panel Says U.S. Is Still Unready
abstract: Despite months of preparations and the spending of millions of dollars, the United States remains extremely vulnerable to a terrorist attack, particularly at seaports, power plants and oil refineries, a panel of security experts has concluded.    In a report being released today, the panel contends that police officials still have little access to intelligence on terror suspects, that only a tiny fraction of vessels entering American ports are inspected and that most emergency workers are ill equipped to handle biowar attacks.

headline: Czechs Republic Is Filing Claim Over Bank's Fall
abstract: Czech Republic says it will press claim against two units of Japanese investment bank Nomura Holdings, for $3.3 billion to $8.5 billion in damages connected to seizure of Czech bank, Investicni a Postovni Banka, in which Nomura bought large stake in 1998; claim is being filed with international arbitration panel in London; Nomura already has claim against Czech state before panel, seeking $1 billion and accusing government of unlawfully seizing bank, known as IPB, after regulators said it was unable to meet cash calls (M)

headline: Part Investigator, Part Counselor
abstract: Craig N Chretien writes My Job column on being managing director of Los Angeles office of IPSA International, doing private investigation work; photo (M)

headline: Nani Palkhivala, 82, Dies; Civil Rights Leader in India
abstract: Nani Palkhivala, leading Indian constitutional lawyer and civil rights advocate, dies at age 82; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Liberate Technologies Shares Rebound
abstract: Shares in Liberate Technologies rebound after falling 14 percent day before; company suspended chief operating officer after it discovered deeper problems with its revenue accounting than previously thought (S)

headline: Palestinian Urges Defiance; Plan to Grab Arafat Reported
abstract: Marwan Barghouti, rising Palestinian leader on trial in Israel on charges of terrorism, calls on Palestinians throughout West Bank to defy Israeli curfews; trial is shaping up as showdown between Israeli officials out to demonstrate links between mainstream Palestinian leaders and terrorism, and Barghouti, one of most articulate of those leaders, who is trying to put Israeli occupation itself in the dock; Israeli newspaper reports that army has rehearsed operation to snatch and deport Yasir Arafat; Prime Min Ariel Sharon has repeatedly sought to exile Arafat, but most of country's top security officials oppose move and coalition government has blocked it; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Asks NATO Nations to Offer Forces for an Iraq Campaign
abstract: Deputy Defense Sec Paul D Wolfowitz, visiting NATO headquarters, Brussels, asks individual NATO nations to contribute forces to potential military campaign to topple Iraqi Pres Saddam Hussein; move is part of Bush administation strategy to build broad international coalition for possible war; coincides with invitation to Recep Tayyip Erdogan, leader of largest party in Turkey's new government coalition, to meet with Pres Bush (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: India: Peaceful Turnout In Gujarat Election
abstract: Peaceful election in Gujarat State, India, draws 63 percent voter turnout; area has been plagued with Hindu-Muslim riots, causing 1,000 deaths in past year (S)

headline: Validating Opus Dei, the Pope Makes Its Founder a Saint
abstract: Pope John Paul II canonizes Josemaria Escriva de Balaguer, founder of Opus Dei, in ceremonies in St Peter's Square attended by hundreds of thousands; canonization represents ultimate validation for deeply conservative Roman Catholic lay group that has grown steadily in influence over recent years, but has stirred considerable controversy and is regarded with suspicion by many progressive Catholics; comes 27 years after Escriva's death in 1975, lightning quick period by previous church standards; photo (M)

headline: Startling His Neighbors, Australian Leader Favors First Strikes
abstract: Australian Prime Min John Howard says he favors change in United Nations Charter to allow pre-emptive strikes against terrorists abroad, television interview; remarks and others he has made since at least 82 Australians were killed in Oct terrorist bombing in Bali, Indonesia, have alarmed other nations in region; Indonesia scores proposal; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing: Hardware
abstract: JUNIPER LOSS WIDENS ON HIGHER COSTS; LEXMARK EARNINGS BEAT FORECASTS; JUDGE RULES AGAINST INTEL ON ITANIUM CHIPS;.

headline: U.S. Says Evidence Confirms Reports of Mass Rapes by Burmese
abstract: State Department reports obtaining evidence that mass rapes of hundreds of girls and women were carried out by Burmese army in Shan Province, Myanmar, where military government has tried for years to suppress ethnic rebellion; says United States has expressed 'deep concern' about rapes and other abuses to Myanmar and urged government to punish guilty; US has also called on United Nations to probe charges, first made by human rights groups (M)

headline: Threats and Responses: The Opposition; Iraqi Kurds Set Sights On Baghdad
abstract: A senior leader of an Iraqi Kurdish group has said his forces intend to push all the way to Baghdad in the event of an American-led war in Iraq.     In an interview here on Friday, Jalal Talabani, the leader of the Patriotic Union of Kurdistan, said he had no intention of limiting his group's military activities to its base in northern Iraq. He predicted that any number of the armed groups who are fighting Saddam Hussein would converge on the capital if the Americans invaded.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Drug Maker Acquired
abstract: Novï

headline: Hot sauces are battling it out for market share.
abstract: Advertising column on increasingly competitive market for hot sauces; Frank's Red Hot Cayenne Pepper Sauce, unit of Reckitt Benckiser, has been given advertising makeover by MVBMS Euro RSCG; new ads for Tabasco Sauce, produced by McIlhenny Co, are aimed at young men; agency is DDB Worldwide; photo (M)

headline: Ronald Moss, 72, New York State Official
abstract: Ronald J Moss, former advertising executive who was New York State commerce commissioner in Cuomo administration, dies at age of 72 (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Vietnam: Jail Term For Internet Dissent
abstract: Le Chi Quang is sentenced to four years in prison for posting essays critical of Vietnam's government on Internet; two other Vietnamese await trial for their Internet essays (S)

headline: Law Firm Sued by Ex-Partner Over Statements
abstract: Frode Jensen, former lawyer at Pillsbury Winthrop, sues firm for sending out news releases last month that said his departure came 'on the heels of sexual harassment allegations' and 'significant decline in his productivity'; Jensen, who planned to work for Latham & Watkins but has since withdrawn, is suing Pillsbury for $45 million, contending firm engaged 'in a disgraceful and repugnant campaign to disseminate false and defamatory information'; Pillsbury's general counsel Ronald E Van Buskirk says Jensen is disgruntled ex-partner making unjustified allegations (M)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Mozambique: Murder Inquiry Cites Leader's Son
abstract: Mozambique news agency reports officials are investigating possible involvement of Nyimpine Chissano, President Joaquim Chissano's son, in slaying of journalist Carlos Cardoso two years ago; reporter was killed while investigating bank fraud tied to many influential people (S)

headline: For Indonesia Leader, Small Talk Edges Tough Talk
abstract: Bombing in Bali that killed more than 200 people forces Pres Megawati Sukarnoputri to finally confront issue of terrorism and Islamic militants in Indonesia who may be linked to Al Qaeda; she is in contradictory position of wanting to avoid harsh crackdown that might increase sympathies for Islamists while avoiding looking too weak in face of challenge from Vice Pres Hamzah Haz, who will likely challenge her re-election bid in 2004; Pres Bush has challenged her to show 'the resolve of a leader' in fighting terrorists; she was one of first foreign leaders to see him after Sept 11 attack, and she promised to fight terror; but she carefully distanced herself from Washington when she came home to widespread anti-Americanism; photos (M)

headline: The Union Label For Young Workers
abstract: Gary Chaison letter responds to Sept 15 Preludes article by pointing out differences between traditional labor unions and workers' advocacy groups

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Mitsubishi Posts A Profit
abstract: Mitsubishi Motors reports profit of 6.6 billion yen ($55 million) and gain 5.6 percent in sales in six months ended Sept 30; company lost 31.5 billion yen during same period in 2001 (S)

headline: Gala at Angkor: 'Cue the Monks,' Then the Tenor
abstract: Gala benefit event for 1,000, featuring light show, concert by tenor Jose Carreras, classical Cambodian dance and fine dining is held at great temple of Angkor Wat; concert earns less than its organizers hoped--about $40,000 each for four sponsoring charities; photo (M)

headline: Coping With the Spiral of Stress That Layoffs Create
abstract: Robert Todaro describes loss of his job during companywide layoffs as 'utterly devastating'; he now has another job, but says he has not forgotten what it was like to be without work; says in addition to worry about money, he was depressed, emotionally and physically; such mental health issues surrounding job loss are drawing more attention from psychologists; vulnerability that worker experiences after being laid off can undermine ability to find next job; photo (Special Section, Working) (M)

headline: U.S. and Israel Clash, Briefly, Over U.S. Doctor Detained, Briefly
abstract: Israel sparks brief dispute with United States with report that it detained Dr Khaled Nazem Diyab, American doctor with Red Cross and Red Crescent, on his Nov arrival in Israel on suspicion of transferring funds to terrorist organizations linked to Al Qaeda; says he resided in Afghanistan in past and had links to groups that identify with Taliban and to Hamas; State Department responds that it has no evidence that Diyab, who was detained Nov 14 and expelled Nov 26, has terrorist ties; later retracts statement (M)

headline: U.N. MONITOR SAYS IRAQIS ARE DENYING HAVING ARMS CACHE
abstract: Hans Blix, UN weapons inspection chief, says Iraqi officials have informed UN inspectors in Bahgdad that they have no weapons of mass destruction and express reservations about inspections of Pres Saddam Hussein's palaces; says Iraqi officials have pledged to cooperate fully, but have also raised host of skeptical questions about declaration of chemical, biological and nuclear weapons due on December 8; says officials are suggesting declaration is too broad to finish by deadline and question whether they must include every detail of their civilian chemical industries; said he warned Iraq would have to provide convincing evidence if it claims to be clean; US moves in UN, to surprise of some diplomats, to add items to list of restricted imports to Iraq on ground they can be used for military purposes; photos (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Clerical Jobs at Center Of West Coast Port Dispute  In the standoff that has shut West Coast ports and threatens to undermine the economy, employers and union officials agree that the heart of the dispute involves a few hundred clerical jobs held by longshoremen who keep track of cargo. The union's fear is that when new technologies are introduced, the jobs will go to companies using nonunion labor.    As the dispute continues, retailers and manufacturers have begun to focus on contingency plans to let them ship goods in case the ports remain closed. [Page A20.]

headline: When Wizards Are Unwise
abstract: Ispend so much time complaining about software design, I'm probably starting to sound like a high-tech Andy Rooney. But this week, something new is bugging me: wizards. (And no, I'm not talking about the marketing blitz for the new Harry Potter movie.)

headline: The Web Loves Babies, Especially at 4 in the Morning
abstract: New parents have great resource in Internet, where scores of sites offer general advice on child-rearing, archives of articles, product information, baby naming tips, child care help, free e-mail newsletters, messge boards and chat rooms; drawing (M)

headline: Paratrooper From New Jersey Dies in Afghan Firefight Near Pakistan Border
abstract: An Army paratrooper was killed in a firefight with gunmen in an eastern border area near Pakistan today, in the most serious of a string of recent attacks against United States and allied forces in Afghanistan.    It was the first American death from hostile fire in Afghanistan since May 19, and underscored the security problems that persist in regions along the ill-defined border with Pakistan even as the Pentagon prepares to shift to nation-building tasks in the rest of the country.

headline: Euro sags as Prodi laments lack of flexibility in rules : EU leader says pact on budgets is 'stupid'
abstract: BRUSSELS:—  Calling the budgetary rules that underpin Europe's common currency "stupid" and inflexible, the president of the European Commission, Romano Prodi, lashed out at the European Union's Stability and Growth Pact on Thursday and sided with France and Germany in calling for "more intelligent" fiscal rules for the euro.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Ex-Chairman of Big Board Selected to Lead S.E.C.  President Bush selected William H. Donaldson, a former head of the New York Stock Exchange, founder of a brokerage firm and a friend of the Bush family, to be the next chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission. Mr. Bush also made a policy U-turn about the budget of the S.E.C. and announced that he would support an increase for 2004.    The selection of Mr. Donaldson and the announcement of the proposed budget increase appeared to be aimed at assuring that the S.E.C. regains its footing by the 2004 elections. The moves followed criticism that the agency's turmoil have been caused by a leadership crisis, White House neglect and a lack of adequate resources and staff. [Page A1.]

headline: Many Are Wireless in the South
abstract: More than half of people in United States now own cellphones, according to data from Telephia, wireless research company; southern states have greatest number of subscribers; photo; graph compares prevalence in 10 US cities (M)

headline: Fears of a Hard Landing Rattle Tokyo
abstract: Japan's Economics Min Heizo Takenaka confirms that Japan's markets are in severe shape; Prime Min Junichiro Koizumi rebuffs politicians' pleas by refusing to try to make soft landing with cushion of several trillion more yen in bonds; Nikkei index drops almost 2 percent, to 8,539.34, new 19-year low; foreign investors sold net $11.3 billion worth of Japanese stock in September; Finance Min Masajuro Shiokawa blames media for running stories as if big companies are going bankrupt and Japan is going into big panic; graph (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Euro falls against dollar, settling at 97.98 cents, down from 98.66 cents Thursday; graph; table of currency conversions (S)

headline: An Outsider, Wounded in a Combative Industry
abstract: With only three months of industry experience under his belt, United Airlines' chief executive, Glenn F. Tilton, has begun the daunting task of hauling his company out of Chapter 11 bankruptcy, and critics are already jumping on him for the few maneuvers he has tried.    Even in the best of circumstances, Mr. Tilton, a former ChevronTexaco executive, would face an uphill battle as an outsider in an industry where the management culture is xenophobic. Unfortunately for him, he is also mired in the worst financial crisis ever to touch United and has no time to figure out a rough-and-tumble industry that has been brutal to outsiders even in calmer times.

headline: Democrats Want Change At the S.E.C.
abstract: Search led by Harvey L Pitt for new top accounting regulator turns into political brawl as Bush admininstration officials defend him against prominent Democrats who call for Pitt to be removed as chairman of Securities and Exchange Commission; Democratic leaders urge Pres Bush in letter to oust Pitt, who has become lightning rod for renewed criticism of administration's handling of economy and what some see as its inability to overcome declining confidence among stock market investors; say Pitt's decision to back away from earlier commitment to support John H Biggs to lead new accounting oversight board represents culmination of pattern of behavior by Pitt that is steadily eroding credibility of SEC; Senate majority leader Tom Daschle says Pitt has given accounting industry veto over who will head new board; Daschle and Rep Richard A Gephardt, in letter, say Pitt has not right person to head agency that oversees financial markets (M)

headline: Iraq Denounces Visit to Palace By U.N. Team
abstract: Iraqi liaison with United Nations arms inspectors, Maj Gen Hussam Muhammad Amin, launches furious broadside against inspectors for their no-notice search of one of Pres Saddam Hussein's innumerable palaces and ascribes it to pressures from United States, Britain and Israel; holds news conference to again deny that Iraq has any banned nuclear, chemical or biological arms; day's events suggest conflicting pressures building in Baghdad, 72 hours before Iraq promises to deliver declaration on any secret weapons programs; Saddam Hussein will seek to meet UN's demands in ways that avoid war while saving his prestige, if not his weapons programs; Amin suggests that inspectors' palace visit was intended to humiliate Hussein; Iraq Foreign Ministry questions why inspectors did not wear protective suits for palace visit if they suspected there might be biological, chemical or nuclear weapons there (M)

headline: Camp for Migrants in France, British Target, Will Shut Early
abstract: France and Britain say asylum camp on France's northern coast will close later this month instead of next Apr; camp, run by French Red Cross, has attracted thousands of immigrants trying to travel illegally to Britain; camp and willingness of asylum seekers to risk death to cross English Channel into Britain has been irritant in French-British relations; France has accused Britain of encouraging illegal immigration with its relatively generous asylum laws; Britain charged France with doing little to prevent asylum seekers from trying to cross Channel; under new arrangement, Britian will receive camp's 1,000 Iraqi Kurds and 200 Afghans, and France will take responsibility for 300 remaining residents; camp is outside Sangatte, whose mayor welcomes its closing (M)
