headline: Accounts
abstract: Rémy Amérique, New York, part of Rémy Cointreau, to KraftWorks, New York, as the agency of record for Cointreau liqueur. Billings were estimated at $10 million to $12 million. The account had been handled by Adair-Greene, Atlanta, part of the McCann-Erickson World Group division of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Applied Microsystems To Liquidate Its Assets
abstract: The Applied Microsystems Corporation, a software developer whose shares have fallen 84 percent in the last year, said yesterday that it would liquidate the company after failing to get financing to develop new products. The feedback the company received from potential financing sources has led it to conclude that liquidation is a ''better alternative,'' Applied Microsystems said in a news release. The liquidation of the company requires shareholders' approval, the company said. Last month, Applied Microsystems sold part of its business to a Motorola Inc. subsidiary. It had planned to focus on developing its Libra Networks hardware and software products for corporate data centers, it said. Shares of Applied Microsystems rose 4 cents, to 21 cents. The news was released after the close of regular trading.

headline: World Briefing: Africa
abstract: IVORY COAST: Rebels Warn French Forces; MOZAMBIQUE: Murder Inquiry Eyes Leader's Son;.

headline: Private Sector; Will the Dinner Guests Want to Eat and Run?
abstract: New York attorney general, Eliot Spitzer, whose aggressive investigations into Wall Street improprieties have caused great discomfort among bankers and other financial professionals, will be guest speaker at American Banker newspaper's Banker of the Year awards dinner; photo (M)

headline: Gadgets as Gifts: A Delicate Dance
abstract: Overview of electronics as holiday gifts with caveat to consider carefully before buying someone complicated and expensive item with high learning curve; drawing (M)

headline: Judge Likens Microsoft's Effect on Java to a Bang on the Knee
abstract: Judge J Frederick Motz, overseeing private antitrust suit against Microsoft, contends that Microsoft hobbled Sun Microsystems the way Tonya Harding's supporters kneecapped rival figure skater Nancy Kerrigan before 1994 Olympics; makes comparison in challenging Microsoft's argument that it should not be forced to include Sun's Java program in Windows, Microsoft software that operates 95 percent of personal computers (M)

headline: INVESTING WITH/Todger Anderson and William S. Chester; Westcore Midco Growth Fund
abstract: Interview with Todger Anderson and William S Chester, co-managers for Denver Investment Advisors of Westcore Midco Growth fund, on their investment strategies; photo; chart; table (M)

headline: Sharon Plans Talks in U.S. on Keeping Iraq at Bay
abstract: Pres Bush and Israeli Prime Min Ariel Sharon will discuss strategies to neutralize threat of an Iraqi missile attack on Israel to avoid need for Israel to retaliate against Iraq itself in event of war; series of imminent meetings in Washington will focus on plans for US to locate and destroy Iraqi missile sites in initial first phase of war; US fears Israeli involvement would inflame Arab world, causing uprisings in countries US hopes will support military action against Iraq; photo (M)

headline: Ex-Leftist In the Center As Brazil Votes Again
abstract: Growing number of Brazilian executives are throwing their support behind Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva, Workers' Party candidate for president; even some who have been his most implacable foes are promising cooperation rather than obstruction; da Silva is ahead of pro-government candidate Jose Serra by 66 percent to 34 percent in latest opinion polls; many Brazilian executives say they see da Silva as candidate more likely to spur growth, stimulate domestic industry, create jobs and better defend Brazil's national interests abroad; photo (M)

headline: Reversing Stance, Director At Tyco Resigns His Post
abstract: Lord Ashcroft, reversing his stand, says he is resigning from Tyco International board to show commitment to his plan to replace directors who served under former chief executive L Dennis Kozlowski (M)

headline: Warnings From Al Qaeda Stir Fear That Terrorists May Attack Oil Tankers
abstract: Threats by Al Qaeda to cut 'economic lifelines' of world's industrialized societies focus attention of intellience agencies and marine police worldwide on vulnerability of oil tankers; reprs of most of world's seagoing nations are meeting in London to discuss how to keep ships safe from long-term problem of piracy and new risks of terrorism; table shows world's major shipping lanes; maps; photo of tanker approaching pirate-infested islands in Strait of Malacca (M)

headline: Horea Journal; Shrine to Lovers, but Will It Swell the Birthrate?
abstract: Corneliu Olar, mayor of Horea, Romania, builds shrine to lovers on Panthing Hill, centuries-old lover's lane that overlooks village and according to local legend derives name from fact that no woman who ever visited hill escaped without having sex; hopes to reverse decline in local birthrates, which in many places in Eastern Europe have dropped steeply; map; photos (M)

headline: Private Sector; Hotels Future, Hotels Past
abstract: Although a new exhibition on hotels at New York's Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum explores fantasy lodgings -- like a ''nature hotel'' made of scaffolding and netting and erected seasonally in city parks -- one hotelier at the opening last week was firmly steeped in current harsh realities.    Jonathan M. Tisch, the chairman and chief executive of Loews Hotels, the show's main sponsor, said business ''is about the same as last year in terms of occupancy, but rates are down 10 to 15 percent'' at his company's 18 hotels. ''The industry's been kept going by the consumer,'' he said. ''There's much less business travel.'' Mr. Tisch predicted that the industry would ''probably'' recover in 2004, ''with a strong prayer there are no further terrorist activities.''

headline: Personal Business; Shuffleboard, Starboard. Finance, Port.
abstract: Cruises featuring investment seminars are proving popular with wealthy retirees; Louis Rukeyser, host of Louis Rukeyser's Wall Street on CNBC, is pioneer in field; Crystal Cruises of Los Angeles says such cruises are fastest-growing segment of its group businsess, attracting 300 to 800 people a cruise; there are circumstances in which participants may be able to write off part of their trips on federal income tax returns, as they do for conventions and seminars held on land; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing: Europe
abstract: BRITAIN: Sales Up At Clothier; SWITZERLAND: Food Unit Sold; BANKER SIGNALS STEADY RATES; BRITAIN: Bank Takeover Expected; BRITAIN: Travel Group Executive Quits; ITALY: Job Cut Warning; GERMANY: Telecom Job Cuts;.

headline: Mixed Signals From White House on Future of S.E.C. Chief
abstract: Bush administration officials send out conflicting signals about Harvey Pitt's future as SEC chairman, complaining privately about political missteps while publicly praising him; advisers also say Pitt will go if investigation of his selection of new accounting oversight board shows improper actions (M)

headline: Technology Briefing: Biotechnology
abstract: AMGEN POSTS $2.6 BILLION LOSS; SERONO REPORTS PROFIT INCREASE; APPLICATION ON MODIFIED GRASS IS WITHDRAWN;.

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; In a Battered Energy Industry, Talk of a New Conflict of Interest
abstract: Latest set of asset sales by El Paso Corp, one of nation's largest energy companies, is drawing new round of criticism from experts, who say that deals raise troubling conflicts of interest; company agreed in two deals earlier this year to sell more than $1.5 billion in pipelines and other property to another publicly traded company that it created and controls, El Paso Energy Partners LP; El Paso says deals are entirely proper and calls them 'win-win' for both companies; will be able to raise cash by selling assets without giving up control of them; growing number of analysts find deals troubling; year after off-the-books partnerships helped topple Enron and send energy industry into tailspin, critics wonder why El Paso continues to transact such large deals with closely held affiliate; note that El Paso--as general partner of El Paso Energy Partners and owner of 27 percent of partnership--controls, operates and profits from assets it sells (Market Place column) (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: META GROUP, Stamford, Conn., an information technology consulting firm, said it would buy an additional 40 percent of Meta Group, its unit based in Ismaning, Germany, for about $1.9 million, increasing its stake to about 96 percent.    FEDDERS, Liberty Corner, N.J., a maker of air treatment products, said it would offer 14 shares of a new class of preferred stock in exchange for 100 shares of its common stock, for up to 15 million shares outstanding.

headline: U.N. Set to Move In Quickly To Seek Iraq Nuclear Arms
abstract: Mohamed ElBaradei says his team of United Nations atomic experts has finished detailed plans for 'full court press' of fast-moving inspections that will quickly uncover any major nuclear weapons program Iraq has undertaken in last four years; says he is confident he would find 'all large components' of nuclear weapons work in Iraq, but cautions that his inspectors could face difficulties detecting smuggled nuclear materials and will need help from other governments; photo (M)

headline: States Talk Tough. Wall Street Sweats.
abstract: State regulators across nation, emboldened by success of Atty Gen Eliot Spitzer in New York, search records of financial firms for evidence of improper and illegal reasons underlying their analysts recommendations to buy shares of certain companies; Morgan Stanley, Lehman Brothers, UBS Paine Webber, Merrill Lynch and Bear, Stearns are among securities firms that states are investigating for conflicts of interest and breach of fiduciary responsibility; Spitzer's success will be hard to duplicate because he is one of few state officials who regulate securities firms from elective office and have power to file criminal charges and because under New York's 81-year-old Martin Act, prosecutors do not have to prove intent to commit securities fraud, merely that fraud occurred because investors were not given all information they needed to make informed decision; photo; table (M)

headline: At Cambridge, furor over royalties
abstract: LONDON—  Researchers at the University of Cambridge are angry over a policy being mooted by administrators whereby the university would retain rights to all intellectual property produced there.

headline: Microsoft Reports Progress In Averting Computer Crashes
abstract: Microsoft releases data about its Watson online error-reporting service, which company says has had significant impact on increasing stability of its software; has struggled in recent years to improve its credibility in face of industry reputation for error-prone programs (M)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Chad: Ex-Ruler Faces Torture Trial
abstract: Chad declares former ruler Hissene Habre no longer exempt from prosecution; Habre is living in Senegal but could face extradition on charges of murder and torture; photo (S)

headline: COMPANY THAT TREATS BLOOD DISEASE TO MAKE PURCHASE
abstract: Baxter International agrees to buy Epic Therapeutics for $50 million to $100 million in order to gain Epic's time-release technology for medicines (S)

headline: JUDGE DISMISSES 2,600 CLAIMS AGAINST EXXON
abstract: Exxon Mobil wins judge's dismissal of about 2,600 asbestos complaints, ending its role in West Virginia trial that once involved 8,000 plaintiffs and hundreds of company defendants; settles 132 claims, agreeing to pay about $2,000 each to plaintiffs with lung cancer who were exposed to Exxon asbestos product; judge rules that workers did not have enough evidence to prove asbestos in Exxon caulk caused their lung illnesses; Union Carbide unit of Dow Chemical is only defendant in trial (S)

headline: J. A. Keller, 84, Head of Linotype Company
abstract: Merganthaler Linotype Company former chief executive J A Keller dies at 84 (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Lava Sets Off Blast
abstract: Lava flow from Italy's Mount Etna causes minor explosion near lake resort injuring 32 people (S)

headline: AETNA CUTS ANOTHER 690 JOBS AFTER DROPPING CUSTOMERS
abstract: Large health insurer Aetna plans to eliminate 690 more jobs as it cuts costs to cope with reduced membership (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Ad Revenue On Net Drops 4% In 2nd Quarter
abstract: Interactive Advertising Bureau says Internet advertising revenue fell 4 percent in second quarter, to $1.46 billion; says marketers spent $2.98 billion in first half of year, down 20.8 percent over first half of 2001 (S)

headline: Cover Art; Step One: Choosing the Software to Brighten the Jewel Box
abstract: Software to design labels for compact discs discussed, including features and prices (M)

headline: A Double Standard For Executive Women?
abstract: Monia Christo letter responds to Sept 15 The Right Thing column by holding that males' and females' stock transactions should be examined under same set of rules and expectations

headline: Big Mexican Cellphone Company Moves Into Brazil
abstract: Domination of its rapidly growing home market has made América Móvil the largest wireless telephone company in Latin America. Now it is charging into Brazil, where it faces much fiercer competition.     América Móvil won an auction on Tuesday for three mobile phone licenses in Brazil, including one covering the most prized market, metropolitan São Paulo, with a $120 million bid. Adding the three licenses to its patchy existing network in Brazil will allow América Móvil, controlled by the Mexican billionaire Carlos Slim Helú, to offer service in most of the country, the continent's largest, and to compete with services owned by deep-pocketed European rivals that already have extensive geographic coverage.

headline: U.S. Should Invade Iraq, Says Council's Middle East Director
abstract: COUNCIL ON FOREIGN RELATIONS, December 2002 - Rachel Bronson, the Council's Director of Middle East Studies, says that there is a 75 percent chance of war this winter with Iraq. She contends that an invasion of Iraq would be "strategically sound and morally just." The entry of the U.N. inspectors into Iraq somewhat earlier than predicted was "a huge unsung win" for the Bush administration because it gives it more time to let diplomacy play its course before Washington has to decide what to do.

headline: Powell Says Iraq Raises Risk of War by Lying About Illegal Arms
abstract: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said Iraq was in "material breach" of Security Council resolutions and "well on its way to losing this last chance" to avoid a war.

headline: Mutual Funds Report; Value Funds a Haven? In This Slump, Hardly
abstract: 'Value' mutual funds, which specialize in identifying undervalued or out-of-favor stocks, decline along with rest of fund industry, as many of their choices continue to suffer share price drops because of dismal earnings prospects; photo (M)

headline: How Not to Sell Obscure Junk on EBay
abstract: Michelle Slatalla column on lessons about selling unwanted stuff on eBay that she learned the hard way; drawing (M)

headline: French Aid to State Utility May Come Under Scrutiny
abstract: European Commission president Romano Prodi says he favors opening investigation into government aid received by state-owned French power monopoly Electricite de France; company's critics say it benefits from unfair subsidies in form of tax breaks and loan guarantees from French government; commission will decide to begin formal inquiry and whether to take legal action against Italy and Spain for enacting 'golden share' laws, which are specifically meant to block Electricite de France by giving government veto over takeovers of privatized utilities (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Tanker Still Burning
abstract: Tanker carrying liquid petroleum gas continues to burn twenty-four miles from Hong Kong; winds continue to keep fire from flamable cargo (S)

headline: World Business Briefing: Europe
abstract: THE NETHERLANDS: Food Company Cuts Prediction; GERMANY: Bill To Postal Service; NEW HINT ON INTEREST RATES; RUSSIA: More Steel To America;.

headline: Economic Scene; If taxes were lower, the economy would grow faster, right? Economists say not necessarily.
abstract: Jeff Madrick Economic Scene column on whether lower taxes will stimulate growth in US; former World Bank economist William Easterly says one can make theoretical case that high taxes impede economic growth, but it is not supported by evidence in US or across countries; study by economists Nancy L Stokey and Sergio Rebelo shows that income tax revenue in US rose to 15 percent of gross domestic product in 1942, from about 2 percent in 1913, but large rise in income tax rates produced no noticeable effect on average growth rate of economy; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing: Asia
abstract: JAPAN: Monetary Policy Unchanged; JAPAN: Profits Grow At Nissan; THAILAND: Interest Rate Cut;.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Credit Suisse First Boston Denies Fraud Accusations  Credit Suisse First Boston responded to a complaint filed by Massachusetts that accused the firm of securities fraud, denying the accusations and calling the complaint ''fundamentally flawed.''    Credit Suisse First Boston denied that it had used its investment advice and new shares issued by clients to reward companies and their executives for hiring the firm. The denials came in an answer to a complaint by William F. Galvin, above, the secretary of the commonwealth. [Page C11.]

headline: Bush Officials Praise Saudis For Aiding Terror Fight
abstract: alliances: bush officials praise saudis for aiding terr

headline: AtHomeAbroad: Fourth or Fifth Culture Kid?
abstract: I am an American living in Japan. Anne-Sophie Bolon's article regarding TCKs was enlightening because she's one of the few people I've heard of whose upbringing was similar to mine. I first heard about TCKs in a previous article in the IHT a few months ago. I read it carefully, but decided that I was not a Third Culture Kid, but a Fourth Culture Kid, or a Fifth Culture Kid. But am I?

headline: U.S. to Sell Military Gear to Algeria to Help It Fight Militants
abstract: Bush administration officials say United States will sell equipment to Algeria's military-backed government to help combat Islamic militants; says US will move slowly on aid, in part because human rights groups have charged Algeria with brutality in crackdown on militants; Asst Sec William Burns says US drafts proposal for Congress on increasing military aid; seeks to intensify security cooperation; US official says there is no clear evidence Al Qaeda operates in Algeria, but that similar groups do (M)

headline: Indonesia Links Muslim  Group With Terrorism
abstract: Indonesian government, in about-face, acknowledges that fundamentalist Islamic group Jemaah Islamiyah exists and is terrorist organization, and that its leader may be Abu Bakar Bashir, Islamic preacher who expresses admiration for Osama bin Laden and loathing for Jews and West; several foreign governments suspect group was involved in blast in Bali; Indonesian government is under pressure from United States to act decisively against terrorism; Indonesia's State Security Minister Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono stops short of saying Bashir will be arrested, as US and other countries have requested; Yudhoyono says for first time publicly that Hambali, another Indonesian cleric, is one of Jemaah Islamiyah's leaders; Asian and Western intelligence agencies say it was Hambali who allied Jemaah Islamiyah with Al Qaeda in 1990's; Philippine officials say they will indict Hambali, who has been fugitive for many months, on charges of illegal possession of explosives that were intended for attacks on American and Israeli Embassies in Singapore that were thwarted by Singaporean police; there is speculation that some of those explosives were used in Bali bombing; photo (L)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Belgium: Bid For Brewer
abstract: Belgian beer maker Interbrew offers 491 million euros ($494 million) to acquire Brauergilde Hannover of Germany, which owns 85 percent of Gilde Brauerei (S)

headline: Finding Rewards in the Job, Not the Pay
abstract: Many young New York college graduates, unable to find jobs in tough economy, are turning to unpaid internships at places like Harper's Magazine; photo (S)

headline: 3rd Day of Protests in Tehran Over Scholar's Death Sentence
abstract: Student protests continue in Tehran for third day over death sentence for Hashem Aghajari, reformist scholar charged with apostasy; students demand his release and call for resignation of Pres Mohammed Khatami, leader of Iran's reform movement, in sign of frustration with continuous setbacks for reform; photo (M)

headline: A New Intrusion, of Soldiers, Threatens an Amazon Tribe
abstract: The Yanomami Indians have lived precariously in the most remote reaches of the jungle here for thousands of years, hunting with bows and arrows, and warring among themselves and with the few white intruders who have appeared in recent years.     But now they are facing a threat to their very existence as a people: the Brazilian Army.

headline: Regulators Say Morgan Stanley Did Not Keep E-Mail Records
abstract: Securities regulators who are investigating practices of Wall Street analysts say Morgan Stanley failed to maintain internal e-mail records as required by securities laws; say there are fewer Morgan Stanley documents to analyze than have been produced by some other firms; Morgan Stanley spokeswoman Diana Quintero says Morgan Stanley has fully satisifed regulators and firm is maintaining good-faith effort to cooperate with every aspect of investigation (M)

headline: SBC Will Combine Its Billing
abstract: SBC Communications is offering local phone service, long-distance calling, wireless service and Internet access on one combined bill (S)

headline: China Fills 2nd-Tier Posts Before Coming Shake-Up
abstract: Chinese news media announces retirement of two of Communist Party's most secretive and powerful officials: Ding Guangen, director of propaganda, and Zeng Qinghong, head of party's organization dept; party insiders call their retirements first steps in wholesale shuffling of positions that will be revealed in weeks ahead; say they do not signify major ongoing power struggle; retirement of Ding, who is 73, has been long rumored; Zeng, who is 63, is expected to vault onto party Politburo's all-powerful seven-man Standing Committee, which in practicerules China (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Computer Sciences Profit Rises As Costs Are Cut
abstract: Computer Sciences Corp reports 36 percent rise in second-quarter profit, to $92.9 million; sales fall 1.2 percent, to $2.73 billion (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Fed Chief Silent on Rates; Regions Show Sluggishness  Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, hailed the continued strong growth in business efficiency but gave no hint as to whether the central bank might consider cutting interest rates when it meets in two weeks.    Later, the Fed said in its beige book report on regional economic conditions that the economy in most parts of the country was sluggish, with retail sales weak and manufacturing activity slowing. [Page C4.]

headline: 10 Killed in Attack on Temple in Kashmir
abstract: Islamic militants attack Hindu temple complex in Kashmir, killing at least 10 people and wounding more than 40; attack is third in three days after period of quiet; together, attacks suggest renewed determination by militants to pursue their drive for secession from India; India accuses Pakistan, which also claims Kashmir, of providing covert support to militants; two countries have fought two wars over disputed territory; photo; map (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Microsoft To Invest $400 Million In India
abstract: Microsoft Corp will invest $400 million in India, where it hopes to create new generation of computer users, expand use of Windows computer operating systems and desktop applications and increase company's technology and product development operations (S)

headline: WORLDCOM GETS APPROVAL FOR $1.1 BILLION LOAN
abstract: WorldCom Inc wins Bankruptcy Judge Arthur Gonzalez's approval of $1.1 billion loan to help finance its reorganization and reassure vendors and customers (S)

headline: Private Sector; Again, a Latin American Exile Turns Into a New Yorker
abstract: Domingo Cavallo is not the first prominent Latin American to find himself in temporary exile in New York. José Martí, the father of Cuban independence, wrote some of his best-known poems while working in New York as a journalist. Antonio López de Santa Anna, the five-time president of Mexico, lived part of his 19th-century exile on Staten Island.    After Mr. Cavallo emerged from 65 days in an Argentine jail earlier this year, he accepted a job as visiting professor at New York University's Stern School of Business.

headline: A Beginner's Guide to Linux
abstract: Ihaven’t written about Linux much in the “State of the Art” column. That’s because from what I’ve heard, Linux isn’t yet easy enough to use for everyday consumers.

headline: Russia Recasts Bog in Caucasus as War on Terror
abstract: Russia recasts its three-year-old war on Chechen separatists as war on terror; Russian commanders are using rationale and sometimes rhetoric of Bush administration's antiterrorism campaign; hold that Chechen war is being financed, armed and increasingly fought by Islamic militants from abroad; shift explains Russia's tensions with Georgia, which borders Chechnya, and which Pres Vladimir V Putin has accused of sheltering what he calls Chechen and international terrorists; Col Gen Vladimir I Moltenskoi, commander of Russian forces in Chechnya, ratchets tensions higher by accusing Georgia, which is overwhelmingly Orthodox Christian, of supplying rebels with stockpile of Soviet-made surface-to-air missiles they have used to devastating effect, shooting down three aircraft in past six weeks; accusations against Georgia appear rooted in Russia's frustration and desire to assign external blame for continued fighting; photos; map (M)

headline: Chief of Advertising Sales Is Leaving CBS
abstract: Joseph D Abruzzese, who has led advertising sales department at CBS for last 12 years, will leave network to join Discovery Networks of cable television as president of sales; CBS Television president Leslie Moonves comments; photo (M)

headline: Sun Reports Loss, Beats Estimates And Cuts Jobs
abstract: Sun Microsystems plans to cut 4,400 employees, or 11 percent of its staff; reports loss for its fiscal first quarter, but still exceeding Wall Street's earnings expectations; says revenue was $2.75 billion, down from 4 percent from $2.86 billion; net loss was $111 million compared with net loss of $180 million year earlier; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Plans to Pressure Iraq By Encouraging Scientists To Leak Data to Inspectors
abstract: Pres Bush, in opening gambit of administation strategy to show that Pres Saddam Hussein will seek to undermine Security Council resolution on arms inspections, urges Iraq's thousands of weapons scientists and members of its military to leak data to inspectors; strategy seeks to lure defectors from arms program with promises that they will not have to return to Iraq under current government; hopes defectors will provide evidence needed to challenge list of weapons sites and research facilities Hussein must produce in 30 days and to funnel to chief arms inspector Hans Blix; photo (M)

headline: Bush Officials Vowing to Seek Tough Penalties In Wall St. Cases
abstract: Bush administration officials are planning to seek tougher corporate fraud penalties and to prosecute vigorously lawyers, bankers, accountants and other who have failed to detect scandals that have rocked Wall Street; Deputy Atty Gen Larry D Thompson has instructed prosecutors to take harder look at 'what kind of advice outside professionals gave to these companies and whether or not they were complicit in wrongdoing'; Justice Department officials say aim is to broaden pool of suspects who may ultimately be prosecuted; want to move investigations beyond boardrooms and executive suites and into offices of professional firms that advise companies; United States Sentencing Commission has proposed stiffer sentencing guidelines under corporate reform bill that Congress passed last summer, Sarbanes-Oxley Act; Justice Department is urging major revisions in commision's plan because department does not think it goes far enough; restoring investor confidence is seen as crucial part of Bush adminstration's efforts to restore confidence in econony (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Jail Terms For Opposition Politicians
abstract: Singapore opposition politicians Chee Soon Juan and Ghandhi Ambalam receive jail terms of up to five weeks for holding rally without permit (S)

headline: BLACK & DECKER TO CLOSE MARYLAND PLANT AND MOVE JOBS
abstract: Blacky

headline: FIVE QUESTIONS for MARGARET M. PEARSON; China's Freshman Year in World Trade
abstract: Interview with Prof Margaret M Pearson on China's first year as World Trade Organization member; she discusses China's mixed progress toward complying with group's trade rules; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: China/Taiwan: Talks On Steel Trade
abstract: World Trade Organization may broker talks between members China and Taiwan in hopes of resolving long-standing steel trade dispute between them (S)

headline: Lift Bugle, Press Play: A High-Tech Taps
abstract: S&D Consulting International, working for Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency, develops device that fits snugly in bugle and plays digital version of taps at veterans' funerals; photos (M)

headline: Technology Briefing: Internet
abstract: 4 COMPANIES SETTLE FAKE-ADDRESS CASE; MOVIE SUBSCRIPTION SERVICE IS SET TO BEGIN;.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: REED SMITH,  Pittsburgh, an international law firm, said it would acquire Crosby, Heafey, Roach & May, Oakland, Calif., a full-service law firm with about 215 lawyers. Terms were not disclosed. The new firm will be known as Reed Smith and employ nearly 1,000 lawyers.    SUNOCO LOGISTICS PARTNERS,  Philadelphia, a publicly traded partnership spun off from Sunoco Inc. in February, said it would buy stakes ranging from 9 percent to 31 percent in three pipeline systems from Unocal Corp., El Segundo, Calif., a diversified energy company, for $54 million.

headline: The Economy's Holiday Treat: Some Reasons for Optimism
abstract: A number of new developments suggest to several economists that the economic weakness that Alan Greenspan, the Fed's chairman, described as a soft patch may be behind us.

headline: More Hospitals Change the Way They Buy Drugs And Supplies
abstract: Growing number of hospitals are reconsidering their use of Premier and Novation, two companies that have long dominated buying of drugs and medical supplies but have recently come under government scrutiny (M)

headline: Hindu Nationalists Win Landslide Vote in Indian State
abstract: Hindu nationalists win landslide re-election victory in Gujarat, India, in vote widely viewed as referendum on India's secular character; vote seems to affirm success of incumbent nationalist party's strategy of focusing on uniting Hindus against threat of Islamic terrorism and implicitly, and sometimes explicitly, against state's Muslims; party's greatest gains come in areas where Hindu-Muslim rioting occurred in spring; Muslims, who make up only 9 percent of state population, and Hindus stood in separate lines to vote in some areas; map; photos (M)

headline: U.S. Wants List of Allowed Imports to Iraq to Be Tightened
abstract: Bush administration, convinced that Iraq has been using gaps in United Nations monitoring to import goods to use in war, wants list of restricted material to be revised by end of next week (M)

headline: For Ramadan, Jerusalem Is Quiet but Tense
abstract: Jerusalem remains quiet as over 130,000 worshippers gather at site revered by Muslims as Haram al-Sharif and by Jews as Temple Mount for first Friday Prayer of Ramadan; conflicts continue between Palestinians and Israeli army in West Bank and Gaza Strip; Israeli Prime Min Ariel Sharon and his new foreign minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, continue to vie for Likud Party leadership; photo (M)

headline: Israel Frees Arrested Principal of Peace School
abstract: Israeli security forces release Ibrahim Issa, principal of Palestinian school in West Bank, after arresting him on suspicion of harboring terrorists; Islamic Jihad claims responsibility for fatal shooting of Israeli rabbi; Palestinian gunman is killed and another seriously wounded as Israeli forces raid Deir el Balah in Gaza; photo (M)

headline: At California's spas, many paths to nirvana
abstract: SAN FRANCISCO—  At Spa Claremont in Berkeley, a thoroughly modern urban resort in the landmark Claremont Hotel, you get cucumber slices in the ice water, pyramids of rolled white towels, and the smell of eucalyptus in the steam bath. And tapes of rainforest pipes and twinkling celestial harps play all day long.

headline: An Italian Official's Blunt Words Set Off Euro-Mayhem
abstract: Romano Prodi, former Italian prime minister and now president of European Commission, says 1997 Stability and Growth Pact is stupid because of its rigidity and European Union needs more intelligent framework for single currency; remarks are met with varied levels of shock, rage, disbelief and delight; pact, which requires each of 12 governments that have adopted euro to hold its deficit to less than 3 percent of gross national product each year and to balance its budget by 2004, has been violated by Portugal and Germany (M)

headline: From Table to Vineyard and Back to the Table
abstract: DIARYFrom Table to Vineyard And Back to the Table.

headline: Business; Patent Donations Are Novel Corporate Gift
abstract: Research by companies that produces patents neither readily usable by them or easily licensed to other businesses spawns increasing donations of inventions to universities, hospitals or nonprofit institutions; most companies utilize 10 percent to 20 percent of patents their research generates; establishing value of donated patents for purposes of tax deductions presents difficulties; photo; table (M)

headline: At Korean DMZ, South takes lead in mine-clearing
abstract: DORASAN, South Korea:—  While South Korean soldiers cleared away mines in the Demilitarized Zone with the latest heavy-duty equipment, North Koreans not much more than a kilometer away worked with picks and shovels at repairing a bridge blown up in the Korean War.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Bank Earnings Increase
abstract: Thailand's consumer spending boom is helping to increase earnings for the country's major banks, as smaller savings accounts translate into lower interest payments. The Thai Farmers Bank, the state-owned Krung Thai Bank, the Bank of Asia and the Bank of Ayudhya posted higher earnings this week.   Wayne Arnold (NYT)

headline: People
abstract: Arlo Oviatt is named senior vice president and executive creative director at Bernstein-Rein Advertising, assuming duties that had been handled by senior vice president-chief creative director Jeff Bremser, who shifting his focus to strategic duties (S)

headline: Paparazzi Cash In on a Magazine Dogfight
abstract: Battle is under way among celebrity magazines--People, Us Weekly and the new In Touch Weekly--and paparazzi are big beneficiaries; magazines will pay up to $200,000 for photo of, say, Sarah Jessica Parker exiting hospital with new baby, a shot that would have run in supermarket tabloids only five years ago; pictures produce both newsstand sales and bragging rights; photos (M)

headline: Grouse Mountain Journal; On This Chick's Future, A Species Could Depend
abstract: Rare spotted owl, numbering only in thousands in US and verging on extinction in Canada, may be down to only few mating pairs in British Columbia; biologists at Grouse Mountain refuge pin hopes on 17-inch, six-month-old owl being protected in special cage in hopes that it can be released next spring to find mate; photos; map (M)

headline: $3 Million Awarded In Salomon Bias Case
abstract: Salomon Smith Barney is ordered to pay almost $3.2 million to an employee, Tameron Keyes, for sex discrimination in case arising from 1997 settlement that paved way for outside mediation of bias complaints in securities industry (S)

headline: Frustration, Rewarded
abstract: Eli Zabar, owner of Eli's Bread, E A T, and other restaurants and food boutiques in New York City, writes about his personal and business history in The Boss column; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing: Asia
abstract: CHINA: Airline Orders Jets; JAPAN: A Dim Outlook For Electronics;.

headline: Technology Briefing: E-Commerce
abstract: SONY MAY BUY STAKE IN USEN UNIT; BROADCOM BUYS PATENTS FROM UNOVA;.

headline: F.C.C. Chief Says Telecom Isn't Doomed By Cutbacks
abstract: Outlook for flagship telecommunications venders like Lucent Technologies, Nortel Networks and Cisco Systems discussed in light of Federal Communications Commission Chmn Michael K Powell's recent speech urging telecommunications companies to spend more on new equipment to insure their survival; brutal recession in telecommunications industry heightens likelihood that suppliers will be forced into bankruptcy; some analysts just foresee their downsizing; graph of sales of telecommunications equipment (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Kashmir: Three Unveiled Women Are Killed
abstract: Nosen Kousar, 20, and Shahnaaz Akhtqar, 21, are killed in their homes and third woman, Tahira Parveen, 22, is taken away and beheaded in Rajouri district of Kashmir; local officials say women may have been killed for not wearing veils (S)

headline: MediaTalk; A Kennedy Defends His Convicted Cousin
abstract: Atlantic Monthly will publish lengthy article by Robert F Kennedy Jr arguing innocence of Michael C Skakel, cousin convicted of murdering Martha Moxley 27 years ago; photo (M)

headline: But pact falls short of U.S. demands as 8 Saddam palaces are off-limits : UN and Iraq strike deal on inspectors
abstract: WASHINGTON:—  Representatives of the United Nations and of Iraq announced Tuesday that they had agreed on the return to Iraq of UN weapons inspectors, who would be granted full access to all sites — but not to eight presidential palaces and compounds. An advance party could arrive in Baghdad within two weeks.

headline: North Korea Says It Will Bar Fuel Inspectors
abstract: North Korea said today that it would refuse to allow foreign experts into the country to verify that American fuel supplies were being used for peaceful purposes.     On Thursday, North Korea said the 1994 agreement to prevent it from producing nuclear weapons had collapsed. It accused the United States of destroying the pact, known as the Agreed Framework. Under the agreement, experts are allowed to verify that shipments of fuel oil to North Korea are used only for peaceful purposes.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Share Offer Reduced
abstract: China's Citic Securities Co cuts its initial share offer second time, to 1.76 billion yuan ($212 million), after profit fell four-fifths in first 11 months of year (S)

headline: Video on Demand Is Finally Taking Hold
abstract: Cable television industry begins to deliver reliable and economical video-on-demand services; Time Warner Cable announces that films, TV series and special programs will be available to New York City subscribers on demand by end of 2002; major cable providers anticipate large revenues from video-on-demand's individualized programming capability; photos (M)

headline: Solo Journal; The Coffee Shop King, 80, With Ladies in Waiting
abstract: Interview with Sri Sunan Pakubr

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of Sept 29 article concerning hostility between Marriott International and owners of hotels it manages

headline: Leader of Austria's Freedom Party Offers to Step Down
abstract: A day after the far-right Freedom Party took a beating in national elections, Jörg Haider said on Monday that he would resign as governor of the southern state of Carinthia.

headline: World Business Briefing: Europe
abstract: FRANCE: Bank Bidding; GERMANY: Toll Venture Investigation;.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Neon Communications emerges from bankruptcy protection after winning approval for its reorganization plan (S)

headline: Saudis Say Cash to Friend Of Hijackers Was Charity
abstract: Government of Saudi Arabia says wife of Saudi ambassador to Washington gave tens of thousands of dollars in what she believed were charitable gifts to family of Saudi man in San Diego who befriended and assisted two of Sept 11 hijackers; Saudi officials and their American friends say payments from Princess Haifa al-Faisal, wife of Amb Bandar bin Sultan, began four years ago, and they were typical of charitable gifts she provided to Saudis in distress, many of them strangers who asked for help by mail; suggestion that money from Saudi royal family may have been used, if only indirectly, to help hijackers and their friends has created alarm in Riyadh and in Washington (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Wireless Access Is Hot, But Profit Potential Is Tepid  With the Wi-Fi wireless Internet access standard becoming a bandwagon that even big players like AT&T, I.B.M. and Intel are joining, equipment companies big and small are hoping to ride along. But many industry analysts say that it could be hard to make money in Wi-Fi, which is unlikely to represent more than a fraction of the overall telecommunications equipment market for at least several years.     Many early leaders in Wi-Fi are obscure companies. And those that do not sell gear directly to consumers must rely on selling to Wi-Fi service providers that are themselves start-ups. While analysts hesitate to predict that any of the start-ups will survive to become widely recognized brands like Netscape, the resemblance to the Internet craze of the 1990's has been widely noted. [Page C6.]

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Fiat Weighs Options With G.M.
abstract: Italian automobile manufacturer Fiat weighs several options for survival, including but not limited to selling remainder of its auto division to its partner, General Motors; photo (M)

headline: Private Sector; The Four-Digit Lunch: Is Vivendi Worth It?
abstract: Bid of $6,000 wins lunch with Vivendi Universal vice chairman Edgar Bronfman Jr at charity auction to benefit Endeavor, which finds local entrepreneurs in Latin America and guides them as they establish their businesses; photo (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Wal-Mart Plans DVD Rental Services
abstract: Wal-Mart has begun testing mail-order DVD rental service through its Web site Walmart.com; service, which will be made available to customers early next year, costs $18.86 per month for unlimited rentals (S)

headline: The Wall Street Journal does business with its free online rivals, the better to make fun of them.
abstract: Cheeky new advertising campaign by Wall Street Journal Online, one of few news Web sites to charge users for access, mocks its free counterparts as uninformed, simplistic and unreliable; free competing counterparts accept and run these advertisements; photo (M)

headline: Buying Savings Bonds in a Virtual Environment
abstract: DIARY Buying Savings Bonds In a Virtual Environment.

headline: The Scare Factor
abstract: Horror films Ghost Ship and The Ring play theaters this Halloween; most frightening films are released at other times of year; photo; graph of top-grossing horror movies (M)

headline: Positive earnings reflect management, not fresh growth : Tech firms lift profits, but slump lingers on
abstract: Microsoft's revenue rises 26 percent, while LG Electronics turns from a loss to a profit. IBM surpasses expectations, and Nokia's net income triples.

headline: BUSH IS EXPECTED TO SAY IRAQ FAILED TO MEET U.N. TERMS
abstract: Pres Bush is expected to declare that Iraq has violated United Nations resolution requiring it to disclose all its weapons of mass destruction; issues confronting Bush -- particularly question of whether time is right to declare 'material breach,' which could provide what US sees as legal justification for going to war -- are discussed by Bush's senior national security advisers, who refuse to say what options they have decided to present to him; consensus appears to be developing that Iraq's failure so far to explain what happened to its chemical and biological weapons programs after 1998 -- and its contention that all work on nuclear weapons stopped decade ago -- should be characterized as evidence Iraq is engaged in 'not so passive resistance' to full inspection by UN; officials say they do not expect violations will be described by Bush as immediate cause for war, but rather as 'serious matter' and evidence that Iraq is again engaging in hide-and-seek with inspectors (M)

headline: Cobbling Peace in the Home With a Wireless Network
abstract: Recent proliferation of wireless home and office networking equipment simplifies sharing broadband Internet connections among several computers; wireless routers also permit sharing of printers and trading files between networked devices; enabling some available security features protects wireless networks against security breaches to limited degree, but completely avoiding determined computer hackers from invading home networks is not currently possible; drawing (M)

headline: Jeffrey D. Sachs
abstract: BORN Detroit, 1954. SCHOOLS AT COLUMBIA Arts and Sciences, International and Public Affairs, Public Health. PAST POSITIONS Director, Harvard Center for International Development; chairman, Commission on Macroeconomics and Health, World Health Organization. TEACHING THIS ACADEMIC YEAR None.

headline: Private Sector; Augusta National's Road to the Boardroom
abstract: William Johnson, chairman of Augusta National Golf Club, is named director of Stephens Group of Little Rock, Ark, which includes holdings of family of Jackson T Stephens, himself a former chairman of Augusta National; photo (S)

headline: Scholarly Mentor To Bush's Team
abstract: Profile of Martin S Feldstein, influential Harvard economics professor who holds no official government role but has been mentor to many on Pres Bush's economic team; his stature and his vigorous defense of Pres Bush's economic policies discussed; photo; tables of biographical data and of prominent economic figures who were his students at Harvard or worked with him there (M)

headline: E-Commerce Report; Amid the loud disputes over music swapping, Internet CD merchants may be faring worst.
abstract: Internet's CD merchants are being hurt more than any other industry group by free online music swapping; sales by online CD retailers have fallen sharply in first nine months of this year, as file-sharing servies like KaZaA, Morpheus and others have added millions more users (M)

headline: Mechanics for United Airlines Reject Proposal on Concessions
abstract: United Airlines' mechans

headline: Annan Presses Bush to Avoid a Rush to War
abstract: Secretary General Kofi Annan said the U.S. seemed to have a lower threshold for war than the rest of the Security Council.

headline: Co-Chief Resigns at Fiat as the Shake-Up Continues
abstract: Co-Chief Resig

headline: BRISTOL-MEYERS SCHIZOPHRENIA DRUG RECEIVES APPROVAL
abstract: Bristol-Myers Squibb receives federal approval for Abilify, medication for schizophrenia that analysts estimate could generate more than $700 million in annual sales; drug is licensed from Otsuka Pharmaceutical Co (S)

headline: Polls Say Leftist Will Win Brazil's Presidency by Wide Margin
abstract: Second and decisive round in Brazil0

headline: New Economy; In the 'Google economy,' businesses thrive by appearing prominently on the search engine's free listings.
abstract: Google, Web's most popular search engine, has become major source of business for many commercial Web sites, not just those that pay Google to promote their sites -- and are labeled as such -- but for many smaller merchants in specialized niches that turn up in Google's free search results; high Google ranking can be tricky platform on which to build a business because Google regularly shuffles its rankings to reflect changes in its own methods or in Web's link structure and content and routinely slashes rankings of sites that appear to be using tricks to secure more prominent display; drawing (M)

headline: Burnett Plans to Combine Units
abstract: Burnett Plans To Combine Units Leo Burnett Worldwide in Chicago will combine various direct, digital and database marketing units into a single network called iLeo. The reorganization comes a month after the acquisition of the Burnett parent, the Bcom3 Group, by the Publicis Groupe.

headline: World Briefing: Middle East
abstract: BAHRAIN: Women Fail In Bids For Parliament; IRAN: Judges Shut Another Research Group;.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Education Profit For Publisher
abstract: Pearson PLC chief executive Marjorie Scardino says decline in advertising revenue at The Financial Times will be offset by growth in education publishing division, which accounts for more than half of Pearson's overall revenue; photo (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Curry Killer To Be Hanged
abstract: Masumi Hayashi, found guilty of murdering 4 people with arsenic laden curry, is sentenced to death by hanging; 63 others also became ill from her curry, which was sold at summer festival in Wakayama, Japan (S)

headline: E-Commerce Report; E-tailers are putting the multimedia tinsel back on their shopping sites this holiday season.
abstract: Online merchants and manufacturers who sell online are adding multimedia features to their product presentations, something they abandoned two years ago, when they had all they could do keeping sites running and delivering goods on time; operations problems have largely been solved, allowing more time for multimedia dazzle; Nike site illustrates trend; photo (M)

headline: Fire on French Tanker Off Yemen Raises Terrorism Fears
abstract: French supertanker Limburg burns off southeastern coast of Yemen following explosion while heading for oil terminal in Gulf of Aden; cause of blast remains unclear; French diplomats and oil company executives suspect terrorist attack by small boat that approached tanker shortly before explosion; Yemeni officials deny attack; say boat was sent to guide tanker into port; all but one of tanker's 25 crew members are rescued; 12 are hospitalized; US temporarily classifies incident as shipboard accident; says there is no solid evidence that blast was work of terrorists but incident raises fears that terrorists may have attacked one of most vulnerable links in oil-dependent global economy; maps; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Dollar falls to two-month low against yen; settles at 119.52 yen, down from 119.78 previously; graphs (S)

headline: For Prospective Tenants, Cash Is King
abstract: Frisco, Tex, Economic Development Corp is paying companies, especially from neighboring Dallas, to relocate to its Hall Office Park; Hall Financial Group, owned by Craig Hall, is using it own money and planning to build four million square feet of office space in 22 buildings over 15-year period; Dallas Mayor Laura Miller says she will press state legislature in next session to prevent Frisco from paying tenants to leave Dallas; Lt Gov William R Ratliff says such measure would be impossible to enforce, but he will support legislation to prevent towns from directly paying corporate officers who make real estate decisions; map; photo (M)

headline: MEMO PAD
abstract: Boeing Co is looking at new opportunities in retrofitting existing planes to offer more overhead storage space for passengers before Jan 1 when federal law will require all stowed bags to be screened by new explosive-detection machines; GetThere.com survey finds most affordable meeting and conference city is Jacksonville, Fla; says tied for most expensive are San Diego and Los Angeles; Delta Air Lines' standby upgrade purchasing options will be offered domestically on select off-peak flights starting Nov 11; Virgin Atlantic Airways will become first airline to operate nonstop services between London and Port Harcourt, Nigeria, twice weekly, starting in January (Memo Pad column) (M)

headline: Possible Late Rescue for Vanguard Airlines
abstract: Vanguard Airlines chief executive Scott Dickson says bankrupt air carrier is preparing to liquidate its assets even as it continues last-minute negotiations with unidentified potential investment group; Vanguard is tallying up its inventory and consolidating holdings to prepare for liquidation (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: China: Leadership Shuffle Starts
abstract: Communist Party leaders Jia Qinglin (Beijing) and Huang Ju (Shanghai) step down from posts; are expected to get positions in China's central government (S)

headline: Belgrade Accused of Involvement in Arms Sales to Baghdad
abstract: Sale of arms to Pres Saddam Hussein of Iraq hampers Yugoslavia's integration into world community; officials in Yugoslavia and neighboring Bosnia have tried to repair damage since US uncovered evidence that state-owned company in Bosnia's Serb republic was shipping weapons material to Iraq with help from Belgrade; there are many unanswered questions about links between aircraft factory in Bosnia, Yugoslav state trading company and ship seized in Croatian waters found to contain 208 tons of nitrogen-based explosive powder used for artillery and missiles (M)

headline: Federal Reserve Leaves Interest Rates Unchanged
abstract: The Fed's policy makers decided today to leave rates unchanged as it waits for its recent cuts to work their way through the sluggish economy.

headline: A Pad That Recharges With Nubs, Not Wires
abstract: MobileWise offers Wire-Free Electricity Base that looks like large mouse pad with nubs and acts as charger for laptops, handheld organizers and other wireless devices, eliminating need for plug in chargers; nubs are contact points that intersect with conductive patch on back of compatible products or adapter; photo (M)

headline: 2 Key Senate Critics Back Bush Over Iraq
abstract: With Congress pushing toward a vote on whether to authorize military action in Iraq, President Bush gained some support from two of the Senate's most outspoken critics of the administration's policy. John Kerry, Democrat of Massachusetts, and Chuck Hagel, Republican of Nebraska, both prominent Vietnam War veterans, announced for the first time their support for allowing the use of force.    The two senators said they made their decisions after the administration agreed to pursue diplomatic solutions to the crisis and to work with the United Nations in efforts to forestall a possible invasion.

headline: ROCHE ADDS A WARNING TO ITS ACCUTANE LABELS
abstract: Roche Holding A.G. has added warnings about violent behavior in patients taking its Accutane drug, a medicine already reserved for the most severe cases of acne because of its side effects, regulators said. Roche changed the label in June and sent a letter to doctors and pharmacists in September, said Gail Safian, a spokeswoman for the drug maker, which is based in Basel, Switzerland. About five million people in the United States have taken Accutane since 1982. Roche has said that there is no evidence to link Accutane with depression and suicide, but the mother of a teenager who crashed a private plane into a Tampa office building has said that Accutane may have affected her son's behavior and sued the company for $70 million.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Economic Growth
abstract: China's economic growth rose in third quarter to 8.1 percent from 8 percent in second quarter (S)

headline: After 70 Quakes, British Are Unshakable
abstract: Normally stable city of Manchester, Eng, has had 70 mostly minuscule earthquakes in last few weeks, contributing to what geologists are calling harmless 'swarm'; earthquakes are truly tiny, and initial panic has turned to sangfroid; photo (M)

headline: Princess Anne, in Courtly Fashion, Is Convicted in Dog Attack
abstract: Princess Anne plead guilty to charges of losing control of her dog, which then bit two children.

headline: Kmart Encouraged as Sales Fall at a Slower Rate
abstract: Kmart Corp lost $176 million in September as sales continued to decline, but rate of decline slowed considerably as company introduced new products and tried fresh strategies in some stores; says it is too soon to say whether company, which filed for bankruptcy protection in January, is on its way to profitability; president-chief operating officer Julian C Day comments; photo (M)

headline: Kuwait Says a Senior Qaeda Member Has Confessed to Planning 2 Attacks in Yemen
abstract: Kuwait says Mohsen al-Fadhli, Kuwaiti member of Al Qaeda, has confessed to planning attack against French supertanker Limburg off coast of Yemen in October and car bomb attack that was to have been carried out against hotel used by American military officials in Yemeni capital, Sanaa; confession traces network of Qaeda activity between Kuwait, Saudi Arabia and Yemen (M)

headline: As Inflation Creeps Up, Brazilians Grow More Nervous
abstract: Brazilians watch nervously as annual inflation rate creeps back up to double digits again, in large part because real has fallen sharply against dollar this year; much of what Brazil exports is priced globally in dollars, so economy as whole is benefiting from exchange-rate shift; but for consumers, it can be very bad news, felt directly in higher prices for imported good and indirectly in domestic goods because producers can charge higher prices in reals and still be competitive internationally in dollar terms; photo of Luiz Inacio Lua da Silva, who takes office as president on Jan 1 (M)

headline: British Cardinal Apologizes for Ignoring Warnings About a Pedophile Priest
abstract: Cardinal Cormac Murphy-O'Connor, leader of Roman Catholic Church in England and Wales, apologizes for not curbing pedophile priest, Michael Hill but denies turning blind eye to other suspect priests; Hill is sentenced to five years in prison for assaulting children, including two disabled youths (M)

headline: Science or Serendipity? Unlocking the Alchemy of Ceramics
abstract: Composition of ceramics makes them versatile enough to be used in range of items from ordinary tableware to telecommunications equipment; specialty ceramics are used for resonators, filters and other components that store, transfer and sort microwave signals that are basic to wireless communications; fundamental understanding of microwave ceramics will contribute to effort to improve existing materials and develop new ones; photo (M)

headline: Berlin Journal; A Dream Desk and an Alarming Bed
abstract: Germany, land of 4 o'clock rush hour and six-week summer vacation, is atwitter over two new inventions, bed that rolls its drowsy occupant onto floor and desk with built-in inflatable pillow for midday snoozes; drawings (Berlin Journal) (M)

headline: OfficeMax Reports a Profit in 3rd Quarter
abstract: OfficeMax Inc reports $16.5 million third-quarter earnings, in contrast to loss of $25.8 million, a year earlier; sales rise six percent, to $1.26 billion (S)

headline: Treasury Chief Promises New Economic Plan
abstract: Treasury Sec Paul H O'Neill, in Manchester, England, speech to Confederation of British Industry, promises that Pres Bush will reveal in early 2003 his proposals for stimulating economic growth and job creation; cites evidence of American economic strength; photo (M)

headline: Totes Isotoner, readying its first campaign in four years, hopes it rains cats and dogs.
abstract: Totes Isotoner will begin braodcasting two television ads to promote its new line of umbrellas; photo (M)

headline: NOVARTIS'S LEUKEMIA DRUG WINS WIDER FEDERAL APPROVAL
abstract: Novartis wins Food and Drug Administration approval to sell its drug Gleevec as first treatment doctors can use for patients suffering from cancer of blood cells called chronic myeloid leukemia; drug was previously allowed only to treat disease in advanced stages (S)

headline: Releasing Rock Albums Again and Again
abstract: Record companies increasingly release 'deluxe edition' albums by popular artists; rereleases often deliver improved sound quality, extensive liner notes and bonus songs in addition to original album contents; photo (M)

headline: Canberra Journal; Australia Revisits a 'Black and White' Murder Case
abstract: New film and reissue of book by historian Ken Inglis recall celebrated 1958 Australian murder case in which Aboriginal Rupert Max Stuart was sentenced to death for rape and murder of nine-year-old white girl; Stuart's sentence was commuted, partly because of efforts of Catholic priest and of Rohan Rivett, editor of Rupert Murdoch-owned newspaper, who began crusade for Stuart and persuaded Murdoch to take up cause; Inglis says Aboriginals now treat Stuart like royalty; map; photo (M)

headline: U.S. and 2 of Its Allies Warn North Korea on Atomic Arms
abstract: United States, Japan and South Korea issue joint statement, Cabo San Lucas, Mexico, calling on North Korea to dismantle its clandestine nuclear weapons program 'in a prompt and verifiable manner' and warning Kim Jong Il, North Korea's leader, that his 'relations with the international community' hinge on his quick compliance with demand; Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation summit opens in Cabo San Lucas; photo of Pres Bush and Pres Vicente Fox of Mexico (M)

headline: Employee Shifts At Two Agencies
abstract: Harry Corsham is named senior vice president and Microsoft brand director at San Francisco office of McCann-Erickson Advertising, assuming duties for Microsoft that was handled by Michael McLaren; Corsham has been senior vice president and worldwide group account director for Hewlett-Packard account at Publicis & Hal Riney; Frank Schumacher will succeed Corsham; Schumacher will be succeeded by Michele Bogdan; Julie Reiger is named senior vice president and global media director on Hewlett-Packard (S)

headline: Hong Kong Is Under New Scrutiny
abstract: Credit rating agencies, investors and bankers are concerned about Hong Kong government's finances, citing huge budget deficit, stagnant economy and falling consumer prices; budget problems are even prompting talk of increase in territory's flat 15 percent tax on salaries; Standard & Poor's Corp says it might lower Hong Kong's rating for long-term local-currency debts; Financial Sec Antony Leung promises that task force will solicit public's views on fiscal problems; says government is determined and has plans to tackle budget deficit; photo (M)

headline: Britain Taking Back Political Control of Northern Ireland
abstract: Britain announced today that it was taking back political authority over Northern Ireland, saying it saw no other way to preserve a future for the province's elected government.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Ssangyong Posts A Profit
abstract: Ssangyong Motor Co reports third-quarter net income of $55 million in contrast to $7.3 million loss in 2001 corresponding period (S)

headline: Britain Reasserts Ulster Rule, Suspending Elected Assembly
abstract: Britain reasserts political authority over Northern Ireland, saying it sees no other way to preserve future for province's elected government, which shares power between its Catholic minority and Protestant majority; announcement made by Northern Ireland secretary John Reid, who says faltering peace efforts need breathing space and chance to gather strength; suspension follows threat by Protestant union politicians to resign from legislature and to end cooperation with Catholic republican counterparts because of evidence that Irish Republican Army is still engaged in military activity while political arm Sinn Fein is participant in government; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: After Protests, Support For A Hanging
abstract: About 1,000 people demonstrated in support of a death sentence against a pro-reform scholar, Hashem Aghajari, as they left Friday Prayer in Tehran. Mr. Aghajari, who was sentenced last week to be hanged, had been charged with insulting the Prophet Muhammad with his speeches in favor of the separation of religion and state. The demonstration followed five days of protests by students demanding Mr. Aghajari's release.   Nazila Fathi (NYT)

headline: Is Germany Looking Like Japan?
abstract: German economic analysts identify disturbing similarities between nation's economy and Japan's, suggesting that German economic stagnation will continue for many years; major German banks, like Japanese banks, are reporting substantial losses; lack of any new economic proposals from Chancellor Gerhard Schroder and absence of public outcry about economy also mirror longtime quiescence of Japanese; photo; graph (M)

headline: WorldCom Beats Microsoft for Ex-Compaq Chief
abstract: Michael D Capellas agrees to become chairman and chief executive of Worldcom; insiders say Capellas, former Hewlett-Packard president, chose position over lucrative offer from Microsoft to become its president and chief operating officer; photos (M)

headline: Modest Halloween Plans
abstract: National Retail Federation survey finds that average American household plans to spend $44 on Halloween items, $1 less than in 2001 (S)

headline: Bertelsmann Offers Regret For Its Nazi-Era Conduct
abstract: German media conglomerate Bertelsmann expresses regret for its conduct under Nazi regime, and for later efforts to cover it up, after group of scholars issues extensive report documenting company's collaboration; group, independent commission appointed by Bertelsmann in 1998 to investigate discrepancies in company's account of its wartime history, says Bertelsmann also probably profited from Jewish slave labor; findings in report discussed; company chairman Gunter Thielen says he accepts report, but management still stops short, despite expression of regret, of apologizing for its wartime record (M)

headline: Exiled Palestinian Is Sent Out of Cyprus
abstract: exiled palestinian is sen

headline: U.S. Fears Islamic Militancy Could Emerge in Cambodia
abstract: Some US analysts fear that Cambodia could easily become refuge and breeding ground for terrorists, citing its porous borders, corruption, its hide-and-seek legal system and and its disorganized Muslim community; face of Islam in Cambodia is already being changed by immigrants from Bangladesh, Afghanistan, Pakistan, Saudi Arabia and other Muslim countries and the mostly fundamentalist Islamic schools and mosques they are setting up; Cambodian Muslims struggle to redefine themselves after Khmer Rouge years, during which more than half their number may have died; they now make up 5 percent or less of country's population of 12.5 million; photos (M)

headline: Compressed Data; Dueling 8.0's: America Online vs. Microsoft
abstract: Separate celebrations in Manhattan will mark rollout of two new software programs: AOL Time Warner's America Online version 8.0 and Microsoft's MSN Internet service version 8.0 (M)

headline: MEDIA: Gazing Into 2003: The Balance of Media Power Is Poised to Change -- Regulation; F.C.C.'s Chief Seeks To Remove Restraints
abstract: FCC chairman, Michael K Powell, will have big year in 2003, when he will unleash set of proposals to unshackle nation's largest broadcasters and telecommunications conglomerates from restraints that have prevented them from growing; he is armed with broad deregulatory agenda and series of court opinions that have questioned or struck down some of agency's most pivotal and long-lasting rules; photo (M)

headline: Private Sector; A New Pursuit, Perhaps Trivial, For a Veteran of Microsoft
abstract: Former Microsoft executive Brad Chase creates board game, Derivation, in which players answer questions about origins of words, names and phrases; his company is called Entspire Inc; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing: Europe
abstract: THE NETHERLANDS: Profit Up At Klm; LEGAL DISPUTE OVER CEGETEL; SWITZERLAND: Sales Up At NestlÉ;.

headline: IHT Insight: Low birthrates pose challenge for Europe
abstract: COTTBUS, Germany:—  No one is entirely sure why so many women in this quaint, cobblestoned city south of Berlin stopped having babies 10 years ago. But it does not take a degree in sociology to see the effects of the rock-bottom birthrate: Thousands of schoolteachers have been laid off for lack of students. Workers have begun to dismantle, piece by piece, dozens of vacant apartments, part of a plan to demolish 5,000 units over the next decade. And the municipal water system is in need of a costly overhaul because water use is decreasing and stagnant water in pipes is a health hazard.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: BT Reverses Loss
abstract: BT Group returns to profit in its second quarter after reducing debt by $445 million; reports quarterly net income of 315 million British pounds ($494.6 million) in contrast to loss of 1.48 billion British pounds in year-earlier period (S)

headline: As the Web Gets Easier, More Time for Fretting
abstract: Michelle Slatalla Online Shopper column reports online merchants have developed efficient, easily navigable sites, with user-friendly features, just in time for holiday season; says record number of shoppers are expected to spend $8 billion during holiday season; suggests several sites; drawing (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: The Philippines: Brief Parole For Ex-President
abstract: Former Philippine Pres Joseph Estrada is allowed short leave from military hospital detention to visit Mother Ignacia Healing Center to receive holy water treatments for his arthritic knees; Estrada's request for medical treatment in US was denied; is being held on charge of plunder (S)

headline: U.S. Says Chip Imports May Hurt Micron
abstract: International Trade Commission says imports from Hynix Semiconductor Inc and other South Korean chip makers threaten to hurt Micron Technology Inc; Micron complained its South Korean rivals were illegally subsidized by government; final ruling is not expected until middle of 2003 (S)

headline: TXU HALTS EUROPE PROJECTS AS BRITISH OPERATIONS FALTER
abstract: TXU Corp halts European projects and says that third-quarter profit fell more than 25 percent, markedly greater decline than forecast; blames tumbling electricity prices in Great Britain (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Partner For GM Daewoo
abstract: China's state-owned Shanghai Automotive Industry Corp agrees to join General Motors Corp in consortium that it has formed to assume controlling stake in GM Daewoo Auto and Technology; Shanghai Automotive agrees to pay $59.7 million for 10 percent of newly formed company (S)

headline: Czech Senate A Safe Haven For Principal In Media War
abstract: Czech media baron Vladimir Zelezny wins one of 27 vacant Senate seats, gaining immunity from lawsuits and possible criminal charges related to his abrupt rupture with American billionaire Ronald S Lauder; Zelezny's Nova television has huge audience that gives him power to shape political agenda; Lauder, who invested in company, charges Zelezny with siphoning off money for other ventures (M)

headline: Key Suspect in Bali Bombing Is Said to Confess
abstract: The police paraded a defiant looking new suspect before the news media today, and said the man, Imam Samudra, had confessed.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Wall Street Firms Ready To Pay $1 Billion in Fines  The nation's biggest brokerage firms have agreed to pay almost $1 billion in fines to end investigations into whether they issued misleading stock recommendations and handed out hot new shares to curry favor with executives during the stock boom of the 1990's, people involved in the negotiations said.    As part of the settlement, which could be announced today, the firms will pay an additional $500 million over five years to buy stock research from independent analysts and distribute it to investors. [Page A1.]

headline: No Peace in Sight, Israelis Trust in a Wall
abstract: Growing numbers of Israelis in settlements on West Bank are accepting idea that wall or fence is necessary to protect them from further acts of terrorism; from Palestinian side, wall looks like land grab; from Israeli side, wall represents tortured compromise with politics, values and history of Israeli Jews; separation wall is being built to stretch at least 70 miles inside boundary of West Bank near Kibbutz Metzer, site of terrorist attack last month in which two children and three adults were killed; another fence is under construction to envelop Jerusalem; photos; map (M)

headline: Even by Bankruptcy Standards, This One Seems Different
abstract: Financial experts and bankruptcy lawyers say that size and complexity of expected bankruptcy filing by United Airlines suggests that it could take years for airline to emerge from bankruptcy, and then probably as radically smaller one; charts (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Synopsys Settles Cadence Lawsuit
abstract: Synopsis, maker of software for integrated circuit design, will pay $265 million to Cadence Design Systems to settle civil source code trade-secrets lawsuit against Avanti Corp, which was acquired by Synopsis in 2001 (S)

headline: PATHMARK SHARES PLUNGE AFTER WARNING ON EARNINGS
abstract: Pathmark Stores warns that its fiscal fourth-quarter results will be lower than it forecast; stock price plunges 23 percent (S)

headline: EchoStar Agrees to Yield Frequencies to Save a Deal
abstract: EchoStar Communications tentatively agrees to transfer dozens of communications frequencies and three satellites to Cablevision in last-ditch effort to win antitrust officials' approval of its proposed acquisition of DirecTV (M)

headline: World Business Briefing: Europe
abstract: BRITAIN: New Bank Governor; SWEDEN: Saab To Cut Jobs;.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Colt Concerned About Its Debt
abstract: Colt Telecom Group says it will fight bondholder Highberry Ltd's attempt to appoint administrator to run company; Highberry has contended that company will not be able to repay or refinance its $1.86 billion of bonds when they mature from 2005 to 2009; Colt says Highberry's allegations are entirely without foundation (S)

headline: Hain to Buy Imagine, a Maker of Organic Foods
abstract: Health food maker Hain Celestial Group buys organic food company Imagine Foods for $52 million in cash and stock and $1.5 million in assumed debt (M)

headline: People
abstract: Pete Charlton is

headline: Powell's Point: The Need for a Much Stronger Resolution
abstract: Excerpt from Sec Colin Powell's remarks on need for much stronger UN resolution on inspecting Iraqi weapons programs (M)

headline: NORTH KOREA SAYS IT PLANS TO EXPEL NUCLEAR MONITORS
abstract: North Korea, citing suspension of US-brokered deal to build two nuclear reactors and US Pres George Bush's designation of country as part of 'axis of evil,' announces it will expel all international nuclear inspectors and restart nuclear fuel reprocessing laboratory; outside experts fear laboratory could supply weapons-grade plutonium; top Bush administration officials, emphasizing that US is not considering military action, urge North Korea to reverse course; UN International Atomic Energy Agency says three inspectors will stay put and demands that North Korea restore cameras and seals on four facilities shut down under 1994 agreement; photo; diagram (M)

headline: Afghan Official Says U.S. Strike Killed Civilian
abstract: Afghan civilian reportedly is killed and several others are injured in US airstrike on feuding factions in Shindand area; cease-fire is declared and government delegation reportedly gains agreement from both sides to pull back (M)

headline: The Troubles in Ulster Shift From Street to the Assembly
abstract: Residents of Belfast, Northern Ireland, express frustration rather than fear over latest setback in peace process, namely, shutdown of Northern Ireland Assembly intended to parcel power equally between province's Protestant majority and its Roman Catholic minority; voice real regret that experiment in local government is coming to halt, but few argue that progress will be reversed or that organized violence of three decades leading up to peace agreement will return; Britain will declare Assembly suspended on October 14, after Protestant members announced plans to resign posts to protest Irish Republican Army's continuing activities while clandestine guerrilla group's political wing Sinn Fein remains participant in government; photo (M)

headline: REGIONAL MARKET -- Newark; Prime Office Space Heading to Market
abstract: Vacany rate for most desirable class of office space in downtown Newark has remained low in recent months, but number of large spaces are to be vacated over next year; brokers representing owners of space are optimistic, saying that amount of interest in soon-to-be-vacated offices is high, especially among small and midsize users; among companies planning to vacate are Verizon, Public Service Enterprise Group and Prudential Insurance; leasing has been brisk in many parts of city, including at Gateway Center buildings; map; photo (M)

headline: Crime: Rising Threat in Many Areas
abstract: Exceprts from warnings to travelers issued on State Department Web site on crime in various countries, including Alabania, Brazil, Colombia, France, Haiti, Jamaica, Mexico, Morocco, Poland and Zimbabwe; drawing (M)

headline: Series of Bombings Shake Soweto, Killing One
abstract: Series of bombs shake sprawling black community of Soweto in South Africa, killing one person and wounding another; police suspect bombings are coordinated strike by white extremists; if so, string of nine explosions would be first attack by radical whites since apartheid ended in 1994; at least 15 white men have been arrested this year in crackdown on right-wing extremists plotting overthrow of government; police have uncovered thousands of rounds of ammunition, grenades and bombs which they believe are part of one such plot; Pres Thabo Mbeki says country's people, black and white, are united against such terror; photo (M)

headline: In Telecom, Optimism On Overseas Companies
abstract: Interview with T Rowe Price Media and Telecommunications fund portfolio manager Robert N Gensler on telecommunications industry's prospects; investors have returned to buying industry stocks and sector is strengthening; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Asks Enron for Details On Dealings Involving Iran
