abstract: Treasury Department directs Enron Corp to provide information about deals company did in late 1990's involving products that originated in Iran; such dealings are generally barred under Federal rules, but Enron was granted licenses by department to deal in Iranian products that included tanker shipments of benzene; department, in letters to Enron on Oct 2, instructed company to provide ecords by Nov 8, of 'all transactions engaged in' under licenses; department in February 1998 approved license that allowed Enron to purchase Iranian benzene from Voest-Alpine Intertrading, Austrian company that had entered into contracts to sell benzene to Iran; license granted to Enron allowed company to participate in 'string transactions'--commodity transactions involving multiple parties which included one of parties delivering product that originated in Iran to satisfy its obligations under deal (M)

headline: It's a Site for the Truly Geeky, And It Even Makes a Few Bucks
abstract: Slashdot.org, online publication with millions of dedicated readers, survives and thrives while print publications of dot-com bubble falter; Ann Arbor, Michigan, venture combines rich view of technology with off-kilter wit under slogan 'News for nerds. Stuff that matters'; photos (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Vivendi Universal Faces Formal S.E.C. Investigation  Vivendi Universal said that an informal inquiry by the Securities and Exchange Commission had become a formal investigation. Vivendi declined to provide details but said that it would cooperate with the S.E.C. inquiry as well as one by the United States attorney for the Southern District of New York.    The investigations in the United States come atop similar inquiries in France, where officials are looking into the timeliness and accuracy with which Vivendi's former chief executive disclosed information to investors. The American investigations are also thought to be focusing on financial disclosures. [Page C6.]

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   4.75   4.75   5.50       Discount rate   1.25   1.25   2.00       Federal funds   1.75   1.76   2.42       3-month T-bills   1.57   1.53   2.14       6-month T-bills   1.52   1.47   2.11       10-yr. T-infl.   2.20   2.18   3.10       10-yr. T-note   3.67   3.68   4.50       30-yr. T-bond   4.71   4.74   5.32       Telephone bd.   6.42   6.38   7.50       Municipal bds.   4.68   4.67   5.20          (Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Telerate; The Bond Buyer)

headline: DELPHI PLANS TO LAY OFF 750 WORKERS AT OHIO PLANTS
abstract: Auto parts maker Delphi Corp plans to lay off as many as 750 hourly workers at three Ohio factories (S)

headline: Microsoft Plans to Introduce Smarter 'Personal Objects'
abstract: Microsoft plans new category of products called 'smart personal object,' including travel alarm clocks and wristwatches, that receive text messages of weather reports, traffic information, sports scores and family messages; National Semiconductor is producing computer chip sets for such devices, and Microsoft is beginning to work with consumer electronics companies, appliance makers and others as partners to produce technology-enhanced devices; Bill Gates, Microsoft chairman, will make announcement in his annual speech opening Comdex trade show in Las Vegas (M)

headline: In a New South Africa, an Old Tune Lingers
abstract: Radio Pretoria remains voice of South Africa's minority Afrikaners, who oppose shift to multiracial democracy and still cling to dream of establishing independent whites-only homeland within borders of South Africa; broadcasts in Afrikaans language, steadfastly opposing country's new multiracial identity; may be forced to shut down because of refusal to hire blacks in violation of constitution, which outlaws racial discrimination; photos (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: TOKHEIM CORP., Fort Wayne, Ind., a maker of pay-at-the-pump terminals for gas stations, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection for the second time since 2000.

headline: Grumbles Grow Louder in Quiet Rural Britain
abstract: Britons in quiet rural places like Chipping Norton are increasingly angry at how government, particularly Prime Min Tony Blair, seems so urbanized as to be wholly indifferent to their concerns; huge march in London of more than 400,000 people, while centering on future of fox hunting, also reflected complaints about farming policy, closing of local schools, railroad stations and post offices, and handling of foot-and-mouth crisis that devastated countryside; march gave focus to country dwellers' perception that traditional way of life is being swept away in relentless tide of urban-centered politics, onslaught that threatens green and pleasant ways that define Britain; photos; map (M)

headline: U.S. PILOTS IN GULF USE SOUTHERN IRAQ FOR PRACTICE RUNS
abstract: Navy warplanes patroling no-flight zone in southern Iraq are conducting mock bombing runs against airfields, towers and other military sites, acquainting themselves with targets they may be called on to strike as Bush administration prepares for possible military campaign to topple Saddam Hussein; are operating from carrier Abraham Lincoln, sidestepping possible objections from Persian Gulf nations; more carriers are expected; map; photos (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Trustee Appoints Members Of United Creditors' Group  A federal trustee has appointed 13 members to the creditors' committee in the United Airlines bankruptcy case, including a representative from each of the airline's three main unions.    Some industry experts said that the strong presence of the unions could lead to tension as United tries to restructure because they might look out for work force-related interests first rather than the interests of the creditors. Union officials, though, said they were committed to helping the airline emerge from Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. [Page C2.]

headline: 3 Big Advertisers Shift Their Accounts
abstract: Saab Cars USA names Baltimore office of Brann Worldwide, part of Arnold Partners Worldwide division of Havas, to handle it direct marketing; spending estimated at $10 million to $15 million; account had been handled by Martin Agency; 7-Eleven names Tracy Locke Partnership to handle its ad account, which had been handled by GSD&M; billings estimated at $30 million; Petsmart ends its relationship with Doner; billings estimated at $20 million; will work with various agencies (M)

headline: Korea's Real Rage for Virtual Games
abstract: Young South Koreans are addicted to virtual reality games on their high-speed computers; photos (M)

headline: AT&T Unit Hires Officer
abstract: AT&T Corp unit AT&T Latin America Corp names Lawrence Young as chief financial officer while it weighs filing for bankruptcy protection; he replaces Nelson Murphy, who will leave company (S)

headline: 3 Japanese Companies Agree to Combine
abstract: Japanese advertising agencies Hakuhodo, Daiko Advertising and Yomiko Advertising agree in principle to merge late in 2003 (S)

headline: Technology Briefing: Hardware
abstract: BROCADE TO BUY RHAPSODY NETWORKS FOR ABOUT $175 MILLION; COMPUTER SCIENCES PROFIT RISES AS COSTS ARE CUT;.

headline: 2 Top Executives at Gemstar Resign After Pressure by Murdoch
abstract: Gemstar-TV Guide International chief executive Henry C Yuen and chief financial officer Elsie M Leung will resign; decision represents victory for Rupert Murdoch's News Corp, which is Gemstar's biggest shareholder, with stake of about 43 percent; News Corp has been trying to oust Yuen and Leung; Gemstar will pay Yuen about $22 million and Leung about $7 million to essentially terminate their employment contracts; two executives will exchange total of roughly 20 million stock options for about 8 million restricted shares and about 9 million new options; Yuen will remain company's nonexecutive chairman; Leung will remain director through at least next year; Yuen is to be succeeded as chief executive by by Jeff Shell, former News Corp executive; Leung will be succeeded on interim basis as chief financial officer by Paul Haggerty, currently News Corp's executive vice president; Yuen has agreed to give company all of many interactive television patents he holds personally, and to give Gemstar right to acquire all television-related inventions he may develop over next seven years (M)

headline: Chechen Missile Downs Russian Helicopter Over Its Base
abstract: MOSCOW, Oct. 29 — A Russian military helicopter was shot down today as it prepared to land at the main Russian military base in Chechnya, killing the three crew members and one passenger.

headline: Sharon Says He Is Ready for Early Elections Over Budget
abstract: Israeli Prime Min Ariel Sharon, facing stiff challenge from main coalition partner over financing for Jewish settlements, says he is ready for early elections if his government unravels; Labor Party led by Defense Min Benjamin Ben-Eliezer, has threatened to vote against proposed 2003 budget if funds are not shifted from settlements to social needs; Sharon has warned vote would result in dismissal of party ministers from cabinet, forcxing early elections; photos (M)

headline: Sentence of 15 to 25 Years Sought for Serb War Criminal
abstract: International war crimes prosecutors seek sentence of 15 to 25 years in jail for Biljana Plavsic, only senior Serbian leader who has confessed to grave war crimes in Bosnia; prosecutor Carla Del Ponte says that without guilty plea she would have sought life in prison for 72-year-old Plavsic (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: I.B.M. To Acquire Tarian Software
abstract: IBM agrees to buy closely held Tarian Software to add programs that maintain personnel records for businesses; graph (M)

headline: Revving Up Four Engines, HotBot Re-enters the Race
abstract: Terra Lycos, parent company of search engine HotBot, introduces new version with more speed and flexibility; photo (M)

headline: Asia Communications Deal
abstract: Singapore Technologies Telemedia, which is controlled by Singapore government, wins auction to buy Indonesian government's 42 percent stake in overseas call operator Indonesia Satellite for $631 million (S)

headline: Israeli Rockets Kill Palestinian Bomb Maker in Gaza
abstract: Five Israeli helicopters destroyed a building in Gaza City today, killing a militant whom was later identified as the inventor of a bomb used against Israeli tanks.

headline: A Slugger Named Godzilla Perfects His Endorsement Game
abstract: A Slugger Named Godzilla Perfects His Endorsement Game.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Nintendo Profit Plunges
abstract: Nintendo Co's fiscal first-half profit is almost halved because of declining sales of its Game Boy Advance hand-held game player and foreign currency losses (S)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Cuba: Europeans Honor Dissident
abstract: European Parliament awards Sakharov Prize for Freedom of Thought to Cuban, Oswaldo Paya, dissident who leads civic movement seeking political change (S)

headline: Bush More Hopeful for Diplomacy With Korea Than Iraq
abstract: President Bush expressed deep concern over Iraq today and said he believed the confrontation with North Korea could be resolved without bloodshed.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Apparel Profit Up
abstract: Sporting-goods maker Adidas-Salomon reports 15-percent third-quarter profit increase, to $131 million; sees likelihood of faster profit growth in 2003; photo (S)

headline: 2 Forecasts Should Project a Better Year
abstract: Two forecasters are expected today to offer brighter predictions for advertising spending in 2003.

headline: Want Bills By Snail Mail? It Might Cost You Money
abstract: Some companies, in move to cut administrative costs and save on paper and postage, are billing customers few extra dollars per month for paper statements; leading charge are telecommunications companies like Primus and MetroPCS; some lenders and insurance providers like State Farm Insurance and USAA, are charging few customers for monthly paper statements; cedit card issuers like American Express are adding paper fees to merchant accounts, and online services that initially mailed statement, like NetBank and Ameritrade, online brokerage firm, have begun charging for them, setting standard for some new businesses that want to do same; these companies say consumers should be ready and even eager to go paperless because Internet transactions have become more secure, not to mention more familiar and accessible; some consumers argue that charging for paper bills punishes people who are not comfortable handling their finances online; photo (M)

headline: Full Speed Ahead On F.D.A. Approvals
abstract: Paul Feiner letter responds to Sept 29 article concerning Food and Drug Administration regulation of vaccines that could protect citizens from effects of bioterrorism

headline: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Mixed News On High-Technology Jobs
abstract: American Electronics Association report shows high-tech employment dropped by 450,000 jobs, or 8 percent, from peak in February and March 2001 to June 2002 (S)

headline: Protesting the Big Brother Lens, Little Brother Turns an Eye Blind
abstract: Civil liberties activists do battle with video surveillance systems that have proliferated since Sept 11; among them are Michael Naimark, who found that he could blind cameras with aid of $1 laser pointer, and Surveillance Camera Players in New York, which has placed hand-drawn maps of video camera locations on Internet and stages brief politically inspired performances in front of cameras; their fears about Big Brother are not universally shared; others argue that Internet camera is step toward global village or that cameras will increase transparency in modern society without encroaching on traditional civil liberties; photos (M)

headline: Ex-Finance Official Of Agency Is Indicted
abstract: Former chief financial officer at RSCG Worldwide, Dominador S Ponsades Jr, is charged with embezzling at least $1 million from agency (S)

headline: 'Jesus' Inscription on Stone May Be Earliest Ever Found
abstract: Inscription in stone found in or near Jerusalem and written in Aramaic language and script of 2,000 years ago bears words 'James, son of Joseph, brother of Jesus'; Dr Andre Lemaire of Sorbonne says this could be earliest artifact ever found relating to historical Jesus; his analysis of inscription is published in magazine Biblical Archaeology Review; other scholars react with caution, saying it will probably be impossible to confirm definite link between inscription and any of central figures in founding of Christianity; also warn that fraud cannot be ruled out, although investigation by Geological Survey of Israel has found no evidence of modern pigments, scratches by modern cutting tools or other signs of tampering; photos (M)

headline: The new leader of I.B.M. explains his strategic course.
abstract: IBM chief executive Samuel J Palmisano introduces marketing campaign for what it calls 'on-demand computing' developed by Ogilvy & Mather; new campaign, which will account for most of its $500 million-a-year advertising budget, pokes fun at fantastic gadgets; photo (M)

headline: Inflation Rate Shows Decline in Poland
abstract: Poland's annual inflation rate cooled off in October on reduced liquor prices and lagging consumer demand.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Phone Concerns Fined
abstract: Dutch antitrust regulators fine five mobile phone companies total of 88 million euros ($92 million) for colluding to reduce handset subsidies to retailers, which led to higher consumer prices (S)

headline: The Big Get the Best of the Corporate Discounts at Hotels
abstract: Substantial discounts are available to business travelers who are part of high-volume corporate contracts negotiated with preferred hotel chains by big companies; individual transient business travelers and those who book accomodations on Web sites pay higher prices; photo (M)

headline: Simon & Schuster Buying Canada Company
abstract: Simon & Schuster agrees to buy Distican, which has been exclusive distributor of its books and audio products in Canada (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: EURO GAINS. The euro rose against the dollar after grim durable goods data put pressure on an American currency already weighed down by worries of war. In New York, the euro settled at $1.0300, up from $1.0263 on Monday.

headline: Preliminary Investigation Indicates Oil Tanker Was Attacked
abstract: French government says explosion that crippled French supertanker in Yemen on Oct 6 was most likely caused by terrorist attack; says further investigation is necessary to verify preliminary conclusion reached by team of French, American and Yemeni technical experts who examined hole in side of tanker and decided that damage was caused by external blast that drove hole inward; Yemen was site of deadly attack on American destroyer Cole two years ago that killed 17 sailors; that attack was carried out with boat filled with explosives, and was blamed on Al Qaeda; photo (M)

headline: Men, Women and Weblogs
abstract: Joe W Vogel letter on Nov 28 article about weblogs disputes assertion that more bloggers are men than women; offers www.livejournal.com as example, where 63.9 percent of users are women

headline: Novartis Broadens Ties to 2 Agencies
abstract: Novartis AG broadens ties to two advertising agencies, Deutsch and Grey Worldwide; combined spending totals $220 million to $240 million (S)

headline: Iraqi General Praises U.N. Arms Teams
abstract: Major Gen Hussam Muhammad Amin, named by Iraq to work with United Nations weapons inspectors, praises their 'professionalism' in first two weeks of surprise searches across Iraq; holds if inspectors continue to resist what he characterizes as American and British pressure, it 'will be hard to be pessimistic' about chances of concluding inspections and avoiding war; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Auto Sales Outlook
abstract: Toyota Motor expects group sales to rise 5 percent in 2003, helped by growth overseas, to 5.79 million cars; photo (S)

headline: Ex-Compaq Chief Quits Hewlett After 6 Months
abstract: Michael D Capellas resigns as president of Hewlett-Packard, raising doubts about whether its recent merger with Compaq has run into trouble; was seen as ideal partner to Hewlett chief executive, Carleton S Fiorina; photo (M)

headline: Playing Pick 3 With Merrill Lynch
abstract: DIARY Playing Pick 3 With Merrill Lynch.

headline: Bids for Houghton Fall Short of Goal
abstract: All bids received by Vivendi Universal for its Houghton Mifflin publishing subsidiary fall short of Vivendi's $1.7 billion minimum price (S)

headline: Retired Partner at Andersen Sues Three Rival Firms
abstract: Gilbert L Viets, retired partner of Arthur Andersen who lost $2.2 million in benefits when firm collapsed, sues three other accounting firms, Deloitte & Touche, Ernst & Young and KPMG, claiming that they unjustly enriched themselves at expense of about 1,000 retired Andersen partners and their spouses (M)

headline: E-Commerce Report; Online Sales Are Up for Holiday, But the Question Is Just How Much
abstract: Online retailers are having their best year ever, but exactly how much better is subject to dispute; comScore puts online sales since Nov 1 at $8.4 billion as of Dec 20, 19 percent jump from comparable period of 2001, but not 30 percent increase it predicted just a few weeks ago; BizRate, however, says sales figure as of Dec 20 was $11.3 billion, 40 percent increase from 2001; analysts differ on whether to go with conservative or more bullish estimates; online merchants seem to be doing good job of managing investories and filling orders; sales at brick-and-mortar retail stores are dominated by clothes, toys and books, music and movies, nearly reverse order of online sales; photo (M)

headline: NEC Machine Again Leads Speed Ranks
abstract: Twice-yearly ranking of world's fastest computers will again be dominated by Earth Simulator, made by NEC Corp of Japan; analysts perceive United States disproportionate spending on computers primarily designed for weapons research as cause of US losing prize for speed it held for many years; Japanese machine operates at 35.8 teraflops, or trillion mathematical calculations per second; Cray Inc, which once dominated supercomputing but has no machine currently among top ten, announced plans for new design that could potentially reach 52.4 teraflops (M)

headline: People and Accounts of Note
abstract: Michael Allen, lead strategist at Rare Method Interactive Studios, Calgary, Alberta, was named to the new post of vice president for strategy. Rare Method is part of Rare Method Capital Corporation.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: New School Where Quake Killed Pupils
abstract: New school opens in Italian village of San Guiliano di Puglia one month after earthquake leveled schoolhouse killing 27 students; school safety issues throughout Italy continue to be debated (S)

headline: Taubman Shopping Mall Empire Again Rejects a Takeover Bid
abstract: A Alfred Taubman's shopping mall empire Taubman Centers again rejects hostile $1.5 billion takeover bid from Simon Property Group (M)

headline: World Business Briefing: Asia
abstract: JAPAN: Machinery Orders Fall; CHINA: Stake In Insurer Bought;.

headline: World Business Briefing: Asia
abstract: TAIWAN: Airline Investment; JAPAN: Car Venture Approved; JAPAN: Economic Risks Rise; SOUTH KOREA: Bank Profit Rises; SOUTH KOREA: Steady Economic Growth;.

headline: Executive Needs Job, Willing to Relocate
abstract: DIARYExecutive Needs Job, Willing to Relocate.

headline: Deal Fizzles for Czech Telephone Company
abstract: Planned sale of Czech government's controlling stake in main telephone company Cesky Telecom apparently falls apart, leaving huge hole in state budget; sale to group of investors led by Deutsche Bank for 1.82 billion euros ($1.8 billion) was announced on Aug 8; sale's failure costs job of company's chief executive Premysl Klima, who is dimissed from board; buyers wanted more of company than just state's 51 percent stake; group also wanted to acquire 27 percent stake held by TelSource, joint venture that is running company; group is unable to agree on price with partners in TelSource venture, Royal KPN of Netherlands and Swisscom of Switzerland; photo (M)

headline: Bumpy Market Has Many Delaying Retirement, Survey Finds
abstract: Among workers 50 to 70 years old who said they lost money in the stock market in the last two years, about one in five said they had postponed retirement because of the losses, according to a survey released today.    The stock market decline has had a ''sobering effect'' on older Americans, according to the study released by AARP, formerly known as the American Association of Retired Persons, with three-quarters of those who lost money in the market saying that their losses had altered their standard of living, work plans or expectations about retirement.

headline: Handbag Maker Takes Aim at Knockoffs
abstract: Barbara Kolsun, former chairwoman of board of International Anticounterfeiting Coalition, is joining Kate Spade, handbag company, as senior vice president and general counsel; Kolsun says for every legitimate Kate Spade bag sold there is at least one counterfeit sold; says Ebay sell hundreds of phony bags as do countless street vendors; photo (M)

headline: Learn How to Win the Battle In the Conference Room
abstract: Computer games have taught players how to slay dragons, build empires and blow up tanks, but they can also be used to teach more mundane skills. Virtual Leader, corporate training software from SimuLearn, is designed to teach managers how to run a business meeting.     Players participate in a series of meetings with peers, superiors and subordinates, with the goal of resolving a crisis or dealing with a problem. You can suggest solutions (chosen from a list) or elicit ideas from others. You must also deal with the constant threat of everyone's agreeing to end the meeting and go to lunch before anything gets done.

headline: United Assures Fliers Service Won't Decline; Skeptics Look Ahead
abstract: United Airlines, on its first day of operating under bankruptcy protection, moves swiftly to assure passengers that they will see no changes in service; airline analysts say it is only matter of time before travelers notice fewer flights, smaller planes and elimination of some routes (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Malaysia: U.S. To Clear Visa Backlog
abstract: US Embassy in Malaysia plans to grant hundreds of visa requests held up by increased security; almost all of 150 student visas delayed are expected to be approved; Malaysia, a predominately Muslim country, has complained of delays and added scrutiny of its citizens in spite of commitment to US campaign against terror (S)

headline: Expedia Drops Northwest Air In Fee Dispute
abstract: Expedia, biggest Internet travel agency, stops selling tickets on Northwest Airlines after contract negotiations between companies break down; refuses Northwest's demand for it to lower its fees substantially to match those charged by Orbitz, online travel agency owned by Northwest and four other airlines (M)

headline: Israeli Soldiers Fire on Crowd, Killing Boy
abstract: It was one of several clashes today in Nablus, in which a reported seven people were injured by fire from Israeli tanks and guns.

headline: World Briefing: Africa
abstract: SOMALIA: New Effort To End Conflict; CONGO: Power-Sharing Under Review:;.

headline: Can It Clock A Nerf Ball?
abstract: MANY parents want to measure the pace of their future Olympic skier -- or the speed of their future big-league pitcher's fastball. A new hand-held radar gun may be their answer.     Bushnell, a privately held company in Overland Park, Kan., that made its mark in binoculars and telescopes, introduced the radar gun, called the Speedster, in January with a suggested retail price of $319 -- though the company says the average sale price is $199. A higher-end radar gun that might be used by Major League Baseball teams, for example, can cost as much as $1,600.

headline: Cigna to Feel Major Loss In Customers
abstract: Cigna Corp says it will lose at least 530,000 members this year and surrender its longstanding position as nation's third-largest health insurer; will cover fewer than 12.7 million people by January, well behind UnitedHealth Group, which has 16.2 million, and Aetna, with 14.4 million; will also trail Wellpoint Health Networks, which recently grew to 13.1 million members; Cigna hairman-chief executive H Edward Hanway and chief financial officer James Stewart comment (M)

headline: Lower Profits at 2 Big Firms In a Year of Weak Markets
abstract: Earnings of largest Wall Street firms continue to suffer; Morgan Stanley reports fourth-quarter net earnings are down 16 percent from 2001 period; profit for all of 2002 is down 13 percent; Goldman Sachs Group reports earnings rose 2 percent in fourth quarter from 2001 period; full-year earnings fell 6 percent; Lehman Brothers, midlevel firm, reports net earnings for year fell 18 percent; fourth-quarter earnings are up 87 percent (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Sweden: Appliance Maker Cuts Jobs
abstract: World's biggest appliance maker Electrolux will lay off 5,091 workers, or 6.3 percent of its Swedish work force, in reaction to faltering demand for its products; graph of share price (S)

headline: World Business Briefing: Europe
abstract: ENERGY SUPPLIER HALTS INTEREST PAYMENTS; FRANCE: Caterer'S Profit Rises; THE NETHERLANDS: A Telecom Profit; BELGIUM: Bid For Brewer; SWITZERLAND: Bourse Questions Bank; RUSSIA: Oil Stake Sold; SWEDEN: Interest Rate Cut;.

headline: U.S. Strategy in Colombia Connects Drugs and Terror
abstract: Bush administration says war on drugs in Colombia is rapidly being subsumed in campaign against terror as US uses tactics of drug war to help new government of Pres Alvaro Uribe fight both right-wing paramilitaries and Marxist guerrillas whose 38-year conflict is fueled by drug money; Atty Gen John Ashcroft says indictments of three leaders of Marxist forces are part of campaign; photos (M)

headline: Inquiries May Delay Work of Panel
abstract: Inquiries into selection of William H Webster as chairman of new accounting oversight board will cause more scrutiny of board's other four members and may delay group's work; trying to meet deadlines set by Congress for board's composition and functioning proves difficult as procedural delays, hidden information concerning candidates for regulatory body and issues of partisanship stir up trouble (M)

headline: Irish Referendum Today Looms Large in the Future of Europe
abstract: Irish voters are set to vote on referendum on whether to ratify Treaty of Nice and admit 10 new nations to European Union; 14 other member of EU have already approved Treaty of Nice, but Irish Constitution requires referendum; Irish voters rejected treaty once, and another rejection could set back expansion of EU for months or years; latest poll indicates that 'yes' vote is clearly ahead; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing: Africa
abstract: SUDAN: Plea For Aid;.

headline: S.E.C. Inquiry On Homestore Has Expanded To Cendant
abstract: SEC reportedly investigates real estate and travel company Cendant's dealings with online real estate company Homestore.com, which has acknowledged overstating revenue in first nine months of 2001 by more than 30 percent; this inquiry helps propel separate investigation into accounting at AOL Time Warner, which has advertising deals with Homestore and has acknowledged its own, smaller revenue overstatements; three former Homestore executive have reportedly told investigators that company counted increasingly on bogus deals with both Cendant and AOL Time Warner to help it meet quarterly revenue projections; investigator have reportedly asked Homestore executives about possible involvement by Robert W Pittman, former AOL Time Warner chief operating officer and former executive at Cendant, on whose board he still sits (M)

headline: Wiz Chain Picks The Wolf Group
abstract: Nobody Beats the Wiz names New York office of Wolf Group to handle creative duties on its account; spending estimated at $30 million to $40 million (S)

headline: MEMO PAD
abstract: System glitch at First Horizon Merchant Services causes overbilling of guests who paid with credit cards at Holiday Inn or Crowne Plaza hotels, owned by Six Continents Hotels (S)

headline: Jordan Leaves a Board
abstract: Oakley Inc, maker of sunglasses, says basketball star Michael Jordan has resigned from its board but will continue endorsing its glasses under agreement that expires in 2005 (S)

headline: ENDO WILL NOT SEEK APPROVAL FOR DRUG THAT FAILED TESTS
abstract: Endo Pharmaceuticals Holdings says it will probably not seek Food and Drug Administration approval for experimental drug MorphiDex after drug fails to show significant benefit in studies (S)

headline: Citigroup Tries To Move On; Plans a Charge Of $1.5 Billion
abstract: Citigroup will take $1.5 billion after-tax charge in fourth quarter to cover expected losses; part of charge is intended to cover Citi's share of settlement regarding conflicts of interest related to research analysts; photo of Sanford Weill, chairman, and Charles O Prince, head of Citi's investment-banking division (M)

headline: Cordiant Gives 3 Executives New Jobs
abstract: The Cordiant Communications Group in London has named three executives to senior management posts at the Bates Group, a division being formed as part of a reorganization of its traditional and nontraditional advertising operations.    Steve Girgenti, 57, chief executive at Healthworld Worldwide, will also serve as chief executive for the Americas at the Bates Group. Toby Hoare, 42, chief executive for Bates Europe, will also serve as chief executive for the European operations of the Bates Group. Ian Smith, 45, chief executive for the Bates Worldwide operations in the Asian-Pacific region, will also serve as chief executive for the Bates Group in Asia.

headline: Praise and Blame for Prize to Carter, and Message to Bush
abstract: Norwegian Nobel committee assures itself extra publicity and sympathetic headlines across Europe when, in awarding 2002 Nobel Peace Prize to Jimmy Carter, it suggests that it is also sending political message criticizing Bush administration's policy toward Iraq; Gunnar Berge, chmn of five-member committee, tells reporters that it 'must be seen as criticism of the line the current US administration has taken on Iraq;' two other committee members challenge this interpretation, contending 'there is nothing about that in the citation'; Berge photo (M)

headline: Text of Statements by F.C.C. Commissioners
abstract: The following is the text of statements by Michael K. Powell, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, as well as the three commissioners, Kathleen Q. Abernathy, Michael J. Copps and Kevin J. Martin. This text was taken from the commission's web site, fcc.gov.

headline: Finding the Hydrogen For Hydrogen-Powered Cars
abstract: Jim Horton letter comments on Dec 15 article on hydrogen-powered vehicles

headline: A New Family Is Destroyed Before It Can Reach America
abstract: Dead after Chechen terrorist attack on Moscow theater and military raid to free hostages include Sandy A Booker, electrician from Oklahoma, and 13-year-old daughter of his Kazakh fiancee Svetlana Gubareva (M)

headline: Mutual Funds Report; This Time, Pain for the Record Books
abstract: Third-quarter performance of vast majority of domestic equity mutual funds is most dismal since third quarter of 1981; some individuals question wisdom of investing in financial asssets at all; photo (M)

headline: MICROSOFT INTRODUCES XBOX LIVE FOR ONLINE PLAY
abstract: Microsoft introduces Xbox Live, online component to its video game platform; product allows users to play games against each other over Internet (S)

headline: Indian Government Announces Pullback From Pakistan Border
abstract: Indian government announces it would pull back troops from its border with Pakistan, its most substantial step to reduce military buildup begun 10 months ago that helped bring two nations to brink of war; Defense Min George Ferdandes says armed forces achieved their objective, including successful conduct of elections in Jammu and Kashmir; Pakistan-backed militants had vowed to disrupt them and did kill hundreds of people, but India earned international credit for largely fair election; Fernandes says pullback will not affect troops stationed along Line of Control in Kashmir (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Fed Officials Say Policy Is Not Limited by Low Rates  The Federal Reserve may have lowered interest rates to the once unimaginable level of 1.25 percent, but officials insist they can still flood the country with money if they need to. ''The U.S. government has a technology, called a printing press -- or, today, its electronic equivalent -- that allows it to produce as many U.S. dollars as it wishes at essentially no cost,'' Ben S. Bernanke, a Fed governor, said.    In an analysis that tracks fairly closely with comments by the Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, Mr. Bernanke described several ways the central bank could inject money into the economy to combat deflation, even if interest rates were to drop to zero. [Page C6.]

headline: Compressed Data; Corporate Chiefs Aren't Amoral. Perhaps They Need More Data.
abstract: NCR Corp survey concludes that corporate chief executives really do not know what is going on in their companies because they have not set up integrated computing systems that offer single view of business operations; drawing (M)

headline: Latin Death Squads and the U.S.: A New Disclosure
abstract: US failure to confront Latin American dictators about rights abuses and right-wing death squads in 1970's is recounted by Peter Kornbluh in book The Pinochet File, which recalls assassination of Orlando Letelier during Augusto Pinochet regime in Chile; US role is also explained in book The Condor Years by John Dinges, based on US government documents released in recent years (M)

headline: S.E.C. Appears Split on Board To Oversee Accountants
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission chairman Harvey L Pitt postpones scheduled trip to Europe to search for candidates to fill new board that will oversee accounting profession; commission appears to be deeply fractured over selection process; Roel C Campos and Harvey J Goldschmid, Democratic commissioners, continue to urge selection of John H Biggs to head board, though Pitt has expressed reservations about his candidacy; photo (M)

headline: Finding a Grateful Home For Your Old Computer
abstract: Q. I would like to donate an old computer to a school or charity, but I don't want to contribute equipment so old and outdated that it is of no use. Are there any guidelines for such donations?    A. Plenty of schools and charitable organizations accept used computers and equipment in good working condition, but guidelines for such donations vary.

headline: BIG CUT IN J. P. MORGAN EMPLOYEE STOCK OPTIONS
abstract: J P Morgan Chase plans to cut stock options for most employees by more than half; shrinking options award reflects J P Morgan's declining stock price and earnings that have fallen in seven of last eight quarters (S)

headline: A Call for Universal Health Care in California
abstract: Blue Shield of California chief executive Bruce G Bodaken calls for legislation that would provide public or private health coverage for every California resident; state has six million uninsured (M)

headline: An improved outlook for online advertising as companies work to hone their approaches.
abstract: Comment on improved outlook for online advertising (M)

headline: Hussein's Obsession: An Empire of Mosques
abstract: Mosque-building on epic scale has become Iraqi Pres Saddam Hussein's grand obsession; he has set out to make Baghdad undisputed center of Islamic architecture, as it was in days of great Abbasid caliphs who ruled Arab world from Baghdad until middle of 13th century; description of Mother of All Battles Mosque, vast, newly constructed edifice of gleaming white limestone and blue mosaic that Hussein oversaw from blueprint to completion on Bagdhad's western outskirts; a few miles from Mother of All Battles Mosque, two others are rising that will dwarf it; photos (L)

headline: FORD SELLS $3 BILLION IN VEHICLE LOANS TO BEAR, STEARNS
abstract: Ford Motor Co sells $3 billion of vehicle loans to Bear, Stearns & Co after concern about Ford's ability to repay debt drove up borrowing costs (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Disarray Grows Worse In Search for S.E.C. Chief  The White House seemed close to naming as the new Securities and Exchange Commission chairman a lawyer who has been the Justice Department's leading prosecutor on corporate fraud and terrorism cases. But both the lawyer, Michael Chertoff, and White House officials backed away from the idea.    It was not clear whether Mr. Chertoff pulled himself out of the running or whether the White House had second thoughts. But the sudden turn of events added to the disarray as the administration tries to work quickly to find a successor to Harvey L. Pitt. [Page A1.]    Ford Executive Gets More Duties  Ford expanded the duties of David Thursfield, left, one of its top executives, reinforcing speculation that Mr. Thursfield is being groomed to eventually take the No. 2 spot at the company. Ford consolidated its foreign units under Mr. Thursfield. Ford also named James Padilla an executive vice president as well as president of North American operations. [C3.]    Decision Is Near on WorldCom Chief  WorldCom hopes to introduce Michael D. Capellas, the former president of Hewlett-Packard and former chief of Compaq, as its chairman and chief executive as soon as today. [C3]    Ex-Official at Adelphia Pleads Guilty  A former official of Adelphia Communications, James R. Brown, pleaded guilty to conspiracy and fraud charges and implicated the company's founder and two of his sons in a scheme to mislead investors and regulators. [C7.]    House Passes Terror Insurance Plan  The House adopted legislation providing up to $100 billion in support to the insurance industry for terrorist attacks. [A19.]    An industry-sponsored bill to make it harder for people to erase their debts in bankruptcy appeared to die in the House. [A28]    Argentina Defaults on Bailout Loan  Argentina defaulted on an $805 million loan installment to the World Bank and said it would resume payment when the International Monetary Fund agreed to restore a credit line that had been cut off. [World Business, Section W.]    Quarterly Income Rises 31% at Dell  Dell reported strong gains in quarterly profits and sales, matching expectations. Net income rose 31 percent, to $561 million, or 21 cents, compared with the year-earlier quarter. Sales increased 22 percent, to $9.1 billion. Dell predicted that its strong performance would continue but mainly because of its ability to take business from rivals. [C2.]    Interpublic Seeks a Financial Officer  The Interpublic Group of Companies is beginning a search for a chief operating officer, a job that is virtually certain to be filled from the outside. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [C5.]    Kmart's commercial about the holiday products in its Martha Stewart Everyday line does not feature Ms. Stewart. [C5.]    Discount Plan Adding Generic Drugs  The Eckerd drugstore chain is taking part in a discount prescription program started by drugmakers and will begin offering discounts on more than 1,000 generic drugs. [C5.]    Stock Markets Rally Broadly  The Dow Jones industrial average closed up 143.64 points, or 1.7 percent, at 8,542.13. The Nasdaq climbed 50.18 points, or 3.7 percent, to 1,411.52. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 21.74 points, or 2.5 percent, to 904.27. [C7.]

headline: New Economy; Chief executives take the education of Congress in hand to help the Postal Service.
abstract: Wunderman New York chief executive David Sable and 13 other corporate chiefs whose businesses cannot function without thriving mail system undertake educating members of Congress regarding actualities of United States Postal Service, of which many congressmen are ignorant; hope to spur workable postal overhaul bill; photo (M)

headline: Wary Companies Are Staying in the Muslim World
abstract: Some of biggest Western multinational companies are holding fast to their investments in most Muslim countries despite apparently globe-girdling reach of Islamic terror groups; though foreign investment is falling in countries where terrorists have struck, other predominantly Muslim countries with good record of controlling violence have experienced little or no diminution; photo (M)

headline: Credit Suisse Chief Waives Severance Pay
abstract: Lukas Muhlemann, departing chairman of Credit Suisse Group, gives up his right to severance package, heading off further outcry from shareholders after big losses (M)

headline: TAP Pharmaceutical Selects New Agency
abstract: TAP Pharmaceutical Products selects Merkley Newman Harty & Partners to create advertising campaigns for Prevacid, prescription drug for heartburn and ulcers (S)

headline: Hospital Network's Switch Is Blow to Novation
abstract: In a blow to Novation, America's largest purchasing agent for hospitals, several prominent hospitals and clinics in San Diego have decided to buy their medical supplies through a smaller, younger company that contends it is a cheaper and a more ethical alternative.    Scripps Health of San Diego, a $1 billion network of five hospitals and about 40 clinics, said it would begin buying supplies through MedAssets, a privately held company founded last year in St. Louis.

headline: Tying the Two Strands
abstract: Jenny J Ming, president of Old Navy division of Gap Inc, writes The Boss column on her family, work life and Chinese heritage; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Unemployment Rises
abstract: German unemployment rate rises to 9.7 percent in November from 9.4 percent in October (S)

headline: Worried Fiat Workers in Italy Rally to Preserve Their Jobs
abstract: Thousands of nervous Fiat employees, backed by powerful unions, have taken to streets since the company announced that it would eliminate as many as 8,100 jobs.

headline: World Briefing: Asia
abstract: PHILIPPINES: Bomb Kills 13; MALAYSIA: U.S. To Clear Visa Backlog; CAMBODIA: Talks On Tribunal; THAILAND: Condoms For Scouts;.

headline: Technology Briefing: Software
abstract: NOVELL LOSS NARROWS ON LOWER EXPENSES; U.S. AND MICROSOFT PROPOSE COMPLIANCE PANEL CANDIDATES;.

headline: World Business Briefing: Europe
abstract: GERMANY: Daimlerchrysler Cuts; RUSSIA: Producer To Increase Output; GERMANY: Inflation Falls;.

headline: Bank Calls Purchase Way to Woo Hispanics
abstract: Bank of America will pay $1.6 billion cash to buy 24.9 percent of Mexican bank Grupo Financiero Santander Serfin from Spain's Santander Central Hispano; seeks to woo Mexican and Mexican-American customers in United States; hopes to win larger share of some $1 billion a year in fees paid to remit money from United States to Mexico (M)

headline: Tougher Rules Are Proposed For Gas Mileage
abstract: Bush administration proposes largest increase in automotive fuel economy in more than decade, calling for 7 percent improvement in performance of sport utility vehicles, pickup trucks and minivans; critics, including environmentalists and top Democrats, say proposal demands no more of auto industry than it has already committed itself to achieve on its own; plan is praised by some moderates, and auto executives call it challenge; graph (M)

headline: Warren Fenzi, 87, Phelps Dodge President
abstract: Warren E Fenzi former Phelps Dodge president, dies at age 87 (S)

headline: AES SAYS IT PLANS TO REFINANCE $2 BILLION IN DEBT
abstract: AES Corp announces refinancing plan to push back maturities of more than $2 billion in debt over next year (S)

headline: SEARS MOVES ACCOUNTING COSTS TO SECOND QUARTER
abstract: Sears, Roebuck & Co shifts $191 million in costs related to accounting change to second qaurter from first after discussions with Securities and Exchange Commission; increases first-quarter 2002 net income by $191 million and reduces second-quarter net income by same amount (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   4.25   4.25   5.00       Discount rate   0.75   0.75   1.50       Federal funds   1.25   1.24   1.92       3-month T-bills   1.18   1.19   1.65       6-month T-bills   1.23   1.25   1.75       10-yr. T-infl.   2.48   2.50   3.52       10-yr. T-note   4.09   4.13   5.16       30-yr.
