headline: His Job: Chasing Wall Street Deadbeats
abstract: Profile of Michael S Colombo, chief of StreetWide Asset Recovery Group, debt collector who pursues stockbrokers and investors who owe money to Wall Street firms on loans or margin calls; photo (M)

headline: Homemade, but It Looks Like Hollywood
abstract: Video-editing programs help novice turn digital video into slick, professional-looking production on DVD or video CD; programs by Apple and Adobe are pricey, but for amateurs, there is software that runs less than $100 that perform admirably; some products described; photos (M)

headline: Peso's Devaluation Gives Argentina Cost Advantages
abstract: Drastic devaluation in Argentina's peso in January is finally giving country's service sectors and some of its export industries cost advantage over even most competitive of their competitors; analysts believe economy is finally bottoming out after four-year slump; Jorge Cassino, president of trade association for Argentine software companies, says Argentina's programmers, who have reputation for being creative, exacting, well educated and bilingual, cost $10 to $15 per hour--$5 per hour less than India and only 10 to 15 percent of what their American counterparts cost; says US company can make huge savings by farming out programming to Argentine company; weak Argentine peso is also helping wide range of other industries, including agribusiness, which accounts for 70 percent of Argentina's exports, steel, aluminum, advertising and film production; trade surplus surged to $11 billion in September; unemployment has hit record high of 24 percent and more than half population is living below poverty line; analysts say banking system must be restructured and foreign debt renegotiated to unlock economy's potential (M)

headline: A First Step to Cutting Reliance on Oil
abstract: Fuel cells could ease the threat of global warming without taking away freedom and mobility.

headline: French labels challenge Italian invasion : Paris's boutiques battle
abstract: PARIS—  While Italian brands continue their invasion of Paris, with Gucci and Dolce & Gabbana recently opening luxury boutiques, the French are mounting a counterattack for the destination shopper.

headline: Canadian Lawmakers Advance Climate Pact as Discord Grows
abstract: Canada's House of Commons overwhelmingly votes to ratify Kyoto climate change protocol; widespread disapproval by powerful provinicial governments and business groups has called into question whether accord will ever be fully put into place in Canada; Canada, one of world's largest producers of carbon dioxide emissions per capita, is one of only few large polluting nations among 100 countries to have ratified or moved toward ratification; Prime Min Jean Chretien, who strongly backs accord, had hoped vote would signify broad national support (M)

headline: U.S. Is Urged to Promote Flow of Refugees From North Korea
abstract: Growing number of Bush administration officials, policy experts and lawmakers say stream of refugees from North Korea could sharply increase, particularly if China agrees not to send refugees back and if South Korea and United States take in more escapees; see exodus speeding collapse of Communist regime; administration and refugee advocates are also calling on China to give United Nations High Commission for Refugees access to North Korean border region, where it can screen refugees and assist their safe movement to other nations; photo (M)

headline: Technology Rebound in 2003?
abstract: IDC reports that worldwide sales for information technology industry are expected to fall 2.3 percent in 2002; predicts industry growth of 5.8 percent worldwide in 2003 and 4.4 percent in United States (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Bank Stake Raised
abstract: Credit Agricole increases its stake in Credit Lyonnais to 17.4 percent in effort to thwart bid by BNP Paribas, which owns 16.2 percent stake (S)

headline: Ugandan Paper Back in Print With a Front-Page Apology
abstract: Uganda's only independent daily newspaper, The Monitor, reappears on streets of Kampala a week after government security agents shut it down for reporting that government helicopter had crashed in northern part of country while fighting rebel group; issues carefully worded apology for article on front page (M)

headline: ONLINE DIARY
abstract: Merry, Merry, Mary       Do you pronounce ''girl'' with two syllables? What do you call a carbonated beverage? Do the three words in the title of this item all sound the same?

headline: Ashcroft Says U.S. Will Place Agents in China
abstract: Atty Gen John Ashcroft concludes three-day visit to Beijing, offering praise for China's efforts to combat international terrorism and announcing opening of FBI liaison office in Beijing to further that effort; provides few details about what form law enforcement coordination between US and China might take or about complicated matter of how American officials would cooperate with police in China; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: BMC Will Manage Systems At Dell
abstract: BMC Software, computer-management program maker whose sales have fallen in nine straight quarters from year earlier, says Dell Computer has agreed to manage its systems with BMC's products and resell them; graph (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Nextel Says It Will Meet 2002 Forecasts
abstract: Nextel Communications Inc says it expects to meet its 2002 forecasts for customers, cash flow and capital spending; graph (S)

headline: McDonald's, Facing a Loss, May Modify Its Hamburgers
abstract: McDonald's Corp tell franchise holders that it is tinkering with its hamburgers, both meat and bun, to stimulate sales; says that despite some misgivings among franchise holders as well as Wall Street, chain's Dollar Menu will be maintained and will be given substantial part of next year's company advertising budget (M)

headline: Japan Vows A New Effort On Bad Debt
abstract: Japan's chief financial regulator Heizo Takenaka says government and Bank of Japan will join forces to deal with 52 trillion yen ($430 million) in bad loans that are plaguing economy; such cooperation would represent break in decade-long deadlock among policy groups that oversee banks (M)

headline: DUPONT DELAYS DEAL FOR CHEMFIRST AFTER BLAST AT PLANT
abstract: DuPont Co's plan to purchase ChemFirst Inc for $408 million is suspended until further investigation of explosion at ChemFirst plant in Mississippi; three employees were injured in Oct 13 explosion (S)

headline: BMG Plans to Simplify Royalty Deductions
abstract: BMG, unit

headline: Crédit Lyonnais Shares Rise On Talk of a Bidding War
abstract: Shares of Credit Lyonnais soar as investors foresee bidding war for French government's 10.9 percent stake in bank; BNP Paribas offers $2.2 billion; speculation grows about suitors for all or part of bank, which is just emerging from many years of financial difficulties; photo (M)

headline: Private Sector; Who, Gucci Asks, Is This Chicken Little?
abstract: Latest, most minimalist Gucci store opens with gala party at 69th Street and Madison Avenue in Manhattan; photo (M)

headline: An Owner of Global Crossing Surprises With Its Latest Bid
abstract: ST Telemedia, little-known Singapore company, bursts into limelight with $631 million winning bid for 42 percent stake in Indonesia Satellite offered by Indonesian government (M)

headline: World Briefing: Asia
abstract: SOUTH KOREA: G.I. Found Not Guilty; SOUTH KOREA: Compromise On Transit Links;.

headline: MEMO PAD
abstract: Air Transport Association president Carol B Hallett, in speech to Aero Club of Washington, says failure to fix root causes of airline industry's meltdown may necessitate nationalization of industry; XM Satellite Radio will be available on about 50,000 Avis rental cars starting this winter for extra $2.99 daily (Memo Pad column) (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Corning Posts Loss And Cuts Jobs
abstract: Corning Inc, maker of fiber optic cable, posts its sixth consecutive quarterly loss and says it will cut another 2,200 jobs, or 8.5 percent of its global payroll; sales fell 45 percent, to $837 million, from $1.51 billion year ago; loss was $260 million compared with loss of $220 million (S)

headline: The Noah's Ark of the Web, 7,000 Characters at a Time
abstract: New set of computer fonts under development by Scientific and Technical Information Exchange (or STIX), organization of six publishers of scientific, technical and medical journals, promises to contain every character -- more than 7,000 in all -- that might be needed in articles published in any scientific discipline; drawing (M)

headline: War Crimes Charges for Kosovo Albanians
abstract: Former Kosovo Liberation Army commander, Rustem Mustafa, and three subordinates are charged with committing war crimes against fellow Albanians accused of collaborating with Serbian authorities; UN authorities in province announce indictments (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Hewlett In Supply Deal With Home Depot
abstract: Hewlett-Packard wins deal to supply 40,000 personal computers for use in 1,456 Home Depot stores (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Top General In Chechnya Is Fired
abstract: Russian Pres Vladimir V Putin fires Chechnya commander Colonel General Gennadi N Troshev after his public refusal to accept Defense Ministry transfer to command in Siberia; war in Chechnya has frustrated Defense Minister Sergei B Ivanov's attempts at Russian military reforms (S)

headline: Private Sector; Will the Glow Wear Off?
abstract: Glow Industries, which sells scented bath and body products, files trademark infringement lawsuit against Jennifer Lopez and Coty, who are coming out with perfume line called Glow by J Lo; photo (S)

headline: Citigroup Deal Approved
abstract: Federal Reserve approves Citigroup's planned $4.9 billion purchase of Golden State Bancorp (S)

headline: BUSH DECLARES U.S. IS USING DIPLOMACY TO DISARM HUSSEIN
abstract: Pres Bush says United States is trying diplomacy 'one more time' to disarm Saddam Hussein 'peacefully' and suggests that if Hussein complies with every United Nations mandate it would 'signal the regime has changed'; White House says Bush is not backing away from his past insistence that Hussein must leave office; some administration officials suggest privately that Bush is toning down talk of removing Hussein by force if necessary to mollify nervous allies on day that US and Britain begin circulating revised resolution in Security Council demanding Iraq's disarmament; Bush himself tells Lord Robertson, secretary general of NATO, that stated policy of US is regime change; his spokesman Ari Fleischer tells reporters that UN resolution is 'moving forward nicely' and that, if passed, it would give Bush all authority he believes he needs to act militarily if Hussein fails to comply; says Bush cannot imagine that Hussein would suddenly comply with UN after 11 years of defiance (M)

headline: Fatal Strike in Yemen Was Based on Rules Set Out by Bush
abstract: Senior government officials say lethal missile strike that killed suspected leader of Al Qaeda in Yemen was carried out under broad authority that Pres Bush has given CIA over past year to pursue terror network well beyond borders of Afghanistan; say Bush was aware that CIA was pursuing suspect, Qaed Salim Sinan al-Harethi; say missile strike does not violate longstanding ban on assassination of political leaders because none of men killed are regarded as leaders under law; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Drug Revenue Rises
abstract: Aventis says third-quarter sales rose 21 percent; net income climbed to 560 million euros ($551 million) from 461 million euros year earlier (S)

headline: U.N. Agency Demands North Korea End Atomic Program
abstract: nuclear fears: u.nÔ

headline: Matera Journal; It's Not Jesus' Jerusalem, but as a Stand-In It's Safer
abstract: Mel Gibson is in Matera, Italy, directing The Passion, movie about last 12 hours in Jesus' life; he is not first to use ancient Italian city of Matera as setting for movie about biblical times; photos; map (M)

headline: Self-Published and Proud
abstract: Susan M Seidman responding to Oct 24 letter says her experience with print-on-demand book publishing has been very satisfying (Oct 17)

headline: U.N. Official Faults Clause On Interviews Of Scientists
abstract: Senior United Nations official warns that clause in Iraq resolution that lets United Nations inspectors take Iraqi scientists out of country for interviews may backfire and make access to scientists more difficult (M)

headline: A Top Lawyer In Antitrust At Giant Firm Joins a Rival
abstract: Kevin J Arquit, global co-head of law firm Clifford Chance's antitrust practice and former senior official at Federal Trade Commission, will become partner at Simpson Thacher & Bartlett, firm best known for its roster of blue-chip corporate and investment banking clients; Arquit is taking along partner Aimee H Goldstein; defections are latest hit to image of Clifford Chance, which was formed from 2000 merger of British firm of same name and New York firm of Rogers & Wells; several other top partners have left since merger; Clifford Chance continues to receive negative publicity, most recently when firm's junior lawyers prepared memorandum describing 'profound problem' at firm; Arquit insists decision to leave is personal choice; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Bangladesh: Journalists Expelled
abstract: Bangladesh deports two journalists being held for visa violations; British and Italian journalists entered country on tourist visas posing as teachers but were allegedly filming documentary about possible Al Qaeda members hiding in Bangladesh (S)

headline: Shoppers from the mainland get red carpet in Hong Kong : Buying luxury:'an exceptional moment'
abstract: HONG KONG—  Bebe Li is proud to be a modern Shanghai woman. She throws back her head, making her wavy ponytail bounce, and pouts her expensively rouged lips. "The economy is doing very well. Life is not bad. Now you can buy just about anything there," the stylish 29-year-old says of her hometown.

headline: President Warns Hussein to Heed a Call to Disarm
abstract: With the Security Council moving toward approving a resolution today to force Saddam Hussein to disarm, President Bush warned Mr. Hussein to comply.

headline: Singapore And U.S. Near A Trade Deal
abstract: US reaches tentative free-trade agreement with Singapore; new agreement, if completed and approved by Congress, would eliminate tariffs on about $33 billion in trade between two countries and would give American banks and service companies more access to one of Asia's main financial centers; US trade representative Robert B Zoellick comments; photo of Zoellick with Singapore's Trade Min George Yeo (M)

headline: Chechens Kill Hostage In Siege at Russian Hall
abstract: Chechen rebels threatening to blow up Moscow theater with as many as 700 hostages, including three Americans, turn over body of young woman who tried to escape theater and turn rocket launcher at two other women who do manage to escape; streets outside music hall are surrounded by scores of Russian soldiers and police; guerrillas set free 7 unidentified hostages and pledge to release some or all of 75 foreign hostages being held; official of Russia's domestic intelligence agency says talks with captors are being held under 'tense atmosphere' and that further releases may be possible; it is unclear whether rebels are negotiating with government through intermediaries or shifting to direct talks; adding to problems, hot-water pipe bursts and floods first floor of theater; hostage-takers claim incident is ploy by government agents and refuse to let repair crews into building; group underscores its threats in videotapes delivered anonymously to Moscow bureau of Al Jazeera, Qatar-based news channel that often broadcasts messages from Al Qaeda leaders; in tapes, masked rebel talks of their 'martyrdom operation' and about being 'keen on dying'; Pres Vladimir V Putin denounces assault as one 'planned in foreign terrorist centers'; photos; map (L)

headline: Poland Said to Pick Lockheed for $3.5 Billion Fighter Deal
abstract: Poland appeared set to award a contract to the Lockheed Martin Corporation to build 48 advanced fighter planes for the Polish Air Force at a cost of $3.5 billion.

headline: DEAN FOODS TO SELL PUERTO RICAN UNITS TO PERUVIANS
abstract: Dean Foods Co agrees to sell its business in Puerto Rico to Peruvian conglomerate Grupo Gloria for $122 million (S)

headline: A Top Iraqi Aide Defies U.S. to Find Proof of Weapons
abstract: A general on Sunday denied that Iraq still has any weapons of mass destruction but hinted that, a decade ago, Baghdad came close to building an atom bomb.

headline: Helsinki Journal; Jacks? Dolls? Yo-Yos? No, They Want Cellphones
abstract: Helsinki, Finland, home to cellphone giant Nokia, is one of most cell-happy cities in world; estimated 92 percent of its households have at least one, if not several cellphones; teenagers have long used cellphones, but now market is undergoing rapid expansiondownward in age; cellphone retailers are making pitch to children as young as 7; at one elementary school in Helsinki, second graders all want Nokia cellphone, accessorized with personal logo on screen; photos (M)

headline: A Change in Flight Plans For Troubled Airlines
abstract: Tariq Al-Rifai letter comments on Dec 6 article concerning necessity of large United States airlines' developing new business models in order to survive

headline: An Uneasy Wait in Oklahoma
abstract: Workers at General Motors plant in Midwest City, Okla, wear red-white-and-blue ribbons for colleague Sandy Alan Booker, feared dead in siege that ended occupation of Moscow theater by Chechen rebels; he was completing preparations in Moscow to bring Russian fiancee back to US; she remains in coma in Moscow hospital (S)

headline: Armored Archer Or Navy Seal? 2 Paths to Glory
abstract: Charles Herold reviews two video games: Socom: US Navy Seals, developed by Zipper Interactive, and Medieval: Total War, developed by Creative Assembly; photos (M)

headline: 'Friends' Coup May Put Focus On 'Sopranos'
abstract: NBC's coup in bringing Friends back for yet another season leads HBO to hope that it can convince David Chase to create another season of The Sopranos after next season; NBC will be paying $9 million for each of 18 episodes of Friends, price it is willing to pay to ensure that it will still be able to go to advertisers next spring and tell them that they will be able to buy commercials in new episodes of television's top-rated show; Chase says he does think he can do sixth season of The Sopranos and is not sure about continuing program in theatrical movies, as has been suggested; he has now, however, completely closed door (M)

headline: Computers and Prisons
abstract: Robert P Weiss letter suggests training prisoners to build computers in program similar to one in Mississippi in which students built computers for every classroom in state (Dec 19 article)

headline: Martha Stewart 3rd-Quarter Earnings Fall 42%
abstract: Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia Inc says third-quarter earnings fell 42 percent, dragged down by investigations into Stewart's ImClone Systems stock trade; predicts even steeper decline for rest of year; sales of products at Kmart declined 6.9 percent in quarter compared with year earlier; corporate overhead rose $2.6 million, or 36 percent, to $9.8 million; company paid out $1.7 million in bonuses, seen as means of encouraging people to stay on; earned $9.3 million in first nine months of year, compared with $21.9 million year earlier; Stewart comments; company announces it is testing new publication called Everyday Food, first not to feature Stewart's name in title, indication that it is looking for ways to rely less heavily on her public image; December holiday TV special showcasing Stewart in various cooking and handicraft roles, which has aired last several years, has been canceled (M)

headline: Qaeda Suspect Talking, U.S. Says
abstract: Deputy Defense Secretary Paul D. Wolfowitz said today that Ramzi bin al-Shibh, the suspected member of Al Qaeda captured in Pakistan earlier this month, was providing American authorities with ''valuable information.''    Speaking at the inaugural meeting of the U.S.-Pakistan Business Council, Mr. Wolfowitz thanked the Pakistani government for seizing Mr. bin al-Shibh, who ''is not only off the streets now, but in fact is providing us with valuable information.''

headline: Native Canadians Bask in New Business Climate
abstract: Recent discoveries of diamonds and proposed natural-gas pipeline are bringing boom to Northwest Territories, attracting business managers and consultants from all over Canada; during past booms, Native Canadians were exploited; this time, 22,000 Native people are beginning to reap benefits that were unthinkable in past; new generation of aggressive Native leaders now run territorial government; series of land claim settlements negotiated with Ottawa in recent years are providing Native communities with hefty reserves of government cash, which they are using as seed money for investment opportunities; photos (M)

headline: Can Settlement Actually Level Playing Field For Investors?
abstract: Settlement requiring major brokerage firms to provide investors with independent research alongside their own is hailed by some independent research firms as beginning of new, ethical era for retail investing, but others balk at idea of selling their independent research to Wall Street firms and say they would lose their objectivity by doing so; settlement certainly creates opportunity for independent research firms, of which there are about 100 of meaningful size and perhaps another 100 that have just a few people; it is too early to tell whether settlement will create level playing field for retail and institutional investors (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Pitt Prods Wall St. Officials; Chief Accountant Resigns  Harvey L. Pitt, in his first public speech since resigning as chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, called on Wall Street executives to restore investor confidence.    Mr. Pitt alluded to his troubles only in closing. He said nothing about how he had handled the appointment of William H. Webster to head an accounting oversight board. Later, he accepted the resignation of Robert Herdman, the S.E.C.'s chief accountant, who worked with Mr. Pitt to establish the board and conducted a background check on Mr. Webster. [Page A1.]

headline: Rome Journal; Pinocchio Infatuates Italians (and That's No Lie)
abstract: Italians are infatuated with Pinocchio, helped by Hollywood-style hoopla preceding release of new, live-action movie of Pinocchio by Italian superstar Roberto Benigni; latex Pinocchio noses and Pinocchio backpacks are everywhere, along with Pinocchio dolls; Pinocchio is even being feminized, with introduction of Pinocchia, book giving Pinocchio a soul mate and exploring passion between puppets; photos (M)

headline: The Rescue, Seen From Inside: 'We Will All Be Blown Up'
abstract: Interviews with hostages in Moscow theater describe their ordeal under siege by Chechnyan guerrillas, and storming of theater by Russian special forces; photos (M)

headline: Palestinians And Israelis Clash in Gaza; At Least 6 Die
abstract: Israeli tanks battling Palestinian gunmen fire cannon and machine guns into densely populated Rafah refugee camp in Gaza Strip, killing at least 6 people and wounding 60 others; Palestinian leadership callskillings 'new massacre'; latest bloodshed comes days after Bush administration expresses deep concern over significant rise in Palestinian civilian casualties during Israeli military operations; Israeli Army says its tanks retuned fire after anti-tank rocket fired by gunmen in camp hit armored bulldozer that was building protective earthwork around army position; says terrorists use Palestinian population as human shield; no Israeli casualties are reported; photo (M)

headline: Rockwell Reports Quadrupling of Profit
abstract: Rockwell Automation says fiscal fourth-quarter profit quadrupled, rising to $49 million, as it reduced costs and increased sales to $1.02 billion (S)

headline: U.S. Carmakers Losing Ground To Imports Despite Deals
abstract: Billions of dollars that General Motors, Ford and Chrysler have spent during last year on generous sales incentives have not brought them bigger share of market; CNW Marketing Research says Detroit carmakers are spending average of $3,764 per vehicle, or 14 percent of selling price, on all manner of incentives, twice as much as average deal on Japanese and Korean brands; many imports are selling well without any incentives; analysts say Detroit's deals have proved all but powerless against imports' reputation for quality, durability and high resale value; Detroit has lost about another 1.6 percentage points of market share this year, with sales by Big Three automakers falling to 61.7 percent of market for cars and light trucks in US; charts; photo (M)

headline: Where There's a Sale There's Also a Shopper
abstract: Mall owners and retail analysts say that American shoppers take to malls in greater numbers than last year as 2002 Christmas shopping season begins; despite half-off sales and early bird specials, few analysts predict that this Christmas will be as successful as last year's, when shoppers were in subdued mood in aftermath of Sept 1; photos (M)

headline: The Survivors Dribble Out, All With a Story to Tell
abstract: Survivors describe terrifying two-day ordeal in Moscow theater, where they were held hostage by Chechen rebels; photos (M)

headline: Fed Lowers Rate a Half Point
abstract: The Federal Reserve moved aggressively today to spur the sluggish American economy, cutting short-term interest rates by half a percentage point.

headline: Fiscal and Technical Advice for Ex-Ford Chief as He Arrives at Polaroid
abstract: Five photography and management experts suggest how Jacques A Nasser might be able to nurse Polaroid back to fiscal health; they are Alexis Gerard, Stuart C Gilson, Henry L Druker, Ulysses Yannas and Don Franz; photos (M)

headline: Taylor Howard, 70, Pioneer In Satellite TV for the Home
abstract: H Taylor Howard, pioneer in sas

headline: Doubts Push Stock of UAL Down 31%
abstract: Stock of United Airlines' parent company, UAL Corp, loses nearly third of its value and company's credit rating is cut as financial markets grow increasingly doubtful that carrier will be able to stay out of bankruptcy court; UAL does not plan to seek bankruptcy protection immediately, however, and it is continuing to try to secure concessions from its workers and loan guarantees from government, participants in airline's restructuring effort say; company plans to take advantage of 10-day grace period on crucial debt repayment of $375 million (M)

headline: Enron's Ex-Treasurer Is Subject Of a Justice Dept. Investigation
abstract: Ben F Glisan Jr, former treasurer of Enron, is subject of Justice Dept investigation (S)

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: BRITAIN: Firefighters Call Off Strike; MONACO: Conviction In Billionaire'S Death; ITALY: Protester'S Killing Called Self-Defense; ITALY: New School Where Quake Killed Pupils; RUSSIA: Swedish Diplomats Expelled; THE HAGUE: Bosnian Serb Sentenced;.

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Dollar gains against yen; settles at 124.58 yen, from 122.60 previously; graph (S)

headline: World Business Briefing: Asia
abstract: SOUTH KOREA: Credit Delinquencies Rise; HONG KONG: Economy Expands;.

headline: Earnings at DuPont Triple in Quarter
abstract: DuPont says its third-quarter profit more than tripled; net income rose to $469 million from $142 million year earlier; sales declined to $5.74 billion from $5.78 billion (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Compromise On Transit Links
abstract: US officials waive part of 50-year-old treaty and allow North Korea to work directly with South Korea in establishing and identifing access for personnel working on roads and rails in demilitarized zone (S)

headline: New Rules Order Companies To Disclose Offshore Moves
abstract: Treasury Department issues regulations requiring companies that acquire offshore addresses to tell their shareholders and notify Internal Revenue Service; February and April New York Times articles reported on major accounting firms, notably Ernst & Young, that encourage companies to engage in this practice to escape taxes on profits earned in United States (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Prices Fall Again
abstract: Japanese consumer prices fall for 36th consecutive month as deflation continues to erode economy; September prices drop 0.9 percent below year earlier (S)

headline: Europeans Fear That the Threat From Radical Islamists Is Increasing
abstract: Political leaders and police investigators across Europe conclude that threat of terrorism from Al Qaeda and other radical Islamic groups is more serious than they have assumed and may take years to neutralize; say recent investigations have uncovered surprisingly well-established networks of Muslim militants with potential to commit terrorist acts and affiliations that stretch across Europe to operatives in North America, North Africa, Middle East and Central Asia; disagree over extent to which Europe is actually more vulnerable to terrorism since Sept 11; map shows recent law enforcement activity against suspected terrorists in Europe (M)

headline: New No. 2 Position Filled at Havas
abstract: Havas appoints Bob Schmetterer president and chief operating officer; he will also continue as chairman and chief executive at subsidiary Euro RSCG Worldwide (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Federal Panel Rejects United Request for Loan Aid  A federal panel has rejected a request by United Airlines for $1.8 billion in loan guarantees. Union leaders said that United executives told them that the airline hoped to avoid an immediate bankruptcy filing, but analysts said the decision all but ensured that United would have to seek court protection.     The Air Transportation Stabilization Board said that government assistance would not solve United's problems. ''This is not just about costs,'' wrote Peter R. Fisher, a Treasury undersecretary who is on the board. ''It's about a business plan that is fundamentally flawed.'' United said it was disappointed by the decision. [Page A1.]

headline: 10 Palestinians Are Killed in Israeli Hunt for a Militant
abstract: Israeli troops, hunting for Palestinian Resistance Committee military leader Ayman Shishniya, raid Bureij Refugee Camp in Gaza Strip, leaving 10 Palestinians dead including two United Nations school workers; UN official condemns attack; Israel insists deaths resulted when Israeli troops responded to Palestinian gunfire; Shishniya escapes attack unharmed; photo; map (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)ú

headline: Technology Briefing: Telecommunications
abstract: QUALCOMM PLANS VENTURE WITH CHINA UNICOM; MARCONI REACHES PACT ON REORGANIZATION;.

headline: Iraqi Opposition Circulates Plan for Post-Hussein Era
abstract: Iraqi opposition figures circulate detailed plan for transforming Iraq from dictatorship into essentially secular democracy in two to three years if Pres Saddam Hussein is removed from office; report follows fierce debate among representatives of State Department-supported group that consists of Iraqi intellectuals in exile, representatives of human rights groups, other private organizations, and representatives of leading Iraqi opposition groups (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Confusing Signals on Fate Of the S.E.C. Chairman  Administration officials said that President Bush would dismiss Harvey L. Pitt as the head of the Securities and Exchange Commission if the investigations into his selection of a new accounting oversight board show he failed to act properly.    But advisers to Mr. Bush continued to send out conflicting signals about Mr. Pitt's future, publicly supporting him while privately complaining about his political missteps. The situation was especially delicate with Congressional elections on Tuesday. [Section A.]

headline: The Angry Appeal of Eminem Is Cutting Across Racial Lines
abstract: White hip-hop artist Eminem draws strong reactions from great variety of listeners; his audience is predominantly suburban white youths; success of his semi-biographical new film 8 Mile will require heavy crossover appeal; photos (M)

headline: C.I.A. Says Iraq Revived Forbidden Weapons Programs After the U.N. Inspectors Left
abstract: Central Intelligence Agency says Iraq took advantage of withdrawal of United Nations weapons inspectors to resume production of chemical arms, expand efforts to develop biological weapons and revive its program to make nuclear arms; report mostly echoes British government's recent assessment of Iraq's weapons programs; CIA report says Iraq would probably not be able to make nuclear weapon until last half of decade unless it acquires fissile material through black market; says sign of Iraq's nuclear intentions is its effort to purchase high-strength aluminum tubes which could be used to make centrifuges to enrich uranium; photo; maps (M)

headline: Alyssa Chen, 34
abstract: Alyssa Chen describes what drove her to open her own card shop in Boston, Mass; photo (Special Section, Working) (S)

headline: U.S. Labels Indonesian Faction as Terrorist
abstract: United States formally declares Jemaah Islamiyah, Southeast Asian radical Islamic group, to be foreign terrorist organization; Bush administration suspects it of involvement in Bali bombing; US and Australia call for group to be added to United Nations list of formally declared terrorist organizations; call is supported by Indonesian government, which weeks ago said group does not exist in its country; group's leader, Indonesian cleric Abu Bakar Bashir, is arrested at his hospital bed in Solo, Indonesia; much of background information on Jemaah Islamiyah that US and Australia use for declaring itterrorist organization comes from CIA's interrogation of Qaeda operative Omar al-Faruq; photos (M)

headline: Roche Increases Reserves For Price-Fixing Lawsuits
abstract: Roche Holding says vitamin price-fixing case from 1990's is taking growing toll on its finances; surprises analysts by announcing that it will set aside additional 1.2 billion Swiss francs ($810 million) to cover costs of lawsuits in matter (M)

headline: Business; Shareholders Rise Up (In Wild West Fashion)
abstract: Angry shareholders who believe they were wronged in corporate fraud scandals are offering 'bounties' to lawyers who succeed in capturing lavish personal wealth of executives accused of ruining some of America's largest companies; investors, mostly pension funds, eye everything from Canadian cattle ranch of Bernard J Ebbers, former head of WorldCom, to Impressionist paintings in collection of L Dennis Kozlowski, former chief executive of Tyco International; graph; photos (M)

headline: Kim Dae Jung sees bright side; Koizumi reminds of promises : Asians diverge over revelations
abstract: SEOUL:—  President Kim Dae Jung of South Korea and Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi of Japan adopted different approaches Friday to persuading North Korea to halt its nuclear program as the United States sought a common response to what all three see as an escalating threat.

headline: Two Magazines Going for Grit, Not for Glamour
abstract: Lifetime, new magazine from Livetime Entertainment Services, promises its readers gritty stories about 'real life, real women'; Ladies' Home Journal says it is looking for stories about 'women who have made changes in their lives in order to become a different person' and 'stories of women who are fighting the good fight' (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: The Hague: Tribunal Demands Croatian General
abstract: United Nations war crimes tribunal demands that Croatia hand over 83-year-old General Janko Bobetko despite ruling in Zagreb (Croatia) court that Bobetko's ill health makes him unfit for trial (S)

headline: Upgrading to Windows XP
abstract: Gordon Mills letter suggests Linux system instead of expensive Windows XP upgrade (Oct 24 article)

headline: The Perishable DVD As Musical Taste Test
abstract: Atlantic Records will give sample DVD to purchasers of CD by group Nappy Roots; sample DVD, developed by Flexplay, becomes unreadable 8 hours after package is opened and exposed to air; promotion is intended to explore consumers' interest in combined audio and video experience DVD's offer; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Philippines: Tax Charge Revived
abstract: Philippine Supreme Court revises case accusing Eduardo M Cojuangco Jr, chairman of San Migel Corp, of stealing public funds; court nullified decision by government prosecutors in 1997 to drop graft charges against Cojuangco; Cojuangco, together with former senator and 10 other people, is charged with misappropriating 9.6 billion pesos in taxes on coconuts during rule of Pres Ferdinand E Marcos (S)

headline: Ex-Executive Of El Paso Is Indicted Over Gas Data
abstract: Todd Geiger, former El Paso Corp vice president, is indicted on federal charges of falsely reporting 48 gas trades in 2001 to newsletters that compile price indexes; federal investigators probe whether false reports were aimed at manipulating prices; photo (M)

headline: Doing Business by Cellphone Creates New Liability Issues
abstract: Use of cellphones to do business may make companies liable if employees using them are involved in car accident; Smith Barney paid $500,000 to settle suit brought by family of motorcyclist killed by one of its brokers who was talking on phone while driving; in another such case, jury concluded otherwise; resulting confusion over law is one reason employers and their lawyers will be closely observing outcome of suit filed in Virginia against law firm whose associate was allegedly talking to clients on cellphone when she killed teenage girl in 2000; cases like these are plowing new legal ground in determining ways companies will be responsible for events outside traditional workplace and outside traditional work hours; no one is sure what kind of policy will shield companies against liability (M)

headline: U.N. Teams Begin Analysis Of Documents From the Iraqis
abstract: Enormous troves of documents containing Iraq's declarations on weapons pgorams arrives at UN offices in Vienna and New York, and arms experts begin daunting task of determining whether material reveals illegal arms activity; photo (M)

headline: Hedge-Fund Investigation
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission investigates whether hedge fund managers inflate value of their portfolios in effort to increase apparent earnings (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Auto Venture
abstract: South Korea's Hyundai Motor is teaming with Beijing Automotive Industry Holding to begin producing cars in China; plans to produce 2,000 cars in China by end of 2002 and 500,000 per year by 2010 (S)

headline: Company Says Traders Gave Out False Data
abstract: Natural gas pipelines owner Williams Companies admits that its traders provided phony information to journal that compiles gas price indexes used by industry in sales contracts; Dynegy and American Electric Power made similar confessions in early October (M)

headline: White House Aides Push for 50% Cut In Dividend Taxes
abstract: White House officials reportedly urge Pres Bush to propose cutting taxes on corporate dividends for shareholders by about half as part of tax-cutting plan he will announce in January; proposal is intended to stimulate economy and reduce what many economists says is incentive in current law for companies to avoid paying dividends and to run up debt; many economists are skeptical that cut in dividend taxes would provide much immediate stimulus to economy, Bush's most important justification for new tax cuts; 50 percent cut would cost Treasury more than $100 million over 10 years, and tax benefits would overwhelmingly flow to nation's very wealthiest taxpayers (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Microsoft Executive Will Retire
abstract: Deborah Willingham will retire as senior vice president for human resources at Microsoft Corp (S)

headline: PFIZER SAYS DRUG REDUCES HEART ATTACKS AND STROKES
abstract: Pfizer Inc says study has found that its Lipitor cholesterol drug reduces heart attacks and strokes, suggesting that lowering cholesterol helps decrease risks stemming from hypertension (S)

headline: World Briefing | The Environment: Twin Threats To Kyoto Treaty
abstract: Concern grows for future of Kyoto Treaty as both Russia and US are hesitant to ratify; Russia wants to study details before decision; US issues declaration similar to last year, when pact was rejected by Bush Administration (S)

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: RUSSIA: 2 Canadians Expelled; RUSSIA: `Getting To Know You' Police Campaign; 'MARKETING' EMISSIONS; SPAIN: Sunken Tanker May Leak More Oil; DENMARK: Lower Refugee Allowance;.

headline: U.S. Is Putting Heavy Pressure on France and Other Skeptics for a U.N. Resolution
abstract: The Bush administration is mounting a campaign of public pressure to persuade France to go along with a single resolution threatening military force against Iraq.

headline: World Business Briefing: Asia
abstract: JAPAN: Mazda'S Profit Rises; JAPAN: Nomura Holdings Rebounds; INDIA: Gain For Petrochemicals; SOUTH KOREA: Consumer Prices Fall; JAPAN: Hitachi Posts A Gain;.

headline: Personal Business; The Search for Sure Footing in a Shaky Work World
abstract: Job seekers and employees on all rungs of corporate ladder are seeking to protect themselves from problems, economic or sometimes ethical, that have dragged down many companies and caused fall of confidence in corporate America; some executives negotiate for specific contracts and severance packages or inquire about liability protection; others work to improve their resumes and reputations in their companies, by taking courses or volunteering for extra work assignments; photo (M)

headline: U.S. to Add to Forces in Horn of Africa
abstract: United States is increasing its forces stationed around Horn of Africa to about 1,200 troops, allowing them to conduct training missions and remain positioned to stage attacks against fighters for Al Qaeda who are believed to be hiding throughout region; Gen Tommy R Franks, commander of American forces in Persian Gulf, says troop buildup is intended to allow US to broaden its security assistance to regional allies, while remaining poised to attack terrorists; photo (M)

headline: Islamic Allies In Pakistan Fail in Talks For Coalition
abstract: islamic allies in pakistan fail in talks f

headline: Leaders of U.N. Weapons Inspection Teams Agree to Delay Their Return to Iraq
abstract: Leaders of United Nations weapons inspections teams, under intense pressure from United States and Britain, say they will delay return to Iraq until Security Council gives them new instructions to guide their work; 15 nations sitting on Council move toward agreement that should toughen rules governing inspections, but members come no closer to accord on strong resolution that would authorize use of military force; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Under Ruling, Prilosec May Still Face Generic Rival  While AstraZeneca scored a victory late Friday in its battle to keep generic drug makers from undermining its $5.7 billion franchise in Prilosec, the popular ulcer treatment, it was hardly a complete one.    A federal judge did uphold two important AstraZeneca patents on Prilosec, and the company said those patents were valid until 2007. But the judge also left the door wide open for an American unit of the German company Schwarz Pharma to make a lower-cost version much sooner. Market Place. [Page C2.]

headline: HealthSouth Names New Board Member
abstract: HealthSouth Corp's board names Robert P May director, and he will oversee efforts to improve its corporate governance; HealthSouth has become mired in controversy over its Medicare billing practices and stock sales of its chairman Richard M Scrushy; company faces numerous shareholder lawsuits and is also being investigated by Securities and Exchange Commission (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Internet Music Sales Fall 39%
abstract: ComScore Networks reports that Internet sales of recorded music fell 39 percent in third quarter, to $121.6 million (S)

headline: Britain Accuses Hussein of Systematic Torture and Killing
abstract: Britain released a dossier today on what it called the systematic rape, torture, gassing and executions of Iraqis by Saddam Hussein.

headline: U.S. Envoy Asks Hong Kong For Text of Anti-Sedition Law
abstract: United States Consul Gen James Keith asks Hong Kong government to disclose legal language of its planned anti-sedition law; criticism of law continues to spread in Hong Kong and abroad; pro-Beijing political parties are organizing large demonstration in favor of tough law providing long prison terms for sedition, treason and disclosure of official secrets and broad powers for police; democratic activists seek public debate before bill goes to Legislative Council, which rarely amends bill sponsored by government (M)

headline: Private Sector; For a Banker, Roots and Reach
abstract: Profile of Rene Carron, new chairman of Credit Agricole, focusing on his deft move to acquire control of Credit Lyonnais in deal that will create France's biggest bank, eclipsing BNP Paribas, which was maneuvering to acquire Lyonnais; photo (M)

headline: Miscellany
abstract: The Robert Wood Johnson Foundation, Princeton, N.J., is renewing its support of the Partnership for a Drug-Free America, New York, which coordinates antidrug campaigns for the advertising industry. The foundation, which has supported the partnership since 1989, is awarding a three-year, $15 million grant to support efforts to raise awareness of ways to treat substance abuse.  Advertising Age, New York, part of Crain Communications, is closing a Web site devoted to international news (www.adageglobal.com), five months after a companion magazine, Ad Age Global, was closed. The online international news will appear on the main Advertising Age Web site (www.adage.com) as the printed version now appears in Advertising Age.

headline: War and Politics
abstract: Analysis: experts in region say perception that Washington remains hostile to Islam is helping drive victories of some religiously oriented parties across Islamic and Arab world; say sudden gain in votes in recent elections in Pakistan, Bahrain, Morocco and Turkey is sign that voters want to assert pride in their faith to outside world; say recent election results may serve as opportunity or risk for United States; say working with moderate Islamic groups could give US credibility it lacks, while opposing them would only fertilize already blooming anti-American sentiment (M)

headline: As It Remakes Itself, Mattel Does Same for Barbie
abstract: Mattel's modernization of Barbie doll line symbolizes company's attempt to recover from years of declining sales, weakening balance sheets and mounting debt by refocusing on core brands and by trying to extend those brands into new territory; new Barbie has bigger head, poutier lips and scantier clothes than her earlier incarnation; photos (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Intersil Cuts Sales And Profit Forecasts
abstract: Intersil Corp, maker of computer chips, cuts fourth-quarter forecasts for sales and profit because of slack demand (S)

headline: Turning A Profit With Higher Education
abstract: Credit Suisse First Boston research analyst Greg Capelli discusses outlook for investing in commercial post-secondary education companies; recommends University of Phoenix Online, Education Management, Career Education Corp and Corinthian Colleges; photo (M)

headline: Building a Better Wall Around Your Name
abstract: Teenage Research Unlimited finds that 12- to 19-year-olds will spend $170 billion in 2002, 1.2 percent less than in 2001; youths continue to shift focus from apparel to electronics; graphs of teenage spending (S)

headline: Iran Forbids Demonstrations Defending a Reformist Scholar
abstract: Iran's National Security Council reportedly bars students from further demonstrations backing Hashem Aghajari, pro-reform scholar sentenced to death, after supreme religious leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei orders review of case; students vow to press their demands through other peaceful means (M)

headline: Glaxo in Talks Over Bayer Unit
abstract: GlaxoSmithKline is negotating taking majority stake in Bayer's pharmaceutical division (M)

headline: World Business Briefing: Asia
abstract: JAPAN: Advertising Merger; JAPAN: Daiei To Sell Restaurants; JAPAN: Car Sales Rise; JAPAN: Bank Holding Company Formed; SOUTH KOREA: More Vehicles Sold; SOUTH KOREA: Energy Venture;.

headline: Movie Studios Provide Link For Internet Downloading
abstract: Five major film studios will begin offering rental feature films that consumers can download from Web site for fee, hoping in this way to protect themselves from rampant online piracy; executives say service, called Movielink, is first significant step toward long-promised bounty of video-on-demand, where anyone with Internet connection can watch any movie ever made whenever they want; key to service is security technology that will prevent movies from being copied and transferred freely over Internet; studios are MGM, Paramount Pictures, Sony Pictures, Warner Brothers and Universal Pictures; Disney and 20th Century Fox considered beginning their own service but abandoned plans after negative signals from antitrust regulators; photo (M)

headline: Compressed Data; Computer Fix Thyself Is Aim of I.B.M. Unit
abstract: IBM launches 'autonomic computing' unit, headed by Alan Ganek, which will seek to develop technology to facilitate and fix corporate data centers automatically (M)

headline: WYETH TO SELL NONPRESCRIPTION VERSION OF CLARITIN
abstract: Wyeth will begin selling nonprescription generic version of Schering-Plough's allergy medication Claritin, which lost its patent protection in Dec (S)

headline: S.E.C. Said to Tell Stewart of Evidence For Civil Complaint
abstract: Martha Stewart has reportedly been told by Securities and Exchange Commission that it has enough evidence to bring civil complaint against her stemming from her sale of nearly 4,000 shares of ImClone Sustems last year; next step is for SEC lawyers to examine formal response filed by Stewart's lawyers and make recommendation to SEC; commission must vote on whether to file complaint and is working with Justice Dept, which may bring criminal action as well; Stewart has been investigated by Congressional committee as well as SEC and Justice Dept for timing of her trading in ImClone; shares of Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia, which have fallen more than 60 percent since her name became linked with ImClone in June, drop 15 percent in after-hours trading after news reports of SEC action (M)

headline: Vodafone Moves to Acquire Control of Cegetel of France
abstract: Vodafone Group offers to buy 85 percent of Cegetel, France's second-largest phone company, that it does not already own for 13 billion euros, or about $12.8 billion; agrees to pay 6.3 billion euros ($6.2 billion) in cash for 26 percent held by BT Group and 15 percent owned by SBC Communications; purchase of those shares would increase Vodafone's stake in Cegetel to 56 percent; Vodafone offers to buy remaining 44 percent stake, held by Vivendi Universal SA, for 6.8 billion euros ($6.7 billion); Vivendi's chief executive Jean-Rene Fourtou has suggested that he might like to take control of Cegetel; photo (M)

headline: RESERVE CALL-UP FOR AN IRAQ WAR MAY EQUAL 1991'S
abstract: Pentagon will mobilize roughly as many reservists as it did during 1991 Persian Gulf war, when approximately 265,000 members of National Guard and Reserves were summoned to action, if Pres Bush orders military action against Iraq; troops would be deployed mainly to protect military bases abroad and at home; would be expected to play important role in protecting array of potential terrorist targets in US, in addition to whatever combat role troops would be assigned; photos (M)

headline: Nasdaq Chairman to Leave at End of 2003
abstract: Nasdaq Stock Market Chairman and Chief Executive Hardwick Simmons plans to leave the second-largest U.S. stock market when his contract expires at the end of 2003.

headline: World Briefing | Ecology: Good News For Sea Horses
abstract: Proposals to protect mahogany forests and sea horses passed, but an effort to further control harvests of the Patagonian toothfish failed at a meeting in Santiago, Chile, attended by the 160 nations that are party to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species. Trade in bigleaf mahogany from Central and South America, where it grows naturally, will be strictly regulated. Trade in plantation-grown mahogany from Indonesia and elsewhere is not affected. Commerce in sea horses, collected for traditional medicine and souvenirs, will be regulated worldwide. But an effort to gain more protection for the toothfish, or Chilean sea bass, failed.   James Gorman (NYT)

headline: A Selective List of Blogs
abstract: Do men’s Weblogs outnumber women’s? Not in this list, at least, drawn from the blogs cited in the accompanying article.

headline: Owner Says Its Deal to Sell Burger King Is Hitting Snags
abstract: Diageo acknowledges that its sale of Burger King to group of investors--Texas Pacific Group, Goldman Sachs & Co and Bain Capital--might be unraveling; Diageo agreed in July to sell restaurant chain for $2.26 billion; analysts expect deal to be completed, though at lower price; photo (M)

headline: I.R.A. Breaks Off All Contact With Disarmament Overseers
abstract: Irish Republican Army says it has broken off all contact with independent panel set up to oversee disarmament of Northern Ireland's paramilitary organizations; says this is in response to suspension of province's fledgling home-rule government by British authorities two weeks ago; accuses British government of imposing 'unacceptable and untenable ultimatums' on IRA while not keeping its own commitments; IRA statement is seen as serious but not irrevocable setback to Northern Irish peace effort; this is second time IRA has stopped cooperating with panel (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Businesses Urge Bush To Reopen Western Ports  Industry groups representing hundreds of businesses have asked President Bush to use his powers to reopen 29 West Coast ports closed in a contract dispute, even as the longshoremen's union canceled a bargaining session. Under the Taft-Hartley Act, the president can order an 80-day injunction against labor disruptions.    In Washington, Ari Fleischer, the White House spokesman, urged the two sides to work with a mediator to resolve their differences and said he was ''not going to speculate what the future may or may not hold.'' [Page A18.]

headline: An A.T.M. for Digital Photos Makes Them Pretty as a Pixel
abstract: In their eternal quest for instant gratification, people have found that digital cameras have certainly helped, by providing electronic copies that can easily be transferred to a computer and e-mailed to friends. Without a photo-quality printer, however, getting a decent hard copy of those photogenic moments can be problematic. Sony hopes to change all that with the PictureStation, which can make getting finished prints as easy as going to an automated teller machine for cash.     The Sony PictureStation even resembles an A.T.M., but instead of an opening for deposit envelopes, the unit has slots that accept popular digital-camera memory cards like Compact Flash, SmartMedia and Memory Stick, plus slots for photos stored on a CD-ROM or diskette. The PictureStation will recognize and display the images on the card or disk and display a preview of each photo on its screen. A touch screen lets you select the pictures you want, the size (3 by 5 inches, 4 by 6, or 5 by 7) and the number of prints. A high-speed digital printer in the unit then creates high-quality prints on the spot, in either matte or glossy finish.

headline: Market Place; Documents Suggest Credit Suisse Linked Banking and Stock Ratings
abstract: Documents obtained by securities regulators show Credit Suisse First Boston used its research analysts' rosy stock ratings to attract investment banking fees from companies hoping to raise money from investors; documents add to evidence that upbeat research reports were crucial sales tool for Wall Street firms interested in generating lucrative investment banking fees from corporations; in July 1999 proposal to Virata, software company interested in selling shares to public, Credit Suisse boasted that it 'stands by its clients' and offered as proof 1998 stock offering by Pilot Network Services; Credit Suisse analysts ranked Pilots shares strong buy immeidately after company's initial offering; prime seeling point in proposal, known on Wall Street as pitch book, was fact that Credit Suisse continued to recommend Pilot shares aggressively to public even after company reported quarterly results that were far below analysts' expectations and its stock had fallen (Market Place column) (M)

headline: Housing Starts Jump 13.3%, Helping Lift The Economy
abstract: Census Bureau reports number of housing starts jumped 13.3 percent in September, biggest increase since 1995, as low interest rates spurred developers to try to satisfy demand; surge reverses three-month streak of declining housing starts that had raised some concern whether homebuilding would continue to add to overall economic activity; builders started construction on homes at annual pace of 1.84 million, highest level since 1986; BankRate.com says average annual interest rate on 30-year fixed mortgage rose to 6.23 percent, from 6.02 percent, over last week; Labor Department reports initial claims for jobless benefits rose to 411,000 last week, from 389,000 previous week; while new claims for unemployment insurance have fallen almost 13 percent since last October, number of people receiving benefits has risen 8 percent, to 3.48 million; Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia survey of executives in Philadelphia area shows that manufacturing activity there decreased more rapidly than it had in nearly year; graphs; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Hungary: Building A Holocaust Museum
abstract: Hungarian Prime Min Peter Medgyessy inaugurates work on Hungary's first Holocaust museum; Budapest museum, dedicated to more than 600,000 Hungarian Jews killed in World War II, will be housed in former synagogue (S)

headline: AtHomeAbroad: U.S. discriminates against retirees abroad
abstract: Regarding "Permanent U.S. expatriates can face hefty liabilities" (Sept. 28-29):

headline: Bond Sales Coming During the Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week included today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and a four-week bill tomorrow.    According to traders, at the close of the New York cash market on Friday the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was at 1.20 percent, the rate on the six-month issue at 1.23 percent and the rate on the four-week issue at 1.20 percent.

headline: RAYTHEON'S CHIEF FINANCIAL OFFICER RESIGNS
abstract: Raytheon Co chief financial officer Frank Caine resigns after Securities and Exchange Commission punished him for selectively disclosing financial data; company names Edward Pliner to succeed him (S)

headline: Russia Taken Off Money Laundering Blacklist
abstract: Russia is released from international blacklist of countries with inadequate monitoring of money-laundering, in move seen in part as political gesture to Pres Vladimir V Putin; Financial Action Task Force on Money Laundering, international agency of 31 member nations, including United States, removes Russia from list of about dozen countries most likely to be havens for criminals and tax dodgers (M)

headline: Pilots Find Themselves Left Up in the Air
abstract: Airline industry has become less friendly place for pilots; factors include decline in passengers attributable to economy, terrorist attacks, increase in competition from smaller, discount airlines, and poor management; at end of Sept 2002, 7,080 pilots were furloughted, about 7.5 percent of pilots with airline jobs in US before terrorist attacks; because pilots are paid for hours they are in cockpit, even some working pilots have seen decrease in their pay as airlines cut flights; photos (Special Section, Working) (M)

headline: Despite Denial, Enron Papers Show Big Profit on Price Bets
abstract: Even as Enron's top executives were insisting that the company did not engage in speculative trading, Enron was reaping the bulk of its profits during the California energy crisis by betting on the direction of gas and electricity prices, according to company records and interviews with former Enron traders and executives.    Enron made the hugely profitable bets -- including one that resulted in a $485 million gain on a single day in December 2000 -- at a time when federal and state investigators say the company was conspiring with other energy trading companies to manipulate power and natural gas prices in the West.

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Cocoa for December delivery falls $201, or 9.5 percent, to $1,910 a metric ton; other commodities indexes noted; graph (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Key Index Falls
abstract: Ifo Institute survey finds that German business confidence is sinking for sixth consecutive month; pessimistic outlook is especially predominant within construction and manufacturing sector, whereas retail sales has improved outlook (S)

headline: Britain Issues File on Iraq's 'Unique Horror'
abstract: Britain releases dossier of evidence arguing that systematic rape, torture, gassing, public beheadings and mass executions of Iraqis by Saddam Hussein are deliberate policy of his 'regime of unique horror'; Foreign Sec Jack Straw asserts that document, which government says is based on intelligence material, first-hand accounts and reports by nongovernmental organizations, sets out powerful human rights case in addition to international security argument for disarming Hussein; photo of antiwar protesters in central London (M)

headline: Opposition Leader Quits in Japan, and a New Party May Result
abstract: Yukio Hatoyama resigns as leader of Japan's largest opposition party, adding to political turmoil; sudden downfall after only three months follows failure to form coalition with Liberals and Democratic Party's poor showing in by-elections (S)

headline: Senate Panel Says Watchdog Missed Many Enron Clues
abstract: Senate Governmental Affairs Committee concludes that Federal Energy Regulatory Commission missed many clues about improper dealings at Enron Corp that could have led to earlier scrutiny of company; finds that FERC is woefully understaffed to monitor trading and transmission of electricity and natural gas; FERC officials dispute many parts of report, especially criticism of its enforcement efforts (M)

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: THE HAGUE: Milosevic Ailing Again; MACEDONIA: Government Includes Ex-Rebels; CZECH REPUBLIC: Post-Havel Plans; BELARUS: New Law Restricts Religions; BULGARIA: Missile Destruction For Nato;.

headline: BMW Starts Reviewing Multicultural Account
abstract: BMW Starts Reviewing Multicultural Account.

headline: Kenya's Porous Border Lies Open to Arms Smugglers
abstract: Kenyan authorities believe surface-to-air rockets fired at Israeli jetliner in Mombasa and possibly bomb that killed 16 people in nearby hotel were smuggled across porous border from lawless state of Somalia; authorities have detained ten men, including four Somalis, caught in boat off coast; historic smuggling routes form 2,000-mile arc from Pakistan down eastern coast of Africa to Comoros Islands; photo; map; Western officials suspect Al Qaeda operatives are using routes to move guns and people through predominantly Muslim areas along coast (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Industrial Output Rises
abstract: India reports industrial output rose 6.2 percent, Oct (S)

headline: Killing Underscores Enmity Of Evangelists and Muslims
abstract: Fellow missionaries eulogize Bonnie Penner Witherall at memorial service in Sidon, Lebanon, where she was fatally shot by gunman at prenatal clinic where she worked; Lebanese authorities are looking at case in context of anti-Americanism raging across Lebanon and much of Middle East, and have yet to make arrest; Wetherall's death exposes new trip wire in Middle East, namely, conflict over renewed effort by evangelical missionaries from US to spread Christian Gospel to Muslims in nation where religious affiliations are more than matter of personal faith since they define political power; photos (M)

headline: Police Official Independent And Known for Bluntness
abstract: When a news conference on last month's attack on a disco in Bali descended into good-natured banter over whether the surprisingly swift progress in the investigation was believable, the chief investigator, Gen. I Made Mangku Pastika, reverted to his favorite, plain-spoken style.     Speaking in Indonesian, he said he was aware that some Indonesian politicians were beginning to snipe at him. Leaning into the microphones, he added in English that he wanted them to ''shut up.''

headline: Results at I.B.M. Defy the Slump in Technology
abstract: IBM reports earnings and revenues that slightly surpass Wall Street's expectations; results provide another sign that company's emphasis on services and software is enabling it to withstand continuing slump in technology spending better than most of its rivals; reports earnings from continuing operations of $1.69 billion; revenue was $19.8 billion and net income was $1.3 billion; chief financial officer John R Joyce comments; stock drops $3.58, to $64.90; photo (M)

headline: Showing 'Talons of the Dove,' Powell Presses for Compliance by Iraqis
abstract: Sec Colin L Powell's known determination to exhaust all diplomatic options before resorting to force makes more significant his warning that Iraqnears loss of its last chance to avoid war; Powell is reassuring in his insistence that Pres Bush is committed to giving arms inspectors chance to produce disarmament results (M)o

headline: Independent Directors, Whatever They Are
abstract: DIARY Independent Directors, Whatever They Are  Portfolio managers and analysts at financial institutions say a majority of a company's directors should be independent, but they don't agree on how to ensure that independence, a survey has found.

headline: World Briefing: Africa
abstract: ZIMBABWE: Warning On Food Shortages; SOUTH AFRICA: Searching For White Militants;.

headline: At Home Abroad / Third Culture Kids : Often more accomplished, but sometimes more troubled
abstract: VIENNA—  Dragan Majetic feels gifted to have been raised abroad. His childhood in India, Africa and Japan opened doors to a world of excitement and opportunity out of reach to his peers back home in Belgrade. But sometimes Majetic wonders at the settled lives of those who stayed behind when his diplomat parents took him along for the ride. Would he have been happier if he had stayed home?

headline: The Old Computer: Upgrade or Retire?
abstract: Performance of sluggish computers can often be improved by replacing hardware components or installing software designed to upgrade system capabilities; but costs, difficulties and limitations of refurbishing older models sometimes makes purchase of new computer most sensible option; drawing (M)

headline: World Briefing: Asia
abstract: CHINA: 4 Christians Sent To Labor Camp; JAPAN: Death Sentence For Nerve Gas Attack;.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Business Confidence Falls
abstract: World Business Briefing: Germany: Business Confidencÿ

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: I.B.M. Executive Takes On Additional Role
abstract: IBM Corp's chief executive Samuel J Palmisano will assume added role of chairman from Louis V Gerstner, who will retire at end of year (S)

headline: Former Hostage Taker Now Likes to Take On the Mullahs
abstract: Muhammad Ibrahim Asgharzadeh, onetime militant Muslim activist in Iran who 23 years ago was an organizer of assault on American Embassy n Tehran, taking dozens of diplomats hostage for 444 days, now leads reformist party and advocates improved relations with United States; photos (L)

headline: Korean Protesters Break Into Big U.S. Army Base
abstract: More than 50 protesters broke through a chain link fence today surrounding a strategic American military post.

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Loudeye And Amazon Reach Deal On Music Samples
abstract: Loudeye Corp reaches agreement with Amazon.com to provide music samples on Amazon's popular retail site (S)

headline: German Court Blocks Law For Foreigners With Skills
abstract: German high court blocks new law that would have opened door to more skilled foreign workers, finding it was enacted improperly; ruling reopens anguished debate on immigration and sets back efforts by German industries to replenish aging labor force (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Norway: Rate Cut
abstract: Norway's central bank unexpectedly cuts borrowing costs by half a percentage point: deposit rate is now 6.5 percent and overnight lending rate is now 8.5 percent; expects consumer spending to drop (S)

headline: Investing; Office Furniture Stocks Take a Seat and Wait
abstract: Waves of corporate layoffs leaves many companies with more furniture than employees, causing sales of office furniture to drop sharply in last two years; stocks of its two largest makers -- Herman Miller and Steelcase -- fall more than 40 percent (M)

headline: Technology Briefing: Hardware
abstract: I.B.M. PLANS TO INCREASE SALES TO SMALL BUSINESSES; CORPORATE STOCK HAS CRITICAL ROLE AT CISCO;.

headline: Technology Briefing: Software
abstract: ELECTRONIC ARTS EARNINGS EXCEED EXPECTATIONS; ADOBE TO DISMISS 7.4% OF WORK FORCE;.

headline: Amnesty Accuses Israeli Forces of War Crimes
abstract: Amnesty International contends that Israeli forces committed war crimes in Jenin and Nablus during large-scale offensive against Palestinian terrorists in West Bank; incidents recounted (M)

headline: Kyrgyzstan And Russia Sign New Pact
abstract: Russian Pres Vladimir Putin, visiting Bishkek as part of Asian tour, signs new security pact with Kyrgyzstan; Russian air squadron and up to 1,000 Russian troops will be based by end of year in Kyrgyzstan as part of new rapid-reaction force (M)

headline: British Judges Criticize U.S. on the Prisoners Held at Guantánamo
abstract: Three-judge British panel, ruling in case brought by mother of Feroz Abassi, British subject detained at Guantanamo Bay, scores United States' indefinite detention of prisoners from Afghanistan there without access to legal appeal as violation of both international law and concept of habeas corpus; admits it has little power in case, but seems to be sending message to US appeals court that weighs same issue (M)

headline: Wind Turbines Are Sprouting Off Europe's Shores
abstract: Hundreds of high-powered wind turbines are being planned or are under construction off coast of Northern Europe, where winds blow harder and more steadily than on land and where turbines' noise is barely audible; Europe, which has capacity of more than 20,000 megawatts of wind-driven energy installed on land, hopes to raise this to 60,000 megawatts in next six years, much of that growth coming from sea-based turbines; some environmental groups welcome wind turbines as renwable source of pollution-free energy, while others fear offshore turbines will disturb fishing and spawning grounds and endanger flocks of birds that migrate at night; photo; map (M)

headline: PUBLISHER IS APPOINTED AT TV GUIDE MAGAZINE
abstract: Gemstar-TV Guide International names J Scott Crystal publisher of TV Guide (S)

headline: Poultry Farm Settles Suit
abstract: MILWAUKEE, Sept. 30 (Bloomberg News) — DeCoster Farms, a poultry and egg processor in Iowa, has agreed to pay $1.53 million to settle government allegations that migrant employees were raped or harassed by supervisors. Some of the money will go to women who said they were sexually assaulted or harassed by supervisors at the company's poultry and egg farm in Clarion, Iowa, about 80 miles north of Des Moines. DeCoster Farms did not admit liability, and the supervisors have been fired for unrelated reasons, said the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, which filed the suit.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: U.S. Drug Approval
abstract: Ranbaxy Laboratories wins FDA approval to sell its version of Roche Holding's acne drug, Accutane, in United States; graph (S)

headline: Nationalist Parties Set to Regain Power in Bosnia
abstract: Three nationalist parties that led Bosnia into war 10 years ago are poised to regain power after winning most votes in elections on October 5, despite international efforts to marginalize them; Muslim hard-liners make biggest gains as almost half of electorate stayed home (S)

headline: Alligators Below City? Try Robo-Inchworms
abstract: Honeybee Robotics, based in Manhattan's Little Italy, makes welding robots and drilling robots, and it clients include Consolidated Edison and NASA, for which it is making drilling system for investigating Mars (S)

headline: Caveats in Coin Collecting
abstract: Greg Donio letter on Oct 27 article that described recent developments in quantifying transactions of coin collecting

abstract: E.U. TO MOVE MEETING SO MUGABE CAN ATTEND; RUSSIA: Copter Crash Ascribed To Chechen Rebels; BOSNIA AND HERZEGOVINA: 7th Mass Grave; GERMANY: School Hostage Siege Ends; GERMANY: Riefenstahl Inquiry Called Off; BRITAIN: Firefighters Vote To Strike; ROMANIA: War Of The Words;.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: New Bank Governor
abstract: World Business Briefing: Britain:1

headline: With Earnings, It's Not Just the Quantity but the Quality
abstract: Gretchen Morgenson column on Ramu Thiagarajan, Mellon Capital Management director of investment research and active strategies, who is obsessive in scrutinizing company reports for warning signals of potential problems and believes that avoiding disasters in this way can produce better investment returns than trying to pick big winning stocks; he suggests several vulnerable and some strong stock issues; table (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Sun Microsystems' Credit Rating Lowered
abstract: Sun Microsystems Inc's credit rating is reduced by Standard & Poor's on concern about weak demand for company's products, including server computers that run business networks and Web sites (S)

headline: Dozens Die in Attack on Chechen Government Headquarters
abstract: At least 46 people were killed today when two explosives-laden vehicles were driven into the main government office in Grozny.

headline: Ulster Leader Urges Blair to Oust Sinn Fein From Parliament
abstract: LONDON, Oct. 8 — David Trimble, the first minister of the Northern Ireland Assembly, called on Prime Minister Tony Blair today to evict Sinn Fein, the political party of the Irish Republican Army, from the power-sharing government in Belfast that he heads.

headline: World Business Briefing: Asia
abstract: TAIWAN: Infineon Ends Venture; JAPAN: A Toyota Recall In Europe;.

headline: HANOVER COMPRESSOR SAYS IT WILL TRIM 500 JOBS
abstract: Hanover Compressor, which provides equipment and s6

headline: French Union Members Protest Plan to Sell State-Owned Utilities
abstract: Tens of thousands of transportation, utility and postal workers march through Paris demanding that Prime Min Jean-Pierre Raffarin abandon plans to sell state-owned gas and electricity utilities to replenish government's coffers; Raffarin is trying to fulfill campaign pledge for more spending on domestic issues while dealing with eroding tax revenues and higher costs for unemployment benefits as result of economic slowdown; predecessor Lionel Jospin sold millions of dollars of shares in state-owned industries to replenish state treasury, but that was at time when economy was strong and stock markets were booming (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Protests On Revolution's Anniversary
abstract: Eighty-fifth anniversary of revolution which brought Communists to power is celebrated by approximately 5,000 people in Moscow and tens of thousands more across Russia; Communist leader Gennadi Zyuganov scolds Pres Vladimir V Putin and calls for him to resign; photo (S)

headline: LEFTIST CANDIDATE TAKES A FIRM LEAD IN BRAZIL ELECTION
abstract: Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva, leftist candidate, surges to emphatic lead in Brazil's presidential election but still appears unlikely to obtain majority needed to avoid runoff; has slightly under 47 percent of vote, with 80 percent of precincts counted; incumbent centrist Jose Serra is running distant second, with less than 24 percent of vote; other candidates account for 29 percent; stalled economy is major issue among voters; photos (M)

headline: Chechen Fugitive on His Way to Britain
abstract: Akhmed Zakayev, senior Chechen representative at center of angry extradition dispute between Russian and Danish officials, leaves Denmark for Britain, raising prospect of similar dispute with British authorities (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: HYUNDAI PARTS SUPPLIER TO OPEN FIRST AMERICAN PLANT
abstract: Hyundai Mobis plans to construct auto-parts plant in Montgomery, Ala, close to a Hyundai Motor factory that will open in tandem with it in 2005 (S)

headline: G.M. to Offer Hybrid Power In 5 Models By 2007
abstract: General Motors, which has been most reticent major carmaker when it comes to prospects for hybrid vehicles, intends to offer some form of hybrid electric power on five of its major models over next four production year; plan is surprising endorsement of fledgling hybrid technology, which improves gasoline mileage by supplementing internal combustion engine with electric power (M)

headline: MOODY'S CUTS RATING OF CABLE AND WIRELESS TO JUNK
abstract: Moody's Investors Service cuts long-term debt rating of Cable and Wireless two levels to junk, on concern that company will spend too much to reorganize its biggest unit (S)

headline: Japan Has No Shortage of Advice on Banks' Woes
abstract: Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development and International Monetary Fund are offering advice on Japan's bank problems; OECD recently said Japan's banks need more taxpayer money to survive; IMF is in middle of yearlong inspection of banks that some hope will shed light on problem of bad loans; former IMF economist Sayuri Shirai says report, scheduled for next summer, will prove that several banks do not meet international capital standards (M)

headline: U.N. Official and 3 Others Killed in Mideast Violence
