abstract: At least four people including a U.N. official were killed today following outbursts of violence in the West Bank and Gaza.

headline: Business; Mad Money Galore: A Cash Cow of a Play
abstract: Profile of Cranberry Productions, whose sole play, Shear Madness, about murder in beauty parlor, has had 24 domestic and 22 foreign productions -- none of them in New York -- and grossed $112 million; Marilyn Abrams and Bruce Jordan, who own Cranberry, paid $50,000 for rights to serious German play by Paul Portner and made it a comedy; photo (M)

headline: A Tough-Sounding Blair Intervenes in Firefighters' Strike
abstract: Prime Minister Tony Blair said he would not endorse a pay raise unless the firefighters radically overhaul the way they work.

headline: World Business Briefing: Europe
abstract: BRITAIN: Insurer Names Executive; BRITAIN: Football Chief In New Field; ITALY: Gucci'S Profit Falls; ITALY: Ruling On Insurance Stakes; FRANCE: Alcatel Revamping; THE NETHERLANDS: Drug Ruling;.

headline: Credit Terms Reflect Weakness at ABB
abstract: ABB, troubled Swiss industrial equipment maker, discloses terms of its latest revolving-credit agreement with lenders; pledges assets to secure $1.5 billion credit line for first time in its history; agrees to pay interest rate one percentage point higher than before even with collateral; photo (M)/

headline: Earnings Reports Ignite Rally and Stocks Gain More Than 4.5%
abstract: Stock prices surged today as investors celebrated upbeat earnings reports from two of the nation's largest financial institutions.

headline: World Briefing: Africa
abstract: SENEGAL: Embassy Takeover; LIBERIA: Inmates To Go Free;.

headline: Neat Trick: Dividends Higher Than Profits
abstract: IT'S not every company that can report a large quarterly loss at the same time it raises its dividend. Nor is it every company that can pay out more in dividends than it makes in profits.    But American Capital Strategies has managed to do just that. It brings in cash by repeatedly selling new shares to the public, with three offerings in the last year. The prices of those offerings have declined of late, but thanks to the high dividend they have always been higher than the company figures its assets are worth.

headline: AtHomeAbroad: Unfamiliar laws can make expats especially vulnerable
abstract: VIENNA—  When Sylvia met her future husband, she was "swept off her feet." A native of Italy, she happily emigrated to her husband's home country of Austria, where she learned the language and tried to fit in. When her daughter was born, she registered her as an Austrian citizen.

headline: STOCK OF HIGH-TECH ID COMPANY GAINS ON U.S. CONTRACT
abstract: Indentix, maker of face- and fingerprint-identification devices, says that Defense Dept will buy 450 fingerprint readers, setting off nearly 15 percent gain in share price (S)

headline: Jewish Groups Want a Teenager's Novel Withdrawn in France
abstract: Jewish orgns call on French government to order withdrawal from circulation of novel written by Italian-born teenager of Egyptian extraction, arguing that it promotes anti-Semitism and hate and glorifies Palestinian suicide bombers who attack Israelis; book, Dream of Palestine, is by Randa Ghazy, who is 15; Ghazy, who lives near Milan, has never lived in Palestine (M)

headline: After Setbacks, John Hancock Will Sell Boston Headquarters
abstract: Life insurer John Hancock Financial Services will sell its landmark tower in Boston and two other headquarters buildings after suffering investment losses reported at $241 million so far in 2002 (M)

headline: Thwarted Hijacker Sought Crash in Tel Aviv, Turks Say
abstract: Turkish police say Tawfik Fukra, Arab Israeli charged with trying to hijack El Al airliner, said he was inspired by Sept 11 terrorism in United States and planned to crash plane into tall Tel Aviv buildings; Fukra allegedly pulled knife aboard flight from Tel Aviv to Istanbul and tried to force his way into pilots' cabin; was tackled by air marshals; photo (M)

headline: Iranian Student Protesters Call Referendum on Hard-Line Rulers
abstract: Iranian student protesters react defiantly to arrest of four of their leaders, saying they will hold referendum measuring popularity of clerical government in at least 14 Tehran universities; four have been freed, but ordered to appear in court on charges of acting against national security and insulting nation's leaders; hard-line militia forces, spurred by supreme religious leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, have staged rallies and clashed with pro-democracy demonstrators (M)

headline: NOVARTIS GAINS APPROVAL FOR USE OF LEUKEMIA DRUG
abstract: Novartis wins approval to sell its cancer drug Gleevec in United States as first treatment doctors should try for patients with chronic myeloid leukemia (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: China: Inquiry Into Tycoon Hired By North Korea
abstract: China confirms investigation of Yang Bin, head of new capitalist economic zone in North Korea, for suspected 'illegal activities'; photo (S)

headline: A 16-Year Slump? If So, Blame It on the Boomers
abstract: Mark Hulbert Strategies column on new study of American demographic patterns and stock market that predicts that, despite intermittent rallies, overall market direction will be downward until about 2018; prediction is based on finding that overall market's price-to-earnings ratio is likely to fall as ratio of number of middle-aged people to number of young adults in population falls, as it is expected to do until 2018; graphs of both ratios (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Banks Report Losses
abstract: TD Bank Financial Group reports loss of 219 million Canadian dollars ($139.3 million) in fiscal fourth quarter ended Oct 31 compared to profit of 203 million Canadian dollars year earlier; reports loss of 160 million Canadian dollars for fiscal year; Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce reports fourth-quarter loss of 100 million Canadian dollars ($63.6 million) compared to earnings of 242 million Canadian dollars year ago; earnings dropped 60 percent, to 654 million Canadian dollars for year (S)

headline: People and Accounts of Note
abstract: Carleton Prince was named to the new post of group president for the Western region at the San Francisco office of Aspen Marketing Services. He had been president at the San Francisco office of Frankel, part of the Publicis Groupe.

headline: AARP Is Seeking Agency for Program
abstract: AARP is beginning review for agency to handle direct marketing and advertising for supplemental health insurance programs it offers to members; ad spending estimated at $25 million out of total annual marketing budget of $100 million; review will include incumbent agency Marsh Affinity Group (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Charge At Lloyds
abstract: Lloyds TSB Group expects to take charge for bad loans and insurance liabilities related to its Abbey Life unit, which is fined 1 million lbs ($1.6 million) by regulators for improperly selling mortgage policies (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Nortel To Sell Unit To Bookham
abstract: Nortel Networks is selling operations that produce optical components for $108 million to Bookham Technology (S)

headline: SLACK DEMAND HURTS MARTIN MARIETTA MATERIALS PROFIT
abstract: Martin Marietta Materials, supplier of building aggregates, says third-quarter profit fell to about 80 cents a share, below its earlier forecast of 95 cents a share (M)

headline: Daily Frustrations Grow for United's Workers
abstract: Thousands of United Airlines employees, some 81,000 around world, are bracing for worst with bankruptcy filing looming after federal government's rejection of United's application for $1.8 billion loan guarantee; airline is expected to continue to operate even if it files for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection from its creditors, but there could be lost jobs and health benefits, more pilot furloughs and legion of shattered careers; some employees comment; chart; photo (M)

headline: Iraq Arms Quest Uncovers a Zest for Drink
abstract: Customers at Tiger Eye liquor store in Baghdad react jokingly to visit by United Nations weapons inspectors to three gin factories outside city in search of nuclear bombs; drinking alcohol in public has been banned since government's 1996 faith campaign, bars and pubs have been closed, Iraqis now drink at home or furtively in restaurants and nightclubs but liquor shop business is booming; photos (M)

headline: Economic Scene; Even without law, contracts have a way of being enforced.
abstract: Virginia Postrel Economic Scene column on origins of contract law and how contracts have way of being enforced even without law; cites Stanford University historian Avner Greif's paper on how merchants in late Middle Ages developed institutions that allowed commercial revolution and who community responsibility system was developed, in which every member of community was liable for every other ember's debt; says University of California Prof Oliver E Williamson's theory called 'lens of contract,' which focuses predominantly on gains from trade whereas orthodoxy is focused on resource allocation (prices and output); holds to 'science of choice' developed by traditional economics, new institutional economics adds 'science of contract'; photo (M)

headline: PFIZER IS BUYING RIGHTS TO EXPERIMENTAL INSOMNIA DRUG
abstract: Pfizer agrees to pay Neurocrine Biosciences as much as $400 million for rights to experimental insomnia drug indiplon (S)

headline: TXU Europe at Risk of Losing Cash Infusion
abstract: TXU will likely withdraw $700 million capital infusion it promised to its troubled European subsidiary TXU Europe, which would then have to restructure and divest to remain financially solvent; TXU Europe suffers from collapse of British electricity prices; Standard & Poor's recently cut TXU Europe's credit rating (M)

headline: Fees Hidden in Plain Sight, Companies Add to Bottom Line
abstract: Hotels, phone companies, theaters and wide array of companies are adding new surcharges to all kinds of services and products as they try to compensate for sputtering economy; in some cases, surcharges are paid only by customers actually using specific services but others are being added across-the-board as way to increase revenue (M)

headline: Air Force May Cut Order for Lockheed Fighters
abstract: Edward Aldridge, Defense Department's top acquisition official, says Air Force may further cut its order for Lockheed Martin F/A-22 fighter to pay for projected $690 million cost overrun in program; projected overrun is about 3.3 percent of program's $20 billion development phase; Pentagon has spent $26 billion of $69 billion planned for program, which 10 years ago called for 750 planes; it now calls for 295, and Pentagon was considering cutting that to 180 before this latest overrun was projected (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Norway: Oil Fleet Acquired
abstract: Norwegian oil company Statoil agrees to sell its Navion shipping unit to Teekay Shipping Corp for about 6 billion kroner ($841 million); acquisition will more than double size of Teekay's tanker fleet (S)

headline: Strong Dollar Runs Into Renewed Resistance
abstract: United States trade deficit surges in August to record $38.5 billion, far beyond economists' expectations; strong dollar severely constrains exports of US goods and lowers prices of imports; persistent slump in domestic production prompts strident protests from manufacturers against dollar's continued strength; government officials proclaim their belief that market forces should determine currency exchange rates; robust consumer spending, low inflation rate and continued foreign investment in US are results of dollar's continuing strength; photos; graphs (M)

headline: Saudis Seize Kuwaiti In Shooting of G.I.'s, Who Are Recovering
abstract: The police here arrested a Kuwaiti policeman accused of shooting two American soldiers and said they planned to hand him over to Kuwait, the Saudi authorities said today.    In a separate incident, the official Saudi Press Agency reported that an armed man set fire to a McDonald's restaurant on Wednesday near the Prince Sultan Air Base, where more than 4,000 American troops are stationed. The Saudi interior minister, Prince Nayef bin Abdel Aziz, was quoted as saying that the government would compensate the restaurant for its loss.

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Britain To Provide More High-Speed Web Access
abstract: British government will spend more than $1.6 billion to provide high-speed Internet access to schools, hospitals, police departments and other public services (S)

headline: F.C.C. Says EchoStar-DirecTV Vote Is Near
abstract: Federal Communications Commission is close to vote on proposal by EchoStar Communications to purchase satellite television rival DirecTV for $23 billion (M)

headline: State Street: In Transition for Years
abstract: Article on transformation of State Street in Chicago's Loop area from city's retail hub into mixed-use avenue of stores, theaters and educational sites; office projects under way include Dearborn Center and Sullivan Center (M)

headline: Indonesian Finance Chief Warns Of Need for More Foreign Aid
abstract: Indonesian Finance Min Boediono warns that deadly bomb blast in Bali will force Indonesian government deeper into debt, raising cost to international community of keeping country afloat; Indonesia relied on foreign aid to recover from Asian financial crisis of 1997 and 1998; in addition to $5 billion economic rescue package administered by International Monetary Fund, it counts on billions of dollars a year in deficit financing from international donors, including World Bank, US and Japan (M)

headline: Compressed Data; The Gap Appears on Amazon, but Without Reviews
abstract: People in Amazon.com's new apparel department can use Amazon's shopping tools, like customer reviews, at dozens of retailers, but Amazon reluctantly agreed to disable reviews for Gap in order to get Gap to validate Amazon's apparel efforts; photo (M)

headline: Sun Reports Circulation
abstract: New York City's fledgling weekday newspaper New York Sun has sales confirmed by Audit Bureau of Circulations averaging just under 18,000 daily for its first six months of publication; price reduction from 50 cents to 25 cents per issue appears to be aiding growth in circulation (S)

headline: UBS Copes With Legacy Of Enron
abstract: Drastic contraction throughout energy trading industry causes investment bank UBS Warburg's eight-month-old acquisition of Enron Corp's trading division to markedly underperform expectations; criminal charges against both former Enron employees and those who remained after UBS takeover further dampen prospects for achievement of UBS' projected profits; continuing investigation is likely to reveal that much of Enron's last five years of 'successful' operations were fictional; photos (M)

headline: G.I.'S HONE SKILLS ON IRAQ'S BORDER
abstract: US Army has quietly doubled number of troops in Kuwait and is practicing offensive operations close to Iraqi border; exercises involve Army engineers trained to blow paths through mine fields, infantry troops conducting mock assaults and howitzers and helicopters blasting targets at test ranges identical to deserts of Iraq; Army has quietly doubled force in Kuwait to about 9,000 troops; photos from Camp New York; Lt Gen David McKiernan notes that US military has ten years of experience working in desert terrain weather (M)

headline: 'Girls Club' Makes Swift Exit, Dimming Creator's Golden Aura
abstract: Fox television network cancels David E Kelley's program Girls Club after second week of disastrously low ratings; canceling show from Kelley is especially significant because he has contract to develop shows for Fox's affiliated studio 20th Century Fox Television, owned by News Corp; photo (M)

headline: Bribery Inquiry Involves Kazakh Chief, and He's Unhappy
abstract: Kazakhstan quietly presses to exempt Pres Nursultan Nazarbayev from Justice Department probe of American oil companies that allegedly gave him large bribes to win oil concessions in 1990's; Bush administration officials have rebuffed effort, despite attempts by Nazarbayev and his representatives to raise issue with Vice Pres Dick Cheney and other senior officials; companies have denied wrongdoing, insisting all payments were made to Kazakh government; map; photos (M)

headline: This Time, Networks Hope To Get the Elections Right
abstract: Broadcast and cable news networks, facing intense scrutiny after mistakenly calling 2000 presidential election, seek to avoid similar mishap in their coverage of coming national elections; plan to expose their behind-the-scenes operations to audience in order to shore up their credibility; refurbishment of network's jointly run election-tallying system -- Voter News Service -- is behind schedule and may not be ready by Election Day (M)

headline: Profit Up 23% At Wal-Mart; Others Gain
abstract: Wal-Mart Stores reports 23 percent increase in fiscal third-quarter net income, to $1.82 billion, or 41 cents a share; revenue increased 11 percent, to $58.8 billion; Federated Department Stores reports earnings rose to $106 million, or 54 cents a share, in period ended Nov 2, from $3 million year earlier; sales gained less than 1 percent, to $3.48 billion; Federated anticipates declining sales in period ahead; Tiffany & Co reports fiscal third-quarter profit rose to $35.2 million, or 24 cents a share, from $24 million, or 16 cents a share, year earlier; revenue gained 9.9 percent, to $366 million; Tiffany reduced its fourth-quarter profit and sales forecasts; photo (M)

headline: 'NOT ENCOURAGING,' BUSH SAYS OF IRAQ ON ARMS DEMANDS
abstract: Pres Bush demands that Saddam Hussein include every detail of Iraq's weapons and missile programs in declaration due at UN on Dec 8, saying Hussein's cooperation is 'not encouraging' so far; says he will consider any 'delay, deception or defiance' as evidence that Hussein is rejecting path of peace; appears to be setting up Dec 8 deadline as crucial measure of Iraqi cooperation, but stops short of declaring that incomplete declaration on Dec 8 would constitute cause for war; officials say Pentagon is not yet ready to fight in Iraq; Bush administration has not revealed intelligence it has collected about Iraq's activities, hoping to leave Hussein guessing how much US knows; Bush may decide to offer up evidence that contradicts Iraqi declaration or points out major omissions; some officials say inspections are unlikely to succeed unless there are defections by Iraqi scientists who have knowledge of where weapons or development laboratories are hidden; Bush's speech, together with similar one delivered by Vice Pres Dick Cheney, mark opening of White House campaign to shift public attention from what inspectors may or may not find to United Nations' demand that Hussein come clean about his weapons programs; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Africa: Lesotho: Bribery Penalty
abstract: World Business

headline: Perils of Migration: 2 Ghanaian Boys Die as Flight Stowaways
abstract: Two Ghanaian boys dressed in clothes for heat of Africa are found dead in undercarriage of Ghana Airways DC-10 airliner that lands in wintry London; deaths underscore pressures and desperation that drive people from poor and troubled lands to seek new lives in wealthy Europe; photos (M)

headline: U.S. Army Finds Allies In the U.S. Air Force
abstract: Reporter's Notebook on Gen Richard B Myers's visit to US air base in Kuwait; AH-64 Apache gunship, Army's main attack helicopter, and Air Force's RQ-1 Predator, propeller-driven robot plane that looks like upside-down spoon, could form deadly new tandem in US-led war in Iraq; Myers visit focuses on morale of US forces in region (S)

headline: Japanese Minister Pushes, And the Banks Push Back
abstract: Japanese bankers are digging in to oppose efforts by Heizo Takenaka, new chief financial regulator, to force faster resolution of country's bad-loan crisis; Takenaka has frigtened banks with hard-boiled talk of forcing them to move rapidly in writing off more than $400 million in nonperforming loans on their books; write-offs on that scale would wipe out so much of banks' capital that analysts say many of them would need infusions of tax money to remain solvent; bankers' allies in ruling Liberal Democratic Party also oppose Takenaka's calls for stricter assessment of banks' loan portfolios; banks have been extremely slow in acknowledging that their loans are in trouble; Bank of Japan, Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development and Japan's largest business lobby back Takenaka's efforts; photo (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: AMERICAN MANAGEMENT SYSTEMS INC., Fairfax, Va., a technology consultant to government agencies, won a seven-year, $156 million contract to run the parking violation computer system of New York City, which issues nine million tickets annually.

headline: Insurance; Quick Passage Of Terrorism Bill
abstract: Insurance executives believe that Republican control of Senate offers improved chance to gain government-backed terrorism-insurance program they have called for since 2001 attacks on World Trade Center and Pentagon (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Marconi Plan Advances
abstract: British telecommunications equipment maker Marconi revises its revamping plan to include deeper cost-saving measures and improved payments to creditors; new plan will reduce Marconi's debt by $318 million (S)

headline: Executive's Job At Walt Disney May Change
abstract: Thomas Schumacher, president of Walt Disney animation division, whose contract expires in June 2003, expresses interest in moving to East Coast to help Disney's Broadway theater business grow; photo (M)

headline: TECHNOLOGY: Gazing Into 2003: Economy Intrudes on Dreams of New Services -- Copyrights; A Call for Partnership, A Hint of Regulation
abstract: Television and movie executives urge solidarity against digital copyright infringers; as television and movies increasingly take digital form, Hollywood is worried that availability of unauthorized, perfect copies online will significantly damage its bottom line; if Silicon Valley executives do not voluntarily heed Hollywood's call to partnership, strong entertainment lobby is pushing federal government to require them to do so; photo (M)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY  Existing-Home Sales -- Oct.    TUESDAY  G.D.P. 3rd Qtr. revised  New-Home Sales -- Oct.  Prices of New Homes -- Oct.  Consumer Confidence -- Nov.

headline: Turkey Waits and Wonders: How Closely Bound to Islam Is Election Victor?
abstract: Voters in Turkey, nation proud of its religious moderation, showed willingness to take risk for broader political change by giving Recep Tayyip Erdogan's party enough seats in Parliament to form government on its own; Erdogan has been quoted as supporting Islamic law, Shariah, and saying that democracy was merely 'means to an end'; many in Turkey and in Western world wary of Islamic radicalism after Sept 11 say he must prove that he has changed, as he says; many who know him or have followed his career say he has either given up his more strident views or understands now that he is unlikely to hold onto power if he acts on them; some say he has always been more pragmatist and populist than Islamist; photo (M)

headline: Conseco Makes Chapter 11 Filing
abstract: Insurance and finance company Conseco Inc files for bankruptcy protection to stem mounting losses and restructure more than $6 billion in debt; case is third-largest such filing on record (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Insurer Names Executive
abstract: Swiss Re names John Coomber, a Briton, to replace Walter Kieholz as its chief executive (S)

headline: CONSECO SAYS TALKS MAY LEAD TO BANKRUPTCY FILING
abstract: Conseco says talks with creditors to rework more than $6 billion in debt might lead to Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing; posts $1.8 billion third-quarter loss (S)

headline: Fiery Zealotry Leaves Nigeria in Ashes Again
abstract: Nigerian Pres Olusegun Obasanjo visits Kaduna in wake of clashes between Muslims and Christians; visits riot victims; religious strife, which has erupted with some regularity in region, is not likely to end with decision to move Miss World beauty contest from Abuja to London; map; photos (M)

headline: Older Voters Hear More Than War Drums
abstract: Fred Brock column contends that despite scant news coverage, economic and social issues dominate older voters' thinking about many coming election races around nation (M)

headline: Illusion and Disillusion: Chechen Crisis Comes Home for Putin
abstract: Analysis of Chechen crisis that is enveloping Moscow with seizure of theater and hundreds of spectators and actors within; Pres Valdimir V Putin rose to power after sending Russian Army into battle with Chechen separatists, and he has several times declared that battle is all but won; Chechen separatists have now made it clear that war not only continues, but could become far worse; they have also made it clear that war can touch civilians as well as soldiers, and kill hundreds in one stroke; map; highlights of Chechen resistance since 1990 (M)

headline: Tyco Is Said to Consider Renomination of 2 Directors
abstract: Board of Tyco International considers whether to renominate two directors, Lord Ashcroft and Richard S Bodman, who planned to step down yet may be privately lobbying to remain; board's reversed stance comes in wake of fraud charges filed against company's two top executives; Ashcroft and Bodman suggest that they could help with board's continuity; their effect on building public confidence in company is not clear (M)

headline: Big luxury labels are losing cachet
abstract: LONDON—  It used to be that fashion buyers could carry on like Texan businessmen on a Las Vegas weekend. Their idea of a buying appointment would be to slap down $35,000 on Armani (or the label of the day) as if they were putting stacks of chips on black, which given the limited color palette of the early '90s was often quite literally the case.

headline: Witnesses Describe Their Glimpses of Suspects in Attacks in Kenya
abstract: Witnesses in Mombasa, Kenya, describe glimpses of suicide bombers who attacked Israeli-owned hotel and three men who fled airport shortly after two surface-to-air missiles narrowly missed Israeli airliner; local investigators resent bid by Israeli investigators to send some evidence to Israel for further testing; some Israeli investigators are chafing at laid-back manner of Kenyan counterparts; Min Julius Sunkuli welcomes Israeli and American aid with high-tech equipment, but says Kenyans can crack case themselves; photos (M)

headline: Bush, at NATO Meeting, Firms Up His 'Posse'
abstract: Pres Bush, lining up NATO support against Iraq, tells Czech Pres Vaclav Havel in Prague that, contrary to his image as 'Texan with two guns,' he is 'more comfortable with a posse'; photo shaking hands with German Chancellor Gerhard Schroder, whom he has frozen out for weeks; Bush also works room of 18 European leaders before opening of NATO summit, seeming at ease in one-on-one meetings and not living up to his reputation as know-nothing lone ranger, even though he will never have Bill Clinton's style of talking for hours on breadth of subjects (M)

headline: MERCK EXPECTS HIGHER SALES AND EARNINGS IN 2003
abstract: Drug maker Merck expects higher earnings next year, helped by sales of bone-building medicine Fosamax and asthma treatment Singulair (S)

headline: Iraq Insists U.S. Experts Are Rushing To Judgment
abstract: Iraqi Gen Amir al-Saadi, apparently seeking to play down any criticism that emerged from United Nations chief arms inspector Hans Blix's report, holds politicians in United States and Britain are making false statements without giving scientists time to properly evaluate Iraq's lengthy declaration of its weapons programs; says Iraq awaits assessment by specialists, not politicians (M)

headline: How Will S. Korea’s Elections Shape Its Policy on N. Korea?
abstract: COUNCIL ON FOREIGN RELATIONS, December 2002 - Why has North Korea escalated its nuclear program?

headline: Toys 'R' Us Shares Rise as Loss Narrows
abstract: Shares in Toys 'R' Us surge more than 20 percent as company reports that its third-quarter loss narrowed to $28 million, better than forecast (S)

headline: The Week's Economic Events
abstract: MONDAYNone.

headline: Word by Word: Hu's Goals
abstract: Transcript of statement by Hu Jintao, new geneal secretary of Communist Party of Chna, as members of new Standing Committee of Politburo are introduced to reporters

headline: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Angiotech To Buy Cohesion For $42 Million
abstract: Angiotech Pharmaceuticals agreed yesterday to buy Cohesion Technologies, a maker of surgical sealants and products, for about $42 million in stock. Shares of Cohesion surged as much as 66 percent. Angiotech said it would pay $4.05 a share for Cohesion, which is 80 percent more than Cohesion's closing stock price on Friday of $2.25. As part of the acquisition, Angiotech, which is based in Vancouver, British Columbia, will gain a 40 percent stake in Neucoll, a provider of biomaterial products, based in Campbell, Calif. Cohesion is a developer of products used in biosurgery, including CoStasis, used in controlling surgical bleeding. Shares of Cohesion, based in Palo Alto, Calif., rose $1.43, to $3.68. Angiotech shares fell 25 cents, to $39.58. They had dropped 29 percent this year.

headline: MAYTAG SHARES RISE AFTER 2003 PROFIT FORECAST
abstract: Shares of Maytag Corp rise as much as 9.9 percent after company reaffirms its 2003 profit forecast (S)

headline: For Afghan Central Bank, It's Out With the Old Money and In With the New
abstract: Afghanistan's central bank in capital of Kabul is astir under American-backed government of Hamid Karzai after years of degeneration under Taliban, who looted vaults at gunpoint under pressure of American bombing before fleeing in November 2001, leaving nation of 25 million with only $30,000 in cash reserves; has first computers linked by satellite to world's financial markets as well as new, economically literate management aided by American financial advisers; is seeking to remake itself into institution with weight across Afghanistan, instead of relic it became in years when war and lawlessness voided very notion of effective central bank; will start by issuing new currency on October 7 to replace estimated 15 trillion old afghani notes; photos (M)

headline: Inside, Fearful Children; Outside, Frantic Relatives
abstract: Actor who managed to escape Moscow theater that has been seized by Chechen guerrillas describes scene of confusion and terror inside, with gunmen firing shots into air; witnesses say some of guerrillas are women with explosives tied to their bodies; frantic relatives waiting outside theater express frustration with rescue efforts (M)

headline: U.S. AND FRANCE NEAR COMPROMISE ON ACTION ON IRAQ
abstract: United States and France move toward compromise on Iraq that would oblige Bush administration to consult United Nations Security Council before embarking on military action against Saddam Hussein but still leave it freedom to act alone; France and US have been arguing for six weeks over how many resolutions and what sort of triggers would be needed to open way for UN-backed military action against Iraq if that country fails to comply with expected new UN demands for destruction of its chemical and biological weapons; US has balked at France's insistence on two resolutions; under proposed compromise, American officials make clear that US would reserve right to lead military action against Iraq if Iraq continues to block inspections, even if Security Council does not give its approval (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Euro gains against dollar; settles at $1.0132, up from $1.0088 previously; graph (S)

headline: A Harvard Professor And Economic Policy
abstract: John P Jennings letter comments on Dec 1 article on Martin Feldstein regarding his views about economic policy under Clinton and Bush administrations; photos

headline: Test Drive; Rooting for Roomba: Can It Catch the Dust Bunnies?
abstract: Report on test of Roomba Intelligent FloorVac made by iRobot; photo (M)

headline: China Frees Dissident Tibetan Nun 9 Years Ahead of Schedule
abstract: Tibetan nun imprisoned nearly decade by China for 'counterrevolutionary' crimes is released nine years ahead of schedule; nun, Ngawang Sandrol, was convicted in 1992 for her protests on behalf of Tibetan independence; her prison sentence was lengthened after she and other jailed nuns made clandestine recording of songs praising Dalai Lama, Tibet's exiled spiritual leader; she is among China's longest-serving female political prisoners; China frequently paroles political prisoners as good-will gesture before summit meetings with Western leaders; Ngawang Sandrol's high-profile release comes weeks before Pres Jiang Zemin's scheduled visit to Pres Bush at his ranch in Texas; release also coincides with signs of mild warming of relations between China and Dalai Lama (M)

headline: In Opening the Gates of Its Gulag, Iraq Unleashes Pain and Protest
abstract: Pres Saddam Hussein's decision to release tens of thousands of political prisoners and common criminals gives Iraqis rare glimpse into gulag that has maintained his power for 23 years, but also prompts small but remarkable protests by black-clad mothers and others demanding to know fate of relatives taken away years ago; photos; protests reflect new and potentially seismic willingness among at least some ordinary people to speak up, even if their words are accompanied by strident praise for Hussein; at least 700 people reportedly appeared at secret police headquarters, defying orders to disperse; women outside Ministry of Information tell nightmarish tales of men, women and teenagers picked up and never seen again; opening of prison gates sends families on desperate searches from cellblock to cellblock, from Baghdad to other cities, confirming worst fears that untold numbers are dead (M)

headline: Magazines; With advertising in deep distress, publishers consider an end to the era of cheap subscriptions.
abstract: Magazine publishers, reeling from deeply distressed advertising revenues, consider ending era of cheap subscriptions; shift would risk drop in readership that could result in lower ad rates; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Is Wooing A Shiite Exile To Rattle Iraq
abstract: Bush administration is forging political alliance of convenience with Iraqi Shiite leader Ayatollah Muhammad Bakir al-Hakim, who has lived in Iran for more than two decades; is wooing man whose father once gave sanctuary to Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, fiery anti-American cleric who rose to power during Iran's 1979 revolution and country accused by Pres Bush of being part of 'axis of evil;' efforts are part of ongoing plan to topple Iraq's Pres Saddam Hussein; are strongly supported by Kuwait and quietly backed by Tehran, in subtle signal that Iran seems prepared to offer modicum of cooperation if US mounts military campaign against Iraq; Hakim says job is to change current regime, and that it is very important that there be understanding between Iraqi opposition and US; has been asked by Bush administration to send representative to December 10 meeting of Iraqi opposition leaders in London; photo (M)

headline: New Athens Mayor Embodies a New Greece
abstract: Dora Bakoyanni, first woman to be elected mayor of Athens, Greece, is one of most popular politicians in country with dismal record of representation by women in government; her dramatic life story has repeatedly intersected with darker chapters of Greece's recent past; her father, Constantine Mitsotakis, was prominent politician who was arrested in 1967 when military junta seized control of country; he then fled country with his family, returning in 1973 to be arrested again; he was released next year when junta fell; her husband, Pavlos Bakoyanni, an opponent of junta, was gunned down in 1989 by Nov 17 Group, which aimed its attacks at prominent public officials in Greece in effort to destabilize country; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Koreas: Delay In Transit Project
abstract: South Korean Defense Ministry announces work stoppage on rail and road project linking North Korea and South Korea through demilitarized zone; North Korea does not want UN command involved in process (S)

headline: They Choke On Coke, But Savor Mecca-Cola
abstract: Tawfik Mathlouthi introduced Mecca-Cola in November in France, to cater to Muslims desirous of boycotting American brands to protest policies in Middle East; orders are now pouring in from around world, together with bids from companies wanting to become local distributors; new flavors will be introduced soon and plans are under way to create new fast-food restaurants to compete with popular American franchises; Coca-Cola executives acknowledge Arab boycott has hurt business; photo (M)

headline: At the Author's Demand
abstract: Neil Friedman letter comments on Oct 17 article about print-on-demand publishing

headline: Flood Cleanup Is Slow Along Prague Riverside
abstract: Karlin neighborhood of Prague, Czech Republic, is slow to recover from heavy damage caused by flooding in August, compared with rest of city, and many of its residents feel neglected; old blue-collar district, affectionately known as 'Brooklyn of Prague,' was undergoing regentrification; was built in late 19th century in what was once bed of Vltava River (M)

headline: Nikon and Fallon End Relationship
abstract: Nikon Inc ends its advertising relationship with Fallon Worldwide (S)

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: THE HAGUE: New Indictments In Bosnia Massacre; ITALY: 300 Illegal Immigrants Captured;." BRITAIN: Pressing Firefighters Not To Strike; IRELAND: New Effort To Shut British Atom Plant; HUNGARY: Pro-Europe Vote Leftist Parties That Favor Joining The European Union Swept Local Elections Over The Weekend, Also Handing A Victory To The New Government Led By The Hungarian Socialist Party. "Thank You, Hungary," The Socialist Prime Minister, Peter Medgyessy, Said After His Party And An Ally Took Nearly 49 Percent Of The Vote.

headline: Radio Ad Spending Rose Sharply in October
abstract: Radio Advertising Bureau reports that spending on radio advertising rose 13 percent in Oct from Oct 2001 (S)

headline: Keen on Stimulus, but Limited in Leeway
abstract: Analysis of Pres Bush's plan to kickstart lagging economy with more tax cuts and incentives; says some experts see room for more spending and tax cuts to ensure that economy returns quickly to strong growth, but others worry that cost of stimulus now will only add to economic problems later; Bush's promise to extend his 10-year schedule of tax cuts well into future, as centerpiece of stimulus package, has been one of most disputed proposals; Massachusetts Institute of Technology Prof Peter A Diamond says making Bush's tax cut permanent is moving in wrong direction (M)

headline: Publisher Sues O'Donnell Over Demise of Her Magazine
abstract: Gruner & Jahr USA files lawsuit against Rosie O'Donnell for ending her relationship with Rosie, magazine that she published with company; contends that beginning last summer O'Donnell abused employees, disrupted editorial process and refused to cooperate in producing magazine; seeks damages in excess of $100 million; O'Donnell will file countersuit (M)

headline: Tyson Foods Is Sued Over Health Issue
abstract: Physicians Committee for Responsible Medicine sues Tyson Foods; claims that Tyson misled consumers with advertising describing its chicken as all natural and heart healthy; company denies suit's merit (S)

headline: U.S. REFINES PLANS FOR WAR IN CITIES
abstract: American military adopts new strategy in training for attack on Baghdad that will seek to avoid house-to-house combat in its hostile streets; new plan calls for isolating city and taking control of it by seizing or destroying Saddam Hussein's pillars of power with such decisive force that Iraqis' will to fight collapses; commanders say any fighting in Baghdad or other Iraqi cities could result in thousands of American casualties and even more civiilian deaths; they may have no choice should Hussein and his die-hard adherents choose to make Baghdad their last stand; even now Republican Guard units are digging in around Baghdad; new American military strategy described in detail; photos (L)

headline: JUDGE APPROVES RENT-A-CENTER SEX-BIAS SETTLEMENT
abstract: Federal judge approves $47 million settlement of sex-discrimination lawsuits against Rent-A-Center Inc; funds will be paid to about 4,600 women who were fired or forced out after Renter's Choice Inc acquired company in 1998 (M)

headline: Pakistan Stages 2nd Ballistic Missile Test
abstract: Pakistan carries out second test involving medium-range missile designed to carry nuclear warhead (S)

headline: Gateway, Lands' End and Avaya, with budgets totaling $225 million, drop their agencies.
abstract: Gateway, Lands' End and Avaya, with advertising budgets totaling $225 million, drop their agencies; Gateway dimisses Siltanen/Keehn and will shift most of duties to Arnell Group; Lands' End names McKinney & Silver as agency of record; spending estimated at $20 million; account had been handled by Element 79 Partners; Avaya names McCann-Erickson as its agency; spending estimated at $25 million; previous agency was Foote, Cone & Belding (M)

headline: Iran to Reconsider Death Sentence
abstract: Iran's supreme religous leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei orders appeals court to review death sentence issued for liberal scholar Hashem Aghajari; his death sentence set off largest and most sustained student protests since 1999; he has refused to appeal his sentence and challenged hard-liners to carry it out; he is war veteran and outspoken pro-reform activist who has called for separation of religion and state (M)

headline: Japan Looks to Eastern Russia for Oil
abstract: Japan is looking to Russian Far East for oil, ensuring that Sakhalin Island will become major supplier of oil and gas to Japan within decade; $13 billion is starting to pour into two gas and oil projects on Sakhalin Island; Sakhalin Energy Investment Co in 2003 is to start work on 560-mile pipeline down island to feed gas from offshore operation to what is to be largest liquefied natural gas plant in world; tankers are to start supplying, in late 2006, dozen gas terminals around Japan; group led by Exxon Mobil is developing Sakhalin offshore section, with goal of producing oil in about three years; project's target of 250,000 barrels per day is equivalent of 6 percent of Japan's daily oil imports; Exxon Mobil plans to start building gas pipeline in Japan in 2006, potentially 1,000-mile, $16 billion undertaking; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Coffee rises on speculation that dry weather will reduce size of crop in Brazil, world's largest grower; in New York, coffee for December delivery rises 5.45 cents, or 9.5 percent, to 62.8 cents per pound; graph; chart (S)

headline: Market Place; Looking Glass On Earnings Just Got Darker
abstract: Standard & Poor's Corp will release its calculations of 'core earnings.' of American companies as it defines them; definition, which is subject to dispute, will make most companies look far rose than they have appeared; core earnings for companies in Standard & Poor's 500 index came to $18.48, compared with operating earnings of $41.58 and compared with reported profits of $26.74; index was trading at multiple of 54 times core earnings based on value of S&P of 989.52 at end of second quarter, figure that has since declined to 47; those using operating income numbers see multiple as 24 at end of June, and 21 now; three principle differences between operating numbers and new core numbers detailed; David M Blitzer, chairman of S&P's core earnings committee, comments; chart (Market Place column) (M)

headline: Syrians' Hopes for Freedom Remain Mostly Unfulfilled
abstract: Syrians' hopes that Bashar al-Assad would usher in freedoms when he became president two years ago are mostly unfulfilled and outright criticism of government remains taboo, although people in private settings no longer fear voicing opinions; Haitham al-Maleh, 71-year-old lawyer who defends political detainees, himself faces military court on charges related to Human Rights Association, which he helped establish; photo; recent jailings come as Syria seeks association agreement with European Union, part of Assad's strategy to open up country's markets and improve economy; he has moved to open tightly controlled society, naming technocrats to economic posts, and reportedly appearing in public in casual settings, but may have backed away from rapid change as he consolidates power (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Setback In Buyout Of Retailer
abstract: Dickson Poon, the chairman of the Hong Kong retailer Dickson Concepts (International), suffered a setback in his plans to take Harvey Nichols, the upscale London department store, private, after one of Harvey Nichols's large shareholders said it would block the deal. Deutsche Asset Management, which owns about 28 percent of Harvey Nichols, said it planned to vote against Mr. Poon's offer of £2.50 ($3.91) a share, because it was too low. Dickson Concepts owns 50 percent of Harvey Nichols, and Mr. Poon needs the approval of shareholders holding two-thirds of the stock. One option open to Mr. Poon is to restructure the transaction. He could first offer to buy the remaining 50 percent of the shares he does not already own. Once they are in his possession, he could then take the company private. Such a structure would require a lower threshold of shareholder approval. After buying Harvey Nichols in 1991, Mr. Poon engineered a turnaround before selling shares to the public in 1996 for £2.70 ($4.22). More recently, sales and profits have been disappointing. Harvey Nichols said on Friday that profit for the six months ended Sept. 28 fell 35 percent, to £3 million ($4.7 million).   Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

headline: Asia Gains in Chip Market
abstract: America's share of $131 billion worldwide semiconductor market continues to plummet, dropping to only 22 percent of worldwide revenue in second quarter of 2002, as communications and other high-technolgy companies cut costs by seeking chips from Asia (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Belgium: Brewer's Sales Fall
abstract: World Business Briefing: Belgium: Brewer's Sales F

headline: German Chancellor Wins Parliament Vote to Extend Afghan Troop Presence
abstract: Chancellor Gerhard Schroder wins critical vote from German Parliament on keeping 1,100 German soldiers with American Special Forces in hunt for members of Al Qaeda and Taliban in Afghanistan (M)

headline: Indonesians, Tracing A.T.M. Use, Arrest Major Suspect in Bali Bombing
abstract: Indonesian authorities use ATM records to trace and arrest Imam Samudra, major suspect in Bali nightclub bombing in October; photo (M)

headline: Pyongyang Rejects Demands to End Atom Bomb Program
abstract: North Korea flatly rejects international demands that it abandon its nuclear weapons program; issues statement at opening session of talks with Japan aimed at establishing normal relations between two countries (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Analysts' Repute As Stock Pickers Under Challenge
abstract: New York State Atty Gen Eliot L Spitzer details results of study commissioned by his office showing that over last three years, most of analysts that were judged best by institutional investors actually turned in lackluster performances when assessed solely on their stock picks, speech to winners of Institutional Investor magazine's All-America Research Team Awards; in each of last two years only one of 51 analysts ranked highest by magazine would have also been ranked best stock picker in his or her industry; photo (Market Place column) (M)

headline: U.N. Inspections Chief Urges U.S. to Provide Intelligence on Iraq
abstract: Hans Blix called on Washington today to give him intelligence information to help in the search for Iraqi weapons sites.

headline: OFFER FOR PART OF BETHLEHEM STEEL IS EXPECTED
abstract: International Steel Group, created by investor Wilbur L Ross Jr, considers buying all or part of Bethlehem Steel; full purchase would almost double International's production capacity; company has 60 days to review operations of Bethlehem, which sought bankruptcy protection (S)

headline: 2 Agencies Merge Back-Office Units
abstract: Mad Dogs and Englishmen and Spier New York are combining back-office operations in New York to cut costs but will continue to operate independently in other areas (S)

headline: SKECHERS CHANGES FORECAST FROM A PROFIT TO A LOSS
abstract: Skechers USA Inc says it will post fourth-quarter loss instead of profit because competition has hurt sales (S)0

headline: Personal Business; How to Find Insurance That Fits
abstract: List of questions to consider in reviewing health insurance plans' offerings offered by employer (S)

headline: French Regulators Limit Use of J.&J. Anemia Drug
abstract: French regulators restrict use of Johnson & Johnson's anemia drug Eprex in patients with kidney failure because of rising incidence of rare but serious side effect; competing erythropoietin-based anemia drugs, perceived as safer, will likely benefit from J & J's loss in sales (M)

headline: ON THE GROUND: In Austin; A High-Technology Star Is Also a Cultural Oasis
abstract: Travel article on Austin, Tex; city's highlights noted; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing: Americas
abstract: NEPAL: Elections May Be Delayed; TAJIKISTAN: Allegations Of Rape And Torture;.

headline: Hands Across Pacific: U.S.-China Ties Grow
abstract: Chinese and American analysts say that China, with its leaders preoccupied by most sweeping changing of guard in two decades, seems determined to improve ties with United States even it if means accepting, for now, increased American assertiveness worldwide (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Ulster: Republican Says 'War Is Over'
abstract: Martin McGuinness, official of Sinn Fein and former IRA leader, ends his fight against Britain; has left IRA and declares he is dedicated to preventing further bloodshed; photo (S)

headline: U.S. Evangelist Is Shot Dead in an Attack in Lebanon
abstract: American evangelist Bonnie Penner Witherall is shot to death at missionary clinic in Sidon, Lebanon, apparently latest victim in lethal atacks against Americans in region; photos; her mission group has been involved in public dispute over proslytizing Christianity to young Muslims (M)

headline: Fewer Media Owners, More Media Choices
abstract: Technological innovations like Internet and expansion of cable and satellite television have allowed media outlets to expand exponentially despite consolidation of media owners, development that would seem to undermine case for public interest advocates who do not want FCC to loosen ownership restrictions on television outlets, radio stations and newspapers; opponents of deregulation still argue that consolidation of media ownership has led to sameness in television and radio programming; proponents say average household has access to so much information in so many different forms that no single company could ever exert undue influence over consumers (M)

headline: A Vulnerable Kuwait Readies Its Defenses For a U.S. Attack on Iraq and the Reaction
abstract: Kuwait prepares its defenses for possible US attack on Iraq; photo (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: AIM GROUP, Southampton, England, a maker of aircraft and train interiors, said talks with a potential buyer had ended.    PLAINS EXPLORATION AND PRODUCTION CO., Houston, the oil-drilling unit of Plains Resources, canceled its planned $70 million initial public offering because of low investor demand for new stocks.

headline: Fed Officials Say Policy Isn't Limited by Low Rates
abstract: Federal Reserve may have lowered interest rates to once unimaginable level of 1.25 percent, but senior officials insist they can still flood country with money if they need to; Ben S Bernanke, one of Federal Reserve's seven governors, asserts US government has electronic equivalent of printing press that allows it to produce as many US dollars as it wishes at essentially no cost (M)

headline: Your Call. Everybody's Business.
abstract: Matt Richtel column on public airing of personal business in cellphone conversations; suggests fanciful innovations that might take trend to an even greater degrees of intrusiveness; cartoon (M)

headline: Hamilton to Lay Off 250
abstract: Hamilton Sundstrand, maker of aircraft equipment, will dismiss 250 workers and close to two offices to save money (S)

headline: Desmond Hoyte, 73, Former President of Guyana, Dies
abstract: Desmond Hoyte, the former president of Guyana who began a thaw of his nation's socialist policies and ushered in a democratic transition to his opponents, died last Sunday in Georgetown, the capital. He was 73.    The cause was heart failure, The Associated Press reported, citing Guyanese media reports.

headline: Carter Accepts Nobel and Gives Message on Iraq
abstract: Former Pres Jimmy Carter accepts Nobel Peace Prize in Oslo and uses platform to try to steer events away from armed conflict in Iraq; warns Iraqi government that it must meet United Nations Security Council's demand for elimination of weapons of mass destruction, but he also appears to warn Bush administration against acting against Iraq without backing of United Nations; Gunnar Berge, chairman of prize committee, goes further, saying choice of Carter, who has been publicly critical of Bush administration's aggressive posture toward Iraq, should be interpreted as criticism of administration's line; prize gives Carter and closest aides cause for hope that his years in White House, dragged down by Iranian hostage crisis and runaway inflation, will be viewed more favorably over time; photos (M)

headline: Marine Killed as Unit Is Attacked During Training in Kuwait
abstract: U.S. Marines came under small arms fire Tuesday during war games in Kuwait. One Marine was killed and a second was wounded.

headline: ALLERGAN WINS APPROVAL FOR CHRONIC DRY EYE TREATMENT
abstract: Allergan Inc wins Food and Drug Adm approval of eye drop called Restasis, first prescription treatment for chronic dry eye; more than million people in US suffer from chronic dry eye (S)

headline: Hostility in Canada's West Threatens Climate Policy
abstract: Opposition from several provinces and business groups threaten ratification of the Kyoto climate control protocol even if it is endorsed by Parliament.

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: FRANCE: No New Refugees At Camp Near Channel; BRITAIN: Jail Term For Spy Who Spilled Secrets; RUSSIA: Evidence For Chechen Extradition Case; YUGOSLAVIA: Rivals Agree To Cooperate; THE HAGUE: More Delays In Milosevic Trial;.

headline: Itching to Rebuild the Tax Law
abstract: Treasury Sec Paul H O'Neill's passion for overhauling federal tax laws toward greater simplicity, fairness and efficiency brings attendant political peril; Bush administration proceeds cautiously to avoid inflaming interest groups; longstanding tangled mass of tax advantages gained by lobbyists might be endangered; individuals of various economic classes and variety of industries could be substantially affected by rebuilt tax code, last overhauled in 1986; photo; drawing; table of proposed changes (M)

headline: Vivendi's Ex-Chief Strikes Back in Book on His Downfall
abstract: Jean-Marie Messier is putting his version of the story of his fall from corporate power on the record in a new book.

headline: More Than Dueling Monsters, Game Boy Now Has Riddles
abstract: Scholastic introduces game for Game Boy Advance system called I Spy Challenger, which is adaptation of popular riddle books and CD-ROM's; games are geared for children 6 and older; photo (M)

headline: Leftist Handily Wins Brazilian Presidential Race
abstract: Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva, leftist labor union leader, is elected president of Brazil, taking 61.2 percent of vote to defeat centrist Jose Serra; overwhelming victory, with nearly 52 million votes, is seen as mandate to remake Latin America's most populous country; is likely to reverberate abroad, energizing left throughout Latin America and further unnerving international financial markets; da Silva's Workers' Party has been consistent critic of US and values it espouses; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Phone Results Improve
abstract: Dominant South Korean telephone company KT Corp offers dour fourth-quarter forecast but reports better-than-expected third-quarter profit of $249 million, nearly double 2001 earnings in same period (S)

headline: Business; A Time When Greed Wasn't Good
abstract: Interview with David Callahan, author of Kindred Spirits: Harvard Business School's Extraordinary Class of 1949 and How They Transformed American Business; photo (M)

headline: CHRYSLER RECALLS 500,000 MINIVANS TO REPLACE PART
abstract: Chrysler division of DaimlerChrysler recalls 500,000 minivans to replace part that can cause malfunction of air bag, horn or cruise control; had 27 recalls in 2001 (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Account changes noted: J P Morgan Chase brokerage division Brown & Co appoints VIA Group as advertising agency of record; Peet's Coffee and Tea selects Kirshenbaum Bond Creative Network to create new ad campaign (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: PRICELINE.COM INC., Norwalk, Conn., an Internet seller of discount airline tickets, hotel rooms and cars, expanded its hotel booking service to Beijing, Shanghai, Hong Kong, Singapore and Bangkok.    ENIGMA INC., Burlington, Mass., a provider of content-driven e-business, agreed on a long-term contract with Japan Airlines, Tokyo, to deliver round-the-clock repair and service information to the company's 5,000 engineers and mechanics. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Full Text of Webster's Resignation Letter
abstract: Full Text of Webster's Resignation Letter

headline: PENTAGON SETS UP INTELLIGENCE UNIT
abstract: Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld and key aides assign small intelligence unit to search for information on Iraq's hostile intentions or links to terrorists that nation's spy agencies may have overlooked; Rumsfeld and Deputy Defense Sec Paul D Wolfowitz are said to feel frustrated that they are not receiving undiluted information on capacities of Pres Saddam Hussein and his suspected ties to terrorist organizations; critics say top civilian policy makers are intent on politicizing intelligence to fit their hawkish views on Iraq; many in intelligence agencies say Hussein cannot be directly linked to Osama bin Laden and Al Qaeda, and that two are unlikely to make common cause against United States; some senior intelligence analysts at CIA contend that Hussein is contained and is unlikely to unleash weapons of mass destruction unless he is attacked; view of Rumsfeld's inner circle is that Hussein's record is so alarming that he should not be left in power; they cite numerous intelligence findings indicating links between Iraq and senior Qaeda leaders; photo (M)

headline: Business; Rival to Pokémon Keeps Market Hot
abstract: Konami of Japan has great success with its Yu-Gi-Oh trading-card characters, which includes card game, game software, cartoons and toys; Yu-Gi-Oh has surpassed Pokeman in popularity in US; photo (M)

headline: Hard-Pressed German Leader Is Now Facing a Strike Threat
abstract: Talks between Germany and union of three million public service workers break down over union's bid for wage increase of over 3 percent; union has called warning strikes in some major cities, causing widespread havoc; threatens national strike if accord is not reached by mid-Jan; experts see threat putting pressure on Chancellor Gerhard Schroder in advance of Feb elections in two provinces (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Borland Acquires Togethersoft
abstract: Borland Software acquires TogetherSoft Corp for $185 million in cash and stock (S)

headline: ALLIED BUILDING FACES 244 ASBESTOS SUITS
abstract: CRH, a building materials conglomerate, said yesterday that a subsidiary in the United States, Allied Building Products, faces 244 personal injury lawsuits related to asbestos in roofing materials made by others that Allied distributed before CRH acquired it. CRH, which is based in Dublin, said that its subsidiaries had settled 33 similar cases for ''minimal'' amounts of a few thousand dollars apiece and that the pending cases were without merit. Still, CRH's stock fell 15 percent in Dublin, in part because investors recalled the troubles other European companies like ABB have had with asbestos liability at American subsidiaries.   Brian Lavery (NYT)

headline: Wall Street Suffers; New York Winces
abstract: Sharp decline in stock market has resulted in waning revenues in security industry and job losses on Wall Street; there are already 18,300 fewer jobs on Wall Street than there were year ago August, and outlook is bleak; graphs (M)

headline: The Rich, the Poor And the Tax System
abstract: Jeffery J Smith letter comments on Dec 8 article about taxation differences between rich and poor taxpayers

headline: NATO Leaders Join Demands for Iraq to Disarm
abstract: The 19 leaders of NATO joined today in demanding that Iraq "fully and completely" comply with a U.N. resolution to disarm.

headline: GROWTH IN SALES FOR HOLIDAY PERIOD IS LOWEST IN YEARS
abstract: This year's holiday season is worst in many years for retail stores; retail analyst Michael P Niemira says growth in United States retail sales for months of Nov and Dec, at 1.5 percent, is lowest since at least 1970; spokesman for National Retail Federation, known for its upbeat forecasts, lowers its estimate of percent growth for Dec to 3.5 percent; Wal-Mart Stores, nation's biggest retailer, lowers its estimates of Dec sales growth to 2 percent to 3 percent, rather than 3 percent to 5 percent it was forecasting earlier; last year, Wal-Mart posed Dec sales growth of 8.1 percent; idea that even Wal-Mart is struggling is taken as sign of wider problems; worry about economy and about impending war with Iraq and new terrorist attacks have kept many shoppers from buying, even with deep discounts on many items; percentage of consumers giving gift certificates as presents this holiday season soared from previous years, to 54 percent; photos; graph (M)

headline: Jerusalem Quiet as 130,000 Worshipers Gather for Ramadan
abstract: Worshipers gathered in Jerusalem at the site in the old city that is known to Muslims as Haram al-Sharif and to Jews as the Temple Mount for the first prayers of Ramadan.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Combined AT&T And Comcast To Cut Jobs
abstract: AT&T Corp and Comcast Corp says 1,700 jobs, or 30 percent of work force, will be cut at AT&T's cable unit after companies merge; cuts will mostly affect executive and management positions; graph (S)

headline: Accord Highlights Wall St. Failures
abstract: Analysis: Regulatory settlement that requires nation's top brokerage firms to pay fines and to make changes in how they do business speaks to more than failures of Wall Street research; settlement, and investigation that led up to it, shows serious breakdown in self-policing by brokerage firms, duty that forms basis of nation's securities laws; shows how regulators at Securities and Exchange Commission, New York Stock Exchange and NASD, all charged with protecting investors, fell down on their jobs during stock surge of late 1990's, as throngs of individuals were entering market for first time; chart; photos (M)

headline: As Russia Renews Crackdown, Chechen Fighters Down Copter
abstract: Russian Defense Min Sergei Ivanov declares new crackdown on Chechen militants, as guerrillas shoot down Russian helicopter, killing nine soldiers; downing is fifth in ten weeks in region, raising further questions about extent of Russian control (S)

headline: Man Believed Slain in Yemen Tied by U.S. To Buffalo Cell
abstract: American officials say United States citizen believed to have been killed in Yemen by American missile was probably Kamal Derwish, ringleader of group of six men from Buffalo area identified by law enforcement officials as sleeper cell of Qaeda terrorist network; say names provided by Yemeni government of those killed in missile attack include known alias of Derwish; he is one of two unindicted co-conspirators in case brought against six who are charged with providing material support to terrorist organization; Derwish was believed to be recruiter of other immigrants living in upstate New York community of Lackawanna; missile thought to have killed him was fired by unmanned Predator drone aircraft operated by CIA; CIA declines to comment (M)

headline: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE: REGIONAL MARKET -- Jersey City; Building Warehouse Space on Speculation in a Frail Economy
abstract: Construction has started on industrial warehouses near Jersey City and Elizabeth, NJ, port areas, even though developer Keystone Property Trust has no agreements yet with potential tenants; Keystone has financial strength to construct buildings without tenants, even at cost of $33 million, and is betting that once buildings are completed by June, they will not sit idle; map; drawing (M)

headline: Technology Briefing: Hardware
abstract: CREDENCE SYSTEMS CUTS 225 JOBS; TRIQUINT SHARES DROP AFTER OUTLOOK IS LOWERED; ELECTRONIC DATA DOWNGRADED BY MOODY'S; I.B.M. OVERTAKES HEWLETT IN SERVER MARKET SHARE;.

headline: WorldCom Investor Hires Giuliani Consulting Firm
abstract: Giuliani Partners, consulting firm of former Mayor Rudolph W Giuliani, is working with David Matlin, leading investor in distressed companies, who is accumulating bonds issued by WorldCom, troubled telecommunications company (M)

headline: The Hand That Feeds Milosevic's Defense
abstract: Zdenko Tomanovic discusses role as 'virtual lawyer' for Slobodan Milosevic at war crimes trial in The Hague; interview; photo; former Serb leader is conducting own defense, but Tomanovic is legal associate who gathers piles of evidence, more than 150,000 documents and exhibits (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Growth Forecast Cut
abstract: The German finance minister, Hans Eichel, cut one percentage point off his forecast for economic growth next year and said he opposed raising taxes to meet European Union budget requirements. The economy will expand 1.5 percent next year, the Finance Ministry said, compared with an earlier estimate of 2.5 percent. Mr. Eichel said he planned spending cuts of 10 billion euros ($9.8 billion) to avoid hurting the economy by pushing up taxes.

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Gas prices rise as colder temperatures in Midwest raise expectations of higher demand; in New York, gas for November delivery rises 14.8 cents, or 3.7 percent, to $4.176 for million BTU's; graph; chart (S)

headline: Japanese Wage Peace With Talks and Money, Pleasing Asians
abstract: Japan is putting its diplomatic offices and money behind peace efforts in Sri Lanka, Philippines and Indonesia; peace diplomacy aims to promote stability in lands neighboring sea lanes vital for Japan's oil imports, and it also reflects constitutional obstacles that will prevent Japan from joining US military action against Iraq (M)

headline: Investor Appeals Ruling on Big Award
abstract: Henryk Henryk de Kwiatkowski, Canadian investor whose $164.5 million damage verdict against Bear Stearns Companies was overturned by three-judge appellate panel, petitions federal appeals court to rehear his case (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Investor Group To Buy Intertrust
abstract: Fidelio Acquisition Company, consortium formed by Royal Philips Electronics, Sony and other investors, will acquire InterTrust Technologies for about $453 million in cash to gain software that limits copying of digital material like music and movies; graphs (S)

headline: Private Sector; The Corporate Weasel Is Everywhere
abstract: One new volume on corporate America offers this theory: People are weasels.    In his fourth book, ''Dilbert and the Way of the Weasel,'' Scott Adams argues that most people's conduct falls within a ''gigantic gray area between good moral behavior and outright felonious activities.''

headline: California Patients Talk Of Needless Heart Surgery
abstract: Federal agents probe accusations that Dr Chae Hyun Moon and Fidel Realyvasquez Jr performed hundreds of unnecessary invasive heart procedures at Redding Medical Center in Redding, Calif, putting patients' lives and health at risk to make money from Medicare; accusations raise questions about role of profit motive in health care and are threatening reputation of Redding Medical Center, one of most profitable hospitals owned by Tenet Healthcare, and Tenet itself; some former patients say they were harmed by procedures, including catheterization and open-heart surgeries, but others credit doctors with saving their lives (M)

headline: An Ex-Official Faces Charges In Enron Deals
abstract: Enron's former chief financial officer Andrew S Fastow is charged with engaging in vast scheme to use off-the-books partnerships to fraudulently disguise company's financial performance while enriching himself with millions of dollars in Enron's cash; charges--including fraud, money laundering and conspiracy--portray Enron as company where fraud and deceit were workaday mechanisms used to disguise failings of corporation secretly spinning out of control; government complaint implicates other executives and financial institutions--notably Merrill Lynch--as having direct involvement in or knowledge of criminal activities; Fastow surrenders to FBI agents in Houston; he is led in handcuffs to federal courthouse, where judge orders him to be released on $5 million bond, secured by $3 million investment account and several homes; Fastow and his wife surrender their passports; photos (L)

headline: Campaigning Door to Door, and PC to PC
abstract: Article examines widespread use of Internet by candidates for federal, state and even municipal offices nationwide; candidates say sites attract number of visitors, generate e-mail exchanges with voters and can be used for fund-raising; Web allows candidates to disseminate views more fully and extends outreach of campaign; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: France: Deadline Set For Refugees In Church
abstract: Interior Minister Nicolas Sarkozy gave refugees in Calais 24 hours to vacate an unused church where they were seeking shelter or face being forcibly removed. Several dozen refugees took shelter in the church during the weekend after the Red Cross began closing a refugee center at nearby Sangatte, which illegal migrants use as a jumping-off point to smuggle themselves into Britain. France agreed to stop admitting refugees to Sangatte this month, leaving dozens of migrants, many of them Afghans and Iraqi Kurds, to wander the streets of Calais and take shelter in public buildings like school gyms.   John Tagliabue (NYT)

headline: Nervousness from war talk contributes to the worst quarter in U.S. since 1987 : The global sell-off extends to Japan
abstract: While stock prices rebounded in most of the world, Japanese shares sank to a 19-year low Wednesday on concerns that the government's cleanup of bad loans could prompt the collapse of some listed companies.

headline: Job Losses Continued In October
abstract: The economy lost jobs in October for the second consecutive month, the government said yesterday, in a sign that economic growth, after accelerating over the summer, has recently slowed to a crawl.    The unemployment rate rose slightly last month to 5.7 percent, and the nation's payrolls shrunk by 5,000 jobs, largely because of layoffs in manufacturing and construction. Companies also cut their workers' hours for the first time since July, suggesting that large-scale hiring is unlikely in the immediate future.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Jefferies Group acquires investment banking firm Quarterdeck Investment Partners (S)

headline: The Gatekeeper For Literature Is Changing At New Yorker
abstract: New Yorker magazine editor David Remnick appoints Deborah Treisman to succeed Bill Buford as short-story editor; her standards and criteria are unknown, but some literary insiders expect to see more-experimental fiction; photos (M)

headline: U.S. Takes Possession of a Copy of Iraq Report to the U.N.
abstract: Washington received the declaration after persuading the other four permanent members of the Security Council that they should insist on seeing it immediately.

headline: Three Are Accused of Plan To Attack London Subways
abstract: Rabah Chekat-Bais, Rabah Kadris and Karim Kadouri face terrorism charges for reportedly planning rush-hour attack on London subway system; Deputy Prime Min John Prescott dismisses press report that they planned to use cyanide bomb; men were among six arrested eight days ago in North London raids by Scotland Yard's antiterrorism branch; three were freed without charge; arrests come amid alert about possible Al Qaeda terrorist strike (M)

headline: AtHomeAbroad: Costs of buying a Portuguese vacation home
abstract: I am an American who dreams of buying a vacation home in Portugal, but I have no idea how to get started. How much money, or what percentage, will I have to put down as a deposit? Do I need to open a bank account in Portugal, and how can I do that if I don't actually live there? What kind of annual property taxes will I be subject to on my new home as a non-resident of Portugal?

headline: Federal Judge Clears Way For Qwest To Swap Debt
abstract: Federal Judge Denny Chin clears way for Qwest Communications International to proceed with exchange offer that seems likely to force bondholders to accept bonds with lower face values; holder of $12.9 billion in bonds are being asked to exchange their bonds for ones that pay higher interest rates but have lower face values; Qwest will reduce its debt by $2.3 billion and will delay until 2007 repayments of principle on bonds that are scheduled to mature from 2004 through 2006 if deal succeeds (M)

headline: 'Clear as Glass' Against War With Iraq, Germans Still Agree to Aid U.S. and Israel
abstract: German Chancellor Gerhard Schroder says that he will grant United States unrestricted freedom to fly in German airspace, as well as to shuttle troops in and out of American military bases there; reiterates, however, that Germany will not take part in war against Iraq; also says Germany would supply Israel with German-made armored vehicles and Patriot antimissile system to protect it from Iraqi chemical, biological or nuclear attack (M)

headline: Russia Sets Tough Terms For Auction Of Oil Assets
abstract: Russian government sets terms for auction of state's controlling stake in Slavneft, oil comapny; sale may turn out to be most competitive Russian privatization since end of Communism (M)

headline: Japan Names New Economy Czar to Tackle Banking Crisis
abstract: Declaring Japan's banks in an ''emergency,'' Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi fired his chief financial regulator today and unexpectedly concentrated economic policy making in the hands of a 51-year-old cabinet member known for advocating aggressive action to tackle Japan's long-running banking crisis.     Heizo Takenaka, the economy minister, emerged today as ''economy czar'' as he took over the portfolio of financial regulator from Hakuo Yanagisawa, a minister who had opposed using public money to clean up commercial banks, which are staggering under the weight of bad loans officially estimated at $423 billion.

headline: World Business Briefing: Americas
abstract: CANADA: Printing Executive Resigns; ARGENTINA: Banker Steps Down; BRAZIL: Industrial Output Rises;.

headline: High-Speed Wireless Internet Network Is Planned
abstract: Wireless technology known as WiFi, which allows users of personal and hand-held computers to connect to Internet at high speed without cables, gets significant stamp of approval when AT&T, IBM and Intel announce new company called Cometa Networks to create nationwide network; Cometa Networks wants to deploy more than 20,000 wireless access points by end of 2004, placing cable-less high-speed Internet connection within either five-minute walk in urban areas or five-minute drive in suburban communities; executives from technology companies and investment firms Apax Partners and 3i that joined to create network say they will begin offering their service through cellular and wired telephone companies, DSL and cable Internet service providers and other Internet retailers some time in 2003; Cometa chief executive Dr Lawrence B Brilliant comments; photo (M)

headline: At News Conference: NATO Role vs. Iraq
abstract: Excerpts from Pres Bush's news conference with Pres Vaclav Havel, Prague; photo

headline: An Old-School Mind Not Fooled by the New Economy
abstract: Robert D Hershey Jr reviews Leon Levy's book The Mind of Wall Street, which contends that corporate profits govern not only stock prices but economic performance as well; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing: Asia
abstract: CHINA: Miners Killed In Gas Explosion; CHINA: Tycoon Charged With Corruption; SOUTH KOREA: Hotel Fined In Harassment Case; SRI LANKA: Rebel Leader Demands Autonomy;.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Never Underestimate The Power, Etc.
abstract: Wives of Fiat workers protest against planned company layoffs at Italian Prime Min Silvio Berlusconi's office, Rome; contend government did not do enough to prevent Fiat's decision (S)

headline: Auto Venture in Korea
abstract: Shanghai Automotive will pay $59.7 million for 10 percent stake in three key Korean factories of bankrupt Daewoo Motors being taken over by General Motors consortium (M)

headline: U.S. Vetoes Condemnation of Israel for U.N. Deaths
abstract: US casts veto against Syrian-proposed United Nations Security council resolution condemning Israel for recent killngs of several UN employees and destruction of UN food warehouse; US Ambassador John Negroponte, just before vote, says Syria and Palestinians seem more intent on condemning Israeli occupation than on ensuring safety of UN personnel (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: New Economic Official
abstract: Chancellor Gerhard Schroder, under pressure to revive German economy, names Wolfgang Clement to run newly combined economics and labor ministry; photo (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Printing Executive Resigns
abstract: World Business Briefing: Canada: Prin

headline: KEYSPAN SAYS EMPLOYEE PENSIONS MAY ERODE PROFITS
abstract: KeySpan Corp forecasts lower-than-expected profits in 2003 (S)

headline: Suspect Tells Police That Target of Bali Bombing Was Americans, Not Australians
