abstract: Gen I Made Mangku Pastika, who heads Indonesia's probe into terrorist bombing in Bali, says bombing suspect Amrozi told interrogators that radical Islamic group that carried out blast intended to attack Americans and regrets that they killed many more Australians instead; Australian and Indonesian police say they expect to make further arrests soon in Indonesia and abroad in connection with Oct 12 blast; Western diplomat says probe findings suggest Al Qaeda leader Hambali, object of manhunt all over southeastern Asia, masterminded blast; photos (M)

headline: CBS Names Top Sales Executive
abstract: CBS Names Executive In Charge of Sales.

headline: Executive Is Promoted to Chief of Frankel
abstract: Executive Is Promoted To Chief of Frankel Frankel in Chicago, part of the Publicis Groupe, said yesterday that Dick Thomas, 46, executive vice president, would be promoted to president and chief executive.

headline: Iranian Lawmaker Opens Door to American Talks
abstract: Behzad Nabavi, deputy speaker of Iran's Parliament, gives rare interview with foreign news media, offering to hold talks with United States; holds pressure from US has hurt cause of Iran's moderates; says talks could not restore diplomatic ties but would ease tensions; photo (M)

headline: Iraq Offers West's Reporters A Kinder, Gentler Face
abstract: Iraq's Information Ministry launches charm offensive to convince Western news media that Iraq is not hostile to Western news coverage; flurry of enhanced amiability seems part of wider effort by Pres Saddam Hussein to present more moderate image to world in face of American war threats; comes amid signs of uncertainty among high-level officials over how far Iraq should go in its efforts at describing itself as something other than repressive state; follows criticisms of ministry by Hussein's son Uday for overreacting in its handling of CNN, whose staff is being expelled for wide coverage of scattered street protests in Baghdad; photos (M)

headline: Japan Seeks Amnesty for Ex-U.S. Soldier Living in North Korea
abstract: Japanese government official asks United States to grant special amnesty to Charles Robert Jenkins, former American serviceman who is married to Japanese woman living in North Korea; Jenkins disappeared while leading Army patrol on South Korean side of demilitarized zone in 1965 and later took part in radio broadcasts to American troops from Pyongyang; Pentagon lists him as deserter (M)

headline: VISTEON OFFERS EARLY RETIREMENT TO 12% OF U.S. WORKERS
abstract: Visteon, auto parts maker spun off by Ford Motor Co in 2000, offers early retirement to 12 percent of its salaried United States employees (about 1,100 workers) as it tries to restore profits in face of falling orders from Ford, its main client (S)

headline: Marketers gather to talk of coping with tough times.
abstract: Growing doubt about course of economy dims mood of consumer marketers as they gather for Association of National Advertisers meeting in Naples, Fla (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Regional Trade Proposal
abstract: Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji is hoping to persuade Asian leaders to set up regional free-trade agreement at economic meeting in Phnom Penh, Cambodia, next week; China present free-trade plan to leaders of Association of Southeast Asian Nations to counter regional concerns that China's booming economy has drawn investment away from its neighbors; photo (S)

headline: Mexican Leader Aims to Offset Tariff Cuts
abstract: Mexican Pres Vicente Fox offers agricultural plan aimed at offsetting effects of tariff cuts mandated by North American Free Trade Agreement some Mexican farmers say will leave them unable to compete with imports from United States; offers bill to speed up procedures for levying tariffs on goods being sold below cost; proposes other help for farmers (M)

headline: A Selection Process Misfires, and Pitt Reels
abstract: Floyd Norris comment on Securities and Exchange Commission chairman Harvey L Pitt holds that Pitt has tried to be effective chairman, and deserves cedit for ideas like making chief executives certify their financial results; says his tendency to circle wagons when under attack, and his apparent belief that no one could question his integrity, has hurt; holds recent selection of William L Webster to head new Public Company Accounting Oversight Board has turned into fiasco; photo of Pitt with Pres Bush (M)

headline: New Leader Tries to Sell Turkey (and Himself) to Europeans
abstract: Recep Tayyip Erdogan, Turkey's new leader, is touring seven member states of European Union in bid to get Turkey into union; visits EU headquarters, Brussels; meets with European Commission president Romano Prodi and enlargement commissioner Gunter Verheugen; warns EU not to discriminate against overwhelmingly Muslim nation, news conference; urges EU to set fixed date for start of talks on when and how Turkey can join; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: Ban On Foreign Workers
abstract: Israel bans entry of foreign workers as part of drive to reduce their numbers; estimated 250,000 foreign laborers are in Israrel, more than half of them illegally and many replacing Palestinians whose entry to Israel has been barred (S)

headline: Costs of Health Benefits Are Seen Rising by 15%
abstract: Hewitt Associates Inc says cost of health benefit plans at big companies will rise more than 15 percent next year on average; says many companies are not only making employees pay larger share of their health care benefits, but are also considering health plans that try to cut costs by making employees take responsibility for their health care spending; expects average cost increases of 15.4 percent in 2003, on top of 13.7 percent rise recorded this year (M)

headline: Survivor Saw Bombers' Race to Death
abstract: Guard at Israeli-owned Mombasa, Kenya, hotel describes truck bomb attack he narrowly survived; says truck, which had passed hotel earlier, came racing back in reverse, stopped and went forward again, crashing through guard gate, plunging into hotel and exploding in lobby filled with Kenyans performers and Israeli tourists; says driver was not local man; many people at blast site express hostility toward Israel and sympathy for Palestinians; those working or living near site speak fondly of Israeli visitors; photo (M)

headline: Indonesia Holds Suspect In Bombings At Bali Clubs
abstract: Indonesian police arrest Ali Ghufron, better known as Mukhlas, who is suspected of being senior commander in regional terrorist network Jemaah Islamiyah and key participant in Bali attack; diplomats and security officials hail arrest, in central Java, as big step in learning more about network and its links to Al Qaeda; he is brother of Amrozi, one of first people arrested in connection with Oct nightclub bombing; is also wanted in Singapore in Dec 2001 plot to blow up American Embassy there; arrest marks toughening in Indonesian government's attitude and policy toward terrorism; fact that he had not fled Indonesia raises questions about whereabouts of other Qaeda members and whether their list of potential hiding places is dwindling; United States and Australia are now focusing search for terrorists in area that includes southern Philippines and remote reaches of Borneo, island divided between Indonesia and Malaysia (M)

headline: Attention, Cows: Please Speak Into the Microphone
abstract: Voice recognition techniques are being used in system called Bowlingual; for example, cows' moos can be interpreted when compared to 700 recorded 'vocalizations' and alert farmer to what they mean; more entertaining use is trying to interpret dogs' barks; photos (M)

headline: SHPS, A HEALTH CARE COMPANY, PLANS TO ACQUIRE EBENX
abstract: SHPS, closely held provider of human resources and health services, agrees to buy EBenX, employee health benefits management firm, for about $98 million cash, or $4.85 a share (S)

headline: DELTA ANNOUNCES A NEW LOW-COST AIRLINE DIVISION
abstract: Delta Air Lines elaborates on its plans to begin low-fare carrier in 2003 that will replace its Delta Express unit and fly some of same routes; still-unnamed low-fare company will run as separate unit of airline; fares will be $99 to $299 each way (S)2

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Trying to Spur Recovery, Fed Cuts Interest Rate  The Federal Reserve cut its main interest rate by half a percentage point, an aggressive move to ward off renewed economic weakness at a time when the terrorist threat and the confrontation with Iraq are weighing down business and consumer confidence.    But the Fed hinted that it does not plan to cut rates again when it meets in five weeks, reflecting a view within the central bank that rates are low enough. [Page A1.]

headline: Australia Comes to Terms With a New Sense of Vulnerability
abstract: Australian officials have belatedly come to realize that terrorists pose threat to Australia in wake of Bali bombing that killed 88 Australians; cite effort by Jack Roche, British immigrant who converted to Islam, to establish clandestine cell for Al Qaeda and Jemaah Islamiyah and to plan bombing of Israeli missions in Australia; Roche, who was arrested in Nov, withdrew from both tasks; officials seek other Al Qaeda recruits and say Jemaah Islamiyah has cells in three cities; map; photos (M)

headline: G.M. Completes Financing For Auto Venture in Korea
abstract: General Motors Corp completes financing for its part ownership of South Korea's Daewoo Motor; new company, to be called GM-Daewoo Auto and Technology, will formally open its doors on Oct 17, bolstered by $2 billion in new loans from state-owned Korea Development Bank and three commercial banks; development bank is also investing $197 million to acquire 33 percent of new company; rest is owned by GM's partner companies in Asia, Suzuki Motor and Shanghai Automotive Industry; GM is putting $251 million into venture, but it is assuming almost none of former car company's $16 billion in debts (M)

headline: G.I.'s Are as Merry as Possible, Considering
abstract: 2,000 US troops in Kuwait celebrate Christmas in desert with football games, turkey dinners and calls to home; photo (S)

headline: Muslim Parties' Election Strength Weakens Musharraf
abstract: Results in Pakistan's first nationwide voting in seven years leave country's military ruler, Gen Pervez Musharraf, in weakened political position to crack down on Islamic militancy along Afghan border; Musharraf emerges from elections with diminished mandate for his support of American campaign against terrorism since Sept 11 attacks last year; photo (M)

headline: Expanded U.N. Teams Pick Up Pace of Site Visits but Lack Details From Iraq
abstract: United Nations teams pick up pace of arms inspections in Iraq; send largest team of nuclear experts yet for third inspection of Al Tuweitha nuclear complex; inspectors also examine two related nuclear sites and sprawling military-industrial plant near Al Fallujah, where they search for chemical plants that played role in Iraq's chemical arms program in 1980's and 90's; growing momentum was aided by arrival of 25 inspectors to join 17 in initial party; number of inspectors is to rise to about 100 by Christmas and maximum of 300 early in 2003; photo (M)

headline: Revised Contract for WorldCom's New Chief Executive Wins Approval From 2 Judges
abstract: Two federal judges approved a compensation plan yesterday for the new chief executive of WorldCom, Michael D. Capellas, which guarantee him $20 million in cash and stock over the next three years.    The approvals clear the way for Mr. Capellas to formally assume a job he has essentially been doing for weeks. Mr. Capellas, a former computer executive, has been working at WorldCom since Dec. 2 without a formal contract. Because of that, he has been unable to sign contracts or make other deals on the company's behalf.

headline: Pierre Peugeot, 70, Chairman of Leading French Carmaker
abstract: Pierre Peugeot, chairman of French automaker Peugeot, dies at age 70; photo (M)

headline: AT LEAST 10 KILLED IN SUICIDE BOMBING OF JERUSALEM BUS
abstract: Suicide bomber detonates powerful explosion on crowded morning rush hour bus, Jerusalem, killing at least 10 passengers and wounding dozens; attack follows months of relative calm in city; Israeli soldiers shoot and kill second Palestinian youth, Tulkarm, West Bank; say boys were throwing gasoline bombs; Palestinians say they threw rocks; photos (M)

headline: Rosary to Undergo First Change in Centuries, Vatican Says
abstract: Pope John Paul II will make a significant change in the rosary, a signature method of Catholic prayer for many centuries.

headline: Accenture Posts Quarterly Profit
abstract: Accenture says net income was $38.1 million in its fourth quarter, compared with net loss of $369 million year earlier; sales declined to $2.69 billion from $2.78 billion (M)

headline: MediaTalk; Different Face for Cover Of Popular Mechanics
abstract: Popular Mechanics magazine presents depiction of Jesus as envisioned by forensic anthropologists, a dark-skinned man with bushy beard and curly hair, 5 foot 1 and weighing about 110 pounds; cover photo (S)

headline: Qaeda Uses Teeming Karachi As New Base, Pakistanis Say
abstract: Pakistani officials say Al Qaeda members are trying to re-establish their network in Karachi, with support from local people, elaborate secrecy and Internet communication; say story of Ramzi bin al-Shibh's final month of freedom and his chaotic arrest illustrates why it is proving so difficult to eliminate Al Qaeda; say bin al-Shibh, thought to be key planner of Sept 11 terrorist attacks on World Trade Center and Pentagon, lived quietly in Karachi, 10 miles from American Consulate, and spent his days with Qaeda friends, logging on to Internet and at night playing cards; Pakistani officials are convinced that Al Qaeda's operations head Khalid Shaikh Mohammed remains in Karachi, hiding in apartment, just as bin al-Shibh did; Mohammed, one of America's most sought men, is alleged mastermind of Sept 11 attacks; Pakistani officials say bin al-Shibh's arrest disrupted Al Qaeda's network in Karachi but did not eliminate it; yearlong crackdown by Gen Pervez Musharraf has failed to stop Pakistani militants from aiding Qaeda members; photo (L)

headline: Buick uses a mid-20th-century designer to lure younger buyers, but also brings out the skeptics.
abstract: Buick division of General Motors Corp, in effort to try to revive its image among younger car buyers, is introducing advertising campaign built around late Harley Earl, who designed cars from 1920's into 50's; McCann-Erickson created ads; photo (M)

headline: Climate Talks Will Shift Focus From Emissions
abstract: Latest round of international talks on global warming opens in New Delhi, with focus more on adapting to changes than on cutting emissions of gases; shift follows Bush administration's rejection of Kyoto protocol, which has little effect without US acceptance (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Executive Selected
abstract: France Telecom's board is expected to appoint Thierry Breton as chairman and chief executive (S)

headline: CNN's Parent May Postpone News Merger With ABC
abstract: Executives at CNN and ABC News make progress in merger negotiations, but say AOL Time Warner, CNN's parent, may postpone finalizing merger, perhaps for months, to deal with other issues roiling company; say board approval could also hinge on position of Ted Turner, AOL Time Warner vice chairman and CNN founder, who is said to want assurances that CNN will be dominant partner in new entity; remain confident that deal will happen because it will result in 'hundreds of millions in cost savings and revenue gains'; Tom Wolzien, analyst for Sanford C Bernstein, says he can find no more than $100 million in cost savings and revenue gains (M)

headline: Miscellany
abstract: Radio Advertising Bureau reports that ad revenue for radio improved in August, continuing trend, increasing 5 percent from August 2001 (S)

headline: Omnicom Has 37% Increase In Earnings
abstract: Omnicom Group says third-quarter earnings increased 37 percent; net income increased to $126.1 million from $92.4 million year earlier; sales rose 13 percent, to $1.77 billion from $1.57 billion (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Wheat For U.N. Food Agency
abstract: Russia, in its first-ever donation to United Nations World Food Program, pledges 30,000 tons of wheat to agency's programs in southern Africa, Afghanistan, and North Korea (S)

headline: Researcher Is Accusing Energy Firms Of Deception
abstract: Energy researcher Michele Markey assert that some of nation's largest energy traders appear to have reported false data about price of natural gas to one of industry's leading publications, Gas Daily; tells California lawmakers that she has long suspected that prices she received in last few years were erroneous (M)

headline: Dreaming of Palestine, Teenager Writes a Novel
abstract: Profile of and interview with 16-year-old Randa Ghazy, whose novel Dreaming of Palestine was published in Italy last spring and has since been translated into six languages; Ghazy, born and reared in Italy by parents who emigrated from Egypt, comments on controversy that her book, fiery case against Israeli's treatment of Palestinians, has raised; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Oil Seeps From Sunken Tanker
abstract: Sunken oil tanker Prestige is reported to be leaking up to 37,500 gallons of fuel per day from 15 cracks in its hull; leaking fuel continues to threaten Galician coast, dashing Spanish government hopes that oil will solidify (S)

headline: AOL Chairman to Present New Initiatives
abstract: Jonathan Miller, recently named chairman of America Online, is expected to address two daunting issues when he lays out his new strategy to investors on Dec 3: how to find new sources of revenue to replace lucrative advertising and marketing deals made during Internet boom and how to persuade growing number of people who connect to Internet over broadband connections to pay $10 more a month for AOL service than for similar services from telephone or cable companies; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: DOLLAR IS MIXED. The dollar was little changed against the euro and the yen. In New York, the dollar settled at 120.37 yen, down from 120.44 yen on Thursday. The euro traded at $1.0269, down from $1.0275.

headline: Coca-Cola to Start Harry Potter Promotion
abstract: Coca-Cola Co will begin second round of advertising and promotional campaign tied to Harry Potter films being released by Warner Brothers; promotion centers on second film in series Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets; Coca-Cola is working with two units of McCann-Erickson World Group (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Sri Lanka: Rebel Leader Sees Mediators
abstract: Velupillai Prabhakaran, reclusive leader of Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam, participates in second round of peace talks with Norwegian mediators; talks are aimed at ending civil war; photo (S)

headline: 'Rebel Colonel,' Ecuador Favorite, Adopts Capitalist Look
abstract: Ecuador presidential candidate Lucio Gutierrez, favored to win, campaigns in pro-capitalist tone that is sharp change from his role as rebellious army colonel who led revolt that toppled president just three years ago; photo; Gutierrez promises to create jobs with economic reforms and foreign investment, pay Ecuador's debt, negotiate deal with IMF and allow US military to continue using its air base in country (M)

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Realistic War Games.

headline: A Lingerie Maker Returns To Its Racier Past
abstract: Frederick's of Hollywood is coming back from bankruptcy with new image intended to attract younger shoppers; chief executive Linda LoRe hopes to come out of Chapter 11 ready to restore company to its rightful status as spicier alternative to Victoria's Secret; bankruptcy hearing is set for Nov 6; LoRe comments; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: ITALY: Death Threat In Andreotti Case; ITALY: Charges Of Highway Robbery;.

headline: OMNICARE CLOSER TO BUYING NCS AFTER RIVAL STEPS ASIDE
abstract: Genesis Health Ventures Inc gives up bid to buy NCS HealthCare Inc, possibly clearing way for rival, Omnicare Inc, to acquire company for about $130 million in stock (S)

headline: Mexican TV Producer Is Set To Sign Up New York Affiliate
abstract: Mexican television production company and broadcaster TV Azteca is expected to add channel WXNY in New York City as its 18th United States affiliate station; Azteca is trying to reach more of highly coveted Hispanic consumer market in US and attract lucrative national and local advertising accounts (M)

headline: World Survey Says Negative Views of U.S. Are Rising
abstract: Pew Research Center for the People and the Press survey of 38,000 people in 44 countries finds people in most non-Muslim nations continue to view United States favorably, but that negative opinions have increased in most nations over past two years; finds wide support for US-led drive against terrorism since Sept 11 attacks is tempered by large minorities or even majorities in many nations that say Bush administration ignores their nation's interests; most people surveyed in several nations with Muslim majorities oppose drive; followup Nov polls in Britain, France, Germany and Russia find substantial percentages of people believe main reason US would go to war with Iraq would be to control Iraqi oil, view held by only 22 percent of Americans; graphs (M)

headline: Are These Folks Crazy, or Cordless? New Sets Make Wireless Weirder
abstract: New cellphone headsets from Bluetooth and Jabra dispense with wire from ear to phone; photo (S)

headline: SOUTH KOREA: Chang Yong Jin
abstract: SEOUL—  Chang Yong Jin

headline: Voice on the Tape: 'You Will Be Bombed'
abstract: Excerpts from audiotape attributed to Osama bin Laden (S)1

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Enron Records Contradict Denials of Speculating  Even as Enron's top executives were insisting that the company did not engage in speculative trading, Enron was reaping the bulk of its profits during the California energy crisis betting on the direction of gas and electricity prices, according to company records and interviews with former Enron traders and executives.    Enron made the profitable bets -- including one that resulted in a $485 million gain on one day in December 2000 -- at a time when investigators say it was conspiring with other companies to manipulate prices. [Page A1.]

headline: Space War Remembered
abstract: Seth Steinberg letter responds to Nov 7 article on computer-aided astronomy; notes that Space War, possibly original video game, began as astronomical test program

headline: To Build Coalition, U.S. Legislators Tour Iraq's Kurdish Region, Pledging Support
abstract: Delegation from Senate Foreign Relations Committee tours Kurdish-controlled northern Iraq and pledges American support as part of coalition being assembled against Saddam Hussein; members say Kurds must participate in united Iraq, must resist civil war and must understand concerns of their neighbors, a reference to Turkey; photo (M)

headline: Indians See Their Political Influence Rising in Ecuador
abstract: Lucio Gutierrez, presidential candidate in Ecuador, is popular among indigenous groups that have always felt ignored by traditional politicians; political experts expect Indians to vote for Gutierrez, former colonel, in big numbers against his opponent, Alvaro Noboa, who controls world's fourth largest banana company; for Indians, a victory would underscore their growing political power; Gutierrez is not an Indian, but his dark complexion and easy manner is appealing in country where great majority of people are not white but are led by white minority; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Koreas: Talks To Resume Tomorrow
abstract: Negotiators from North and South Korea are set to resume talks that will focus on rail and road connections (S)

headline: Chechens Seize Moscow Theater, Taking as Many as 600 Hostages
abstract: Forty Chechen guerrillas wearing masks and camouflage and firing automatic rifles storm into crowded theater in Moscow and take up to 600 hostages, threatening to blow up building; witnesses say guerrillas have wired themselves and three-story music hall with explosives and appear to be preparing for assault by police; Russia's domestic intelligence agency says attackers are demanding end to war in Chechnya as well as large amount of money; Moscow police officials deny that negotiations have been opened with guerrillas or that ransom demand has been made; gunshots ring out periodically from building and there are reports that one man has been taken to hospital and that grenade was tossed at police; truckloads of police officers and soldiers surround building and block off streets; Pres Vladimir V Putin cancels planned visit to Germany and orders alite Alpha counterterrorist squad to scene; clearly terrified hostage, speaking from inside theater on cellphone, warns that any attempt by police or soldiers to enter building would end in carnage; guerrillas release unknown number of hostages, mostly children, at outset of seizure; photos; map (L)

headline: Rosie, the Magazine, Lays Off Staff
abstract: Almost the entire staff of Rosie magazine -- 120 people -- was laid off this morning at Gruner & Jahr USA.

headline: Technology Shares Leading the Way in a Year-End Rally
abstract: Technology stocks lead year-end rally; stocks are little changed in holiday-shortened trading; Dow Jones industrial average falls 35.59 points, to 8,896.09; S&P 500 slips 2.56 points, to 936.31; Nasdaq composite index falls 9.16 points, to 1,478.78; table shows favorite stocks; graph of Dow Jones industrial averatge, Nov 2001-Nov 2002 (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Sweden: Ericsson's Loss Rises
abstract: Swedish wireless network equipment maker Ericsson reports $596 million third-quarter loss, exceeding deficit posted in year-earlier period (S)

headline: Taking French Children's Fashion Global
abstract: French children's apparel company Jacadi plans to double number of its retail outlets worldwide in next three years from about 400 today; Jean-Pierre Charpentier runs company; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Airlines Post Profits
abstract: Korean Air and Asiana, the South Korea airlines, both posted profits for the third quarter of this year because of South Korea's economic recovery. Korean Air, South Korea's flagship airline, earned $70 million after having lost $83.5 million in the quarterly period a year earlier. Asiana reported a profit of $41.4 million after losing $28 million in the comparable period of 2001. Korean Air's profit was lower than expected, according to analysts in Seoul, while Asiana's exceeded expectations. Despite the turnaround in the fortunes of the airlines, investors feared that a war in Iraq could drive profits down and cause oil prices to increase.   Don Kirk (NYT)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Panasonic Reaches Pact On Digital Services
abstract: Panasonic Co becomes first major television manufacturer to strike deal with cable television industry to make televisions that can display digital television services without requiring set-top box; receives required certification from CableLabs, cable industry's research consortium (S)

headline: Stop the Clock? Critics Call the Billable Hour a Legal Fiction
abstract: There is widespread consensus among lawyers, judges, recruiters and academics that hourly billing leads to punishing work schedules, unhappy lawyers, ill-served clients, over-lawyered cases, perverse incentives and outright fraud; Robert E Hirshon, departing president of American Bar Assn, traces many of legal profession's contemporary woes to billable hour; many lawyers feel only realistic career solution would be to move from law firm to corporate law department or academic position that does not require tracking one's hours; drawing (Special Section, Working) (M)

headline: Text: Announcement of 2002 Nobel Peace Prize
abstract: Following is the complete text of the Norwegian Nobel Committee's announcement of the 2002 Nobel Peace Prize today as distributed by the committee:.

headline: Spain Loves a Pop Music Show, but Critics Hate the Reality
abstract: Operacion Triunfo, extremely popular Spanish reality television show that manufactures pop stars, prompts quixotic campaign by more than 100 musicians and critics, who complain about show's near monopoly of television music; show's contestants dominate Spanish record charts, and critics say show is elbowing out other music programs from prime-time space on public television (M)

headline: People and Accounts of Note
abstract: The Advertising Agency Council of Long Island named Ed Brennan, vice president, as president, succeeding Lyn Nielsen.

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Silicon Graphics Increases Supercomputer Speed
abstract: Silicon Graphics Inc increases speed of its supercomputers by one-third in attempt to remain competitive with International Business Machines, whose similar model sells for more than twice SGI's $2.9 million (S)

headline: Keeping J. Lo in Spotlight Has Risks for Her Career As Well as Rich Rewards
abstract: Jennifer Lopez, singer and star of forthcoming film Maid in Manhattan, and men guiding her career are working to prevent overexposure and to see that she does not spread herself too thin as she branches out from her hip-hop roots; Thomas D Mottola, chairman and chief executive of Sony Music Entertainment, Benny Medina, Lopez's agent, and Lopez confer on all matters, from which tracks to put on album to movie scripts and ways to tweak her image; photos (M)

headline: Fitch Downgrades Interpublic's Debt
abstract: Fitch Ratings downgrades senior unsecured debt of Interpublic Group of Companies (S)

headline: South Korea's President-Elect Faces New North Korean Test
abstract: North Korea's decision to remove seals on ponds containing spent fuel rods at its nuclear complex at Yongbyon presidents Pres-elect Roh Moo Hyun with first test of his campaign pledge to maintain South Korea's policy of reconciliation with North; he and Pres Kim Dae Jung are expected to demand that North Korea abandon its nuclear weapons program, even though they both differ with US on how to get North to acquiesce (M)

headline: Patents; In the season of bubbly, a bottle cap that better regulates the bubbles, and an easier way to get the plastic corks out.
abstract: Pelliconi, maker of bottle caps, patents new type of Champagne crown that it claims gives producers better control over bubbles during production-fermentation process; Darryl Weaver seeks patent for new type of Champagne cork remover (M)

headline: After Freeing Dissident, Burmese Rulers Move Slowly on Reform
abstract: Myanmar's military rulers seem

headline: Free, Fast Browser in a Box Does More Than Simply Search
abstract: GoBox is free all-in-one search tool that provide access to various search engines and news pages and can be customized by location (S)

headline: Pop-Up 'Alerts': Spam In Sheep's Clothing
abstract: Q. An alert box popped up on my screen the other day, and I assumed that it indicated a serious Windows XP error. Then I read closely and realized that it was an advertisement. How can advertisers take over my computer's dialogue boxes like this, and how can I prevent it?    A. The advertisement disguised as a system alert box that you saw is a new type of spam favored by some advertisers.

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Kenya: Opposition Candidate For President
abstract: Kenyan opposition parties merge to support Mwai Kibaki as their presidential candidate; assert themselves as a group hoping unity will bring an end to 39 years governed by Kenya Africa National Union party; photo (S)

headline: Bankruptcy Filing Expected For Health Services' Lender
abstract: National Century Financial Enterprises is expected to file for bankruptcy as early as November 18; filing is being organized by Alvarez & Marsal, turnaround firm hired by board to stabilize its finances (M)

headline: Cheating on international exams also said to be widespread : In China, flood of fake diplomas
abstract: BEIJING—  Ever since it launched market-oriented reforms of its socialist educational system in the 1990s, the Chinese government has struggled to wean college students from their long-standing expectations of subsidized schooling, and persuade them instead that an advanced degree was worth paying for.

headline: Technology Briefing: Telecommunications
abstract: NEXTEL PLANS TO CURB SPENDING; NOKIA RETREATS FROM EARLIER GROWTH FORECAST;.

headline: HANCOCK LOWERS QUARTERLY ESTIMATE 9 CENTS A SHARE
abstract: John Hancock Financial Services reduces its third-quarter earnings estimate by $27.5 million, or 9 cents a share (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: F.T.C. Approves Sale Of I.B.M. Unit To Hitachi
abstract: International Business Machines gets Federal Trade Commission clearance for $2.05 billion sale of its computer hard-disk drive business to Hitachi Ltd (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Hewlett-Packard Co signs five-year pact to provide computers and services to DirecTV (S)

headline: ERROR BY BB&T PUTS ACQUISITION PLAN IN DOUBT
abstract: BB&T is forced to cancel plan to buy Florida First Bancorp Inc for $134.8 million because of precedural error that violated federal regulations (S)

abstract: THE HAGUE: Effort To Speed Milosevic Trial; SWITZERLAND: Inquiry On Ex-Argentine Leader; NORTHERN IRELAND: Man Released In Spy Case; RUSSIA: More Ill From Tainted Dairy Products;.

headline: Brussels Journal; Deep in the Heart of Europe, Trying Not to Fit In
abstract: Brussels hosts several European organizations, including European Parliament whose members include Euro-skeptics mistrustful of super-national institutions; British Tory delegates Roger Helmer and Christopher Heaton-Harris and Danish members Jens-Peter Bonde and Ole Krarup comment; photos (Brussels Journal) (M)

headline: In Grief, Israeli Family Questions Army Aid to Settlers
abstract: Family of Cpl Keren Yaacoby, first Israeli woman in army to die in combat since Sept 2000, questions high cost to other Israelis of protecting religious Jewish settlements in West Bank; Yaacoby was killed with fellow soldier by Palestinian gunmen while guarding Hebron settlement; settlers, paying visit to mourners, defend settlements; photos (M)

headline: Foreign Banks Are Reported To Be Bidders In Korea
abstract: Foreign banks are bidding for South Korean government's 80 percent stake in Chohung Bank; front-runner appears to be South Korea's Shinhan Financial Holding; Korea First Bank says it still wants to acquire Chohung and has financial capacity; Chohung is valued at more than $2 billion (M)1

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Elan Sells A Product
abstract: Irish drug maker Elan will sell off Abelcet, anti-fungal drug that it acquired in 2000, for $370 million; manufacturing plant in Indiana and more than 150 employees will transfer to buyer Enzon, but Elan will retain European rights to Abelcet; graph (S)

headline: J. P. Morgan Plans Job Cuts Up to 4,000, Executives Say
abstract: J P Morgan Chase will eliminate as many as 4,000 employees, including many managing directors, from its investment banking operations; write-offs and loan-loss reserves will rise for third quarter which, compounded by weak trading results, will produce earnings below analysts' estimates; other banks make similar efforts to pare down costs before year-end; 60,000 Wall Street workers have lost jobs in last two years (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Fees Are Criticized
abstract: World Business BriÔ

headline: Can Maxim, A Magazine For Young Men, Translate to TV?
abstract: Dennis Publishing, publisher of successful Maxim magazine, plans two television specials on ESPN and NBC that are related to magazine; Dennis Publishing is co-sponsor of The Maxim NFL Beach Bash in February, one-hour ESPN show that will run after Pro Bowl and feature actors Jennifer Love-Hewitt and Orlando Jones as hosts; special will be partly awards show and partly filled with parodies of hit TV shows; Maxim's Hot 100, issue of magazine that displays women on rise in variety of fields--and poses--will come to life as one-hour show on NBC in June; Dennis Publishing owner Felix Dennis says programs are just beginning of effort to develop entire cable channel called Maxim Entertainment Network, or MEN; photo (M)

headline: In Bitter Race In Argentina, Peronists Trip Each Other
abstract: Argentine politics remains as chaotic as ever, even as battered economy shows signs of finally hitting bottom; fierce dispute between Pres Eduardo Duhalde and former Pres Carlos Menem plunges governing Peronists into crisis threatening election timetable; Peronists cannot even agree when to hold presidential nominating primary; Duhalde's candidate, Carlos Reutemann, has declined to run, so Duhalde wants more time to stitch together coalition; beneficiary is Adolfo Rodriguez Saa, who is running as old-fashioned populist (M)

headline: NATO Backs Bush on Iraq but Germans Oppose War
abstract: The 19 leaders of NATO joined today in demanding that Iraq "fully and completely" comply with a U.N. resolution to disarm.

headline: READER'S DIGEST REVISES PLAN AFTER LAWSUITS
abstract: Reader's Digest Association Inc revises stock-conversion plan that was opposed by some investors; plan, which would replace two classes of shares with single class, calls for Reader's Digest to buy 4.6 million Class B shares from its main shareholders, Lila Wallace-Reader's Digest Fund and DeWitt Wallace-Reader's Digest Fund; company will pay $21.75 per share, or $100 million (S)

headline: World Briefing | United Nations: Seeking Aid
abstract: United Nations hopes to raise more than $3 billion for annual Consolidated Inter-Agency Appeal; fund aids 50 million people in 30 countries (S)

headline: On Covers of Many Magazines, A Full Racial Palette Is Still Rare
abstract: Blacks rarely appear on covers of mass-circulation magazines, whether men's or women's, entertainment publications or teenagers' magazines; this may reflect fact that only 6.1 percent of magazine industry's professional staff is nonwhite, but another factor may be ingrained conservatism of industry in which everyone is afraid of making a misstep; some black and Hispanic women are making inroads, but black males are still mainly restricted to sports and music magazines; photos; graphs (M)

headline: BUSINESS TRAVEL: ON THE GROUND -- In Nashville; There's the Country Music And Other Good Stuff, Too
abstract: Travel article on Nashville, Tenn; city's highlights noted; photo (M)

headline: Clean Your Closet and Save on Taxes
abstract: Income Dynamics produces booklet and software that provide suggested values for tax purposes of about 2,000 items that are commonly donated to charity; table (S)

headline: Russians Extend Media Restrictions From Hostage Crisis
abstract: Moscow news radio station Ekho Moskvy says it weighs moving its Web site abroad after Russia forced site to remove interview with Chechen guerrilla holding hostages at Moscow theater and pressured news media to limit coverage of hostage crisis; Parliament, 231-106, approves even tougher curbs on reports on counterterrorism efforts; journalists and other free-speech advocates warn of further censorship; photo (M)

headline: Researchers Say Science Is Hurt by Secrecy Policy Set Up by the White House
abstract: Presidents of National Academies say Bush administration is going too far in limiting publication of some scientific research out of concern that it could aid terrorists; says policy threatens to stifle scientific creativity and to weaken national security; say administration has already withdrawn thousands of reports and papers deemed sensitive but unclassified from public domain (M)

headline: Tokyo Journal; Teaching Japan's Salarymen to Be Their Own Men
abstract: tokyo journal: teaching Japan

headline: WALL STREET FIRMS ARE READY TO PAY $1 BILLION IN FINES
abstract: Nation's biggest brokerage firms reportedly agree to pay almost $1 billion in fines to end investigations into whether they issued misleading stock recommendations and handed out hot new shares to curry favor with corporate clients; firms also agree to sweeping changes in way research is done on Wall Street and way new stocks are distributed; firms also agree to pay additional $500 million over five years to buy stock research from independent analysts and distribute it to investors; agreement comes after five months of fractious negotiations between firms and securities regulators; goal is to force Wall Street to produce honest stock research and to protect analysts from pressure within firm to issue upbeat forecasts to attract investment banking fees; deal will bar brokerage firms from dispensing hot stocks to top executives or directors of public companies; broad agreement does not include punishment of any Wall Street analysts or executives who supervised them; state and national regulators may still pursue investigations of some analysts; photo; chart (L)

headline: Indonesia Orders Muslim Cleric to Undergo Questioning
abstract: Abu Bakar Bashir, fundamentalist Islamic preacher linked to Al Qaeda and string of terrorist attacks in Southeast Asia, is ordered to appear for questioning by Indonesian police; heads Jemaah Islamiyah, which American officials believe was involved in Bali bombing; Bashir is declared admirer of Osama bin Laden; it is not clear if he would be arrested or detained under new emergency powers Indonesian Parliament just granted government; measure allows country's intelligence agency to detain terrorist suspects for year without trial, and provides for death penalty in most severe cases; Indonesian government has long been criticized by United States for its refusal to take terrorism seriously; planned interrogation of Bashir comes as government seeks to shore up political support among moderate Muslims for more aggressive action against Jemaah Islamiyah; photo (M)

headline: The Week's Economic Events
abstract: MONDAYNone.

headline: Equity Offerings Scheduled for This Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:    Advance Auto Parts Inc., Roanoke, Va., 8.6 million shares. Credit Suisse First Boston and Merrill Lynch.    Chesapeake Energy Corp., Oklahoma City, 20 million shares. Credit Suisse First Boston, Morgan Stanley and Salomon Smith Barney.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Spain: Talking With Morocco
abstract: Agreement has been reached to try and restore diplomatic relations between Spain and Morocco; disagreement began over ownership of Parsley Island (S)

headline: Japan and U.S.: Bubble, Bubble, Toil and Trouble
abstract: Few economists expect US to remain in doldrums as long as Japan has since its stock market and real estate bubble burst in 1990, but there are some disturbing parallels between early years of Japanese downturn and American record since Wall Street started to fall in early 2000; overall US stock market is likely to decline this year for third consecutive year, its longest losing streak since 1939-41; none of American economy's three engines -- consumers, business or government -- appear poised to propel nation sharply ahead in near future; graphs; photo (M)

headline: Seoul Leader Joins Calls For U.S. Action On Girls' Death
abstract: Pres Kim Dae Jung tells Sens Ted Stevens and Daniel K Inouye that South Koreans do not understand why no one has been held responsible for deaths of two teenage girls crushed by American armored vehicle in June; warns issue makes it hard to head off rising anti-Americanism; political activists gather signatures for petition demanding surrender to Korean authorities of two sergeants absolved by US military court; two have returned to US (M)

headline: Canada's Health Care System Needs More Money, Panel Says
abstract: Canadian government commission recommends major increase in federal financing for national health care program to shore up its finances and bar development of parallel system of private medical services; commission head Roy J Romanow calls for some $4 billion increase in annual spending over three years to stabilize system's finances and expand coverage and services (M)

headline: SLOT MACHINE MAKER SELLS OFF CASINOS IN COLORADO
abstract: International Game Technology, leading maker of slot machines, agrees to sell its Colorado casinos to Isle of Capri Black Hawk for $84 million (S)

headline: Israeli Forces Again Seize Control of Palestinian West Bank City
abstract: Israeli forces again tighten their grip on West Bank city of Jenin in what Israel says is hunt for terrorist cell behind suicide attack that killed 14 people on Oct 21; incursion comes as Bush administration envoy William J Burns tries for thrid day to promote 'road map' toward peace; in separate development, Israeli Army announces it has withdrawn troops from most Palestinian areas of Hebron (M)

headline: North Korea Demands U.S. Agree to Nonagression Pact
abstract: North Korea demands that United States agree to nonagression pact before giving up its nuclear weapons program, statement; says Pres Bush's inclusion of North Korea as part of 'axis of evil' amounts to 'declaration of war' that threatens North Korea's existence; photo (M)

headline: Irish Crackdown on Drivers Quickly Cuts Fatalities
abstract: During the 1990's, skyrocketing car ownership in Ireland and a treacherously dilapidated road network became a deadly combination, and deaths on the roads steadily increased.    But since an aggressive government minister took the helm of a newly established transportation department this summer, a dizzying array of new rules and reforms has altered what it means to drive in Ireland. The crackdown is already credited with cutting the number of fatal accidents down to levels unseen in years.

headline: Advertisers Association Names a President
abstract: The Association of National Advertisers in New York will promote an executive to succeed John J. Sarsen Jr., the president and chief executive for almost nine years, who is retiring, executives of the association said.

headline: Greenspan's Speech Focuses On Deflation, Not Inflation
abstract: Federal Reserve Chmn Alan Greenspan warns, in speech to Economic Club of New York, that deflation, general decline in prices, could be more damaging to United States economic growth than inflation; repeats past assertions that American economy is not near falling into deflation; renders cautious assessment of economic outlook; photo; table (M)

headline: BUSINESS TRAVEL: ON THE GROUND -- In Lisbon; An Accessible City With an Empire in Its Past
abstract: Travel article on Lisbon; city's highlights noted; photo (M)

headline: For Now, Insurers Say Risk Is A Hard Sell
abstract: Merrill Lynch analyst Jay A Cohen discusses prospects for recovery of property and casualty insurance industry and stocks of companies within industry; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing: Americas
abstract: JAMAICA: Voting For New Parliament; BRAZIL: Gangsters Attack Governor'S Palace;.

headline: CHIEF QUITS AT INSTINET'S ELECTRONIC TRADING UNIT
abstract: Island ECN says president-chief executive Matthew Andresen has resigned to become head of global trading at Sanford C Bernstein & Co; chief technology officer Will Sterling replaces Andresen as president (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Troubled Telecom Debt
abstract: Alestra, troubled Mexican long-distance carrier that is 49 percent owned by AT&T, will be unable to make $35 million interest payment due; proposes restructuring package to avert falling into default; reports third-quarter net loss of $32 million and 12 percent decline in total traffic (S)

headline: World Briefing: Asia
abstract: THE KOREAS: Envoy Ready For Talks; BANGLADESH: Acid Attacks On Rise;.

headline: New York Police Select Hodes for Campaign
abstract: New York City Police Department selects Bernard Hodes Group to handle creative duties on ad assigment to spur recruitment (S)

headline: Technology Briefing: E-Commerce
abstract: INFINEON SIGNS CHIP DEAL WITH KINGSTON; NEXTEL SAYS IT WILL MEET 2002 FORECASTS;.

headline: British Cable Company Is Said to Get Loan
abstract: Telewest Communications, the second-biggest cable-television operator in Britain after NTL, has agreed to the terms of a £2 billion ($3.1 billion) bank loan that would allow it stay in business, people familiar with the talks said.    About 30 banks will provide the money to replace existing debt and finance operations. The agreement with Telewest's main banks will also allow it to complete a plan to hand bondholders control in return for £3.5 billion ($5.4 billion) of debt.    In September, Telewest said it would give bondholders 97 percent of the equity in return for all its outstanding bonds. The unprofitable company accumulated debt building networks and buying rivals in a bid to compete with Rupert Murdoch's British Sky Broadcasting Group.

headline: Agency Executives Change Jobs
abstract: Several senior agency executives are making moves.    The Publicis Groupe in Paris named David Droga, the executive creative director at one of its agencies, Saatchi & Saatchi in London, to the new post of worldwide creative director at another of its agencies, Publicis Worldwide.

headline: World Briefing: Asia
abstract: JAPAN: Human Rights Advocate Missing In China; INDIA: Peaceful Festival After Terror Scare; SOUTH KOREA: Officials Quit After Suspect'S Death;.

headline: Sales explode to cater to wahines and their wannabes : Surfwear's making a big splash
abstract: PARIS—  California, the pioneer of skater chic and sophisticated sportswear, has now sent out a tsunami of trendy surfwear for women. When most people think about women surfing, images of the 1960s Gidget films and Annette Funicello, the star of "Beach Blanket Bingo," come to mind — with men wearing wigs to double as the female stars for the necessary surfing shots.

headline: Organizer With a Low Price Has High-End Features
abstract: Royal Consumer Information Products hand-held organizer offers usual functions as well as modem and e-mail capability for low price; photo (M)

headline: FIVE QUESTIONS for DEREK YACH; Fighting Fat by Going to the Source
abstract: Five Questions column interviews World Health Organization official Dr Derek Yach about private meetings held with executives from some large food and beverage companies that are concerned about effects on their businesses of agency's efforts to fight global proliferation of unhealthy, fattening foods; WHO estimates that one billion people worldwide are overweight or obese; photo (M)

headline: At a Crossroad, Brazil's Undecided Consider a Left Turn
abstract: Brazil's 115 million voters will decide whether they want leftist government in what everyone in Brazil recognizes as watershed presidential election; front-runner in race has been Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva of left-wing Workers' Party, who polls say is favored by 48 percent of voters; da Silva would be first working-class president in Brazil's history if elected; Jose Serra of centrist Brazilian Social Democratic Party is gaining some ground bujt is still running more than 25 points behind da Silva; photo (M)

headline: Taxes; Additional Cuts To Revive Growth
abstract: Prime concern of several business groups is getting tax reductions to stimulate economic growth while holding down government spending to avoid structural budget deficits that would persist even after economy recovers; Republican dominance of recent elections makes it more likely that Pres Bush's tax-cutting plans will receive warmer reception in Congress (S)

headline: Saudi Tries to Calm U.S. Opinion
abstract: Profile of Adel al-Jubeir, polished and earnest young Saudi official who is trying to mend fences with United States in wake of furor that arose over report that money from Saudi royal princess--wife of Saudi ambassador--might have been diverted to two of Sept 11 hijackers; Jubeir has become increasingly familiar face in US; in many ways, he is perfect interlocutor, moving breezily between two vastly different lands and staking out common ground; he plans to present detailed accounting of his nation's moves in fight against terrorism; photo (M)

headline: Ottawa to Ease Effect of U.S. Lumber Tariff
abstract: Canada announces aid package valued at 247 million Canadian dollars ($155 million) to help part of nation's lumber industry and small sawmill communities overcome effect of punitive duties on Canadian lumber that Bush administration imposed in May; measures produce mixed response from employers and unions, with some calling for more generous assistance; others voice concern that package amounts to yet another round in cycle of government intervention on boths sides of border that has worsened slump in North American lumber market by allowing inefficient mills to remain in business, and even increase production (M)

headline: The U.S. Catalogs 'Material Omissions'
abstract: Text of State Department's list of what it calls inadequacies in Iraq's declaration about its weapons programs

headline: U.S. Says Evidence Possibly Ties Al Qaeda to the Attack in Kenya
abstract: United States officials find evidence linking Al Qaeda to failed missile attack on Israeli-chartered plane departing from airport in Mombasa, Kenya, minutes before hotel in Mombasa is car-bombed; say Soviet-made missile launcher used in failed attack had serial number close to one on launcher of same type found last year after failed Qaeda attack on American warplane in Saudi Arabia; bombing of Hotel Paradise in Mombasa kills 10 Kenyans and 3 Israelis; suspicion of Qaeda involvement is further strengthened by statement on Islamic Web site attributed to group, claiming involvement in both Mombasa incidents; statement calls incidents a Ramadan greeting to Palestinian people and refers to 1998 attacks by Al Qaeda on American Embassies in Kenya and Tanzania, which killed 231 people and wounded more than 5,000; government officials say experts regard message as credible, although officials caution that Al Qaeda has not usually struck specifically Jewish targets or taken direct responsibility for its terrorist actions (M)

headline: As Bodies Start Coming Home, Australians Criticize Leaders
abstract: First bodies from Bali nightclub bombing are sent home as angry Australians question their government for not taking terrorism warnings seriously enough; estimated 200 Australians died in attack; just as pointed is debate over Prime Min John Howard's strong support for Bush administration's campaign against Iraq; critics say pro-American policy is dragging Australia into fights far from home (M)

headline: The Week's Economic Events
abstract: MONDAYConstruction SpendingOct.

headline: Partial Plea Of Guilty Seen For Ex-Chief Of ImClone
abstract: ImClone Systems Inc's former chief executive Samuel D Waksal is expected to plead guilty to charges of insider trading, bank fraud, perjury and obstruction of justice; plea is not part of agreement with government; Waksal hopes judge will be lenient in sentencing and that prosecutors will drop remaining charges by pleading guilty to many of charges; Waksal is not pleading guilty to tipping off his father Jack to sell ImClone shares in two days before company announced unfavorable news that caused its shares to drop sharply in price; is expected to plead guilty to causing his daughter Aliza to sell all of her shares in that same period; will not plead guilty to conspiring with his daughter to trade on insider information; Waksal has in recent weeks been asked by prosecutors whether he knows anything about trading by friend Martha Stewart, who is also under investigation (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Kazakhstan: Hunger Striker Is Force Fed
abstract: Sergei Duvanov, Kazakh journalist and human rights advocate, on hunger strike to protest his arrest on rape charges, is being force fed by police; was preparing to visit United States to speak on press freedom and human rights when he was arrested in late Oct (S)

headline: World Briefing: Africa
abstract: SUDAN: Goverment Agrees To Resume Talks; CONGO: Peacekeepers Fire At Protesters;.

headline: Shares Inch Higher as Mixed News Saps Rally's Vigor
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average rises 36.96 points, or 0.4 percent, to 8,579.09; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index climbs 5.56 points, or 0.6 percent, to 909.83; Nasdaq composite index slips 0.38 point, to 1,411.14; yield on 10-year Treasury note slips to 4.03 percent, down from 4.05 percent day earlier but up from 3.85 percent week ago; graphs; table of key rates (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Software Acquisition
abstract: Logica agrees to buy rival CMG PLC for 512 million British pounds ($800 million) in stock to create Europe's third-largest computer-services and -software provider; combined company plans to eliminate about 1,400 jobs, or 6 percent of its work force (S)

headline: As Royal Rumors Swirl in Britain, Charles Orders a Palace Inquiry
abstract: Office of Britain's Prince Charles says it will probe charges about royal intervention that collapsed trial of Princess Diana's butler, Paul Burrell, charges that prince covered up alleged homosexual rape of former valet George Smith by top aide and that his courtiers sold royal gifts for cash; apparently seeks to stem tide of charges and innuendo against royal family since Burrell trial ended abruptly in Oct; Sir Michael Peat, who heads probe, pledges thorough, unbiased inquiry; is closely identified with monarchy and his remarks seem to absolve royal household (M)

headline: Drug Makers Cutting Back On Discounts for the Elderly
abstract: Bristol-Myers Squibb and GlaxoSmithKline cut back on discounts they promised to low-income elderly people, fearing government will demand similar deep discounts for Medicaid program; other drug makers say they may follow suit; federal officials express surprise at moves and say they have not taken any action against discount plans (M)

headline: ROYAL DUTCH/SHELL WARNS RUSSIA ABOUT OIL PROJECT
abstract: Group of oil companies led by Royal Dutch/Shell warns Russian government that it will not move forward with $8.5 billion phase of oil and gas development project in Russia unless country adopts laws to make tax environment more stable (S)

headline: Venezuela Braces for a New Round of Antigovernment Protests
abstract: Venezuelan government of Pres Hugo Chavez deploys armed forces in capital of Caracas, bracing for antigovernment march on October 10 that might be largest since April 11 demonstration that briefly toppled him; government forces raid homes of former foreign minister and military officers accused of participating in conspiracy against Chavez, though they have not been charged; government says it has evidence anti-Chavez organizations were planning coup (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Charges Filed Against Putin Critic
abstract: Charges are filed against financier Boris A Berezovsky for alleged $15 million dollar fraud of Avtovaz, Russia's largest automobile company; Berezovsky, opponent of Pres Putin, denies charges, which Berezovsky feels are politically motivated; photo (S)

headline: BorgWarner Dividend Up
abstract: Transmission parts maker BorgWarner raises its quarterly dividend by three cents, to 18 cents a share, its first increase since 1994; company posts 73 percent rise in third-quarter profit, to $31.9 million (S)

headline: Ad Spending Rises in First 3 Quarters
abstract: Ad Spending Rises In First 3 Quarters Bouncing back somewhat from the depressed advertising market of 2001, advertising spending in major media rose 2.2 percent for the first three quarters of 2002 compared with figures in the period a year earlier, according to a report yesterday from CMR in New York, a division of Taylor Nelson Sofres that tracks ad spending.

headline: READER'S DIGEST TO POST FIRST-QUARTER LOSS
abstract: Reader's Digest Association will post loss for first quarter of its fiscal year after deciding to delay recognition of some sales and profit from unit Reiman Publications it acquired in May (S)

headline: AOL Is Moving Music Unit
abstract: AOL Time Warner's WEA Corp unit will close some branch offices and move headquarters to New York City from Burbank, Calif (S)

headline: Stock Market Cuts Year's Losses, but Some Hurdles Remain
abstract: Wall Street is wondering whether a recent rally will last long enough to make a major dent in the market's losses for the year.

headline: Strong performances at television and radio units keep Viacom's results in line with estimates.
abstract: Viacom Inc posts record third-quarter results in line with expectations; net income was $640.3 million compared with loss of $190.4 million year earlier; revenue rose 10 percent, to $6.3 billion from $5.7 billion; Blockbuster Video unit reports 10 percent increase in revenue, to $1.36 billion; profits were $80 million compared with loss of $272.8 million last year; Viacom confirms board has authorized additional $3 billion of stock repurchases; president Mel Karmazin comments; photo (M)

headline: White-Collar Oil Workers Key in Venezuela Crisis
abstract: As tensions continue to rise in Venezuela after last week's call by opposition movement for general strike next week to protest Pres Hugo Chavez's left-wing government, much attention is focused on country's powerful oil industry and state-owned oil giant, Petroleos de Venezuela; dissident white-collar workers at company are increasingly angry over what they see as drive to rid company of managers opposed to Pres Chavez; photo (M)

headline: Pet Quarantine Is Eased
abstract: Britain extends to United States and Canada its relaxation of quarantine rules for vaccinated dogs and cats brought into country; cites low rabies risk (S)

headline: Edinburgh Journal; Haggis, the Food of Poets (Well, One Scottish Poet)
abstract: Increasing popularity in Scotland of haggis, traditional sausage made of sheep lungs, heart and liver, oatmeal and other ingredients in sheep stomach lining, discussed; Edinburgh's haggis makers now offer vegetarian versions; map; photo (M)g

headline: Panevezys Journal; In a Lithuanian Prison, the Beauty Is Unconfined
abstract: Beauty contest h

headline: World Business Briefing: Europe
abstract: BRITAIN: Television Acquisition; BRITAIN: Sales Down At Reuters; GERMANY: Porsche Drops Listing Plan;.

headline: World Briefing | Asia: China: Tycoon Charged With Corruption
abstract: Entrepreneur and Chinese national Yang Bin is arrested by Chinese authorities and charged with bribery and fraud; also faces regional charges in Shenyang for illegally occupying farmland; charges have stopped him from assuming duties as head of new North Korean zone near China that was devised to attract foreign investors; photo (S)

headline: Technology Briefing: Software
abstract: APPLIED MICROSYSTEMS TO LIQUIDATE ITS ASSETS; IDENTIX WILL MISS FORECAST; SHARES FALL;.

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Unisys Creates Consulting Practice
abstract: Business computers and services vendor Unisys Corp creates consulting division to help customers protect their offices and computer systems from security breaches (S)

headline: Russia, Pressing to Oust Chechens, Nearly Empties Border Camp
abstract: Russian authorities nearly complete effort to close down refugee camp near Chechen border, ignoring pleas of UN and human rights groups (S)

headline: Chávez Rejects Call by U.S. for Early Vote in Venezuela
abstract: Venezuela Pres Hugo Chavez's government, whipsawed by 13-day strike that is debilitating economy, rejects Bush administration call for early elections to resolve political turmoil in oil-rich nation; government officials say that early election, as demanded by opposition, would be in violation of country's Constitution, which permits binding referendum on president's rule no earlier than August; photo (M)

headline: 13 Protesting Bush's Stance Enter U.N. and Are Ousted
abstract: Demonstrators protesting Bush administration's confrontation with Baghdad get inside United Nations General Assembly; episode raises new questions about security at UN headquarters; photo (S)

headline: United and Machinists Reach Deal on Concessions
abstract: International Association of Machinists union at United Airlines agrees to concessions worth $1.5 billion in effort to help airline avoid bankruptcy, becoming last employee group to sign on to company's turnaround effort; United's fate now rests with federal Air Transportation Stabilization Board, which is considering airline's application for $1.8 billion in loan guarantees so it can pay for its operations, which are costing airline about $7 million per day (M)

headline: Letterman's 'Late Show' Will Be on Radio, Too
abstract: David Letterman will not allow his CBS television show to be edited in any way when it is broadcast on radio in nation's largest cities; photo (M)

headline: Division in Past Bush White House Echoes in Current Struggles
abstract: Simmering philosophical disagreements between Vice Pres Dick Cheney and Secretary of State Colin L Powell over Iraq have their roots back in Persian Gulf war; few experts expect divide between hawk and dove, unilateralist and multilateralist, to go away; in fact, they expect divide to affect not only future choices on Iraq but also other countries and issues; White House officials say Pres Bush likes to hear conflicting opinions, though he expects them to remain private; photo (M)

headline: Ex-U.S. Aide Sentenced to 25 Years for Spying for Cuba
abstract: Ana B Montes, former Pentagon intelligence analyst who spied for Cuba for 16 years, says she wanted to help Cuba's Communist government defend itself against unjust American policies; Judge Ricardo M Urbina sentences her to punishment she agreed to in plea bargain: prison term of 25 years, followed by five years' probation; she was analyst for Defense Intelligence Agency; intelligence and law enforcement officials describe her as probably most damaging spy in long history of efforts by Cuban intelligence serrice to penetrate US government (M)

headline: Lighter styles for year-round wear : Return of an outlaw:Fur bounds back
abstract: PARIS—  For years fur was fashion's outlaw. Stars shunned it, designers deserted it and the rich recoiled from it. But fashionistas love a comeback, and for the new millennium fur has come out of hibernation.

headline: Conflict in Oslo Over a Pointed Peace Prize
abstract: Award of Nobel Peace Prize to former Pres Jimmy Carter has created rift among Nobel jurors, as well as new difficulty of how to dispel any suspicion that prize was pretext for upbraiding White House that many Europeans see as abandoning diplomacy for force; Carter, passed over by Nobel committee for more than two decades even though reputation as humanitarian and global peacemaker had soared, was awarded prize for untiring efforts to find peaceful solutions to international conflicts and, by declaration of panel's chairman Gunnar Berge, for labors as critic of Bush administration's 'pistols-cocked brand of geopolitics'; photo (M)

headline: War, Murder and Suicide: A Year's Toll Is 1.6 Million
abstract: World Health Orgn report states that violence kills more than 1.6 million people each year, and suicide claims almost as many lives as war and homicide combined; experts say report is first comprehensive documentation of problem of global violence; report finds violence accounts for 14 percent of all deaths among men, and 7 percent among women; study challenges health ministers to view violence as pressing public health problem; its release is timed to coincide with new campaign by WHO to promote violence-prevention efforts; report's main premise--that violence can be studied as health problem and prevented same way as disease--is not new; it originated at Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, which in 1983 opened violence epidemiology branch to track patterns of violence; since then programs to prevent various forms of violence have become commonplace, but there is no definitive proof that they contribute to overall decline in violence; chart (M)

headline: Kenya Clears Fishermen, Saying They Had No Ties to Attackers
abstract: Kenyan Chief Magistrate Hanna Okwengu finds nine Somali and Pakistani fishermen detained in November hotel bombing and failed missile attack on airliner in Mombasa guilty of entering country illegally; orders them to pay fines or serve year in jail after which they would be deported; Deputy Police Comr William Langat says he no longer believes men had any links to attackers; another judge orders release on bail of mother and brother of Saleh Ali Saleh Nabhan, Kenyan who police say purchased vehicle used in hotel bombing; photo (M)

headline: Economic Scene; Some may shrug off 5.7 percent unemployment, but it pinches hard at the bottom of the economic ladder.
abstract: Jeff Madrick Economic Scene column on how 5.7 percent unemployment rate affects family incomes of bottom 20 or 30 percent of labor market; Jared Bernstein, senior economist at Economic Policy Institute, compares conditions of labor markets in first nine months of 2002, when unemployment rate averaged 5.7 percent, with first nine months of 2000, when it averaged 4 percent; graph (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Dell Chief Says Hardware Demand Is Improving
abstract: Dell Computer chief executive Michael Dell says worldwide demand for computer hardware has improved and that Far East will be good market; reiterates that rebound in personal computers will be driven by improvement in corporate customers' profits; photo (S)

headline: Workers' Productivity Climbed 4% in the Third Quarter
abstract: The gains could lay the foundation for long-term improvements in living standards, but do not necessarily foreshadow an upturn in the slack economy.

headline: New Royalty-Reporting Method
abstract: Universal Music Group amends method of reporting royalty payments to recording artists; responds to dispute between recording labels and musicians by strengthening artists' ability to audit manufacturing records on which their royalty payments are calculated (M)

headline: A Harvard Professor And Economic Policy
abstract: Dan DiMaggio letter comments on Dec 1 article on Martin Feldstein regarding his introductory economics course at Harvard; photo

headline: People
abstract: Mark Wilmot is named to new post of client management director for Burger King account at Interpublic Group of Companies (S)

headline: Whistler Journal; Repair of British Columbia Road Is Olympic Event
abstract: Provincial government of British Columbia embarks on one of most expensive engineeering projects in Canada's history, to widen and improve Route 99, treacherous road called Highway of Death in local news media; Vancouver fears that highway's deadly reputation could threaten its bid to host 2010 Winter Olympic games; alpine resort of Whistler, off Route 99, would host many events; photo; map (M)

headline: World Briefing: Asia
abstract: EAST TIMOR: Agreement With Indonesia; SOUTH KOREA: Rally By Kin Of The Kidnapped ; CHINA: Inquiry Into Tycoon Hired By North Korea; INDIA: Medicine, Not A Miracle, Doctors Say;.

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Ariba Reports Smaller 4th-Quarter Loss
abstract: Ariba Inc says net loss narrowed to $142.5 million in fourth quarter ended Sept 30 from loss of $224.3 million year earlier; sales fell 7 percent, to $58.2 million from $62.7 million (S)

headline: Label Mania Lends Dazzle to Humble CD's
abstract: Appearance of label is vital to people distributing home-made compact discs; professional label gives recording added legitimacy; photos (M)

headline: Pakistan Stages Missile Test, First Since War Scare in May
abstract: Pakistan stages what it calls routine test-firing of medium-range missile capable of carrying nuclear warhead, first since it conducted similar test in May at peak of war tensions with India; government says it gave advance notice of test 'to neighbors,' and Indian officials react calmly to firing, while noting that India also conducted test-firing, with smaller conventional-warhead missile (M)

headline: A Lack of Money Forces Computer Initiative to Close
abstract: Computer initiative called PowerUP that was born three years ago by computer executives to donate millions of dollars to help bridge 'digital divide' between rich and poor will close and centers will be left to fend for--and finance--themselves; other groups, including Boys and Girls Clubs of America, will keep many of centers open with local financing; PowerUP spokeswoman Denise Keyes says it was never intention of initiative to go on indefinitely, and that centers were always supposed to become self-sustaining; Case Foundation executive vice president Jerry Dovalis says over life of organization, total corporate and foundation donations were estimated to be as much as $100 million; America Online chairman Stephen M Case took prominent role in introducing initiative, providing $10 million in start-up money (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Kazakhstan: Environmental Penalty
abstract: Regional court in Kazakhstan rules that group called Tengizchevroil led by ChevronTexaco must pay $71 million in environmental fines for storing sulfur at its Tengiz oil field; group originally protested penalty in court in February, when fine was imposed (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: China: Actress Convicted Of Tax Evasion
abstract: Well-known Chinese actress Liu Xiaoqing is convicted of tax evasion; is ordered to pay $700,000 in fines and nearly $2 million in back taxes; photo (M)

headline: BOSTON PROPERTIES SELLS ASSETS FOR $345 MILLION
abstract: Boston Properties Inc. sold 1 and 2 Independence Square in Washington for $345 million to the Wells Real Estate Investment Trust, part of a strategy to sell off assets after its $1.06 billion purchase of the headquarters of Citigroup Inc.'in New York. Boston Properties, the third-largest office real estate investment trust, used the proceeds to pay off $190 million of first mortgage debt and to pay down unspecified unsecured debt, the company said. The company, headed by the publisher Mortimer Zuckerman, bought Citigroup's 39-story tower at 399 Park Avenue in August for $631 a square foot, close to a record on a per-foot basis for a New York office building.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Austria: Kosovo Refugees Sent Home
abstract: Austria sends back to Kosovo 42 ethnic Albanians who sought asylum (S)

headline: Iraqi Groups Draft Statements
abstract: Iraqi opposition groups, meeting, London, draft statements covering their shared political vision for future and general framework for governing Iraq immediately after collapse of Saddam Hussein's government; United States government pushed for conference, but has not said what role opposition will play in governing Iraq if US invades (M)

headline: Investing; Coin Trade Becomes More Like A Market
abstract: Market for collectible coins, although thinly traded, is being closely tracked by Professional Coin Grading Service in much same way as Standard & Poor's tracks stock markets; photo; graph (M)

headline: Pop Star, Freed From Jail, Returns to Mexico to Face the Music
abstract: Gloria Trevi, Mexico's biggest pop star in 1990's, is extradited from Brazil to Mexico, where she and her manager, Sergio Andrade, face charges of holding girls in their entourage in kind of sexual slavery (M)

headline: Muckraking Governor Slain By Sniper on Moscow Street
abstract: Valentin Tsvetkov, governor of Russian provice of Magadan, is shot dead by sniper in Moscow; investigators and fellow politicians suspect that Tsvetkov, who had reputation of reformer, ran afoul of criminal interests; Magadan is known for its lucrative -- and, many say, corrupt -- gold-mining and fishing industries; photo (M)

headline: North Korea Clarifies Statement on A-Bomb
abstract: North Korean radio broadcast clarifies earlier broadcast that appeared to claim nation has nuclear weapons; government says it is 'entitled' to such arms because of continuing United States threats; unusual move follows flurry of statements of concern in region (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Rate Unchanged
abstract: Brazil's central bank keeps overnight interest rate unchanged at 21 percent, hoping to contain rising consumer prices (S)4

headline: Israeli Raid in Gaza Kills 9 And Hurts 50, Witnesses Say
abstract: Israeli tanks backed by helicopters raid neighborhood in Gaza Strip town of Khan Yunis, reportedly killing 9 Palestinians and wounding more than 50 others; map (S)
