headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Philippines: Water Dispute
abstract: Officials inø

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: REGIS CORP., Minneapolis, the world's largest operator of hair salons, said it had purchased 59 salons in seven transactions. The salons, in Missouri, Kansas, Arizona and North Carolina, are expected to generate $21 million a year in revenue. Terms were not disclosed.    ALCOA, Pittsburgh, the world's largest aluminum producer, said that its $82.4 million bid to buy a controlling stake in Elkem, Oslo, a metals and materials producer, failed after it was blocked by key shareholders.

headline: Private Sector; What Could Have Been at Pan Am
abstract: Seventy-fifth anniversary of first flight taken by Pan American World Airways will be marked at La Guardia Airport in New York (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Sun Accused Of Violating Export Rules
abstract: Commerce Department accuses Sun Microsystems of violating export rules in selling computers to Egypt in 1998 and Hong Kong in 1997; Sun says it faces potential fines and restrictions of exports that government has told it to expect additional charges; will seek settlement; Goldman Sachs cites flagging sales and reduces its estimates for Sun's first quarter (S)

headline: World Briefing | Environment: New Rice-Growing Technique Reduces Methane
abstract: Over past two decades Chinese farmers have changed system of growing rice resulting in 40% reduction in methane emissions; methane, although not most prolific of heat-trapping gases, is 21 times more vigorous than carbon dioxide in trapping sun's heat; new method of draining rice fields several times a year not only slows atmospheric effects, but also gleans larger harvests and conserves water (S)

headline: ASBESTOS-RELATED COSTS INCREASE AT GEORGIA-PACIFIC
abstract: Georgia-Pacific Corp says costs of asbestos-related lawsuits this year were 63 percent more than it expected; discloses costs as it reports third-quarter profit of $66 million, up from loss of $167 million year earlier; sales fell to $6.15 billion from $6.31 billion; expects to pay about $132 million to settle lawsuits instead of $81 million (S)

headline: Watching the Returns
abstract: Nielsen/NetRatings finds that 28 percent more Americans visited Internet news sites on Wednesday following elections than on previous Wednesday; photo; graph; table (S)

headline: A Low-Cost Model Is a Big Headache for Ford
abstract: Ford Motor Co's Focus model might be most error-prone car in industry; low-cost car, which was introduced in 1999, has had total of 11 safety recalls and is subject of five defect investigations by federal regulators; two new recalls this week, including wiring problem that could in worst-case situations, cause engine fires, raise even more questions; five pending investigations into Focus account for at least 7 percent of entire defect investigation caseload of National Highway Traffic Safety Administration; Ford officials say two latest recalls, which they initiated, will address some of problems, including suspension defect; executives have acknowledged that Focus has had problems since it was brought over from Europe in 1999, but they say newer versions of car are much improved; photo (M)

headline: Interpublic Group surprises investors with yet another warning of financial setbacks.
abstract: Interpublic Group of Companies, which had previously warned of earnings disappointments and accounting irregularities, surprises Wall Street again with disclosures of additional financial shortfalls and setbacks; unexpected announcements threatens to unleash firestorm of criticism that is likely to reach highest levels of advertising agency company; disclosures include additional charges related to restatement of earnings for last five years; charges will be almost twice what was indicated to investors in unexpected announcement two months ago; Interpublic significantly reduces estimates of earnings for third quarter and full year (M)

headline: EMI Reports A Profit, But CD Sales Remain Weak
abstract: With CD sales slumping at music stores and Internet users downloading recordings without paying, the EMI Group said today that it would not be able to achieve even its modest goal of matching last year's sales.    The company, whose roster of artists includes the Rolling Stones and the British pop singer Robbie Williams, said sales in its principal business, music, would probably be down 3 to 6 percent for the fiscal year, which ends March 31. In May, the company forecast flat sales for the fiscal year.

headline: Paris Mayor Recovering After Being Stabbed During Festival
abstract: Bertrand Delanoe, mayor of Paris, France, is out of danger after being stabbed in abdomen in City Hall by man who told police he disliked politicians and homosexuals; is in stable condition after surgery; assailant identified as Azedine Berkane, 39-year-old computer technician who has police record for violence; Delanoe is one of France's few openly gay politicians; photo (M)

headline: Edison Turns to a Profit in the Quarter
abstract: ROSEMEAD, Calif., Nov. 1 (Bloomberg News) — Edison International posted a third-quarter profit of $352 million in contrast to a year-earlier loss and forecast a drop in 2003 earnings on lower power prices.

headline: CHINA CARRIES OUT AN ORDERLY SHIFT OF ITS LEADERSHIP
abstract: China's Communist Party names Hu Jintao as new chief; sweeping generational shift of leadership is achieved through most orderly transition in party's 81-year history; Hu is 59-year-old insider known as brilliant and bland; new leaders are selected by small group in total secrecy; Hu and eight other members of expanded ruling council then appear before reporters and national television audience; Hu pledges continuity with policies of Jiang Zemin, whose drive to broaden party and overhaul economy while keeping tight lid on politics is endorsed by just-ended 16th Party Congress; Wu Bangguo, protege of Jiang Zemin, is given No 2 ranking in party elite; four other men seen as close allies to Jiang are also appointed to inner circle; Jiang will remain state president until Parliament meets in Mar, when Hu is expected to take over that title as well; whether Jiang will give up his third post, chairman of military, is unclear; enormous turnover in leading party councils is result of recent unwritten rule that officials older than 70 should step down; Hu and his colleagues are expected to proceed cautiously and in unison; photos of members of China's new Standing Committee of the Politburo (M)

headline: A Satellite and Thou: Web Browsing in the Wilds
abstract: Two-way satellite systems provide Internet access to people in remote areas, but at a price in terms of money and certain capabilities; table; drawing (M)

headline: Amazon.com Previews a New Apparel Site, Snags and All
abstract: Amazon.com previews apparel and footwear departments on its Web site, displaying products from 400 manufacturers and retailers; Forrester Research estimates that online apparel and footware sales will grow 21 percent in 2002, to $5.2 billlion (M)

headline: Israeli Troops Enter West Bank Town
abstract: Hundreds of soldiers supported by scores of tanks vehicles swept into the city, in what Israel called a hunt for a terrorist cell.

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: Scholar's Death Sentence Appealed
abstract: Iranian scholar Hashem Aghajari's attorney ignores client's wishes and appeals death sentence for apostasy (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Allergy Drug Is Approved For Sale Over the Counter  Regulators approved the nation's top-selling allergy drug, Claritin, as an over-the-counter medicine, a decision that will bring substantial savings for the uninsured. Schering-Plough, the maker of Claritin, said that the nonprescription drug would be available in mid-December.    With prescription costs rising, insurers are pressing regulators to make more brand name drugs available over the counter. WellPoint, the insurer that initiated the reappraisal of Claritin, has also asked regulators to make Clarinex, Schering-Plough's newest allergy drug, available over the counter. [Page A1.]

headline: In Baghdad, There's Little Romance in Music by Candlelight
abstract: Members of Iraq's once-thriving middle class, whose living standards have plunged since economic sanctions were imposed after Iraq invaded Kuwait in 1990, now find themselves bracing for another war in which they have little voice; in Baghdad, audiences pack National Theater every night for show called Vagabounds, which gently mocks Iraqis for having become nation of beggars; Iraqis are bitter about Draconian sanctions and sense they are caught in twilight zone; it is difficult to gauge their mood toward what Bush administration says and does because Ministry of Information attends every interview between Iraqis and foreign journalists; photos (M)

headline: Competition Forces AOL To Emphasize Faster Links
abstract: AOL Time Warner presents new strategy for its AOL division to compete with high-speed Internet users, acknowledging that service that helped make Internet mass medium is now in danger of falling behind as consumers seek faster connections online; says AOL is redirecting its efforts toward marketing upgraded version of its high-speed servive intended to take advantage of elaborate multimedia potential of high-speed Internet connections, partly by offering music and videos from its sister companies; will seek to persuade high-speed users to pay additional monthly fee of about $15 for its service even after buying broadband access from another company for as much as $50 per month; many online companies, including Yahoo, have tried with little success to charge for online information or entertainment; AOL chairman Jonathan Miller argues that with end of boom in online advertising, online media companies will increasingly charge for access to their contents; chart; photo (M)

headline: Israeli Troops Sweep Nablus In Response to Kibbutz Attack
abstract: Israeli forces take up positions and search houses across Nablus in response to Palestinian terrorist attack on kibbutz that killed five people, including two children (S)

headline: It Slices, Dices and Grabs Headlines in Germany
abstract: Tabloids in Germany are focused on a cucumber slicer that has caused a new set of sharp insults to fly between eastern and western Germans.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Vivendi Trims Management
abstract: Vivendi Universal plans to cut 152 jobs at its Paris headquarters to help save $138 million a year (S)

headline: On the Track or the Dance Floor, Wrong Moves Are Costly
abstract: Charles Herold Game Theory column reviews games DDRMAX: Dance Dance Revolution and Rallisport Challenge; photos (M)

headline: NORTHROP GRUMMAN COMPLETES TRW ACQUISITION
abstract: Northrop Grumman Corp completes $11.8 billion acquisition of satellite maker TRW after stockholders and Justice Department approve deal (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Siemens Unit Posts Profit
abstract: Siemens reports that its United States arm returned to profit for fiscal year ended Sept 30, despite 4 percent decline in sales; US operations earned 823 million euros ($823.5 million) (S)

headline: Stock Offerings This Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:    Dick's Sporting Goods Inc., Pittsburgh, an initial public offering of 7.3 million shares. Merrill Lynch & Co. and Goldman, Sachs & Co.

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: Opening Of Parliament Delayed
abstract: Pakistan President Pervez Musharraf postpones opening session for first elected Parliament since 1999 (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Bank Rule Tightened
abstract: South Korea's Financial Supervisory Commission raises regulatory standards for banks by requiring them to report overdue mortgage payments that they previously ignored, thereby slowing mortgage lending (S)

headline: A new trend has unrelated brand-name products endorsing the products of other companies.
abstract: MADISON AVENUE has found a new set of celebrities to endorse the products of its clients: other products.    Advertising agencies are increasingly using unrelated brand-name products to help sell the brands they are paid to pitch.

headline: Costs Are Important, But Revenue Is Crucial
abstract: Analysis: United Airlines' descent from highly profitable airline--and world's largest--few years ago to one on cusp of bankruptcy involves far more than salaries and other costs; industry statistics and many analysts say what separates United from its peers who are still solvent may be its struggle to bring in new revenue even more than its inability to contain costs; chart; photo (M)

headline: Sears Earnings Will Be Hurt By Credit Unit
abstract: Sears, Roebuck says its credit division has suffered unexpected losses from delinquent cardholders that will depress earnings for rest of year; says earnings for third quarter will be higher than last year but still 26 percent below company's prediction made in early October; most of credit trouble seems to be rooted in Gold MasterCard programthat Sears began offering two years ago; chairman Alan J Lacy comments; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | World: Species Face Extinction, But Two Rise From Dead
abstract: World Conservation Union says 11,170 plants and animals face extinction; reports that two species believed to be extinct have been rediscovered (S)

headline: AtHomeAbroad: Strategies for landing that overseas assignment
abstract: As more companies do business globally, many young people are eager to land a job overseas — an experience that can boost résumés, not to mention enrich lives.

headline: Jidda Journal; Underneath, Saudi Women Keep Their Secrets
abstract: There is quiet but growing trend among women in Jidda, Saudi Arabia, to fight some of minor injustices they suffer in society designed almost exclusively by men and for men; women are beginning to speak out in newspaper columns and letters to editors about matters in which they can clearly claim moral high ground, like inadequate time and space given to female visitors at prophet Muhammad's tomb; women are barred from jobs like public sales, meaning female shoppers must buy even their undergarments from salesmen; Nema Basheer, who is technically marketing director of lingerie store, wears shroud as shopper would, but quietly dispenses help to women shoppers; photo; map (M)

headline: Tablet PC's: Computing Drawn Anew
abstract: David Pogue State of the Art column on Microsoft's Tablet PC, which enables user to write directly on screen with special pen; concept, known as pen computing, has been failure in previous products; chart compares features and prices of Microsoft and other models, set to be introduced soon; photos (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Network Appliance Posts Profit As Sales Rise
abstract: Network Appliance reports net income of $15.8 million for fiscal second quarter, in contrast to loss of $11.2 million year earlier; revenue climbs 11 percent, to $215.2 million (S)

headline: Kurdish Leader May Spare Man Who Tried to Kill Him
abstract: Qais Ibrahim Khadir awaits trial in Kurdish prison for killing three guards in failed attempt to assassinate Dr Barham Salih, prime minister of eastern zone of Kurdish-controlled Iraq; in ironic twist, although Khadir admits to murders, Salih refuses to sign death warrants because he is opposed to capital punishment; photos; map (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Adobe Reports Rise In 4th-Quarter Profit
abstract: Software maker Adobe Systems reports net income for fourth quarter ended Nov 29 rose to $40.1 million, up from $34.3 million year earlier (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Consumer Prices Fall
abstract: South Korean consumer prices fall unexpectedly by 0.3 percent in October because of decline in cost of agricultural products; Bank of Korea is expected to hold interest rates at 4.25 percent in reaction to economic stagnation (S)

headline: Technology Briefing: E-Commerce
abstract: COORSTEK ACCEPTS PACT WITH COORS FAMILY; WILDBLUE RAISES $158 MILLION IN NEW CAPITAL; SANDISK AND MIRON SETTLE PATENT LAWSUIT;.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Bank Sells Shares
abstract: World

headline: Playing the Angles in Class-Action Lawsuits
abstract: Article discusses jurisdiction in class-action lawsuits; explains requirements for hearings in federal courts; cites issue of venue in current suit involving Intel's performance claims for its computer processors; table (M)

headline: A Fight Over Farms Ends, Opening Way to Wider Europe
abstract: Leaders of European Union begin talks on integrating 10 new countries into their ranks by 2004; project of enlarging their world eastward will create economic and political entity with third largest population in world; EU is also in midst of negotiations to draft new Constitution for the new Europe, possibly with new name; cost of expansion--$42 billion over three years--is considered relatively inexpensive, but there is intense wrangling over who will pay what; latest European Union survey of its citizenry shows only slight majority support expansion; entry of 10, most of them formerly Communist countries with dysfunctional economies, will further strain western European governments now struggling with slowest economic growth in decade; new members are Cyprus, Czech Republic, Estonia, Hungary, Latvia, Lithuania, Malta, Poland, Slovakia and Slovenia; Turkey is being kept off list until it improves its human rights record and makes other political reforms; map (M)

headline: Ottawa, Citing Arrest, Says Al Qaeda Is Operating in Canada
abstract: Canadian intelligence officials say that Al Qaeda is operating in Canada and has capacity to support terrorist activities across North America; assessment is contained in court documents released in connection with detention of Mohammed Harkat, Algerian immigrant suspected of ties to senior Qaeda members (M)

headline: Negative News From Some Blue Chips Takes Heavy Toll
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average drops 215.22 points, or 2.9 percent, to 7,286.27, five-year low; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index falls 21.79 points, or 2.7 percent, to 776.76, lowest in five and half years; Nasdaq composite index is off 15.10 points, or 1.3 percent, at 1,114.11, lowest in more than six years; US Treasury bond interest rates continue to fall to new lows; yield on 10-year note falls to 3.57 percent, lowest rate since 1958; price rises 17/32, to 106 20/32; yield on two-year note falls to 1.67 percent; graph; chart; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Convictions In Chiapas Massacre
abstract: A federal court convicted 18 men in the 1997 massacre of 45 peasants in the village of Acteal, in the mountains of the southern state of Chiapas. Each was sentenced to 36 years in prison. The ruling brings to 77 the number of people convicted in connection with the killings, one of the worst attacks in Mexico in the last decade. The victims -- mostly women and children -- were supporters of the Zaptista rebels, who declared war against the government in 1994. Most of those convicted were government loyalists.   Ginger Thompson (NYT)

headline: Latest Revisions to Nasdaq 100 Leave Index With Less Technology
abstract: Nasdaq 100, which comprises 100 of largest nonfinancial companies listed on Nasdaq stock market, announces that 15 companies will be dropped from index on Dec 23, to be replaced by 15 others; most of companies vanishing are fallen technology stocks, which many of those being added have gained from operating stores or such old-economy businesses as oil services or industrial fasteners; deletions and additions noted; graph (M)

headline: Pakistani Who Treated bin Laden Is Questioned by U.S.
abstract: Dr Amer Aziz, Pakistani surgeon who once treated Osama bin Laden in Afghanistan, says he was interrogated intensively by American intelligence agents about his connections to Al Qaeda during monthlong detention, only to be released without charge and with an apology; Aziz is known to sympathize with groups waging jihad in Afghanistan and Kashmir; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Belarus: Russian Lawmaker Thrown Out
abstract: Boris Y Nemtsov, leader of Russia's largest liberal party, is taken into custody in Minsk and expelled from Belarus; Nemtsov indicates he was set up by Belarussian KGB in response to his political opinions (S)

headline: Personal Business; Health Plans Are Offering Fewer Choices and Higher Costs
abstract: Many American workers are finding that their health insurance plans offer fewer choices and higher costs, along with new options that reflect employers' moves to reduce costs and shift more responsibility for health care to their employees; increases in premium costs are far greater than gains in salaries or overall inflation; photo; graph (M)

headline: Trial Opens in J.P. Morgan's Effort To Collect Insurance on Enron Deal
abstract: J P Morgan goes to court to try to collect about $1 billion owed to it by 11 insurance companies that had guaranteed certain oil and gas contracts bank had arranged with Enron Corp; both sides struggle in their opening statements to describe complicated transactionsx to jury; J P Morgan tries to deflect insurance companies' attempts to damage bank's reputation further by linking it with Enron; J P Morgan sued insurers after Enron sought bankruptcy protection last December; trades that are focus of lawsuit have led to some negative publicity for bank, contributing to nearly 30 percent drop in its stock price over last 12 months (M)

headline: Casino Offering Raises $450 Million
abstract: Wynn Resorts raises $450 million in initial public stock offering after reducing share price as much as 43 percent; sale is part of financing plan to build Le Reve casino in Las Vegas (S)

headline: Orlando Villas-Boas, 88, Brazilian Explorer
abstract: Orlando Villas-Boas, who explored Brazil's vast interior regions in 1940's, dies at age 88; photo (M)

headline: Law Firm Leaves Conclusions From Report to HealthSouth
abstract: Fulbright and Jaworski, law firm that investigated accusations that HealthSouth chairman, Richard M Scrushy, traded company shares on insider information, says it takes no responsibility for his or company's interpretations of its findings; Scrushy hailed firm's report as vindication; report says firm 'uncovered no oral interview or written document' that would have established that Scrushy had inside knowledge when he sold $74 million in stock in May and sold $25 million in shares to company in July to repay a loan (M)

headline: Private Sector; . . . While His Publisher Has Other Priorities
abstract: Rupert Murdoch entertains guests at party with gossip reminiscent of style of his tabloid newspapers; photo (S)

headline: Online Advertisers Adopt Guidelines
abstract: Interactive Advertising Bureau

headline: Technology Briefing: Software
abstract: MICROSOFT EXECUTIVE WILL RETIRE; SYNOPSYS SETTLES CADENCE LAWSUIT;.

headline: ECHOSTAR SEEKS TO OVERCOME U.S. OBJECTIONS TO DEAL
abstract: EchoStar Communications, hoping to overcome opposition from regulators over its plan to buy Hughes Electronics, offers to sell Cablevision Systems enough spectrum to reach entire United States with new satellite television service (S)

headline: United Is in Separate Talks With Unions on Concessions
abstract: United Airlines is starting to negotiate separately for concessions with each of its five unions, even though unions have formed coalition to present single concession plan to executives; proposal, calling for $1 billion in annual labor costs over five years, was delivered on Sept 25 to UAL chief executive Glenn F Tilton (M)

headline: Safety Chief Tries to Make Travel Easy, Too
abstract: Interview with Adm James M Loy, undersecretary of transportation for security and head of Transportation Security Administration, which is scrambling to meet Dec 31 deadline for start of airport screening of all checked baggage; his can-do philosophy and lighthearted demeanor have won him praise from both parties on Capitol Hill and even within ranks of airlines and airport managers whose business he is restructuring; photo (M)

headline: MediaTalk; No Party, Just a Garage Sale at Time Inc.
abstract: Time Inc cancels its traditional holiday festivities; new chief executive Ann S Moore decides that lavish parties would not match somber atmosphere while company closes down some of its magazines (M)

headline: From Terror Site to a Hindu Shrine
abstract: Thousands of Balinese gather at site of terrorist bombing on Oct 12 to purify area with Hindu religious ceremony; photo

headline: Carter, in Oslo for Prize, Says U.S. Should Work With U.N. on Iraq
abstract: Former Pres Jimmy Carter, speaking at news conf in Oslo on day before his formal acceptance of Nobel Peace Prize, asserts that United States should work with United Nations toward peaceful resolution of tensions with Iraq, expressing belief that such an outcome is possible (S)

headline: IRELAND'S ESB TO RUN A SOUTHERN ELECTRICITY SYSTEM
abstract: Ireland's state-owned energy company, ESB, won a five-year contract to manage the SeTrans regional electricity transmission system, which provides electricity to Georgia, Alabama, Louisiana and five other states. A consortium formed by ESB and Accenture will establish a company with 250 employees and annual revenue of $150 million, to manage about 51,000 miles of transmission lines and 73,000 megawatts of power capacity.   Brian Lavery (NYT)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Yen has its biggest decline against dollar in eight weeks; graph (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: A Break For Smokers
abstract: Economic Secretary John Healey announces Britains can now bring 3,200 cheap duty-free cigarettes per person from Europe; number is up substantially from 800 previously allowed by customs (S)

headline: Hussein Says Inspections Will Expose 'American Lies'
abstract: Pres Saddam Hussein uses occasion of his Christmas greetings to Iraq's Christian minority to denounce US, saying weapons inspections will demonstrate fact that US merely seeks pretext to seize Iraqi resources; Sabah Abdel-Nour, Iraqi scientist who was involved in nuclear program, acknowledges being interviewed by inspectors; says he declined offer to leave country (M)

headline: China's Leader Urges Party to Reform Economy, Not Politics
abstract: Pres Jiang Zemin, summarizing his tenure as national leader, vows China will continue economic transformation but rules out any sweeping changes in political freedom, speech opening Communist Party Congress, Beijing; says China will become strong, prosperous, democratic and culturally advanced socialist nation by mid-century; cites need to crack down on corruption and address other problems arising along with spectacular economic growth; is expected to step down as party leader (M)

headline: CHARTER SAYS IT HAS FIRED 2 TOP EXECUTIVES
abstract: Charter Communications, cable TV operator, dismisses its chief financial officer, Kent Kalkwarf, and its chief operating officer, David Barford, because of federal investigation into company's accounting (S)

headline: Signs of Revived Qaeda Are Seen In Latest Strikes and New Tapes
abstract: American officials fear terrorist attacks in past week and taped messages from leaders of Al Qaeda signal beginning of new wave of terrorist activity and possibly large-scale attack; say pattern of recent incidents show terror network has reconstituted itself, with smaller groups prompted to begin new attacks by inflammatory new messages from Qaeda leaders; latest intelligence analysis is based on attack against French oil tanker off Yemen and shooting of two American marines on island off Kuwait, in which one died (M)

headline: Interpublic fills one of two senior posts that are critical to its plans to regain investors' trust.
abstract: Interpublic Group of Companies hires Arthur E D'Angelo as chief financial officer at its McCann-Erickson World Group division; appointment seen key move in bid to repair recent financial and operational difficulties (M)

headline: Paris Journal; Duke's Cognac Sold High, but Then, So Did the Gin
abstract: Christie's in Paris auctions off wines and liquors once owned by Duke of Windsor; photos (M)

headline: Terror-Tracking Agency Weighed, but Discarded, Plan Reconfiguring the Internet
abstract: Pentagon research agency studying creation of vast database of electronic transactions that could be analyzed for terrorist activity has rejected proposal for tagging Internet data with unique personal markers that would make anonymous use of some parts of Internet impossible; eDNA plan touched off angry dispute among computer scientists and policy experts (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: 5 In Kidnap Inquiry Charged With Burglary
abstract: British police hold five men originally arrested for plot to kidnap former Spice Girls singer Victoria Adams on burglary charges; investigation into reported abdution scheme will continue (S)

headline: Private Sector; A Fighter for Burgers and Fries
abstract: Profile of Joe Langteau, chief executive for last seven months of AmeriKing Inc, one of largest Burger King restaurant operators, with 329 outlets; he has closed 23 unprofitable restaurants and hired new team of top managers in attempt to return company to profitability; AmeriKing filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection on Dec 4; photo (M)

headline: EARNINGS RISE AT NURSING HOME CHAIN
abstract: Sunrise Assisted Living's fourth-quarter earnings will rise as much as 77 percent, more than company expected, because it sold nursing homes in seven states ahead of schedule (S)

headline: Responsive or Quiet? The Ideal Keyboard
abstract: Q.My wife says I need a quieter keyboard. Are keyboards that use so-called membrane technology significantly quieter than ordinary keyboards?    A.The sound produced by computer keyboards of different types can vary, but other factors, like the speed and technique of the typist, can also affect the amount of noise generated.

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: Judiciary Spokesman Resigns In Protest
abstract: Islamic Republic News Agency reports spokesman for Iranian judiciary Hossein Mir Muhammad Sadeghi has resigned in protest of scholar Hashem Aghajari's death sentence (S)

headline: War, Murder and Suicide: A Year's Toll Is 1.6 Million
abstract: Violence kills more than 1.6 million people each year, and suicide claims almost as many lives as war and homicide combined, according to a new report.

headline: A Top General Still Stands Behind Chávez
abstract: Top Venezuelan Gen Raul Baduel, despite pleadings from leaders of antigovernment movement, ordinary Venezuelans and some military officers, rejects requests to help oust Pres Hugo Chavez; national strike continues amid rumors of possible coup; military officers and experts say Chavez has taken steps to ensure that important commands are in hands of trusted allies; photo (M)

headline: TV Guide's Editor Resigns After 7 Years in Job
abstract: Steven Reddicliffe resigns as editor of TV Guide magazine (M)

headline: North Korea Asks the South to Join in Pressing the U.S. to Sign a Nonaggression Treaty
abstract: North Korea asks South Korea to join it in pressing United States to sign nonaggression treaty; North's unusual appeal to its estranged neighbor is apparently aimed at reducing its isolation; it comes as US, Japan and South Korea have initiated penalties against North for its violation of nuclear arms control agreements (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Belgium: Telecom Executive Dies
abstract: John Goossens, 57-year-old chief executive of Belgian state-owned phone company Belgacom SA, dies of heart attack following board meeting (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Bank Takeover Expected
abstract: Shares of Abbey National rise 3.5 percent to 5.54 pounds ($8.60) on hope that it will receive other takeover offers now that it has rejected approach from Bank of Ireland (S)

headline: The Week's Economic Events
abstract: MONDAYLeading IndicatorsSept.

headline: Europeans Set Date for Entry Of 10 Nations To the Union
abstract: European Union foreign ministers, meeting, Brussels, tentatively set May 1,2004, as date for 10 more nations to join 15-nation union; candidates, Cyprus, Czech Republic, Estonia, Hungary, Latvia, Lithuania, Malta, Poland, Slovakia and Slovenia, hope to conclude talks on joining union at Dec gathering; accord comes after candidates accept compromise farm aid formula (M)

headline: Job Expenses May Add to Debt for Women
abstract: DIARYJob Expenses May Add To Debt for Women.

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Intel Introduces Server Products
abstract: Intel introduces four processors and related products designed to increase performance of server computers sold to businesses (S)

headline: Radio Transmitters to Follow the Bouncing Soccer Ball
abstract: Hanno Reinert of Cairos Technologies proposes replacing human eyes with electronic signals to judge soccer games; system developed at Fraunhofer Institute for Integrated Circuits in Erlangen, Germany, relies on tiny microwave radio transmitters carrying rechargeable batteries built into players' shin pads and the ball; receiving antennas create virtual three-dimensional grid and computer figures out location of ball and players by analyzing signal delays; plan is to run test games with system, which is already installed in Nuremberg's Franconia Stadium, in 2004; drawing (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Electronic Data Downgraded By Moody's
abstract: Technology: Ele

headline: Technology Briefing: Hardware
abstract: ADVANCED MICRO DEVICES TO CUT WORK FORCE; INTEL ADDS SHARES TO STOCK BUYBACK PLAN;.

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Adobe To Dismiss 7.4% Of Work Force
abstract: Adobe Systems Inc is dismissing about 260 employees, or 7.4 percent of work force (S)

headline: HSBC to Buy a U.S. Lender for $14.2 Billion
abstract: HSBC Holdings, British banking giant that built its empire in Asia, agrees to pay $14.2 billion in stock for Household International, biggest mortgage lender to people with blemished credit histories in US; deal is significant shift in strategy for HSBC, which has typically focused on servicing very wealthy; HSBC's chairman Sir John Bond comments; consumer group Inner City Press/Community on the Move says it plans to block deal because it is well known that Household has engaged in predatory lending practices; chart; photos (M)

headline: General Counsel at ImClone Has Resigned
abstract: ImClone Systems announces resignation of John B Landes, who was company's general counsel as controversies arose over stock trading by executives and about drug maker's disclosures; he was apparently under pressure and had been demoted (M)

headline: Job Expenses May Add To Debt for Women
abstract: Consolidated Credit Counseling Services reports that single women age 18 to 25 seek help managing debt in greater numbers than their male counterparts, disparity it attributes in part to greater spending by women on clothing for work (S)

headline: International Hit for a Saucy Spanish Trio
abstract: Asereje, single recorded by Spanish trio Las Ketchup, has become global phenomenon, selling four million copies and topping charts in 17 nations; trio member Lola Munoz comments, phone interview (M)

headline: Executive Life; Tough at the Top: Get Your Own Coffee
abstract: Budget cutting at many corporations takes aim at executive's privileges, and one of prime targets is their full-time administrative assistants; executive secretary who specializes in catering to needs of individual executive has become almost endangered species; photo (M)

headline: Finding the Hydrogen For Hydrogen-Powered Cars
abstract: Richard Risemberg letter comments on Dec 15 article on hydrogen-powered vehicles

headline: The Experts' Advice For the Golden Arches
abstract: Peter Sherman letter replies to Oct 20 article about McDonald's fast food restaurant chain

headline: REGIONAL MARKET -- Hell's Kitchen; Where F-Stops Have Replaced Pit Stops
abstract: Hell's Kitchen section of Manhattan, frequently referred to as Clinton, has many high-rise apartment buildings with rents to match but area has reatined blue-collar character; Splashlight Studios, new building designed to offer rental photographic and digital studios for fashion and magazine industries, discussed; photo (M)

headline: DataBank; Markets Greet a Rate Cut With a Big Sigh
abstract: Summary of week's market trading; graphs; tables (S)

headline: US Airways And Unions Agree on Cuts
abstract: US Airways reached tentative agreements on concessions last night with unions representing its machinists and flight attendants, completing a package for an additional $200 million in wage and benefit cuts that the airline needed to avoid liquidation.    The moves came as US Airways prepared to file a reorganization plan in United States bankruptcy court. The plan, which a judge will consider at a hearing on Jan. 16, was set to include proposals for returning the airline to profitability. It hopes to emerge from bankruptcy by spring.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Firefighters Urged To Cancel Strikes
abstract: Britain's 50,000 firefighters end initial two-day strike, and government urges them to call off three planned eight-day strikes and says troops may be sent across picket lines to operate their firefighting equipment if stoppages continue (S)

headline: A $58.5 MILLION VERDICT AGAINST CHRYSLER IS OVERTURNED
abstract: Pennsylvania appeals court overturns $58.5 million verdict against DaimlerChrysler's Chrysler Corp subsidiary for vehicle owners who said they were injured by defective air bags (M)

headline: Unhindered by Iraqi Officials, Arms Inspectors Visit 3 Sites
abstract: United Nations arms inspectors, nearly four years afer quitting their work in frustration at Iraqi defiance, begin new search for banned weapons programs that could determine whether United States carries out its threat to go to war to topple Pres Saddam Hussein; inspectors are armed with new, no-tolerance mandate; two teams of inspectors check three sites for traces of illegal weapons, and UN officials report they faced no Iraqi resistance; photo (M)

headline: The Pinch of Piracy Wakes China Up On Copyright Issue; It's More Than a Trade Dispute When the Victims Are Chinese
abstract: Chinese artists have begun to join big foreign interests like Microsoft Corp and AOL Time Warner to protest China's seemingly limitless capacity to make cheap knockoffs; throughout 1990's, intellectual property was mainly seen as trade dispute pitting wealthy West against developing East; it is now also domestic struggle, with local stars complaining that they get little advantage; China's creative industry has been hard hit by failure to enforce copyright laws; artists and their lawyers say piracy has worsened since China joined World Trade Organization late last year and pledged to meet international standards for protecting intellectual property; precautions taken to protect integrity of of Zhang Yimou's film Hero at recent preview in China discussed; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Head Of Orthodox Church Ailing
abstract: Russian Orthodox Church Patriarch Aleksy II is hospitalized while visiting Russian republic of Astrakhan; photo (S)

headline: Results Are Glum at Dow Jones, and Outlook Is Gloomy
abstract: Dow Jones & Co, publisher of Wall Street Journal, reports third-quarter net income of $2.4 million, decline of about 85 percent from $16.7 million in quarter year earlier; says revenue fell about 11 percent, to $352.4 million from $397.6 million year earlier; chief executive Peter R Kann calls business environment for The Journal 'uncontrollable and awful'; chief operating officer Richard F Zannino expects fourth-quarter revenue decline of about 13 percent to 15 percent; Kann and Zannino confirm that they expect additional job cuts across company but say no decisions on number of cuts have been made (M)

headline: Chinese Power Company Chief Flees the Country and Scrutiny
abstract: Gao Yan, director of China's giant State Power Corp, flees country to avoid prosecution in one of several corruption cases embarrassing Communist Party during leadership transition; Gao has ties to party boss Li Peng (S)

headline: Magazine Ad Pages Off a Bit Last Month
abstract: Publishers Information Bureau data indicate 0.2 percent decline in magazine advertising pages in October compared with same month year earlier; ad pages are down 5.9 percent to date in 2002 compared with same period in 2001 (S)

headline: Using a Peaceful Time to Reclaim a Painful Past
abstract: Profile of Krzysztof Czyzewski, Polish intellectual, who leads group that seeks to reclaim past, bad and good, for Poland; he spent years under Communism as underground theater director and performer with interest in Poland's cultural traditions; last year he helped set off one of most searing recent debates in Poland, when his group's publishing house printed book that alleges that it was Poles, not occupying Nazi troops, who killed 1,600 Jews in 1941 in village of Jedwabne; book ultimately led Pres Aleksander Kwasniewski to apologize on behalf of Poles; photo (M)

headline: Tension Mounts Between United and Machinists
abstract: Executives and union leaders of United Airlines step up their pressure on United's mechanics, seeking their approval of $700 million package of wage and benefit concessions that airline says could help it avoid bankruptcy court; mechanics' vote is scheduled for Dec 5 and outcome is uncertain; United also announces plans to lay off 220 pilots in early January and 132 in early February, reducing total to about 8,250, and cut senior management ranks by 18 percent, to 36 senior managers; chief executive Glenn F Tilton says remaining managers will take average annual pay cut of 11 percent over airline's planned five-and-a-half year recovery period and will forgo merit and incentive bonuses this year; management savings will total more than $60 million; chart; photo (M)

headline: I.B.M. Business Unit Will Focus on Electronics Companies
abstract: IBM forms business unit to sell design assistance, production management and other services to electronics companies eager to outsource aspects of production; division, IBM Engineering and Technology Services, will seek to distinguish itself by supplying best solutions to clients' needs -- regardless of source of those solutions (M)

headline: Man in the News; General for the Hawks -- Shaul Mofaz
abstract: Man in the News profile of new Israeli defense minister, Gen Shaul Mofaz; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Fails to Curb Its Saudi Oil Habit, Experts Say
abstract: America remains as dependent as ever on Saudi Arabia for oil, nearly 12 years after Persian Gulf war when reliance on Saudi supplies prompted calls for US to diversify sources; Saudi Arabia supplies approximately one-sixth of US imports, but has considerable political strength as only producer with spare capacity to replace millions of barrels daily, which could be drained from market by US military action against Iraq; produces approximately eight million barrels per day; officials say it could raise output to 10 million barrels fairly quickly and to 10.5 million within three months; US Energy Department official Guy Caruso says if war halts Iraq's exports of between 1.5 million to 2 million barrels daily, situation would be manageable; says it would be harder to replace steeper decline in exports, which would occur if exports from other Persian Gulf suppliers are reduced by terrorist attacks or by prohibitive insurance premiums on oil tankers; graphs; chart (M)

headline: World Business Briefing: Asia
abstract: SINGAPORE: Telecom Profit Slips; JAPAN: Bank Forgives Debts; SOUTH KOREA: Ssangyong Posts A Profit; SOUTH KOREA: Phone Results Improve; CHINA: Stock Rules Loosened; CHINA: Phone Stake Sold;.

headline: DIANON SYSTEMS TO PAY $4.8 MILLION IN MEDICARE CASE
abstract: Dianon Systems agrees to pay government $4.8 million to resolve accusations that it overcharged Medicare and other federal health programs (S)

headline: ON THE GROUND: In Sacramento; Good Times Continue to Roll In a Gold Rush Capital City
abstract: Travel article on Sacramento, Calif, as business destination; photo (M)6

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: LONDON: Damages For Adoption Gone Violently Awry; LONDON: Prince Is Off Public Assistance; PARIS: Trying To Cut Traffic Deaths; IRELAND: Speak Gaelic Or Hit The High Road; RUSSIA: Top General In Chechnya Is Fired;.

headline: Indonesian Suspect, Due for Questioning, Lands in Hospital
abstract: Abu Bakar Bashir, who had agreed to turn himself in for questioning, was unexpectedly admitted to a hospital.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Schröder Sworn In For 2nd Term
abstract: German Chancellor Gerhard Schroder and his cabinet are sworn in for second four-year term after parliament approves coalition government (S)

headline: Europe Limits Cod Fishing, but Rejects Ban
abstract: European Union fisheries ministers, meeting in Paris, agree to compromise that would cut 2003 cod fishing quota in North Sea to 45 percent of 2002 levels and restrict cod vessels to nine fishing days per month; reject total cod fishing ban, favored by International Council for the Exploration of the Sea (M)

headline: Split at U.N. Over Products That Iraqis May Import
abstract: Security Council acts to revise list of goods that must be approved by UN before Iraq can import them, with Russian and Syria abstaining from vote; list was first drawn up last May under oil-for-food program, in which UN uses revenues from Iraq oil to buy goods for civilian population; US wanted to add items by Dec 31 to bar Iraq from making new purchases of questionable goods when administration expects pace of preparations for potential war to quicken (M)

headline: George Barrie, 90, Songwriter, Producer and Fabergé Executive
abstract: George Barrie, an executive who not only created the men's fragrance Brut but also produced movies and received two Oscar nominations for his songwriting, died last Saturday in Aventura, Fla., where he lived.    He was 90.

headline: Business; An Insider's Advice on Corporate Ethics
abstract: Interview with Muriel Siebert, author of book Changing the Rules: Adventures of a Wall Street Maverick; photo (M)

headline: Viacom Leader Hopes to Keep Its President
abstract: Viacom Inc chairman Sumner M Redstone says he is optimistic that president-chief operating officer Mel Karmazin will remain at company; also says he plans to ask all eight former CBS board members, including Karmazin, to remain at company; photo (M)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY  None    TUESDAY  Consumer Confidence: Oct.

headline: Drug Release To Be Delayed Once Again, Akzo Says
abstract: Akzo Nobel says it is forced to delay for at least another year release of antidepressant drug gepirone ER, formerly known as Ariza, it is testing; company's pharmaceutical division Organon is having hard time recruiting patients for clinical trials of drug; Akzo had hoped to release drug next year for treatment of severe depression but has put off plans to do so until at least 2004 (M)

headline: Personal Business; Before Signing on the Dotted Line, Think It Through
abstract: List of considerations one might think through before finalizing lease of automobile (S)

headline: World Briefing: Americas
abstract: SENATE APPROVES U.S. ENVOY TO MEXICO; MEXICO: Convictions In Chiapas Massacre; VENEZUELA: Capital Tense After Clashes;.

headline: Irish Protestant Leader Issues Ultimatum on Sinn Fein Ouster
abstract: Northern Ireland first minister, David Trimble, says he and fellow Protestant officeholders will stage mass resignation that would cause legislature to collapse unless Britain throws Sinn Fein out of Assembly; meets with Prime Min Tony Blair in London; cites evidence from police raid that is said to show that IRA is conducting espionage and that British law enforcement personnel are targets (M)

headline: World Business Briefing: Europe
abstract: SWITZERLAND: Credit Suisse Assurances; BRITAIN: A Deal To Buy Littlewoods; GERMANY: Bayer Sees Lower Operating Profit; SWITZERLAND: Financier Sells Chemical Stake;.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Aluminum Investment
abstract: Aluminum Corporation of China, world's third-largest producer of the metal, will spend 17.8 billion yuan ($2.17 billion) to double its smelting capacity and ensure jobs for its 68,000 workers; Alcoa is third-largest shareholder in Aluminum Corp (S)

headline: French Court Fines Soros for Insider Trading
abstract: A French court today fined the American financier George Soros 2.2 million euros, or about $2.3 million.

headline: Rejecting Boycott, Researchers Gather in Israel
abstract: Group of medical researchers from Columbia University, saying they are taking stand against academic boycotts of Israeli institutions, organize scientific conference this weekend in Eilat, Israel; conference, Frontiers in Cardiovascular Science, is featuring speakers from US, Canada and Europe; aims to share research findings and to send broader message of solidarity to Israeli scholars, who have found themselves isolated in recent months by boycott protesting Israel's presence in West Bank and Gaza Strip; boycott began with petitions drawn up by British neurochemist Steven Rose (M)

headline: Executive Life; Doing Good Can Mean Big Headaches
abstract: Article describes difficulties executives sometimes encounter donating their time and services to nonprofit organizations; photo (M)

headline: European Proposal Would Ease Merger Rules
abstract: European Commission proposes law on takeovers that it hopes will ease merger process in 15-nation European Union; aim of proposal is to enable takeover bids to be made in union under best possible conditions for all those concerned; commission has tried to avoid confrontation with Germany, union's biggest member (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: France: Trying To Cut Traffic Deaths
abstract: French government proposes variety of regulations attempting to reduce highway deaths; France has fourth highest fatal accident rate in Europe; sanctions include new speed-detection systems, higher fines and stricter licensing laws; zero tolerance for people who drink and drive is also being considered, but not without controversy (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: ELECTRONIC DATA SYSTEMS CORP., Plano, Tex., the provider of computer services, said it extended contracts for a combined $240 million with Weyerhaeuser Co., Tacoma, Wash., the world's largest lumber company, and Integral Energy, a power company in Australia.    WAYNE BANCORP INC., Wooster, Ohio, agreed to buy Banc Services Corp., Orrville, Ohio, the parent of Savings Bank and Trust Co., for $45.8 million.

headline: Visions of a Union: Europe Searches for New Identity
abstract: Analysis of European Union leaders' actions during Copenhagen summit; EU formally invites 10 new members to join by 2004, and also rejects Turkey's demand that its candidacy be given more urgency; photo (M)

headline: Making Cameras Smaller, In Size and (Maybe) Price
abstract: David Pogue State of the Art column offers gift ideas for shutterbugs; explores pros and cons of new superslim digital microcameras; prices and features of five models compared; drawing; photos (M)

headline: Brushing Aside Objections, Hong Kong Proceeds on Security Law
abstract: Brushing aside objections, the Hong Kong today ended a public comment period on plans for tough internal security laws and said it would proceed directly with legislation.

headline: Tyson Foods Is Sued Over Health Issue
abstract: Tyson Foods Is Sued Over Health Issue.

headline: People and Accounts of Note
abstract: Adient, Parsippany, N.J., part of the CommonHealth unit of the WPP Group, hired one employee and promoted another.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: GENERAL DYNAMICS, Falls Church, Va., the military contractor, said it had won an order valued at $450 million to integrate equipment and software for the digital radio system it sold to the British Army last year.    CENTURION WIRELESS TECHNOLOGIES, Lincoln, Neb., a portfolio company of Cornerstone Equity Investors, New York, agreed to buy a phone antenna unit from Allgon, Stockholm, for $20 million.

headline: A Double Standard For Executive Women?
abstract: Patrick Crowley letter, responding to Sept 15 The Right Thing column, contends that Martha Stewart's stock trading faces scrutiny because she is celebrity, not because she is woman

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Credit Suisse Assurances
abstract: Steep plunge in Credit Suisse's share price prompts company to reassure investors of strength of their investments and of firm's stability; analysts fear company may be forced to increase its capital reserves; graph (M)

headline: A Bandage That Just Fades Away
abstract: Dr Steve Koontz commends on his role in developing Liquid Bandage for Johnson & Johnson; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Opposition Lashes Out At Schröder
abstract: The leader of the opposition Christian Democrats, Angela Merkel, accused Chancellor Gerhard Schröder of duping voters on everything from taxes to pension reform to foreign policy in order to win re-election in September. ''Schröder and his government lied without even batting an eyelash,'' she told delegates at a party congress in Hanover. She said the party would fight the chancellor's plans to restructure the labor market.   Hugh Eakin (NYT)

headline: Russia Battles Video Piracy; But the Pirates Shoot Back
abstract: russia battles video pira

headline: Executive Life; Who Says Unions Must Dislike the Chief?
abstract: Some chief executives know how to developed respectful relations with unions that represent their employees; among them are Jeffrey L Bleustein of Harley-Davidson, David Freedman of New Brunswick Scientific and George C Halvorson of Kaiser Permanente; photo (M)

headline: Dresden Journal; Recovering From Flood, With Operatic Flourish
abstract: High culture in Dresden, Germany, has made all sorts of accommodations since Elbe River flooded old city in Aug, leaving opera house and Zwinger Palace, which houses city's renowed art collection, partly submerged; Semper Oper is performing in modern Volkswagen factory; Zwinger has reopened, displaying great works saved by army of volunteers from underground storage vaults in rows ten deep while hot-air pumps continue to dry out basement rooms; is pushing for new storage facility, holding there is no way to protect vaults from future floods; photos (M)

headline: Article 2002112192398260972 -- No Title
abstract: function pop_me_up(pURL, features) { new_window = window.open(pURL, "popup_window", features); new_window.focus(); } Ingredients for Luscious Listening As Music Players and Accessories Shrink, the Sound Gets Fuller

headline: Credit Cards Seek New Fees on Web's Demimonde
abstract: Visa and MasterCards are imposing new rules and fees on adult sites on Internet; say such sites cost them more money in fraud and practice known as 'chargebacks,' in which card holder denies having made purchase and demands that company take charge off bill; sums are insignificant to larger sites, but could well take profitability out of smaller sites, of which there are tens of thousands on Web; some adult site entrepreneurs fear credit-card companies will use their position to regulate content on their sites, noting how they have strangled many online gambling sites; photo (M)

headline: Corn Near Gene-Altered Site to Be Destroyed
abstract: Federal regulators order destruction of Iowa cornfield surrounding ProdiGene test site for gene-altered crops they fear might contaminate food supply (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: GOLD RISES. Concern about an attack on Iraq has helped to fuel a run-up in gold, a traditional haven in times of international turmoil. In New York, futures contracts for February rose $3.80, or 1.1 percent, to $337.60 an ounce.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Insurance Fund Renewed
abstract: Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party will pump 400 billion yen ($3.3 billion) of taxpayers' money into fund to repay policyholders of bankrupt life insurers (S)

headline: Iraq and the Arabs' Future
abstract: The driving motivation behind a new U.S. endeavor in Iraq should be modernizing the Arab world. Most Arabs will see such an expedition as an imperial reach into their world. But in this case a reforming foreign power's guidelines offer a better way than the region's age-old prohibitions, defects, and phobias. No apologies ought to be made for America's "unilateralism."

headline: Deutsche Telekom Names Chief Executive
abstract: Deutsche Telekom names Kai-Uwe Ricke as chief executive and simultaneously reports loss of $24.7 billion in first nine months of 2002; rumors persist that many executives approached to run Deutsche Telekom refused position and that changes in its mobile phone division, Voicestream, renamed T-Mobile USA, will be necessary components of remedy for parent company's financial malaise; photo (M)

headline: Law Won't Alter U.S. Stand On Jerusalem, Officials Say
abstract: Bush administration says it will ignore as unconstitutional new Congressional dictates requiring US to acknowledge Jerusalem as capital of Israel; provision is in State Department authorization bill newly signed by Bush (S)

headline: U.S. Criticizes North Korea For Rejecting Inspections
abstract: Bush administration says it is 'disppointing' that North Korea rejects International Atomic Energy Agency demand to inspect its newly revealed program to develop nuclear arms from highly enriched uranium; muted comments seem to be part of strategy to defuse any sense of imminent confrontation with North Korea; agency expresses 'deep concern' (M)2

headline: Holocaust Writer in Storm Over Role of Catholic Church
abstract: Daniel Jonah Goldhagen's new book, A Moral Reckoning: The Role of the Catholic Church in the Holocaust, provokes outrage among church officials; Munich archdiocese files lawsuit against German publisher over photo caption that misidentifies figure marching in Nazi rally as Cardinal Michael Faulhaber; photo; Goldhagen acknowledges that papal nuncio in photo is Cesare Orsenigo, but also charges that church does not want truth told of its role nurturing anti-Semitism that culminated in Holocaust; some critics say book breaks little new historical ground on church's often compliant relationship with Nazi regime; Goldenhagen himself has been literary celebrity in Germany since first book, which stimulated national debate on Holocaust's roots (M)

headline: A Smarter, Lighter Keyboard, for Typing on the Go
abstract: David Pogue State of the Art column on AlphaSmart Dana, which is somewhere between hand-held organizer and laptop; runs Palm operating system but offers more flexibility, full-size keyboard, but is not feature-laden; drawing; photo (M)

headline: ABC Extends Contract For Jennings
abstract: ABC News completes deal to keep Peter Jennings as its main news anchor for next three years; will also buy four documentaries a year from Jennings's new production company, PJ Productions; photo (M)

headline: S.E.C. Lawyer To Leave Agency
abstract: William Baker III, associate director of enforcement at SEC, is quitting agency at end of month (S)

headline: Man in the News; A Diplomat Who Won't Take 'No' -- Hans Blix
abstract: Man in the News profile of Hans Blix, Swedish lawyer who heads United Nations weapons inspection team in Iraq; photo (M)

headline: Robotics Slumps, but Recovery Is Predicted
abstract: UN Economic Commission annual survey shows investment in industrial robots plummeted in Japan and US in 2001, but recovery is expected over next three years; overall rate of investments in robotics around world fell by 3 percent last year; number of robots is expected to exceed 960,000 by 2005, growing at annual rate of 7.5 percent (S)

headline: Health Service Is Bankrupt
abstract: ANDOVER, Mass., Nov. 27 (Bloomberg News) — Med Diversified Inc., a provider of home health care services, has filed for bankruptcy protection after the collapse of its primary financing source, National Century Financial Enterprises.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Yugoslavia: Convictions In Kosovo Killings
abstract: Serbian military court jails two Yugoslav Army officers and two former soldiers for three to seven years for murders of two Kosovo Albanian civilians in April 1999; war crimes trial is second to be heard in Yugoslavia, federation of Serbia and Montenegro (S)

headline: Schröder's Tax Surprise Angers Many Germans
abstract: Germans are angry about raft of taxes on individuals and companies that Chancellor Gerhard Schroder has proposed in desperate effort to reduce budget deficit that has breached limit set by European Union; Schroder, who won re-election by reed-thin margin in September after campaign in which he said little about taxes, says dire condition of public finance became clear only after elections; photo; map (M)

headline: In Rumsfeld's Words: Guidelines for Committing Forces
abstract: Excerpts from memorandum by Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld setting out guidelines for committing US forces to combat (S)

headline: U.S. Tells Iraq It Must Reveal Weapons Sites
abstract: US says Iraq must physically take UN inspectors to weapons sites and make available all people who developed and worked on them; stiff demand comes as deadline nears for Iraq to declare all weapons of mass destruction; Saddam Hussein appears on Iraqi television to urge 'patience' in dealing with inspectors to 'keep our people out of harm's way'; White House dismisses Iraqi claims to have no nuclear weapons but offers no new evidence; Sec Donald Rumseld says Hussein could leave Iraq, admit to weapons and open up sites or continue 'to lie and deceive,' which is what White House thinks will happen (M)

headline: Irish Recall Sad Homes for 'Fallen' Women
abstract: Peter Mullan film The Magdalene Sisters describes Ireland's Magdalene Asylums, where women who offended country's moral codes were sent to live, and sometimes die, in disgrace; Magadalene homes took in 30,000 women over decades until last one finally closed in 1996; Mullan's film depicts casual cruelty and commonplace despair in homes; families sent to homes daughters who, for whatever reason, had brought shame on them; women worked long hours and received no pay; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Dispute Affecting Tourists Ends
abstract: Officials reached an agreement with shrimp fishermen from the upper Gulf of California, resolving a dispute that temporarily affected local tourism. Last weekend, hundreds of fishermen protesting a new law that bans fishing in the upper gulf's federally protected marine reserve blocked the highway to the Arizona border, stranding hundreds of American tourists. The compromise will allow 130 boats to fish in the protected zone if they use special nets to prevent killing the endangered vaquita, the world's smallest porpoise.   Eduardo Castillo (NYT)

headline: US Airways Gets Lender; United Wins Pay Cuts
abstract: Retirement Systems of Alabama wins bid to become primary lender for US Airways, giving it lending role in airline's effort to emerge from bankruptcy court; pension fund offered in September to invest $240 million for 37.5 percent stake in airline, which had filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection; David G Bronner leads fund; United Airlines discloses that its salaried employees agreed to pay cuts of $1.3 billion over next five and half years as part of overall $5.8 billion package of concessions from its workers; pilots for United also vote overwhelmingly to approve $2.2 billion in concessions as their contribution; photo (M)

headline: Big Hopes for Commuting by Bike
abstract: Nation's bicycle makers are exploring commuter bike; idea is to provide inexpensive and comfortable bicycle that comes with essentials--lights, locks, suspension, fenders and bell--necessary for getting to work and back; $4.2 billion American bicycle industry also senses market opportunity in continued sluggish, travel-compromised economy; some bicycle makers attending industry's trade show, International Bicycle Expo in Las Vegas, comment; photo (M)

headline: Personal Business; Leasing Loses Allure For Car Dealers and Buyers
abstract: Concentration of automobile makers on inducing customers to buy vehicles outright replaces mid- to late-1990's subsidized leasing promotions; shift causes volume of leased cars and trucks to shrink and allure of leasing to lessen for both customers and dealers; photo; graph (M)

headline: 2 Perfume Companies At Odds Over Territory
abstract: In a case of ''Truth'' and possible consequences, a small cosmetics company that makes a perfume called Truth is suing Calvin Klein Cosmetics, the maker of Truth Calvin Klein perfume, for breach of contract. At issue is whether Calvin Klein's fragrance is trespassing on the smaller company's territory.     The Revelations Perfume and Cosmetics Company, a start-up based in New Hope, Pa., said in a suit filed last week that Calvin Klein Cosmetics went back on a deal between the companies by selling its version of Truth in the food, drug and discount stores specifically reserved for the other, cheaper Truth.

headline: Barnes & Noble Takes New Tack and Buys Sterling Publishing
abstract: Nation's largest bookseller, Barnes & Noble, buys its first publishing house, Sterling Publishing, for about $100 million (M)

headline: Tape Spurs Terror Warning
abstract: Federal officials issued a new warning about possible terrorist attacks, based on threats in a tape they believe was made by Osama bin Laden's top aide. Page A19.

headline: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Ebay and Autotrader Will End Partnership Early
abstract: EBay Inc and AutoTrader.com will end their partnership on Jan 1, six months earlier than planned, and become competitors in online vehicle auctions; EBay sells its 2.6 percent stake in AutoTrader; financial terms undisclosed (S)/

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Oil Profit Rises
abstract: Petroleo Brasileiro reports $650 million net consolidated third-quarter profit, 45 percent higher than in 2001 period; revenue rose 34 percent, to $5.8 billion; production increased 13 percent and exports rose 59 percent (S)

headline: World Business Briefing: Europe
abstract: BRITAIN: Bank Names Chief; SWEDEN: Ericsson'S Loss Rises;.

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Sweden: Man Sentenced For Taking Gun On Plane
abstract: Kerim Chatty, Swedish man arrested in airport for having loaded gun in carry-on baggage, is sentenced to four months in prison for illegal weapons possession; hijacking charges are dropped for lack of evidence (S)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of picture caption with Dec 8 article on longtime ties between William Clay Ford Jr, chairman and chief executive of Ford Motor Co, and John L Thornton, president and co-chief operating officer of Goldman Sachs Group
