headline: A False Alarm Calls R.A.F. Over London
abstract: Britain orders warplanes into skies to escort British Airways flight to landing site at Heathrow after passenger aboard flight overhears what is taken to be suspicious conversation between two other travelers; emergency is later described by police as false alarm (S)

headline: U.S. Raids Foil Plots to Send Arms to Al Qaeda and Others
abstract: Federal law enforcement officials say they have broken up two major drug operations aimed at furnishing weapons to terrorists; in first case, two Pakistanis and American in Hong Kong are charged with plotting to trade heroin and hashish for four Stinger antiaircraft missiles; they allegedly told FBI undercover agents they were planning to sell missiles to Al Qaeda; in second case, four men linked to Colombian rightist paramilitary organization are arrested on charges they sought to trade $25 million in cash and cocaine for five containers of Warsaw Pact weapons; authorities say both plans were stymied by FBI undercover agents, who moved in before plans could be carried out; Atty Gen John Ashcroft and FBI Dir Robert S Mueller III say drug interdiction remains hig priority for administration, particularly when it crosses paths with terrorist organizations; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Financial Scandal Uncovered
abstract: Japan's Foreign Minister Yoriko Kawaguchi reports that ministry has disciplined 39 officials who doctored expense reports defrauding government of almost $4 million dollars; Vice Minister Yukio Takeuchi and Deputy Vice Minister Shinichi Kitajima are censured; last year 328 officials were similarly exposed and punished (S)

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: FRANCE: Suit On Criticism Of Muslims Dismissed; NORTHERN IRELAND: New Talks To Start Today; RUSSIA: Raising The Bar For Parliament; RUSSIA: Smart Thieves Fail To Outwit Police; BOSNIA: Compensation Sought For Massacre;.

headline: F.D.I.C. Is Considering Investment Changes
abstract: Federal Deposit Insurance Corp, facing growing number of bank failures, weighs major changes in its investment portfolio; considers sale of some of its Treasury securities in search for higher yields (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Nepal: Elections May Be Delayed
abstract: Nepal government may delay parliamentary elections because of potential violence by Maoist rebels (S)

headline: Call to Arms: Bush's Plea on Iraq
abstract: President Bush called for a historic reformulation of NATO's mission and weaponry so it can join in combat against global terrorism.

headline: AtHomeAbroad: On the comfy, cozy side of Tokyo
abstract: TOKYO—  Despite common perceptions of difficult and unfriendly living conditions, to hear some people tell it, Tokyo is an expatriate's heaven.

headline: Council Toils Over Wording Of Resolution Aimed at Iraq
abstract: Five permanent members of UN Security Council negotiate hard behind closed doors to forge compromises that might clear way for 'very different' resolution on Iraqi disarmament that Pres Bush has demanded; Bush's 'tough immediate requirements' discussed (M)

headline: Cairo Journal; For Women, a Male Mannerism: The Water Pipe
abstract: Growing number of women in Egypt are smoking water pipes, called shishas, at fashionable cafes; experts cite growth in middle-class cafe society, peer pressure and new assertivenes of young women in country were women are rarely seen smoking cigarette in public; some Egyptian women say they are drawn to pipe as means of expressing their independence; most shisha tobacco in Egypt's trendier coffee shops is scented and milder than that found elsewhere in Middle East; Egypt's religious authorities have not ruled on shisha smoking as yet, but they do not like this trend among women; photo (M)

headline: Can Celine Dion help Chrysler rebound? The automaker is betting millions that she can.
abstract: Chrysler Group division of DaimlerChrysler AG will announce broad-based partnership with singer Celine Dion and Sony Music Entertainment that will include her appearances in advertisements, cross-promotions of her music with the cars and special Chrysler song she will sing; Dion will receive tens of millions of dollars; Chrysler and Dion are both currently in need of promotion; photo (M)

headline: Burial Box Linked to Jesus Cracks in Transit
abstract: Ancient burial box cracks and comes close to falling to pieces in transit from Israel to Royal Ontario Museum for its first public showing since announcement that it could have held bones of James of Jerusalem, referred to in New Testament as Jesus's brother; museum officials say box can be repaired before exhibition opens Nov 16; photo (S)

headline: Private Sector; A Shaker, Not a Stirrer, at Revlon
abstract: Profile of new Revlon Inc chief executive Jack L Stahl, who leads expensive and aggressive marketing campaign to boost debt-ridden cosmetic company's sales; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Telecom Profit Slips
abstract: Singapore Telecommunications reports 25.5 percent drop in third-quarter earnings, to 415 million Singapore dollars ($235 million); performance of Australian subsidiary Optus weakens ST's results and creditworthiness; graph (S)

headline: Eyeing Moscow Warily, Lithuania Clasps NATO
abstract: Russia remains subtext in Lithuania's plan to join NATO; Vytautas Landsbergis, free Lithuania's first leader, cites Russia's long dominance of its smaller neighbors, interview; sees NATO allowing Lithuania to deal with Russia from position of strength; others say Russia is no longer serious threat and that NATO membership is pro-Lithuanian, not anti-Russian; map; photo (M)

headline: Bush Appears To Soften Tone On Iraq Action
abstract: Pres Bush appears to soften tone about military action against Iraq, saying he is open to compromises with Congress and UN as long as both agree to 'tough' resolutions that do not tie his hands if Saddam Hussein refuses to disarm; repeats that goal is 'disarming this man' and, in apparent nod to Security Council, makes no reference to engineering Saddam's overthrow, although spokesman Ari Fleischer later reiterates policy of 'regime change' and suggests less expensive ways of removing Saddam, such as one-way ticket out or 'one bullet, if Iraqi people take it on themselves'; White House also spurs compromise efforts with Congress hoping for quick resolution authorizing military action, though under more limited terms than Bush would like (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Telekom Bidders Selected
abstract: Germany's Deutsche Telekom selects three bidders as potential buyers of its six regional cable networks (S)1

headline: World Briefing: Americas
abstract: CANADA: Accord With Inuit;.

headline: UBS Closing Trading Floor It Acquired From Enron
abstract: UBS Warburg will sharply reduce size of energy trading unit it acquired from Enron Corp less than year ago and shut down Enron's former trading floor in Houston; trading operation, which had about 630 employees when UBS acquired it in February, is expected to be reduced to fewer than 100 employees, all of whom will be moved to company's office in Stamford, Conn (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Telekom Succession
abstract: Shares of Deutsche Telekom fall on rumor that ousted chief executive Ron Sommer will be replaced from within company (S)

headline: A Kansas Cardiologist With His Eye on the World
abstract: Dr Joseph Galichia, cardiologist who opened $20 million Galichia Heart Hospital in Wichita, Kan, in February, hopes to eventually have as many as 30 Galichia heart hospitals worldwide; Galichia has parlayed his reputation as cardiology research pioneer into burgeoning enteprise; group is close to finalizing plans for Galichia facilities in Texas and Arizona, and Galichia is in Beijing lining up investors for hospital there that will carry his name; photo (M)

headline: Kmart Studies List of Stores As Candidates For Closing
abstract: Kmart executives begin assessing chain's 1,832 stores to decide which ones they may close; one retailing consulting says that company may close as many as 598 stores in United States and Puerto Rico (M)

headline: Worldwide servers overwhelmed with data : Attack briefly disrupts Net
abstract: An unusually powerful, coordinated attack on the 13 computers around the world that act as the backbone of the Internet briefly crippled more than half of them, but because of the built-in workarounds in the system, few Internet users likely even noticed.

headline: Zimbabwe Bars Blair Over Visa Policy
abstract: Zimbabwe bars Prime Min Tony Blair and 93 other British officials from visiting nation and sets new visa requirements for Britons hoping to travel there; reacts to Britain's plan to require most Zimbabweans to apply for visas in effort to curb illegal immigration (M)

headline: Greek Appeals Court Overturns Conviction of 14 Plane Spotters
abstract: Three appeals court judges in Kalamata, Greece, overturn conviction of 12 British and 2 Dutch aviation enthusiasts who raised suspicions of terrorism by plane spotting nearly year ago while tracking Greek jets at air force base; accusations of international espionage caused friction with Britain and Netherlands; 14 plane spotters were imprisoned for 37 days in cells with convicted felons; they were released after British and Dutch diplomats strenuously argued that arrests resulted from cultural misunderstading of an eccentric hobby; former NATO official testifed that notes collected by enthusiasts were neither sensitive nor secret (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: King's Son Returns, Briefly, From Exile
abstract: Vittorio Emanuele, son of Italy's last King, makes first trip to Italy since forced exile more than 50 years ago; is accompanied on trip by son Emanuele Filiberto di Savoia; emotional visit also includes meeting with Pope John Paul II; photo (S)

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: GREECE: Effort To Avoid Clash On Cyprus; RUSSIA: Charges Filed Against Putin Critic; BELARUS: Russian Lawmaker Thrown Out; GERMANY: Troops To Stay In Macedonia;.

headline: Westar Says U.S. Seeks Details on Trades
abstract: Westar Energy Inc, Kansas utility owner, says it received subpoena from federal energy regulators for details on power trades; inquiry by Federal Energy Regulatory Commission includes $19.8 million in electricity trades made by Cleco Corp (S)

headline: Martha Stewart Is Less Visible in Ads for Kmart
abstract: Kmart's holiday television advertising for Martha Stewart Everyday products does not contain image of Stewart, who is under Justice Dept and Securities and Exchange Commission investigation for her sale of shares she owned in Imclone Systems; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Airline Drops Logo
abstract: Russia's biggest airline, OAO Aeroflot, said it would drop its Soviet-era hammer-and-sickle symbol as it rebuilds its image to attract higher-paying business passengers. The winged hammer and sickle harks back to Aeroflot's role as the sole Soviet carrier. According to the Communist Party, the sickle represented the peasants and the hammer the workers, uniting to throw off their chains and build a socialist paradise.

headline: DRUG COMPANY BUYS ANOTHER FOR $55.9 MILLION IN STOCK
abstract: Hyseq Pharmaceuticals agrees to buy Variagenics for $55.9 million in stock to accelerate its development of products (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: New Threat From Basque Group
abstract: Basque separatist group ETA threatens to attack offices of Spain's governing and opposition parties (S)

headline: Britain to Put Armed Guards on Flights
abstract: Britain says it will put covert armed marshals aboard British passenger planes on both domestic and international flights as part of increased antiterror travel security; Britain's pilots' association expresses doubts (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Theater Siege Lawsuits
abstract: Moscow district court agrees to hear compensation lawsuits stemming from Moscow theater stand-off in which at least 129 Russians died; $40 million dollar settlement sought by 38 families is unprecedented in Russia; theater, taken over by Chechen gunmen, was infused with narcotic gas by Russian Special Forces to subdue terrorists; gas injured and killed both terrorists and hostages; original settlement offered to victims' families was $5,000 each (S)

headline: A Scandal Embarrasses Israeli Party
abstract: Prime Min Ariel Sharon vows to root out corruption in his Likud party, amid revelations centering on charge that powerful members of central committee forced parliamentary candidates to pay to get favorable spot; photo (S)

headline: E-Commerce Report; There is more cheer in the virtual realm as online gift certificates soar.
abstract: Online merchants tallying results of stronger-than-expected holiday season get further boost from gift certificates, a favored scrip among post-holiday bargain hunters, which had their best season ever online; photos (M)

headline: Claus von Amsberg, 76, Popular Dutch Prince
abstract: Prince Claus von Amsberg, husband of Queen Beatrix of the Netherlands, dies at age 76; photo (M)

headline: ABB to Shed Units and Cut 10,000 Jobs
abstract: Jurgen Dormann, new chief executive of Swiss heavy-machinery maker ABB, tries to restore investor confidence by outlining his plan for radical overhaul; company will divest itself of multiple subsidiaries, cut 10,000 jobs and institute other cost-cutting measures designed to restore profitability and growth; ABB will shrink by a third; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing: Asia
abstract: SOUTH KOREA: Securities Firm Warned; CHINA: Share Offer Reduced;.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: White House Backs Off Big S.E.C. Budget Increase  Less than three months ago, President Bush signed sweeping legislation with great fanfare that called for a huge increase in the budget of the Securities and Exchange Commission to police corporate America and clean up Wall Street.    Now the White House is backing off the budget provision and urging Congress to provide the agency with 27 percent less money than the new law authorized. [Page A1.]

headline: Deutsch Is Named to Lamisil Account
abstract: Deutsch Is Named To Lamisil Account.

headline: Schering Chief Executive Is Stepping Down
abstract: Schering-Plough Corp chief executive Richard J Kogan will retire 'by mutual agreement' following year of company's manufacturing problems and impending investigation into its pricing practices (S)

headline: France Is Set to Offer the U.N. A Separate Resolution on Iraq
abstract: France, in bold diplomatic challenge to United States, announces that it might formally introduce its own resolution on disarming Iraq at United Nations Security Council; French Foreign Min Dominique de Villepin emphasizes that France is willing to use draft resolution formally presented to Security Council by United States as basis for agreement among its 15 members (M)

headline: FORMER CHAIRMAN OF STOCK EXCHANGE IS BUSH'S S.E.C. PICK
abstract: Pres Bush selects William H Donaldson, former head of New York Stock Exchange and longtime family friend, to head SEC, and he also promises to nearly double agency's budget, which he earlier targeted for cuts; appointment and budget increase come after sharp criticism from lawmakers and experts that agency's turmoil has been caused by leadership crisis, White House neglect and lack of resources and staff; Donaldson's appointment is endorsed by prominent members of both parties; if confirmed by Senate, he faces panoply of significant regulatory decisions in coming months that affect every aspect of corporate governance; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Lukoil Stake Sold
abstract: Russian government sells 50 million shares, or 5.9 percent, of Lukoil, Russia's largest oil company, for $775 million on London Stock Exchange, reducing its stake in company by about half (S)

headline: Why did free diver die?: Tragic plunge to the limits
abstract: Push your limits too far in most sports and you lose. Push your limits too far in free diving, Audrey Mestre's sport, and you die.

headline: Business; Marriott Strategy Brings Savings, and Lawsuits
abstract: Some developers who use Marriott International to manage their hotels sue seeking to force hotel supply company Avendra to disclose financial data; Avendra is joint venture of Marriott and Hyatt; developers want to know about volume-discount rebates and actual prices paid for goods by Avendra to verify company's claim that it saves hotel owners 10 to 15 percent; photo (M)

headline: Goldman Names 2 to Global Banking Positions
abstract: Goldman Sachs Group names John S Weinberg and Christopher Cole to manage global investment banking along with Scott Kapnick (M)

headline: Experts Conclude That Voice On Tape Belongs to bin Laden
abstract: United States intelligence officials decide that recorded audio tape broadcast on Arab television network is genuine and contains voice of Osama bin Laden, apparently ending debate in government over whether terrorist leader survived war in Afghanistan and is alive (M)

headline: Swipe at Record Labels In Ads for Rolling Stone
abstract: Bartle Bogle Hegarty designs advertising campaign for Rolling Stone magazine, intended as in-your-face declaration of its primacy in popular-music culture and its intimacy with music fans; campaign lampoons music business executives (M)

headline: Throngs Again Demand Venezuelan Leader Quit
abstract: Hundreds of thousands of protesters march through Caracas, Venezuela, demanding that Pres Hugo Chavez leave office or agree to early elections; tensions are persisting six months after he was briefly overthrown in aftermath of similiar protests; protest leaders threaten nationwide general strike on Oct 21; last such strike led to week of chaos that brought about Chavez's temporary ouster; Chavez and his ministers have repeatedly refused to contemplate referendum on his rule until next Aug; photo (M)

headline: Japan-North Korea Talks Conclude With Deep Splits
abstract: Japan and North Korea end two days of negotiations, angrily talking past each other on issues that each side depicts as major obstacles to normalized relations; Japan's insistence on visits by immediate relatives of people kidnapped by North Korea draws strong rebuke from North Korean delegates; Tokyo says economic aid will not be forthcoming until abduction issue and concerns about North Korea's nuclear weapons program are resolved; desite deep divide, two sides claims some modest progress; agree to establish panel to discuss security issues, although it is unclear whether North Korea would agree to discuss nuclear arms at that forum (M)

headline: JUDGE UPHOLDS THE PATENT FOR PAXIL, AN ANTIDEPRESSANT
abstract: GlaxoSmithKline says US judge upheld one of its patents for Paxil, its antidepressant medicine, helping company fend off cheaper competitors for drug; Glaxo is trying to protect Paxil from lawsuits filed by Canadian competitor Apotex Inc (S)2

headline: Technology Briefing: Telecommunications
abstract: MOTOROLA WILL TAKE $500 MILLION CHARGE; GATES INCREASES STAKE IN NEXTEL; LUCENT SEEKS APPROVAL FOR REVERSE STOCK SPLIT; RIVERSTONE SHARES SOAR ON ANNOUNCEMENT OF CHINA DEAL;.

headline: São Paulo Journal; With These Outriders, the Famous Ride Happily
abstract: Sao Paulo Journal on military police unit, batedores, who slice through city's chaotic streets astride shiny scarlet-and-white Harley-Davidson motorcycles; photos (M)

headline: Bridgestone to Raise Tire Prices Up to 5%
abstract: Bridgestone/Firestone North America tire unit plans to raise prices as much as 5 percent for car and truck tires because of raw material costs (S)

headline: PIER 1 RAISES PROFIT OUTLOOK AND INCREASES DIVIDEND
abstract: Pier 1 Imports says that third-quarter profit rose more than forecast after sales last month exceeded projections; profit put at 32 to 33 cents a share (S)

headline: Hard Truths Are Avoided On Social Security
abstract: David E Rosenbaum Economic View column cautions not to believe anything said during election campaigns concerning Social Security; says politicians do not tell hard truth, that system will run out of money during most of today's workers' lifetimes; sees raising taxes or lowering benefits as only two possible outcomes; foresees no real attempts to repair Social Security until crisis is on doorstep, not on horizon; graph of depletion of system's assets (M)

headline: Miscellany
abstract: Richards Group, Dallas, and Oricom Co, Tokyo, form alliance to share clients and information (S)

headline: New Billboards Sample Radios As Cars Go By, Then Adjust
abstract: Tom Langeland, Sacramento-based entrepreneur, intends to modify electronic freeway billboard advertisements by remote control to reflect drivers' tastes; has erected 10 billboards that can display both video and text and can be programmed with changing messages and images; billboards include fledgling technology that is designed to identify radio frequencies of passers-by, use that information to determine drivers' demographic data and adjust advertising accordingly (M)

headline: 12 Americans Stage Protest Hussein Is Happy to Allow
abstract: Group of 12 Americans from Chicago-based pacifist group, Voices in Wilderness, gather in Baghdad to bring American style of protest to Saddam Hussein's Iraq; since Americans come to protest against Pres Bush and his threats of war against Iraq, Iraqi police keep well away, giving visitors as much time as they need to make their case; Kathy Kelly, 49-year-old former Chicago high school Enlgish eacher who is co-founder of Voices in Wilderness, speaks out against Bush administration and in defense of positions taken by Hussein (M)

headline: Private Sector; Dismissed and Sued, but Nothing Personal
abstract: Doron Kempel, former executive of data storage company EMC, laid off and later forced by EMC to give up top job with rival, resurfaces as chairman and chief executive of new EMC-backed data storage software company Diligent Technologies (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: General Is Suspended
abstract: A major general who told Parliament that the defense minister had ignored his warnings of a North Korean plan to attack a South Korean boat has been suspended for a month. After five South Korean sailors were killed in a North Korean attack on a Southern patrol boat in the Yellow Sea on June 29, Maj. Gen. Han Cheol Yong made his assertion about the response of the defense minister at the time, Kim Dong Shim. A defense ministry legal officer said General Han had ''failed to protect classified information and breached military discipline.'' The general said he would appeal.   Don Kirk (NYT)

headline: Venezuela Ready to License Rights to Offshore Gas
abstract: Venezuela's Pres Hugo Chavez has announced plans to start granting licenses to exploit Deltana Platform, set of offshore natural gas fields on maritime border with Trinidad and Tobago; licenses for first four blocks are expected by end of year; fifth license is to follow in 2003; $4 billion that energy companies are expected to invest in venture would be largest foreign investment in Venezuela since Chavez was elected; Chavez, facing deep recession, growing budget deficit and increasingly unstable political situation, needs licensing fees companies will bring; map (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Monaco: Trial In Billionaire's Death Starts
abstract: Trial of personal nurse Ted Maher begins in Monaco; Maher admits to setting fire which killed billionaire banker Edmond Safra; Maher's scheme to win acclaim for rescuing Safra went awry when reclusive Safra died rather than leave his estate (S)

headline: A Barn-Raising for the Internet Age
abstract: Mississippi students build 6,000 computers as part of statewide initiative to put computer in every classroom; $4.4 million grant from Mississippi Development Authority pays for components, and students receive practical experience and training, as well as some self-confidence; photos (M)

headline: Commission to Investigate Moscow Siege Is Rejected
abstract: Russia's lower house of parliament rejected two proposals today to create an independent commission to investigate the circumstances surrounding the 57-hour siege of a Moscow theater.

headline: Missiles on a Budget: Navy Meets Home Depot
abstract: Venture of Office of Naval Research and Titan Corp develops prototype of missile made from off-the-shelf commercial components as alternative to Tomahawk cruise missiles; new missile will cost $40,000 apiece, compared with $500,000 for Tomahawks (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Economy Slows
abstract: Singapore's Trade and Industry Ministry says economy unexpectedly slowed in third quarter to annual pace of 3.7 percent, down from 3.9 percent in second quarter; says industries that produce goods expanded 7.8 percent from year earlier, same pace as in second quarter; services grew 1.8 percent, more than 1.6 percent growth in previous quarter (S)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Venezuela: Opposition Sets Strike Date
abstract: The opposition coalition seeking a referendum on President Hugo Chávez announced that it would mount a nationwide general strike on Dec. 2, or earlier if conditions warrant. It would be the fourth general strike since December in the conflict between Mr. Chavéz and his opponents. The announcement was the latest setback to the talks between the government and the opposition, which are mediated by the Organization of American States.   David Gonzalez (NYT)

headline: Putin and Chinese Leader Pledge Friendship and Caution North Korea on Nuclear Arms
abstract: China and Russia call on North Korea to abandon any attempt to acquire nuclear weapons, and call on Washington to honor previous agreements with North; message comes during quick but high-profile visit to Beijing by Pres Vladimir V Putin of Russia; 13-page declaration is notable for its strong emphasis on unsettled situation on Korean peninsula; China, one of North Korea's few allies, does not want to see country collapse; its diplomats have been exasperated by North's military posturing, which it fears could destabilize region (M)

headline: Secret Deal Part of Tangle In Enron Case
abstract: Andrew S. Fastow, the former chief financial officer of Enron, will be charged in a criminal complaint as soon as tomorrow with defrauding shareholders through a secret agreement guaranteeing that Enron would shield his LJM partnership from losses, people involved in the case said yesterday.    Such an agreement involving the partnership -- one of the off-balance-sheet entities at the heart of Enron's tangled finances -- might prove to be the most explosive element in a raft of allegations that the government is expected to bring against Mr. Fastow.

headline: Operating Systems Matter
abstract: Rob Norman letter relies to David Gelerntner's Nov 7 article on 'narrative information management' promised by Microsoft

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Steel Maker's Profit Rises
abstract: South Korea's Pohang Iron and Steel posts net profit of $300 million for third quarter, nearly double its net of $165 million year earlier, on 12.1 percent increase in sales for period (S)

headline: House Panel Chides ImClone Over Conduct Of Its Founder
abstract: ImClone Systems' directors acknowledge that former chief executive Samuel D Waksal was allowed to remain at company even after board learned of two incidents in which he may have forged signatures, once in 1986; acknowledgments come in hearing before House Energy and Commerce Committee subcommittee, whose members harshly criticize ImClone's board for not firing or disciplining Waksal, despite apparent forgeries and personal spending of corporate funds that caused board to restrict Waksal's use of corporate credit cards; ImClone chairman Robert F Goldhammer and Paul B Kopperl, chairman of board's audit committee, testify that board learned of possible forgery in early February and asked outside lawyer to investigate; investigation was not completed before Waksal was asked to resign; committee says Waksal also appears to have forged signature of ImClone's general counsel John B Landes on stock certificate that he transferred to someone else for $90,000 in 1986, previously unreported incident; photo (M)

headline: Account Changes
abstract: Accounts  Four European divisions of Sony consolidated the media planning and buying duties on their accounts at the London office of OMD, part of the Omnicom Group. They are Sony Europe, Berlin; Sony Music Entertainment Europe, London; Columbia TriStar Film Distributors International, London; and Columbia TriStar Home Entertainment, London. Advertising Age estimated that the divisions spent $500 million a year on European advertising. The media duties had been divided between offices of OMD, which handled assignments for Sony Europe and much of Sony Music, and the Zenith Optimedia Group, which handled assignments for the Columbia units. Zenith is owned by the Publicis Groupe and by the Cordiant Communications Group.  American Standard Cos., Piscataway, N.J., consolidated the media planning and buying for the accounts of its American brands of air-conditioning, bath and kitchen products by awarding the combined assignment to Initiative Media North America, New York. Spending was estimated at $10 million. The Richards Group, Dallas, had handled media duties for air-conditioning products, and Carmichael Lynch, Minneapolis, had handled media duties for the other products. Carmichael Lynch and Foote, Cone & Belding, New York, handle creative duties for American Standard. Initiative Media, Carmichael Lynch and Foote, Cone are part of the Interpublic Group of Companies. People  Rick Bendel, regional chairman for the British and Nordic region operations of Publicis Worldwide, part of Publicis Groupe, will fill the new post of chief operating officer. He will work with Maurice Lévy, chairman and chief executive at Publicis Worldwide and Publicis. Mr. Bendel, now based in London, will divide his time between London and Paris, where Publicis is based. Miscellany  Will Vinton Studios, Portland, Ore., spun off Character, a consulting company focused on developing and revitalizing brand characters in advertising campaigns. David

headline: Iran Pardons Cleric Who Was Jailed for Insulting Islam
abstract: Iran's supreme religious leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei pardons Abdullah Nouri, veteran cleric who three years ago had been jailed on charges of insulting Islam; Nouri was considered leading reformer at time of his arrest (S)

headline: New Charges Against AOL Made in Suit On Homestore
abstract: California State Teachers' Retirement System suit against online real estate company Homestore.com contains new accusations of financial fraud at AOL Time Warner, including detailed descriptions of conversations among senior executives who allegedly planned to inflate revenue improperly; new complaint portrays former AOL Time Warner executives David M Colburn and Eric Keller as conspiring with their Homestore counterparts to overstate companies' revenues; both companies acknowledge accounting problems (M)

headline: Bush Aides Back Effort for U.N. Denunciation of North Korea
abstract: Pres Bush's top national security advisers reportedly decide to back effort by International Atomic Energy Agency to ask UN Security Council to declare North Korea in violation of Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty and other agreements; administration officials are trying to cast issue as international one rather than confrontation between North Korea and US (M)

headline: DELIA'S, A CLOTHING RETAILER, HIRES ADVISORY FIRM
abstract: Delia's Corp, retailer of clothing and accessories for teenagers and young women, hires Peter J Solomon Co as adviser as company considers alternatives including sale (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: In Iraqi's Words: White House Seems to Be Caught in 'Hysteria of War'
abstract: Excerpts from speech by Amb Mohammed Aldouri of Iraq to United Nations Security Council; photo (M)

headline: Theater Founders Are Charged With Fraud
abstract: Royal Canadian Mounted Police charge Livent Inc founders Garth H Drabinsky and Myron I Gottlieb with defrauding investors and creditors of $325 million; former Livent executives Gordon Eckstein and Robert Topol are charged with taking part in schemes to defraud investors and creditors; police say four men falsified financial statements for nine years in effort to misrepresent financial health of company; Drabinsky, through his lawyer Edward Greenspan, reiterates his innocence; Greenspan says Drabinsky will vigorously defend himself (M)

headline: Stocks Dip From Early Rally, but Still Close Higher
abstract: Stocks rose today, helped by a surge in Microsoft and the hope for an interest-rate cut from the Federal Reserve on Wednesday.

headline: A Nation That Exports Oil, Herring and Peace
abstract: Article on Norway's history as broker of peace; diplomats and government officials note country has no colonial past, has no grand designs on other countries, does not engender suspicion, has no serious alliances, has financed much humanitarian work, is remote and is relatively untroubled; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing: Asia
abstract: TAIWAN: Extra Cargo Flights; THAILAND: Bank Earnings Increase; JAPAN: Paper Profit For Retailer; MALAYSIA: Bonuses Challenged; SOUTH KOREA: Profit For Samsung;.

headline: Cancer Vaccine Test Has Promising Result
abstract: Clinical trial of cancer vaccine developed by Antigenics demonstrates virtual elimination of tumors in 2 of 28 patients with advanced melanoma; vaccine, known as HSPPC-96, showed little toxicity; cancer vaccines do not prevent disease but rather harness patient's own immune system to fight disease (M)

headline: Disclosing Funds' Votes
abstract: Vanguard Group founder John C Bogle backs Securities and Exchange Commission proposal to require mutual funds to disclose their proxy votes, letter to SEC; current Vanguard management and many other large investment companies oppose disclosure (S)

headline: Web Offers Help To Worried Fliers
abstract: Some Web sites offering information on schedules and news about United Airlines in wake of its bankruptcy filing and other airlines noted (S)

headline: U.S. IS PRESSURING INSPECTORS IN IRAQ TO AID DEFECTIONS
abstract: Bush administration pressures Hans Blix and his UN inspection teams to identify key Iraqi weapons scientists and spirit them out of country so they can be offered asylum in exchange for disclosing where Saddam Hussein is hiding weapons of mass destruction; Condoleezza Rice meets with Blix in New York to press issue; US offers to set up witness protection program; private tips and defectors have contributed to US intelligence on secret Iraqi programs, but it is unclear how much US is sharing with UN; UN officials, uneasy with soliciting or demanding defections, is looking for way to conduct private interviews with Iraqi scientists inside country; Blix reportedly resists forcing Iraqi scientists to take life-threatening step of leaving for interrogation (M)

headline: How Politics and Rivalries Fed Suspicions of a Meeting
abstract: A year after reports of a meeting came to light between Mohamed Atta and an Iraqi intelligence officer, the story behind the story of their supposed meeting in Prague is perhaps more interesting.

headline: Some Tentative First Steps Toward Universal Health Care
abstract: Insurance execs across nation, worried that growing number of uninsured patients will undermine nation's health care system, are pressing for new steps toward universal health care; many health plans are developing or offering insurance with lower premiums and slimmer coverage to attract customers who cannot afford more comprehensive policies; some plans proposed by Blue Cross Blue Shield of Montana, Blue Shield of California and UnitedHealth Group discussed; Bruce G Bodaken, chief exec of Blue Shield of California, calls for statewide universal health care system, to be financed by employers, individuals and a new tax; photos of Bodaken and Dr William McGuire of UnitedHealth (M)

headline: Pentagon Says It Will Give Journalists Access to Frontline War Units
abstract: US Defense Department, which has battled reporters for decades over access to frontline troops during combat operations, pledges to 'embed' hundreds of correspondents, photographers and video crew members with troops if US attacks Iraq; organizes, for first time, 'media boot camps' to prepare journalists to report on troops; photos (M)

headline: Technology Briefing: Software
abstract: JDA CUTS JOBS AND CLOSES SOME OFFICES; SYNOPSYS SHARES SOAR AFTER PROFIT BEATS FORECASTS;.

headline: Oh So Quietly, Fed Ponders What Follows Greenspan
abstract: Ben S Bernanke, Federal Reserve governor, raises question of how Federal Reserve will operate when Alan Greenspan is no longer chairman, specifically whether it should adopt numerical target for inflation to replace its vaguely defined goal of price stability; is one of foremost proponents of approach, known as inflation targeting; plan has many advantages, including making central bank more accountable for its performance and erasing any doubts financial markets might have about Fed's commitment to keeping inflation under control; most attractive selling point is that it could be perceived as way to continue Greenspan's policies; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Carmaker In Debt Deal
abstract: Worï

headline: Qaeda Meeting in Thailand Reportedly Plotted Attacks on Tourists
abstract: Western officials say Al Qaeda operatives met in Thailand and discussed plans to attack bars, nightclubs and tourist resorts in region, months before October bombing in Bali; say group was led by senior lieutenant of Osama bin Laden and included Qaeda explosives expert, Riadun Isamuddin (Hambali), who was later arrested and told US interrogators of meeting; officials now believe Bali nightclub attack was hatched during January meeting; Bangkok itself is teeming city where terrorists can easily hibernate, government asks few questions and intelligence agencies are inexperienced and disorganized; photos (M)

headline: E-Commerce Report; Complications with cookies arise over privacy policies that don't mesh.
abstract: Confusion and complications with cookies and pop-up ads surround use of latest Microsoft Web browser, Internet Explorer version 6.0; industry experts say users are getting more privacy protection but are also getting more pop-up ads and less personalized service than in past; photo (M)

headline: Saved by U.S., Kuwait Now Shows Mixed Feelings
abstract: Many Kuwaitis now have mixed feelings about United States, even though US rescued Kuwait from Iraqi domination just over 11 years ago; anti-American sentiment is growing among Kuwait's 800,000 people, with people unhappy with US military presence there; ambivalence is being fed by growing fundamentalist movement, which bridles at American presence, and by US support of Israel, which many Muslims consider American puppet; combination of these forces is what apparently drove two young Kuwaiti men to suicidal attack this week that killed one American marine and wounded another (M)

headline: S.&P. Cuts Its Rating Of Ford Debt To Record Low
abstract: Standard & Poor's cuts Ford Motor long-term debt rating to lowest level ever, citing competitive pressures that it fears will hinder company's restructuring and comeback plans; says outlook for Ford remains 'negative,' designation that dismays analysts more than debt downgrade; Ford executives, however, promise $7 billion annual operating profit by 2005; new long-term debt rating is two steps above junk status (M)

headline: Deutsch Is Named To Lamisil Account
abstract: Novartis Pharmaceuticals names Deutsch to handle advertising account of Lamisil, drug for toenail fungus; billings estimated at $25 million; account had been handled by Alchemy (S)

headline: A New Path on Insurance
abstract: Dr Jerry Frankel letter comments on Oct 6 article about fewer choices and greater costs of health insurance plans currently being offered to employees

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Czech Republic: Plot To Darken NATO Summit
abstract: Five Czech Republic high school and university students are arrested for plan to cut electricity to NATO summit in Prague; group has no apparent connection to terrorist organizations (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Asbestos Concern
abstract: Shares of Royal and Sun Alliance, Britain's second-largest insurer, fell more than 10 percent, to £1.04 ($1.63), on fears it could be liable for millions of pounds in asbestos-related claims. Turner & Newall, a British engineering firm that is in administration, which is similar to bankruptcy proceedings, is suing Royal and Sun on behalf of former employees who have suffered asbestos-related illnesses. Royal and Sun provided employer liability coverage to Turner & Newall. Karen Donhue, a spokeswoman for Royal and Sun, said the case had no merit. Dozens of firms are being sued for asbestos-related liabilities, including ABB, the giant Swiss industrial company. For insurers like Royal and Sun, the potential for liabilities comes as a downturn in world stock markets has wiped out reserves and hurt profits.   Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

headline: Taiwan Imports a Made-in-U.S. Political Issue: Central Park
abstract: Taiwan mayoral candidate Lee Ying-yuan proposes to raze downtown airport for domestic flights and create replica of New York's Central Park, complete with ring of luxury apartment buildings; incumbent Ma Ying-jeou wants to use airport for nonstop fights to Shanghai, which would make day trips to mainland possible (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Legal Dispute Over Cegetel
abstract: Vivendi Universal is suing Vodafone Group in attempt to gain more time to put together counterbid for French phone company Cegetal; Vodafone offered to buy 85 percent of Cegetel it did not already own for 13.1 billion euros ($12.8 billion); offer includes stakes held by BT Group, SBC Communications and Vivendi; Vivendi has option of counterbidding and can supersede Vodafone's offer for BT or SBC stakes; Vodafone has given Vivendi deadline of Nov 10 to make counteroffer; Vivendi is arguing that deadline violates part of Cegetel shareholder agreement, which stipulates that any offer for Cegetel must be accompanied by 30-day grace period for due diligence; Vodafone says rule does not apply to existing shareholders (S)

headline: Deal to Sell Burger King Collapses
abstract: Planned $2.26 billion sale of Burger King is scuttled after its parent Diageo PLC acknowledges that group of financiers--Texas Pacific Group, Goldman Sachs & Co and Bain Capital--that had agreed to acquire it backs out of deal; Warren E Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway is taking serious look at possible offer; photo (M)

headline: Why These Drivers Steer Clear of S.U.V.'s
abstract: Four experts on motor vehicle safety give their assessments of which cars are safe and tell which they've chosen for themselves; photo (M)

headline: The Week's Economic Events
abstract: MONDAYConsumer BorrowingAug.

headline: In Brazil Runoff, the Straggler Labors On Against Huge Odds
abstract: Polls indicate that Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva, presidential candidate of Brazil's leftist Workers' Party, will easily defeat Jose Serra of centrist Brazilian Social Democratic Party in Oct 27 runoff election; Serra soldiers on, but his followers are growing more discouraged, and fence-sitters are flocking to da Silva (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Officials React To Protest
abstract: Hong Kong officials estimate 60,000 people took part in march protesting new antisedition legislation; march prompted leaders to give consideration to popular view (S)

headline: Saudis Brush Aside Criticism Of Record Against Terrorism
abstract: Saudi Arabia brushes aside criticism of its efforts to fight terrorism, claiming that it has also been major target of Al Qaeda and that cooperation with US to stem Islamic extremism is unappreciated; senior adviser Adel al-Jubeir, in Washington, charges Americans are consumed by anti-Saudi sentiment that borders on hate; releases report on freezing of 33 bank accounts containing $5.5 million, requiring all Saudi charities to undergo audits and creating financial intelligence unit to investigate money-laundering; report says Saudi Arabia has questioned more than 2,000 people and detained about 100 others on suspicion of aiding terrorists; Jubeir argues that Osama bin Laden purposely used 15 Saudis in Sept 11 attacks to drive wedge between two countries; Sec Colin Powell lauds Saudi efforts but sees more steps need to control money flow; Sen Richard Shelby says Saudis are in denial, hoping issue will go away; he is taking over as Banking Committee chairman and will investigate Saudi funding of terrorists (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Bank Executive Named
abstract: Citing the evolving requirements of corporate leadership, the TD Bank Financial Group named John M. Thompson as its chairman, separating the jobs of chairman and chief executive. Mr. Thompson recently retired as vice chairman of I.B.M. He succeeds A. Charles Baillie, who stepped down as chief executive yesterday and will give up the chairman's post in April. W. Edmund Clark was earlier named the next chief executive. TD is the second of Canada's big five banks, after Royal Bank of Canada, to separate the jobs of chairman and chief executive.   Bernard Simon (NYT)

headline: ABB Proposes a Settlement For All Asbestos Lawsuits
abstract: Seeking to put behind it the swelling asbestos-liability problems that have pummeled its stock price, the Swiss heavy-machinery maker ABB said today that it was negotiating with claimants over a settlement that would pay them up to $1.1 billion.    Most of the money would come from an American subsidiary, Combustion Engineering, which would file a prepackaged Chapter 11 bankruptcy reorganization plan that has been approved by most creditors in advance.

headline: Beijing Says Chinese Muslims Are Among Detainees in Cuba
abstract: Chinese Deputy Prime Min Qian Qichen says US is holding more than dozen Uighur Muslims from western China, seized in Afghanistan, at its terrorist detention center at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba (S)

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: Popular Film Is Blocked
abstract: Islamic Republic News Agency reports halt in screening of popular movie The Women's Prison in several Iranian cities; influential clerics oppose film, which gives gritty insight into prison life and confronts several taboo subjects, including suicide (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Netro Gets Offer From Wyndcrest
abstract: Netro Corp, money-losing maker of equipment for high-speed Internet access, receives $158.5 million acquisition offer from Wyndcrest Holdings; Netro shares rise 75 cents, to $2.73; Wyndcrest would pay about $4.15 a share (S)

headline: Persistent Drop in Fertility Reshapes Europe's Future
abstract: Fertility rates in many European countries have plummeted over last decades, shifting one-child families close to statistical norm; World Health Orgn figures show Europe to be continent with lowest fertility rate; no West European country has total fertility rate of 2.1--marker that demographers say means exact replenishment of population; in United States rate is 2.0, which demographers attribute to greater immigration; trend in Europe has been evident for many years, but its slow-building consequences are now coming into starker relief; more West European countries are taking new steps to address specter of sharply winnowed and less competitive work forces, surfeits of retirees and pension systems that will need to be cut back deeply; fertility rates are starkest in East European countries, but trend hit Western Europe earlier, and has had more time to produce hand-wringing and soul-searching; among reasons for trend are that people are studying longer and marrying later, that contraception and abortion are readily available, that divorce is more common and that would-be parents' attachments to leisure time, conveniences and indulgences do not easily accommodate multiple children--or sometimes, any children at all; photo; graphs (L)

headline: Northrop Says Sales Will Double by 2005
abstract: The Northrop Grumman Corporation expects annual sales to more than double, to $30 billion, by 2005, helped by last week's purchase of the satellite maker TRW.    Northrop, one of the nation's largest military contractors, forecast sales of $25 billion to $26 billion in 2003 and growth of at least 10 percent in 2004 and 2005, the chief executive, Kent Kresa, told a news conference yesterday after closing the $10.7 billion TRW acquisition.

headline: A Mexican Daily's Downfall
abstract: Excelsior, once prominent newspaper of Mexico, is bought by group of unidentified American and Canadian investors for $150 million; 25 years ago rulers of Institutional Revolutionary Party secretly bought newspaper's loyalty and over time drained it of independence; when Pres Vicente Fox's election ended Institutional Revolutionary Party's control, under-the-table subsidies and payoffs ended, and newspaper quickly fell into near bankruptcy (M)

headline: American Ecology Set to Close a Plant
abstract: American Ecology Corp, which runs hazardous-waste plants, expects to lay off about 20 percent of its work force after closing Tennessee plant that processes radioactive material; 63 jobs will be eliminated at Oak Ridge plant, which reduces levels of radioactivity in waste from nuclear plants, hospitals and research institutions (S)

headline: Adelphia Sues Its Former Accountants, Citing Negligence
abstract: Adelphia Communications sues its former accountants Deloitte & Touche, accusing it of 'professional negligence, breach of conduct, fraud and other wrongful conduct'; argues that Deloitte either knew of wrongdoings at company and failed to disclose them or was negligent in its duty because it did not know about them; Deloitte contends that wrongdoing within company was meant to deceive its accountants as well as the public (M)

headline: BNP to Buy France's Stake in Bank for $2.2 Billion
abstract: BNP Paribas will pay 2.2 billion euros ($2.2 billion) to buy French government's 10.9 percent stake in Credit Lyonnaise, France's sixth-largest bank; analysts say hastily arranged auction could trigger bidding war for Credit Lyonnais; other interested parties include Credit Agricole, Society Generale and AGF, subsidiary of Allianz, all of which already own shares in Credit Lyonnais; price BNP has agreed to is 49 percent premium over closing price of Credit Lyonnais stock on Nov 22 (M)

headline: New Test Site From Google Focuses on Products for Sale
abstract: Internet search engine Google enters online shopping domain with test site Froogle that focuses on products for sale (M)

headline: After Oil Spill, Spain and France Impose Strict Tanker Inspections
abstract: Spanish Prime Min Jose Maria Aznar and French Pres Jacques Chirac, spurred by oil spill from tanker Prestige, set rigourous inspection standards for older single-hulled tankers carrying oil or tar through waters their nations control; empower maritime authorities to inspect ships up to 200 miles out to sea and to expel those not considered seaworthy from 200-mile zone (M)

headline: U.S. Rejects United Airlines Bid for Loan Guarantee
abstract: A federal panel rejected United Airlines' plea for $1.8 billion in loan guarantees this evening, all but ensuring that United will have to seek bankruptcy protection.

headline: Offering an Incentive to Disarm
abstract: United States Amb to Japan Howard H Baker Jr says Washington could respond with surprising speed to engage with North Korea if that country takes verifiable steps to dismantle its nuclear weapons program; says Pres Bush has made clear that he does not want conflict with North Korea (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Comsat Buys Latin American Assets From Lockheed
abstract: Comsat International Holdings is expected to announce it has completed acquisition of telecommunications assets in several Latin American countries from Lockheed Martin; will take 81 percent control of satellite and fiber optic operations that provide communications services to companies in six nations, including Brazil, Argentina and Colombia; financial terms undisclosed (S)

headline: Holmes Announces U.S. Plant Closings
abstract: Holmes Group, maker of cooking equipment and accessories, will close all of its United States manufacturing operations and lay off at least 800 workers by end of Jan; will shut down other US facilities during first half of 2003 and expand in Asia (S)

headline: Making Robots, With Dreams of Henry Ford
abstract: IRobot Corp, founded by Helen Greiner, Colin Angle and Rodney Brooks, develops robots for variety of uses, ranging from household chores to military applications; successes and range of applications cited; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Telecom Offer Turned Down
abstract: Japan's NTT DoCoMo Inc rejects request by KPN Mobile to invest more money in Dtuch mobile phone carrier; DoCoMo's stake in KPN will fall to 2.2 percent from 15 percent (S)

headline: People and Accounts of Note
abstract: Popular Science Properties, New York, which publishes Popular Science magazine, named Hanft Byrne Raboy & Partners, New York, as agency of record, to create consumer and trade campaigns and advise on strategic marketing. Billings were not disclosed. Popular Science is part of Time4Media, a division of Time Inc., part of AOL Time Warner.

headline: U.S. Oil Still Pours From a Mideast Barrel
abstract: Western oil companies are showing no intentions of veering away from Middle East; Bush administration has made broadening sources of America's oil supplies touchstone of its energy and foreign policies, but officials concede that progress has been slow; Energy Sec Spencer Abraham says administration's emphasis on increasing and diversifying global energy supplies is having positive impact on investment decisions, but impact is difficult to quantify; administration has encouraged efforts to import more Russian crude oil to US and announced plans to open new consulate in oil-rich Equatorial Guinea; proportion of US oil imports flowing from Middle East remains high, about 24 percent, down from levels during oil crises of 1970's, but up by third over last few years; oil executives say they have not changed their plans for where to seek out, produce and purchase oil; map; chart; photo (M)

headline: C.I.A. Hunts Iraq Tie to Soviet Smallpox
abstract: CIA investigates informant's accusation that Iraq obtained particularly virulent strain of smallpox from Russian scientist; American officials say several American scientists were told in August that Iraq might have obtained mysterious strain from Nelja N Maltseva, virologist who worked for more than 30 years at Research Institute for Viral Preparations in Moscow before her death two years ago; photo (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: Fidelity Fund Is Reopening
abstract: Fidelity Investments will reopen Fidelity Low-Priced Stock Fund to new investors after six months' closure (S)

headline: Erroneous Order for Big Sales Briefly Stirs Up the Big Board
abstract: Errant order to sell $4 billion in stocks briefly roils market, providing another warning of how clerical error can produce huge risks; New York Stock Exchange says Bear, Stearns intended to place order to sell $4 million worth of stocks in Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, but instead asked to sell $4 billion; orders were canceled within minutes, but not before $622 million in stock had been sold; exchange says Bear, Stearns assured it that risk from executed orders had been substantially hedged, but it is unclear how Bear, Stearns hedged its exposure (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Embattled S.E.C. Chairman Resigns Under Pressure  Harvey L. Pitt, the embattled chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission who has been under fire for a number of missteps, resigned last evening, a spokeswoman for the agency said. The timing of Mr. Pitt's resignation, tendered just as politicians and Americans from coast to coast were following election results, seemed likely to be viewed as no coincidence.    Mr. Pitt had come under heavy fire for not informing S.E.C. commissioners and the White House that the new chairman of an accounting oversight board, William H. Webster, had headed the audit committee of a company facing accusations of fraud. [Page A1.]

headline: Credit Suisse Sets a Record With Its Loss of $1.4 Billion
abstract: Credit Suisse sets record for biggest quarterly loss in Swiss corporate history, 2.1 billion francs ($1.44 billion); says 2002 dividend will likely be 10 centimes (7 cents) a share, down from 2 francs ($1.37) in 2001; promises profit in all divisions in 2003; main culprit for dismal results is Winterthur insurance subsidiary, which lost 1.4 billion Swiss francs ($960 million) in third quarter, mainly on falling value of its investments; Winterthur recruits former Dresdner Bank executive Leonhard Fischer to become chief executive and improve its investment performance; Credit Suisse First Boston, investment bank unit, has net operating loss of 426 million francs ($292 million); signs of weakness appear in Credit Suisse's traditionally strong private banking and investment management divisions; parent company's two co-chief executives, John Mack and Oswald J Grubel, divide their time between running parent company and managing their respective divisions to reverse group's bleak financial circumstances (M)

headline: British Bank Sells Stock in Hong Kong
abstract: Standard Chartered started the sale of about $355 million of new shares in Hong Kong today.

headline: American Express Third-Quarter Earnings More Than Double
abstract: American Express Co reports third-quarter earnings more than dbouled from year earlier; earings rose to $687 million from $298 million; revenue totaled $5.9 billion, up 3 percent from $5.7 billion; chief executive Kenneth I Chenault comments (M)

headline: Technology Briefing: Hardware
abstract: LEXMARK POSTS 29% INCREASE IN INCOME; TEXAS INSTRUMENTS REPORTS NET INCOME; SUPERCOMPUTER TO USE ADVANCED MICRO CHIPS;.

headline: In the Home, a Tool Kit For a Wireless Network
abstract: David Pogue State of the Art column examines wireless computer networking for home; describes installation procedure for technology known as Wi-Fi; offers ratings and prices of gear by LinkSys, NetGear and Microsoft; drawing; photos (M)

headline: RIBAPHARM EXECUTIVES THREATEN TO RESIGN OVER ICN ISSUE
abstract: ribapharm executives

headline: Groups Outline Plans for Governing a Post-Hussein Iraq
abstract: Saddam Hussein's Iraqi enemies meet in London and issue nearly unified call for democratic, federal, parliamentary government to replace him and demand that US allow Iraqis to take immediate control of country if Hussein is driven from power; remain deeply divided, and constellation of six major groups that have long dominated opposition is left largely unchanged (M)

headline: Unwrap the Gift. Discard the Directions. Dial a Geek.
abstract: Shiloh Cray-Baker, founder of 888 Geek Help, telephone support company, expects banner day on Christmas after gifts are unwrapped and perplexed recipients reach frustration level; other similar services noted (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Qualcomm Plans Venture With China Unicom
abstract: Qualcomm plans joint venture with China Unicom to provide technical support and training for Qualcomm's wireless technology; will train Chinese application developers in use of standard that gives users ability to download applications onto their mobile devices via Internet (S)

headline: Australian Bank Shares Fall on News of Slower Profit Growth
abstract: The news from Australian banks has been so good for so long that a forecast of merely somewhat slower profit growth was greeted yesterday like a towering thundercloud.    At the annual meeting yesterday of the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, the country's second-largest lender, the chairman, John T. Ralph, told shareholders that slumping stock markets were battering the bottom line and that they should expect only modest profit growth this fiscal year.

headline: Flying Solo, in the Extreme
abstract: Unmanned drone aircraft, known as unpiloted aerial vehicles (UAV's), are being used for growing numer of tasks, civilian as well as military; FAA has no standard guidelines for use of drones, so groups that want to operate them must wait months for waivers that permit only narrowest of flight plans; photos (M)

headline: Mutual Funds Report; Investors With a Cause Hold Their Own
abstract: 'Socially responsible' mutual funds, which try to avoid investing in companies involved in tobacco, alcohol and gambling, perform in 2002 about same as other domestic mutual funds; photo; graph (M)

headline: Opposition Party Makes Strong Showing in Peru Election
abstract: Voters in Peru chose main opposition party and host of independents over governing party in electing 25 new regional government bodies intended to decentralize country; results widely viewed as vote of no confidence in Pres Alejandro Toledo's 16-month-old government, which took office with broad support but has suffered from political disarray and image problems generated by Toledo's personal behavior; political experts say big winner is Alan Garcia, former president and Toledo's most vocal adversary (M)

headline: Behind a Lender's Crash, Bravado and Risk
abstract: National Century Financial Enterprises, which has filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, and its former chairman, Lance K Poulsen, have history of court cases alleging fraud; company's business was to provide cash to hospital and home-health-care companies in exchange for rights to money due them from slow-paying insurance companies and to package those receivables into collateral for highly rated bonds that were then sold to investors, who received interest derived from insurance payments; Credit Suisse First Boston, bonds' underwriter, alleges massive fraud and will take $214 million write-down on $258 million of National Century bonds its owns; at least five National Century client companies are forced to file their own Chapter 11 petitions, and others are scrambling to find alternative financing; holders of $3.35 billion in National Century bonds, now defunct, are fighting for restitution in court; photos (M)

headline: Promotion at Times
abstract: New York Times names Lydia I Reynolds vice president for strateÿ

headline: So Much for the Plan To Scrap Old Weapons
abstract: $378 billion military budget Defense Sec Donald Rumsfeld will deliver to Pres Bush, trumpeted earlier as new strategic vision that would replace cold-war weapons systems with new, lighter and more lethal fighting forces, will continue to fund traditional weapons systems; military contractors, united with allies in Pentagon and Congress, succeeded in saving armaments that many military experts believe should be scrapped as obsolete; nearly every weapons system Bush administration promised to eliminate in name of modernization will continue to be funded; revenue streams of Lockheed Martin, Northrop Grumman, General Dynamics and dozens of other arms makers appear guaranteed for many years; big military contractors are among Washington's largest lobbyists; many decision makers in Pentagon worked for military suppliers before taking their current government posts; photos; graph of lobbyist spending; table of United States military leaders' former industry ties (M)

headline: One Dead, 3 Hurt as Bomber Attacks Afghan Security Site
abstract: Suicide bomber blows self up at entrance to headquarters of German contingent in international security force, Kabul, Afghanistan, killing self and Afghan interpreter and injuring three others; attack is second in 48 hours against foreign troops in Kabul, raising concerns about new campaign against international force (M)

headline: COLGATE REPORTS PROFIT INCREASE AND 3 PROMOTIONS
abstract: Colgate-Palmolive reports 12 percent increase in quarterly profit and fastest rise in sales in five years; net income climbed to $330.7 million from $296.2 million; sales increased 3.3 percent, to $2.38 billion; promotes Lois D Juliber, Javier G Teruel and Ian M Cook in advance of eventual retirement of chairman Reuben Mark (S)

headline: DANA TO CLOSE AN INDIANA PLANT AND CUT SOME JOBS
abstract: Dana Corp will close Indiana foundry that makes truck engine component in 2003 and eliminate most of plant's 210 jobs (S)

headline: Fugitive Muslim Cleric, an Outspoken Supporter of Al Qaeda, Is Arrested in London
abstract: British authorities are reported to have arrested fugitive Islamic cleric known as Abu Qatada, wanted in United States as an emissary of Osama bin Laden and labeled by British legislator 'some sort of Muslim Scarlet Pimpernel'; arrest of Abu Qatada, said to have taken place in armed raid in South London housing project, is most high-profile of Britain's efforts to uncover bin Laden's suspected network of support among radical Muslims in Britain; Abu Qatada, 42-year-old Jordanian of Palestinian descent, is only one of several outspoken imans who have voiced support for bin Laden, but he is depicted by terrorism most influential; he has been identified in court testimony in United States as member of Al Qaeda (M)

headline: Author Charged for Islam Remark Is Acquitted
abstract: Paris court acquits French novelist Michel Houellebecq of charges of inciting racial hatred for calling Islam 'the most stupid religion'; public prosecutor recommended dropping case, which was brought by three Muslim groups and human rights league; Houellebecq, who lives in Ireland, is not present; photo (S)

headline: E-Mail Slips to the Bottom of City Hall's In Box
abstract: Survey finds that most mayors and city council members give more weight to opinions voiced by constituents in meetings, letters and telephone calls than to those communicated via e-mail (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: India: Request To Portugal To Yield Bomb Suspect
abstract: India reportedly plans to ask Portugal to extradite Abu Salem, wanted for alleged involvement in 1993 bombings that killed 260 people in Bombay (S)

headline: North Korea Urges U.S. to Join Nonagression Pact
abstract: North Korea called today for the United States to negotiate a nonaggression pact between the two countries, calling it the only way to avoid a war.

headline: U.S. Issues Warning To Foes in Arms Plan
abstract: The Bush administration published a new strategy on combatting weapons of mass destruction that included a statement that is clearly directed at potential opponents like Iraq. The United States is prepared to ''respond with all our options'' if such weapons are used against American troops or allies.    The warning was contained in an unclassified version of a new presidential document that outlines the administration's approach to countering and deterring the use of chemical, biological and nuclear weapons. It underscores a longstanding American policy, but officials acknowledged that it bears a resemblance to a private warning sent to Saddam Hussein before the Persian Gulf war.

headline: Partners Abroad Are Wary but Are Ready to Help
abstract: Partners Abroa

headline: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Broadcom Buys Patents From Unova
abstract: Broadcom, biggest maker of semiconductors used in cable modems, buys about 150 patents and patent applications from Unova for $24 million in cash (S)

headline: Colby & Partners Adds Part of D'Arcy
abstract: Colby & Partners in Los Angeles, part of Dentsu, agrees in principle to absorb much of Los Angeles office of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, part of Publicis Groupe (S)

headline: IN COST-CUTTING MOVE, BANK OF AMERICA TO TRIM WORKERS
abstract: in cost-cutting move, bank of america to trim workers**Bank of America Corp plans to lay off 900 technology and operations workers by end of year to cut costs; is trying to reduce expenses by $1 billion a year (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: The Hague: New Indictments In Bosnia Massacre
abstract: Drago Nikolic, Vujadin Popovic and Ljubisa Beara are charged with genocide in Bosnian Serb Army massacre of 7,000 Muslims at Srebrenica in 1995 (S)

headline: This year, marketers are trying to take the boo out of Halloween.
abstract: Many marketers and advertisere are emphasizing fund instead of fright in promotions for Halloween for second consecutive years; some advertising campaigns noted; photo (M)

headline: From Belgian Jail, Man Brags About His Plot to Bomb Air Base
abstract: Nizar Trabelsi, Tunisian man being held in Belgium on charges of involvement in organized crime and illegal possession of firearms, calls radio station from prison and gives interview in which he boasts of plot to bomb Kleine Brogel air base in northeastern Belgium, which is believed to house American nuclear weapons; denies testimony of Jamal Beghal, another suspect now detained in France who has admitted to involvement in plot to bomb American Embassy in Paris and named Trabelsi as planned suicide bomber; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Bank Lowers Outlook
abstract: Bank of Japan lowers its view of economy for first time in 11 months because of growing concerns about global growth and slowing output in Japan; says economy over all has stabilized, but risks to recovery are rising (S)

headline: Kabul to Send Team to Check on Afghans Held at Guantánamo
abstract: Pres Hamid Karzai says he will send delegation to American naval base in Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, to check conditions under which Afghans are being held there in indefinite detention; makes announcement after meeting with three Afghan men just freed from Guantanamo, who say they are innocent and were wrongly detained for months (M)

headline: Labor Party in Israel Names Former General as Its Leader
abstract: The Labor Party chose as its standard-bearer Amram Mitzna, who campaigned on immediate peace negotiations.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: STERICYCLE INC., Lake Forest, Ill., a provider of medical waste services, said it would acquire rival Micro-Med Industries. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: What Mature Gamers Need.

headline: Networking for the Long Term
abstract: Robert Half Management Resources says people should continue networking while they are employed in order to improve their job prospects in case of future unemployment; offers some tips (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: India: Stalemate In Kashmir
abstract: Today is deadline for recently elected rival leaders in Jammu and Kashmir, India,to choose state's chief minister; failure to meet deadline could result in State's Gov assuming power (S)

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Egypt: Citizenship Restored To Child Of Israeli
abstract: Egyptian Interior Ministry drops objection to citizenship request of nine-year-old girl with Egyptian father and Israeli mother; although law permitted her full citizenship, request was initially denied because children of Israelis are considered national threat to Egypt (S)

headline: Peruvian Leader's Party Fears Setback in Regional Voting
abstract: Peru Possible, party of Pres Alejandro Toledo, is expected to suffer stinging setback in nationwide elections intended to decentralize Peru's government with creation of 25 new government bodies; Toledo plays down his troubles, explaining that his government has had difficult task of solidifying democracy while satisfying needs during his 16 months in power; latest poll shows his approval rating at 23 percent, up from 11 percent earlier this year; photo; map (M)

headline: Calpers to Reveal Investment Returns
abstract: California Public Employees' Retirement System agrees to disclose returns on its private equity investments, step toward greater openness in evaluating financial performance of leveraged buyout and venture funds (S)

headline: Tenet Faces Agency Audit Of Payments For Medicare
abstract: Department of Health and Human Services plans to conduct comprehensive review of Medicare reimbursements to Tenet Healthcare, focusing on payments for cases that are unusually costly and therefore qualify for special reimbursement; company expresses confidence that federal audit will find its hospitals obey all rules; photo (M)

headline: Hussein, Cranking Up War of Words, Denounces U.S. on Documents
abstract: Angry Iraqi statements, including one by Pres Saddam Hussein, indicate Iraq plans to go toe-to-toe with Bush administration in war of words over its alleged weapons; Iraq scores American maneuvering to gain quick access to Iraqi arms declaration; Iraqi television shows Hussein meeting with his war cabinet, apparently girding them for battle; United Nations arms inspectors search mine that yielded 'yellowcake' uranium dioxide that Iraq has tried in past to enrich for nuclear weapons, other sites; map; photos (M)

headline: Ruinous Drought in Australia Is Called the Worst in 100 Years
abstract: Australia is experiencing what govenrment officials claim is worst drought in century; rainfall over last 18 months has been 50 to 70 percent below average; farmers and livestock breeders are hard hit (M)

headline: Proposal to Test Smallpox Vaccine in Young Children Sets Off Ethics Debate
abstract: Federal health officials propose to test smallpox vaccine in toddlers and preschoolers, proposal so fraught with ethical questions that FDA is seeking comment from public before allowing experiment to proceed (M)

headline: People
abstract: Jean Mojo succeeds Carl Nichols as managing partner at Einson Freeman agency; roundup of other advertising industry executive changes (M)

headline: BMG Buys J Records and Shuffles Executives
abstract: BMG acquires remaining 50 percent of share of J Records, joint venture that it started with music impresario Clive Davis two years ago after he was forced to leave company; move will help BMG, music division of Bertelsmann, save overhead costs and give Davis sweeping control over two record units; Davis photo with singer Alicia Keys (M)

abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   4.25   4.25   5.00       Discount rate   0.75   0.75   1.50       Federal funds   1.25   1.28   1.78       3-month T-bills   1.17   1.17   1.65       6-month T-bills   1.22   1.21   1.75       10-yr.
