headline: A Big Victory By California In Energy Case
abstract: Williams Companies agrees to pay more than $400 million to settle accusations that it helped drive up prices and overcharged customers during California's power crisis; also agrees to restructure 10-year, $4.3 billion power contract it signed with California at height of energy crisis last year, when power prices were soaring; state officials say they can save more than $1 billion by renegotiating power contract with Williams; Gov Gray Davis says settlement is important victory for ratepayers; Mirant and AES receive federal subpoenas regarding energy they supplied to California; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Jail Term For Spy Who Spilled Secrets
abstract: Former British spy David Shayler is found guilty of violating Official Secrets Act and is to serve 6 months in jail; sold classified documents that derogatorily depicted British intelligence to new media; photo (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Starbucks Expects A Loss
abstract: Starbucks Coffee Japan expects full-year loss of 500 million yen ($4.1 million); will pay no dividend in 2002; reduces its sales target by nearly 10 percent (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Bosnia And Herzegovina: Election Today
abstract: Bosnians vote today for a government that will probably have to try to stand alone before the end of its four-year term, as Western aid and supervision slowly dwindle away. International officials, who are letting Bosnia's deeply divided Serbs, Muslims and Croats run an election for the first time since the war ended in 1995, are urging people to vote for moderate parties. But nationalist parties are expected to do well, particularly in the semi-autonomous Serb Republic formed under the Dayton peace accords.   Daniel Simpson (NYT)

headline: World Business Briefing: Americas
abstract: BRAZIL: Interest Rate Raised; CANADA: Bell Canada Cuts Jobs;.

headline: Mexico Fears Migrant Deaths Will Increase With Despair
abstract: Mexican government fears death of 11 migrants in locked boxcar in Iowa is harbinger of more to come as desperation continues to drive illegal migrants from poor farming villages (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Genuity To Seek Bankruptcy Protection
abstract: Data-network operator Genuity Inc, which defaulted on $3 billion in loans, plans to seek bankruptcy protection; nears accord to sell most of its assets to rival Level 3 Communications for $240 million (S)

headline: Ex-Officer of Safety-Kleen Indicted in Fraud Case
abstract: Former Safety-Kleen Corp chief financial officer Paul Humphreys is indicted on charges of plotting to overstate earnings by $267 million and helping drive industrial waste management company into bankruptcy (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Airport Lounges To Add T-Mobile Net Service
abstract: Airport club lounges of American Airlines, Delta Air Lines and United Airlines will add HotSpot high-speed wireless Internet service from T-Mobile USA, division of Deutsche Telekom, in next 12 months (S)

headline: A Legal Uproar Over Proposals To Regulate The Profession
abstract: Corporate lawyers have organized to block some proposed standards of conduct for profession, arguing that government proposals would critically damage their relationships with clients; lawyers contend provision that would require lawyers to take evidence of protential fraud to company's top managers and even its board could drastically hinder business deals; are livid over provision requiring them to withdraw from representing client--and to tell government that they have withdrawn--if client does not appropriately resolve lawyer's concerns about possible fraud; assert that would violate privilege preserving confidentiality of conversations with clients; American Bar Association has created task force to respond to proposed rules, in addition to existing task force responding to corporate scandals; few lawyers at big firms have begun letter-writing campaign seeking to kill some of provisions; proposed rules, which would take effect at end of January, were called for in corporate governance legislation this summer, and comments are being accepted through Dec 18; Securities and Exchange Commission released proposals on Nov 21 (M)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Burundi: Peace Talks Break Off
abstract: Talks, Tanzania, between Burundi government and major rebel group break off without cease-fire accord (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Aluminum Unit Acquired
abstract: World Business Brie

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Michelin To Exchange Shares
abstract: Michelin is offering to exchange shares in its Swiss-based finance unit for shares in main company to simplify its finance structure; will offer 13 shares of group stock for every share of Compagnie Financiere Michelin, 23 percent premium to average September trading price (S)

headline: People
abstract: Brian Carty, executive vice president at San Francisco office of Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos, is named president at New York office, succeeding David Wecal, who continues as creative director and becomes executive vice president (S)

headline: U.S. PANEL REJECTS PLEA FOR LOAN AID BY UNITED AIRLINES
abstract: United Airlines' plea for $1.8 billion in loan guarantees is rejected by Air Transportation Stabilization Board, which calls United's business plan 'not financially sound' and says government assistance would not solve its 'competitive problems'; analysts expect airline to file for bankruptcy protection; airline's parent company, UAL Corp, has lost more than $2.9 billion since Jan 1, 2000, worst financial performance of any carrier during industry's worst downturn; UAL's chairman and chief executive Glenn F Tilton says 'United will continue to fly'; travel experts say even if United goes into bankruptcy court, airline would be able to live up to Tilton's vow in short run, maintaining 1,800-flight daily schedule and honoring its frequent-flier miles; say that to fix its broken business, United will have to shrink operations and put jobs of untold number of its 81,000 employees at risk; photo (L)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Trading Company Downgraded
abstract: Moody's Investors Service downgrades Mitsubishi Corp's credit rating because of faltering business climate and risks on company's balance sheet (S)7

headline: Militia Force and Students Clash in Continuing Tehran Protest
abstract: Hundreds of hard-line paramilitary forces clash with students gathered at downtown Tehran university to back Hashem Aghajari, reformist scholar sentenced to death after calling for separation of religion and state; protests continue despite order by Ayatollah Ali Khamenei to appeals court to review case that used language indicating sentence might be dismissed; student leaders say they seek release of all political prisoners and guarantee of freedom of speech (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)ú

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Intel To Introduce New Cellphone Technology
abstract: Intel Corp to introduce new generation of semiconductor technology aimed at cellphone industry; new products will highlight new generation of flash memory chips based on its most advanced 0.13-micron process technology, which saves battery life and adds memory capacity; new chips are available in densities of 64,128 and 256 megabits; company also announces new stacked packaging technology for cellphones, method that will allow it to package most of microelectronics needed for modern cellphone in single semiconductor device (S)

headline: An Authentic Ham
abstract: Michael Alexander letter Dec 12 online shopper column on buying country hams online contends best purveyor was omitted

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Profit For Samsung
abstract: Samsung Electronics reports earning $1.39 billion in third quarter, up from $336 million in year-earlier period; sales of mobile telephones rose sharply (M)

headline: Prague Battens Down, Fearing a Storm of Protests
abstract: Vast security operation is under way for NATO summit meeting, Prague; whole areas of city are being blocked off; schools have been shut and parents urged to take children to countryside; many residents without young children have left town for week, even with few signs of protest evident, to avoid traffic tangled by security measures; police have vowed to respond aggressively if demonstrators get rowdy; defuse small homemade bomb tied to rail track (M)

headline: 3 Global Policy Superstars Sharing Turf at Columbia
abstract: With Jagdish N. Bhagwati, Jeffrey D. Sachs and Joseph E. Stiglitz, Columbia University has an unmatched trio of prominent voices in the debate on globalization and economic development.

headline: Chechnya Bomb Toll Rises Past 80; Putin Stands By Vote Plan
abstract: Unofficial death toll in bombing of Russian regional offices in Chechnya soars past 80, and Pres Vladimir Putin warns that militants are using more violent tactics in effort to sabotage restoration of Russian rule in region; Putin says plans to establish Chechnya as self-ruling republic in Russian federation will stand (M)

headline: Earthquake in Italy Kills 20 Pupils and Traps Many More
abstract: Earthquake collapses nursery and elementary school in San Giuliano di Puglia, Italy, trapping more than 50 children; at least 20 are killed; huge somber army of police and firefighters work through night, digging out bodies and trying to reach survivors; photos; map (M)

headline: WHAT THEY'RE READING
abstract: List of books currently being read by Icosystem chairman Eric W Bonabeau, Menlo Worldwide chief executive John H Williford and Ford Motor Co vice president Anne Stevens (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Technology Stocks Lead A Year-End Rally on Wall St.  The Nasdaq composite index, which includes many technology stocks, has rallied from its low of 1,114.11 on Oct. 9 and is leading a year-end rally that looks a lot like last year's. And as the last month of 2002 begins, the question is whether the rally will last long enough to make a major dent in the market's losses for the year. The Nasdaq composite dropped 9.16 points yesterday, to 1,478.78, but rose 0.7 percent for the week, its third consecutive weekly gain. The Nasdaq's loss for the year is 24.2 percent, compared with 42.9 percent on Oct. 9.    The Dow Jones industrial average fell 35.59 points, or 0.4 percent, to 8,896.09, but still finished up for the eighth consecutive week. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index slipped 2.56 points, or 0.3 percent, to 936.31, but was up 0.6 percent for the week. [Page C4.]

headline: United Amends Cost-Cut Plan To Try to Get Loan Guarantee
abstract: United Airlines files revised business plan with federal government to increase its chances of receiving $1.8 billion loan guarantee, which would help it avoid bankruptcy filing; says it will end service at four overseas airports and switch to smaller jets on some international routes; reductions in labor costs are most significant part of plan, which would save company $5.8 billion over five and half years (M)

headline: The Motorbike at a Mosque At Midnight and Other Clues That Led to a Bali Suspect
abstract: Chief investigator of Bali bombing almost month ago says Indonesian police were led to first suspect, named Amrozi, by discovery of getaway motorcycle combined with old-fashioned detective work; says names of 10 Indonesians have been given to police during interrogation of Amrozi, and all are believed to be followers of militant Islamic ideology; arrest of Amrozi, acolyte of Indonesia's most prominent radical Islamic preacher Abu Bakar Bashir, comes as surprise in country where police are considered to be largely corrupt and not overly competent; photos (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Pressplay Adds BMG Tracks To Catalog
abstract: Pressplay, online music service that offers consumers ability to listen to and download more than 100,000 songs for monthly fee, adds tens of thousands of tracks distributed by BMG, part of Bertelsmann, to its catalog (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Inquiries Raise Questions About Tenet's Strategy  In Tenet Healthcare's annual report, the chief executive, Jeffrey C. Barbakow, said that last fiscal year was ''the best in our company's history -- so far.'' Strong profits and falling debt were signs that Mr. Barbakow had rescued the company from scandals and near collapse and had turned it into one of the best-performing hospital operators in the nation.    But the man brought in to clean up Tenet is finding his integrity being questioned as the companies face a series of government inquiries all too reminiscent of its past. The inquiries are raising concerns about the propriety of the strategy Tenet pursued of aggressively raising prices and whether its quest for higher profits threatens the quality of its care. [Page C2.]

headline: The Weary Holiday Shopper Is Giving Plastic This Season
abstract: Growing numbers of Americans are giving cash or gift certificates instead of presents this holiday season; national survey conducted by America's Research Group finds number of people who want to give cash or gift certificates has increased to 51 percent, from 39 percent last year; American Express survey finds 69 percent are opting for money or gift certificates, up from 41 percent five years ago; finds 72 percent want to receive them; old-fashioned gift certificates are being replaced by electronic gift cards that can be ordered in any amount for almost any occasion; many merchants are promoting these cards heavily; merchants love these cards: up to 15 percent of recipients never cash them in; photos (M)

headline: Microsoft Antitrust Decision Expected Tomorrow
abstract: U.S. District Judge Colleen Kollar-Kotelly said a court ruling in the long-running Microsoft antitrust case will be announced at 4:30 p.m. ET Friday.

headline: Bush Will Meet A Leading Turk On Use of Bases
abstract: Pres Bush is eager to shore up ties with leading member of Turkey's governing coalition and discuss use of military bases in Turkey in event of war with Iraq; invites Recep Tayyip Erdogan to White House for talks; Erdogan's Justice and Development Party, Muslim-based political organization with pragmatic agenda, came to power in election last month, and he is eager to burnish his credentials as forward-thinking moderate and advance his country's bid to enter European Union, move Washington strongly supports; question is whether Bush and Erdogan will agree on scope of American military deployment in Turkey; in event of war, Pentagon hopes to carry out airstrikes from Turkish air bases as it did during Persian Gulf war in 1991; it also wants to use Turkish soil as staging area for American ground attacks in northern Iraq as way to complement main attack from Kuwait and therefore enable US and allies to quickly overwhelm Iraq's overstretched forces; US officials also calculate that opening of northern front would enable Washington to fend off Iraqi attack on ethnic Kurds and stabilize Kurdish area if Hussein is toppled; this is important to Turkey, given its tension with its own restive Kurdish minority and Iraqi Kurds; photo (M)

headline: Ruling Leaves Most Players Exposed to Suits on Enron
abstract: In a decision that broke new legal ground, a federal judge in Houston ruled yesterday that banks, law firms and investment houses that helped construct Enron's off-the-books partnerships could be sued by investors seeking to regain billions of dollars they lost when the company collapsed.    The long, complex ruling dismissed claims against only two defendants -- Deutsche Bank and Kirkland & Ellis, the Chicago law firm -- while allowing the suit to proceed against almost a dozen other institutions and firms, including Citigroup, J.P. Morgan Chase, Merrill Lynch and Vinson & Elkins.

headline: Shares End Mixed, Despite Souring of Confidence
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average closes up 0.90 point, or 0.01 percent, at 8,368.94, while Standard & Poor's 500-stock index is off 8.08 points, or 0.9 percent, to 882.15; Nasdaq composite index falls 15.29 points, or 1.2 percent, to 1,300.54; US Treasury bonds rise; price of 10-year note is up 1 6/32, to 103 16/32; yield falls to 3.94 percent from 4.09 percent; yield on two-year note falls to 1.76 percent from 1.90 percent; euro is 98.52 cents, up marginally from 98.44 cents; dollar closes at 122.68 yen, down from 123.64 yen; graph; charts (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Inflation Rises
abstract: Canada's inflation rate, measured by the consumer price index, accelerated to 4.3 percent in the 12 months to November, the biggest rise in several years, Statistics Canada said. The increase in the year to October was 3.2 percent. The surge was mostly a result of energy prices, which fell in the fall of 2001, leading to a lower base for comparison. Measured on month to month, the index rose at a more modest rate of 0.2 percent in November. Excluding energy, inflation rose by 3.5 percent in the year to November, reflecting advances of more than 10 percent in auto insurance premiums and cigarette prices.   Bernard Simon (NYT)

headline: Australia Is Noncommittal On Scope of Any Role in Iraq
abstract: US Deputy Secretary of State Richard L Armitage, visiting Australia during Asian tour, says America expects Australia to contribute to any US military effort against Iraq; statements by Prime Min John Howard and Foreign Min Alexander Downer indicate Australia, given deadly terrorist attack on Bali in October, would be contributing less to any Iraqi campaign than envisioned a few months ago (M)

headline: Austria Expects Close Election As Far Right Yields to Center
abstract: National elections Nov 24 figure to be among closest in Austria's history, as nation's traditional center-left and center-right parties battle for largest plurality and right to name next chancellor; most intriguing political story concerns certain loser: country's self-destructing right-wing Freedom Party and Jorg Haider, its once magnetic but now increasingly marginalized leader; Haider became international pariah during 1990's for praising Hitler's labor policies; political analysts say voters have grown tired of his antics; photo (M)

headline: Texas Republican to Join UBS After He Retires From Senate
abstract: Sen Phil Gramm will become vice chairman of UBS Warburg investment bank after retiring from Senate; Gramm says he was hired by UBS for his expertise and abilities, not as reward for his work in Congress; photo (M)

headline: MOODY'S CUTS EL PASO DEBT TO JUNK STATUS
abstract: Moody's Investors Service cuts credit ratings on $25 billion of El Paso Corp debt; El Paso shares fall sharply (S)

headline: Big Brother, Take My Little Sister!
abstract: Matt Richtel humorous article on consequences of bill that would make it illegal to use toy device to copy few seconds of music; drawing (M)

headline: Aegis Reports Gains From Broadcast Ads
abstract: Aegis Group in London says it is reaping benefits of 'further clear improvements' in broadcasting advertising in US since first half of year and that it expects results for year before one-time costs to be 'significantly better' than in 2001; also says it will appeal New York State Supreme Court ruling against subsidiary Carat USA; jury awarded $6.8 million to Independent Media Services in New York, which contended Carat violated noncompetition agreement when it participated in review for account of New Line Cinema, division of AOL Time Warner (S)

headline: SECURITY COUNCIL VOTES, 15-0, FOR TOUGH IRAQ RESOLUTION; BUSH CALLS IT A 'FINAL TEST'
abstract: United Nations Security Council unanimously adopts resolution Pres Bush calls 'final test' of Pres Saddam Hussein's willingness to disarm; Bush says Iraq must respond promptly and unconditionally or face 'severest consequences;' lauds UN for meeting its leadership responsibilities; vote, unexpected triumph for Bush, follows intensive talks and wording change that won reluctant support of Syria and Russia; most Council nations still oppose any rush to war; United States officials hold language gives US legal basis to go to war unilaterally if Council cannot agree how to respond to new Iraqi violations; table of wording changes; photos (M)

headline: Bush Appeals To Iran's Public In Radio Talk
abstract: US Pres Bush, in radio broadcast carried on new Voice of America service Radio Farda, sends warm greetings to people of Iran and urges government to embrace freedom and democracy; Radio Farda (Radio Tomorrow), which tries to appeal to young people by playing music, is criticized by dissidents in Iran and some Voice of America staff members, who say it risks muting vital outlet for people seeking political change in Iran (M)

headline: LEHMAN BROTHERS IS SAID TO CUT 500 EMPLOYEES
abstract: Lehman Brothers Holding Co lays off 500 employees, or about 4 percent of its work force, in cuts throughout company; Jeffrey M Applegate, chief Lehman investment strategist, is reportedly among those terminated (S)

headline: 3rd-Quarter Loss Narrowed at Hughes Electronics
abstract: Hughes Electronics says third-quarter loss narrowed to $13.6 million from $227.2 million loss year earlier; sales rose 5.3 percent, to $2.21 billion, from $2.1 billion year ago (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Bank's Uncertain Outlook
abstract: Bank of Japan says industrial output and exports continue to slow and there is substantial uncertainty about current economic recovery; leaves its overall view of economy unchanged (S)

headline: Debate to Intensify on Copyright Extension Law
abstract: Supreme Court is set to hear arguments on constitutionality of 1998 law extending copyright protection by 20 years; decision will determine whether large amount of material enters public domain and becomes costless to users or remains in control of copyright holders; debate intensifies concerning possible redefinition of balance between producers and consumers of copyrighted intellectual property; photo (M)

headline: For South Africa's Poorest AIDS Victims, a Place to Die
abstract: Scene at Sparrow Rainbow Village, hospice for AIDS patients near Roodepoort on outskirts of Johannesburg, South Africa, described; hospice has taken in about 200 indigent AIDS patients since it opened in February and more than 100 have died; South Africa, with nearly 25 percent of all adults infected, is believed to have five million people that have HIV virus; photos (M)

headline: Iraq Official Says Nation Is Armed for War
abstract: Deputy Prime Min Tariq Aziz says Iraq is preparing for war and has distributed hundreds of thousands or possibly millions of guns to its people to fend off American-led attack, United States television interview; says Iraq hopes to avoid war (S)i

headline: World Briefing: Africa
abstract: IVORY COAST: Government And Rebels Meet; TRIBUNAL TRIES TO MEND RIFT WITH RWANDA;.

headline: Chechen in Extradition Dispute: Criminal or Peacemaker?
abstract: Russian government sees Akhmed Zakayev as Chechen terrorist and murderer, but others, even some in Russia, see him as best hope for peaceful resolution of long, bloody Chechen conflict; he is chief envoy of Chechnya's ousted president Aslan Maskhadov, and is now subject of Russia's second extradition dispute in recent weeks, this time with Britain; he was arrested on his arrival in London after authorities in Denmark rebuffed Russian demands to extradite him; he is now free on bail pending hearing; his fate has become test of Pres Vladimir V Putin's efforts to portray Chechen conflict as part of larger struggle against terrorism; Zakayev insists Chechnya's rebels want peace, but warns that some are prepared to stage new attacks like 57-hour siege of Moscow theater in Oct that left 129 hostages and 41 Chechen guerrillas dead; he has denounced that attack; photos (M)

headline: Going Electronic, Denver Reveals Long-Term Surveillance
abstract: Article on growing debate over privacy that has come to light after Denver police, which had been gathering information on unsuspecting local activists since 1950's, transferred information from index cards to computer program supplied by Orion Scientific Systems; among those police spied on were nuns, advocates for American Indians and church organizations, some of which were categorized in computer as criminal extremists; incident highlights some pitfalls of police intelligence software, which has been hailed as major tool in war against terrorism; photos (M)

headline: MEMO PAD
abstract: America West Takes New Swipe at Fares      America West Airlines, which gave the major domestic carriers an advanced case of the vapors in March when it cut business fares and eliminated Saturday-night stay requirements on most advance-purchase tickets, continues to punch away at the competition.    Yesterday, America West announced a fare sale -- seven-day advance purchase and one-night minimum stay required -- in four new markets that it begins serving today. Sample round-trip fares, through Dec. 31:

headline: Bush's Speech on NATO Enlargement
abstract: Following is a transcript of the speech by President Bush yesterday in Prague, as recorded by the White House.

headline: Nepalese King Fires Prime Minister and Seizes Power
abstract: The king of Nepal removed the country's elected prime minister Friday night, seized power and postponed elections scheduled for next month.

headline: Yuzhno-Kurilsk Journal; Between Russia and Japan, a Pacific Tug of War
abstract: Southern Kuriles, volcanic islands administered from town of Yuzhno-Kurilsk, remain under Russian control decades after end of World War II, keeping Russia and Japan from officially making peace; photos; map; foreign ministers of two great Pacific powers will meet and yet again vow to close books on war, but good intentions may once again founder on desolate land that has become apple of the eye of Japan's newly muscular right wing; about one-third of Kunashir Island's population left after 1994 earthquake, and total population of disputed islands is now 17,000 (M)

headline: Business; A Fashion Designer at Odds With His Label
abstract: Fashion designer Joseph Abboud and company he helped found, JA Apparel, are suing each other, further aggravating estrangement between Abboud and JA Apparel president Robert J Wichser; dispute centers on Abboud's design authority; photos (M)

headline: XEROX TO RECEIVE UP TO $5 BILLION IN FINANCING
abstract: GE Capital will provide Xerox with as much as $5 billion in financing over next eight years; deal comes as surprise on Wall Street, because both companies have led investors to expect GE Capital would assume Xerox's financing business in US; arrangement keeps debt on Xerox's books (S)

headline: Arrest in Turkmenistan
abstract: Turkmenistan arrests opposition leader

headline: Dread and Dreams Travel by Bus in Israel
abstract: James Bennet describes making three-day bus trip through northern Israel, beginning and ending in Jerusalem; bus route would take it past sites of repeated attacks by Palestinian suicide bombers; sees Israel today bracketed by growing fear--of violence, of economic stagnation, of pious bullying or secular decadence--and by lingering, sometimes wistful, faith in dreams of Jewish statehood; Israel, like its buses, has been battered; a state of six million citizens, among them one million Arabs, and in addition holding more than three million Palestinians with their own national dream under its military control, Israel is groping for some route that will allow it to be Jewish, democratic and at peace; photos; map shows route of bus trip (L)

headline: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: I.B.M. Wins Services Pact From J. P. Morgan
abstract: IBM wins 7-year computer services contract from J P Morgan Chase & Co valued at over $5 billion; about 4,000 J P Morgan workers who perform computer-related tasks will leave bank to join IBM (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: DANA CORP., Toledo, Ohio, a maker of axles for light trucks, said it would sell three nonautomotive businesses to the Riverside Co., New York, a leveraged buyout firm, to focus on selling car and truck parts. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Nike's Chief Takes Top Stake in Vinton
abstract: Philip H Knight, Nike chairman, becomes majority shareholder in Will Vinton Studios, company known for its animation work for advertising, films and television; terms are not disclosed (M)

headline: Italians Study Ways to Safeguard Buildings Against Earthquakes
abstract: Many schools in southern Italy remain closed week after death of 26 children in earthquake in San Giuliano di Puglia; frightened parents keep children home as public demands to know why school built in 1953 collapsed; blame falls on ill-advised renovations and government negligence, especially after discovery of 1998 seismic map by scientists warned of town's vulnerability; officials say map never reached proper authorities (M)

headline: World Donors Praise Kabul's Budget and Development Plans
abstract: Afghan government wins resounding endorsement from international donors for its budget and development plan to lift country out of destitution and work toward self-sufficiency, positioning it well to win badly needed long-term assistance; Finance Min Ashraf Ghani presents comprehensive plan to conference in Kabul between Afghan ministers and international donors; government of Pres Hamid Karzai still needs $90 million to fill gaps in $460 national budget for 2002; Afghan officials and donors estimate government will need at least $10 billion, beyond everyday expenses and emergency aid, to rebuild country's shattered infrastructure and develop economy that can sustain people; photo (M)

headline: Jobless Rate Surged Unexpectedly in November
abstract: The nation's unemployment rate rose to 6 percent in November, the highest level since a peak almost nine years ago.

headline: World Business Briefing: Europe
abstract: GERMANY: Weak Outlook For Siemens; IRELAND: Profit For Crystal Maker; ITALY: Debt Restructuring;.

headline: MEDIA: Gazing Into 2003: The Balance of Media Power Is Poised to Change -- Cable News; At CNN, Hoping For Restored Glory
abstract: CNN, trailing Fox News in domestic ratings, can reclaim former glory if war in Iraq allows it to overtake Fox in a big way; to lose in ratings to Fox during war could be real blow; photo (M)

headline: A Freud Action Figure? Novelties Online
abstract: Roundup of novelty Christmas gifts that can be bought online (M)

headline: Bitter Divide as Securities Panel Picks an Accounting Watchdog
abstract: Members of Securities and Exchange Commission split bitterly over qualifications and competency of new leadership of board overseeing accounting profession; vote is 3 to 2 to approve selection of William H Webster to head new board; Democrats on commission say Webster lacks credentials to lead accounting board; say he has no recent experience in accounting issues; handling of selection process leaves SEC Chmn Harvey L Pitt further politically wounded after year of missteps; choice of Webster over John H Biggs, who is considered by some to be too aggressive a reformer, is widely criticized by leading members of Wall Street and by Sen Paul S Sarbanes, main author of law creating new board; Pitt seems to retain support of White House; brief sketches of new members of Accounting Standards Board: Webster, Kayla J Gillan, Daniel L Goelzer, Willis D Gradison Jr and Charles D Niemeier; photos (M)

headline: Inquiry on Andersen Lawyer Is Urged by House Committee
abstract: House committee urges Justice Department to probe former Arthur Andersen internal lawyer Nancy Temple for making 'apparently false statements' in Congressional testimony; she denied e-mail she sent to colleague shortly before Enron collapsed suggesting Andersen employees working on account be reminded to destroy unneeded documents was attempt to destroy evidence; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Countries To Bar Belarus Leader
abstract: At least 118 people die after thousands of Maoist rebels storm remote Nepalese towns, fighting pitched battles with security forces (S)

headline: Technology Briefing: Internet
abstract: GATEWAY TO SELL SERVICES ON CONNECTED PC'S; TOO EARLY TO FORECAST REBOUND, INTEL SAYS;.

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Ethiopia: Eritrea Rebuffed On Food Aid
abstract: Ethiopia snubs Eritrea's offer to allow food donations to pass through their ports in spite of critical food shortage; friction still exists between countries although border war ended in 2000 (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Evidence For Chechen Extradition Case
abstract: Russia presents evidence to Denmark in attempt to extradite Chechen envoy Akhmed Zakayev; he stands accused of organizing Chechen rebel group that carried out kidnappings and killings over past decade (S)

headline: WorldCom Strikes a Deal With S.E.C.
abstract: WorldCom strikes agreement with SEC settling civil fraud suit against company in way that may allow it to avoid paying fines; deal takes form of permanent injunction and consent decreet and requires WorldCom to refrain from breaking securities laws; SEC accused company of misstating its financial results by $3.8 billion, amount that after subsequent disclosures now exceeds $9 billion; Judge Jed S Rakoff approves deal and will continue to oversee company's behavior, largely through Richard C Breeden, WorldCom's court-appointed monitor and keeper of its purse strings; some WorldCom critics say settlement is too lenient (M)

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: NORTHERN IRELAND: Soldier Changes Testimony; NORTHERN IRELAND: Blair Pushes Peace Effort; BOSNIA: Policemen Fired For Aiding Sex Traffic; SPAIN: Court To Weigh Ban On Basque Party;.

headline: WorldCom Director Quits and Agrees to Pay for Using Plane
abstract: WorldCom Inc director Stiles A Kellett Jr resigns and agrees to pay hundreds of thousands of dollars for benefits he received before company collapsed into bankruptcy; Kellett agrees to reimburse company at rate of $3,000 per hour for his use of corporate plane, resulting in total obligation of $304,000; certain amounts owed to Kellett, including board fees, are subtracted from total; Kellett will provide WorldCom with check for $156,000 (M)

headline: London Journal; Diana's Faithful Butler: In the End, Was He False?
abstract: Paul Burrell, butler to late Princess Diana, faces charges of plundering 310 items from her estate, and from her former husband, Prince Charles and their elder son, Prince William; items were found in police raid on Burrell's home in Jan 2001; he has pleaded not guilty to charges; police report lists many explanations he has given for not having returned objects to family; trial is expected to last six weeks; charges against him are punishable by up to seven years in jail; photos (M)

headline: Caveats in Coin Collecting
abstract: David Ginsburg letter on Oct 27 article that described recent developments in quantifying transactions of coin collecting

headline: Another Accounting Error at Swiss Life
abstract: Swiss Life for second time in less than month says it has to restate its results by hundreds of millions of dollars to correct accounting error; chief executive Roland Chlapowski calls latest discrepancy 'very regrettable'; says problem, discovered by PricewaterhouseCoopers auditors, reveals shortcomings in new computer system meant to track value of securities; company says it will not change its plans to sell $790 million worth of new shares to existing investors on Oct 23 to raise cash; stock is down almost 78 percent this year despite modest rally last week; company says its loss in first half of year was really 578 million Swiss francs ($382 million), not 386 million francs it initially reported; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Study Focuses On Unsolicited E-Mail At Work
abstract: Study by Pew Internet and Amer

headline: STANDARD & POOR'S LOWERS INTERPUBLIC'S CREDIT RATING
abstract: Standard & Poor's downgrades long-term corporate credit rating of Interpublic Group of Companies for second time in seven weeks, this time to one level above junk status (S)

headline: A Stocking Stuffer For a Big Stocking
abstract: Neiman Marcus prepares to take orders for 99 limited-edition 2004 Cadillac XLR convertible sports cars; $85,000 cars will go into production in April 2003 (M)

headline: PARENT OF PEARLE VISION TO RESTATE 5 YEARS' EARNINGS
abstract: Cole National Corp, parent of Pearle Vision optical stores, will revise its accounting for revenue from customer warranties on eyeglasses and restate corporate earnings of last five years; Cole's shares fall (S)

headline: Carreker Results Delayed
abstract: Carreker Corp delays its quarterly earnings report; may restate previous earnings and sales data; shares fall on news (S)

headline: From Inside, Palm Makes A New Start
abstract: David Pogue State of the Art column on Palm OS 5, new operating system developed to accommodate chips at wider range of speeds, prices and manufacturers; new system may help company compete with Pocket PC's, which offer more features; Palm hopes that explsion of interesting gadgets will result; drawing; photo (M)

headline: RUMSFELD FAVORS FORCEFUL ACTIONS TO FOIL AN ATTACK
abstract: Defense Secretary Donald H Rumsfeld sets out personal set of guidelines for committing US forces to combat that echo and refine military thinking of Caspar W Weinberger, defense secretary in Reagan administration, and Sec of State Colin L Powell, former chairman of Joint Chiefs of Staff; argues that America's leaders must quickly judge when diplomacy is failure, and must then act forcefully and early to foil attack on nation; says if actions fall short, America must be willing and prepared to act decisively to use force necessary to prevail, plus some; says nation's leaders must never 'dumb down' mission to gain support from public, Congress, UN or allies; says leaders must avoid promising not to do certain things, since such pledges simplify planning by foe, just as artificial deadlines for American military withdrawal allow enemy to 'simply wait us out' (M)

headline: Bluetooth, Do You Read Me? Wireless Typing and Clicking
abstract: Microsoft's Wirelesss Optical Desktop relies on Bluetooth protocol to connect keyboard and mouse wirelessly; photo (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: A Plea For Fiat Funds
abstract: Italian Prime Min Silvio Berlusconi, facing calls for government

headline: U.S. Applauds Tokyo's Dispatch of Warship to the Indian Ocean
abstract: Deputy State Sec Richard L Armitage, in Tokyo on first stop of Asian tour meant to explain American policy toward Iraq, hails Japan's decision to send sophisticated warship to Indian Ocean; deployment is seen in Japan as tacit support for American policies in Iraq and has spurred constitutional debate (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Plan For Tighter Asylum Rules
abstract: Britain proposes that asylum claims from ten countries expected to join European Union by 2004 be automatically presumed unfounded because those countries are safe (S)

headline: Europeans Smooth Over Differences, but Tensions Remain
abstract: Fifteen leaders of European Union arrive at agreement on how to pay for 10 countries invited to join union, only after bitter haggling over money and deferral of some decisions for years; subsidies to be given to new members will reach same level as existing member states in 10 years; new members are Poland, Hungary, Czech Republic, Slovakia, Slovenia, Lithuania, Latvia, Estonia, Cyprus and Malta (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Corel Lays Off 22% Of Work Force
abstract: Canadian software company Corel Corp lays off 220 employees, or 22 percent of its work force; hopes to save $12 million annually (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Phone Stake Sold
abstract: China Telecom raises 11.2 billion Hong Kong dollars ($1.4 billion) through sale of shares, 60 percent less than hoped for; investors now own 10 percent of state-run company; company will reduce investment and expansion during next two years (S)

headline: U.N. Team Faces Its First Locked Rooms in Weapons Search
abstract: UN weapons inspectors, for first time since resuming inspections in Iraq, are kept waiting for two hours for access to several locked rooms at Health Ministry communicable diseases center in Baghdad; tensions rise as inspectors try to place seals on rooms; telephone hot line to Iraq National Monitoring Directorate is activated for first time; Iraqi Gen Hussam Muhammad Amin agrees to have rooms sealed (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: France: Conservatives Unite In New Party
abstract: Union for a Popular Movement, new French political party, is formed and led by former Prime Min Alain Juppe; group which allied with other groups to help Pres Jacques Chirac to landslide victory last June is now official party made up of several conservative and centrist groups (S)

headline: Clean Coal Effort Planned
abstract: Clean Coal Power Resources plans to spend $4.5 billion to build plants to make natural gas from coal and generate power in Fayette County, Ill (S)

headline: Big retailers are seeking an edge with private-label brands.
abstract: PRIVATE-LABEL apparel brands have long been the neglected stepchildren of department stores, receiving minimal ad support or prime floor space.    But the stores -- needing to attract customers who are shunning them for specialty retailers and discount chains like Target -- are increasingly investing in the design and promotion of their once homely brands, giving them the star treatment as if they were designer labels like Liz Claiborne or Jones New York. And they are turning to Madison Avenue-type marketing techniques to create hip images for their revitalized (and in some cases newly created) brands.

headline: KING PHARMACEUTICALS TO BUY MERIDIAN MEDICAL
abstract: King Pharmaceuticals agrees to buy Meridian Medical Technologies for $247.8 million, adding EpiPen injector for allergic shock and other devices that ease administration of drugs (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Industrial Output Rises
abstract: Brazil's industrial production rose 8.9 percent in October, up from 1.7 percent in September; country is running $12 billion 12-month trade surplus (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Convenience Stores Acquired
abstract: Britain's Tesco PLC agrees to buy T&S Stores for 377.3 million pounds ($587 million) in stock to expand in convenience stores (S)

headline: Oil From Crippled Ship Fouling Beaches in Spain
abstract: Clean-up crews begin removing sludge from beaches in northwestern Spain fouled when stricken tanker Prestige leaked over 3,000 tons of fuel oil into Atlantic; spill threatens birds, marine life and livelihood of thousands of fishermen in region famous for seafood; calmer weather has allowed tugs to tow tanker, which began to leak again, to area southwest of coast; ship will remain serious environmental threat until its 77,000 tons of fuel oil can be loaded onto another tanker; Spain has refused ship access to any port and seeks to exploit crisis in talks with Britain on future of Gibraltar, British colony claimed by Spain; Britain denies Gibraltar has any link to accident (M)

headline: RUMSFELD ORDERS WAR PLANS REDONE FOR FASTER ACTION
abstract: Defense Sec Donald Rumsfeld orders regional military commanders to rewrite all war plans to capitalize on precision weapons, better intelligence and speedier deployment; says change will allow military to begin combat operations on less notice and with far fewer troops than thought possible, or even wise, prior to September 11 terrorist attacks; officials say approach is already shaping planning for possible war against Iraq; command has stockpiled weapons and positioned some troops in Persian Gulf in effort to be able to stage quick offensive against Pres Saddam Hussein that planners say would be vastly different from 1991 war over Kuwait; photo (M)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of Dec 22 Boss column featuring Eli Zabar

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Profit For Crystal Maker
abstract: Waterford Wedgewood reports first-half profit of 34.1 million euros ($34.5 million), compared with 13.5 million euros a year earlier; sales fall 4.4 percent, to 471.2 millin euros (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Leaking Tanker Towed From Coast
abstract: Dilapidated tanker causing 20 mile oil slick off coast of Spain is towed out to sea in hopes of preventing further environmental disaster (S)

headline: A Cadillac and Other Plunder: Iraq-Kuwait Issue Resurfaces
abstract: Prospect of new war between United States and Iraq gives new significance to Iraq's record in dealing with legacy of its seven-month occupation of Kuwait that was ended by American troops in 1991; Iraqi troops fleeing Kuwait took cars and other expensive items from Kuwait; official registry in Kuwait of booty Iraq seized records that 29,440 privately owned cars were stolen during occupation; Iraq has long shunned issues of missing persons and stolen property; now, eager to improve its image in Arab world and win wider circle of friends in showdown votes at United Nations, Iraq has told Kuwait it wants to address those issues; Kuwaiti officials believe that way Saddam Hussein has ignored Security Council resolutions demanding accounting of Kuwait's losses and professed eagerness to tackle these issues now has wider resonance, going to heart of current crisis with United States; say issue now is truth: whether Hussein's government can show honesty now that many have found lacking in past; photos (L)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Kenya: Kickoff To Presidential Campaigns
abstract: Kenyan presidential candidates Uhuru Kenyatta and Mwai Kibaki officially register their nomination papers in Nairobi; tens of thousands attend event and listen to their campaign speeches (S)

headline: Tripling of Profit Reported
abstract: NASHVILLE, Oct. 8 (Bloomberg News) — American Healthways, a provider of services for diabetes and heart-disease patients, said fiscal fourth-quarter revenue rose 71 percent and profit more than tripled after the company sold more services to established customers.

headline: Philip Denies Calling Diana Vulgar Names
abstract: Queen Elizabeth's husband Prince Philip makes public denial of news reports that he sent Princess Diana insulting letters calling her 'harlot' and 'trollop'; report first appeared in one British newspaper and was picked up by every other newspaper in Britain's fiercely competitive press (S)

headline: Indonesia Stocks Fall 10%; Others in Asia Off Modestly; Severe Tourism Losses Seen
abstract: Bombing ofdiscotheques on Bali, Indonesia, by terrorists jolts financial markets across region on Oct 14, bringing warnings for increased security around production sites and other facilities that are mainstay of Indonesia's already tottering economy; Indonesian stock market falls 10.4%, and currency falls sharply; effects of bombing on other markets in region noted; chart (M)

headline: TWO SENIOR MANAGERS AT MERRILL LYNCH RESIGN
abstract: Two more senior managers are leaving Merrill Lynch & Co, latest departures in E Stanley O'Neal's first week as chief exec; they are Paul Roy and Michael Marks (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Proposal To Recognize Sex Changes
abstract: British government proposes legislation granting transsexuals right to be legally recognized, to marry under their chosen sex, to be granted birth certificates noting their new sex and to claim pensions at age 60 for women and 65 for men (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Synopsys Shares Soar After Profit Beats Forecasts
abstract: Shares of Synopsys Inc rise as much as 17 percent following statement from company that indicates its fourth-quarter profits topped forecasts (S)

headline: NORTH KOREA SAYS IT HAS A PROGRAM ON NUCLEAR ARMS
abstract: Bush administration says North Korea admits it has been conducting major clandestine nuclear-weapons development program for past several years and that it has 'nullified' its 1994 agreement with US to freeze all nuclear weapons development activity; surprise revelation comes after American diplomat James A Kelley confronts North Korean counterparts in Pyongyang with American intelligence data suggesting secret project is under way; Bush administration officials refuse to say whether North Koreans acknowledged successfully producing nuclear weapon from their project; administration calls for North Korea to comply with its commitments under Nonproliferation Treaty; Washington's response is muted in comparison with ominous-sounding warnings put to Iraq, another country thought to be developing weapons of mass destruction; map (M)

headline: SCHERING-PLOUGH TO BUY BACK MARKETING RIGHTS TO DRUG
abstract: Schering-Plough Corp plans to buy back marketing rights to cancer drug Leucomax from Novartis (S)

abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   4.25   4.25   5.00        Discount rate   0.75   0.75   1.50        Federal funds   1.25   1.36   1.71        3-month T-bills   1.19   1.20   1.67        6-month T-bills   1.25   1.26   1.75        10-yr. headline: A Scramble For Goodies Means They Will Go Fast
abstract: Edmund L Andrews Economic View column notes tax cuts are centerpiece of Pres Bush's economic 'stimulus' program; cites diversity of interests pressing to ensure that cuts benefit them (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Cyprus: Advice From U.S. On Peace Plan
abstract: American envoy Thomas G Weston pushes Cyprus's Greek and Turkish leaders to give earnest consideration to recent UN peace initiative (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Bad Loan Strategy
abstract: Mizuho Holdings, the world's biggest bank by assets, plans to shed as much as 1.6 trillion yen ($13 billion) of its worst loans. It is the first Japanese bank to respond to the government's call to be tougher on delinquent borrowers. By March 2004, the lender plans to sell, write off or recover 80 percent of loans to companies that moved into the ''near-to-failure'' or a worse category in the year ended March 31, a spokesman, Misao Yoneyama, said.

headline: More Charges Expected Against Gas Traders
abstract: Legal experts say they expect more charges against energy traders after announcement that Todd Geiger, former vice pres of El Paso Corp, had been indicted in Houston on charges of falsely reporting natural gas trades (S)

headline: PUTIN QUESTIONS U.S. TERROR ALLIES
abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia welcomed President Bush to his hometown today, then raised pointed questions about the reliability of two important American allies in the campaign against terrorism, Pakistan and Saudi Arabia.    In remarks made at Mr. Bush's side in the majestic setting of Catherine Palace outside St. Petersburg, Mr. Putin also suggested that the disappearance of Osama bin Laden, the leader of Al Qaeda, was a major piece of unfinished business as the Bush administration focused its attention on a possible war in Iraq.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Business Confidence Falls
abstract: Germany's Ifo Institute says its business-confidence index fell to 87.7 in October from 88.2 in September amid fears that tax increases and spending cuts proposed by Chancellor Gerhard Schroder's new government will revive torpid economy; private-sector economic forecasts for Germany predict near-zero growth in 2002 (S)

headline: Text: Statement From Carter Accepting Prize
abstract: Following is the complete text of the statement from former President Jimmy Carter today in accepting the 2002 Nobel Peace Prize, as distributed by The Carter Center in Atlanta:.

headline: Nextel Has Hired a Strategy Consultant
abstract: Nextel Has Hired A Strategy Consultant.

headline: AurionGold to Accept Placer Dome Offer
abstract: Australia's AurionGold abandons its opposition to hostile takeover bid from Placer Dome Inc of Canada; AurionGold's directors say that it is no longer in best interests of shareholders to reject Placer's offer of stock and cash, valued at 1.5 billion to 2 billion Australian dollars ($820 million to $1.09 billion); recommend that shareholders either accept offer or sell their shares on market; combined company would be world's fifth-largest gold producer, with annual output of about 3.8 million ounces; photo (M)

headline: Compressed Data; Another Big Fish Story Comes Unraveled
abstract: Photo circulating on Internet purporting to show great white shark leaping of water at military diver hanging on ladder from hovering helicopter is revealed to be a hoax, a composite of two different photograhs; photo (S)

headline: Dollars and Euros: A Look Beyond the Parity Line
abstract: Dollar's 12.2 percent decline against euro to date in 2002 creates windfall for Americans invested in European stocks and bonds, reducing their stock losses and amplifying their bond gains; currency analysts predict continuation of relative dollar weakness directly tied to further disappointing performance of American economy; persistence of trend causes investors to sell dollar; rebound in United States economy would lead to weakened euro and strengthened dollar; graph (M)

headline: U.S. IS PREPARING BASE IN GULF STATE TO RUN IRAQ WAR
abstract: US military is installing new command center at As Sayliyah base in Qatar to serve as main headquarters in event of war on Iraq; command and control procedures practiced at major American military exercise there in Demember will be same used for war with Iraq; US has not yet asked Qataris if it can run war with Iraq from their country, but their willingness to allow US to build and operate base is breakthrough for Pentagon and represents level of cooperation that far outstrips what Saudi Arabia has been prepared to offer; map (M)

headline: A Coming Flood Erodes the Life of a Chinese City
abstract: Impact of Three Gorges Dam, largest hydroelectric project ever attempted, in Yunyang, China, described; low-lying Yunyang, county seat, is most intensely affected of 120 cities and towns whose residents will be displaced; 160,000 people must relocate from Yanyang; government has provided some relocated people with homes in wealthier places, like Shanghai; others now live about 20 miles upstream in New Yunyang; heaviest burden is borne by those who are staying on in what will remain of old city; just over six months from now, silt-laden Yangtze River, swelled by giant Three Gorges Dam, will inundate Yunyang; photo; map (L)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Factory Orders Rise
abstract: German factory orders were stronger than expected in August with monthly increase of seasonally adjusted 1.7 percent; foreign orders rose 2.6 percent and domestic orders 1.1 percent from July (S)
