headline: His Book, His Turn: Messier Speaks Up
abstract: My True Diary, new book by Jean-Marie Messier, who transformed Vivendi Universal from French water utility into global media conglomerate before he was ousted in July, contains vitriol toward his enemies, repentance for his mistakes and musings on future of Western capitalism; Messier cunningly orchestrates events to promote release of book that defends his approach and attacks those he claims engineered his downfall; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Is Putting Heavy Pressure on France and Other Skeptics for a U.N. Resolution
abstract: Bush administration mounts campaign of public pressure and private diplomatic and economic concessions to persuade France and other skeptical members of United Nations Security Council to go along with single resolution threatening military force against Iraq; there is rising concern in Washington that time is short for passage of such a resolution, since many experts say military action would be easier in winter (M)

headline: Nara Journal; Japanese Masters Get Closer to the Toilet Nirvana
abstract: Article on intense research competition among engineers in Nara, Japan, to produce high-tech toilet seats with array of exotic features; some designs described; photos (M)

headline: Japan Settles For Baby Steps To Help Banks Buried in Debt
abstract: Japanese government unveils proposals to revive nation's ailing financial system by calling on banks to purge half of their bad loans over next two years; several economists say package it little more than vague and watered-down version of tougher plan blocked last week by bankers, bureaucrats and parliamentarians; Bank of Japan increases its purchase of government bonds by 20 percent, to about $10 billion per month; new expansion of money supply is aimed at countering deflation in Japan, where prices have dropped for 37 consecutive months (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: U.S. Rape Suspect Surrenders
abstract: United States Marine Major Michael J Brown, wanted on rape charges, turns himself in to Japanese authorities; because victim is not Japanese, case has been low-profile compared to others involving military in Okinawa (S)

headline: Defense Dept. Renews a Dental Contract
abstract: Delta Dental Plan wins five-year renewal of contract, valued around $1 billion, to provide dental benefits to US military retirees and their families (S)

headline: Opposition to Venezuela's President Grows After Deaths
abstract: Political tumult and uncertainty escalate in Venezuela after shooting in Caracas leaves three antigovernment protesters dead and dozens wounded; opponents of Pres Hugo Chavez demand his resignation, accusing him of fomenting climate of hate that led to shooting; Chavez administration responds with huge pro-government rally at which Chavez accuses opponents of trying to topple him from power; photo (M)

headline: Iraq's Response to the U.N.
abstract: Excerpts from Iraq's response to UN on weapons inspections (S)

headline: Tyco Relies On Unusual Definition For Cash Flow
abstract: Tyco International sold $350 million in receivables to CIT, finance company that it owned until early July, on Sept 30, last day of its fourth fiscal quarter, allowing it to report free cash flow of $1.3 billion for quarter, significantly above its previous estimate, but only under its own, somewhat peculiar, definition of cash flow; beginning in June, Tyco began factoring out cash it took in from selling receivables -- or spent to buy them back -- from its definition of free cash flow; accounting rules give companies flexibility to define cash flow as they choose, but Tyco's definition is 'brand new' to J Edward Ketz, associate professor of accounting at Pennsylvania State University; graph (M)

headline: UAL EXECUTIVES ARE REVIEWING UNION CONCESSIONS
abstract: UAL chief executive Glenn F Tilton says executives are meeting with union leaders at United Airlines to review concessions offered by company's five unions (S)

headline: Inquiry Said To Examine Citigroup Role In Enron Deal
abstract: Congressional investigators are examining series of undisclosed deals between Enron and Citigroup that raise questions about whether bank ignored its internal guidelines and sidestepped accounting requirements in order to satisfy important client; want to know why Citigroup went forward with deal called Sundance over strong objections of risk managers and others at bank; also probe Citigroup's investment of 3 percent of equity in off-the-books partnership called Bacchus, in which Enron placed its pulp and paper business, after receiving oral commitments that Enron would 'support' bank's investment; Sundance and Bacchus demonstrate aggressiveness in recent years of major banking institutions in putting together structured finance deals, which combine complex investment vehicles with efforts to evade or maneuver around accounting, tax and other rules (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Tightening The Border
abstract: Italian Interior Min Giuseppe Pisanu is temporarily reinstating border controls on European neighbors in hopes of preventing violent individuals or groups from disrupting antiglobalization meeting scheduled in Florence (S)

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: RUSSIA: Cyrillic For All; BOSNIA: Karadzic'S Wife Quits Red Cross Post; GERMANY: Bosnian Serb Prisoner Moves In; BOSNIA: U.N. Ends Police Training;.

headline: In Europe, Sex Slavery Is Thriving Despite Raids
abstract: US officials report mixed results from intensive European operation to crack down on trafficking of women for sex trade; 237 victims were identified and 239 traffickers arrested in 20,588 raids across Central and Eastern Europe in September, but little was done in Bosnia, considered center for international prostitution and major transit point to northern Europe; International Organization for Migration estimates that 700,000 women are transported, mostly involuntarily, over international borders each year for sex trade (M)

headline: Investing; Companies Are Divided On Providing Online Data
abstract: Great variation exists among companies concerning availability online of their financial information; some companies' Web sites contain company quarterly and annual reports going back many years; other sites reveal minimal historical financial data (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Natural gas prices for November delivery rise 1.5 cents, to $3.739 per million BTU's; graph; table of commodities indexes (S)

headline: BCE Sells Directory Unit
abstract: bce sells directory unit*

headline: Burry Port Journal; Sniff. What's Cooking? Funny Fuel, That's What.
abstract: Seaside village of Burry Port, Wales, is enjoying notoriety spawned by drivers perpetrating novel alternative-fuel scheme in which homemade mixture of methanol and cooking oil is being used in diesel-powered cars to avoid high fuel prices and corresponding excise taxes; police are arresting violators, impounding their cars and penalizing them with heavy fines; is tipped off usually by tell-tale odor of cooking oil in fuel tanks, which is said to smell like used French fry grease; map; photos (M)

headline: DYNEGY TO SELL A NATURAL GAS STORAGE SITE IN BRITAIN
abstract: Dynegy said yesterday that it had agreed to sell part of its British natural gas storage business to Scottish and Southern Energy for $202 million. Scottish & Southern, an owner of power plants in Britain, will buy the Hornsea storage site, which has 325 million cubic meters of storage space in nine caves, the companies said. Scottish and Southern, based in Perth, Scotland, said it hoped to tap rising demand for gas storage services in Britain. Dynegy, whose shares have fallen 96 percent this year, has been selling assets to raise cash after energy trading collapsed in the wake of the Enron Corporation's demise. Dynegy is based in Houston.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: TEMPLE-INLAND INC., Austin, Tex., a maker of lumber and boxes, agreed to sell Mid-America Packaging, a bag-making business, and a paper mill in Pine Bluff, Ark., to an undisclosed buyer for $41 million.    KRAFT FOODS INC., Northfield, Ill., a unit of Philip Morris, agreed to sell its Fleischmann's Latin American yeast and industrial bakery unit to Burns Philp, Sydney, Australia, a food processor, for $110 million.

headline: JUDGE BACKS TERMS OF U.S. SETTLEMENT IN MICROSOFT CASE
abstract: Judge Colleen Kollar-Kotelly, in hard-fought victory for Microsoft Corp, approves company's antitrust stettlement with Justice Department; rejects virtually all of stiffer sanctions sought by coalition of 9 state attorneys general; scores states for suggesting company be punished for actions beyond those covered in appeals court ruling; imposes some new obligations on company, requiring it to give competitors more data about its Windows operating system and to install compliance committee of board members; Microsoft chairman Bill Gates hails decision; chronology of events in case; photo (M)

headline: Many in Washington Are Waiting for United's Next Move
abstract: President Bush expressed ''respect'' today for the decision by a federal panel not to bail out United Airlines as even the airline's strongest supporters in Congress said there was little they could do to keep it from filing for bankruptcy protection from creditors.    But the next round of political warfare over United, the nation's second-largest airline, is certain to begin almost immediately.

headline: International Briefs | Europe: Belgium: Bank Posts Loss
abstract: Fortis, the DutchBelgian banking and insurance group, posted a worse-than-expected third-quarter loss of 1.61 billion euros. Anton van Rossum, left, the chairman, said that next year would also be difficult. ''The recovery is frustratingly slow,'' he said, adding that Fortis did not see a solid recovery until 2004. Weak stock prices in the quarter cost the bank 2 billion euros, it said, adding that the recent rebound in share prices has alleviated that loss. On Nov. 15, it was calculated at 1.5 billion euros.   Paul Meller (NYT)

headline: North Korea Told It Must Dismantle Nuclear Arms Project Promptly
abstract: US, Japan and South Korea call on North Korea to dismantle its nuclear weaons development program in prompt and verifiable manner (S)

headline: The Many Flavors Of Tort Reform
abstract: Harley Schnall letter concerns Nov 17 article on tort law reform and federalizing class-action lawsuits

headline: Laborites Meet and Blair Takes a Beating
abstract: This working-class resort on the Irish Sea is the busiest vacation spot in Britain, but delegates to the Labor Party annual conference here were in no holiday mood today as they greeted their leader, Prime Minister Tony Blair.     Their anger at him boiled over on two issues: his unflagging support for President Bush in the campaign against Iraq and his government's determination to raise funds for Britain's crippled public services by tapping private money.

headline: Chief Steps Down At Chain of Casinos
abstract: Thomas Gallagher resigns as president and chief executive of Park Place Entertainment Corp, whose shares and earnings lag those of rivals; Wallace Barr, chief operating officer, will succeed him (S)

headline: Protest Against G.I.'s Leads to Breaching Of Post Near Seoul
abstract: Over 50 protesters break through fence around Camp Red Cloud, Uijongbu, South Korea, and parade for 35 minutes through strategic American military post demanding American troops leave nation; Korean police arrest marchers (M)

headline: World Briefing: Middle East
abstract: LEBANON: Disputed Water Project Tested;.

headline: Pakistanis Test Ballistic Missile
abstract: Pakistan successfully test-fires Shaheen-1 medium-range ballistic missile, fourth in series of tests since late May; terse government press release offers few details (S)

headline: Grand Soviet Scheme for Sharing Water in Central Asia Is Foundering
abstract: Soviet Union's grand water projects that turned desert and scrub of Central Asia into great cotton-growing region is being sundered by capitalism, nationalism and legacy of waste; Soviet Union, controlling land from mountainous Chinese border to Caspian Sea, remade Amu and Syr Rivers, building 20,000 miles of canals, 45 dams and more than 80 reservoirs; photos; map; failure to use water efficiently now threatens economic and social crisis in region already racked by Islamic insurgencies and oppressive rule; Uzbekistan, its arid neighbors Turkmenistan and Kazakhstan and mountainous neighbors Tajikistan and Kyrgyzstan have drunk dry natural flow of two great rivers, reducing Aral Sea to lifeless brine lakes; five countries have swelling populations and do not keep up repairs to water systems, causing staggering waste; raising water prices could wipe out entire class of small farmers; Kremlin's original scheme to link wild rivers and glaciers of mountains with arid plains described (M)

headline: The Envelope, Please: Those Bonuses Come Crawling Back
abstract: Company executives, union officials and compensation consultants say that millions of varied American workers, from manufacturing employees to chief executives, will be pleasantly surprised by upcoming word about their annual bonuses; say bonus checks this year will outstrip last year's despite plethora of layoffs, bankruptcies and falling stock prices; drawing; photos; table of compensation statistics (M)

headline: Kenya Joyful as Moi Yields Power to New Leader
abstract: After 39 years of domination, Kenyan Pres Daniel arap Moi hands over power to new president Mwai Kibaki, in ceremony many Kenyans never expected to see; Kibaki, who has vowed to change course of beleaguered country, pledges to begin immediately to revive economy, stamp out corruption and rebuild government; expectations are high among those who turn out to witness transition (M)

headline: FIVE QUESTIONS for MICHAEL F. JACOBSON; The 'Organic' Label: Who Wins at the Bank?
abstract: Michael F Jacobson, executive director of Center for Science in the Public Interest, answers questions about Agriculture Department's new standards on food approved for being labeled 'organic'; photo (M)

headline: Candidates In South Korea Differ Sharply On the North
abstract: South Korean presidential candidates differ sharply in debate on approaches to North Korea; Roh Moo Hyun defends Pres Kim Dae Jung's 'sunshine' policy of engagement; conservative rival Lee Hoi Chang alludes to North's reported nuclear weapons program, saying he would make clean break and stop financial support; they and Kwon Young Gil say they would move to renegotiate agreement on legal rights and conduct of US troops, subject of intense protests (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Canadian Tourism Commission awards its advertising account to Palmer Jarvis DDB; Crispin Porter & Bogusky will handle creative advertising for Buca Inc (S)

headline: Kurds Keep a Wary Eye on the Iraq Border, Open for Now
abstract: Kurds living in Chamchamal in militarized zone between Iraq proper and autonomous Kurdish enclave in nation's northern mountains, which is out of Saddam Hussein's control, keep wary eye on border; in theory, flatlands are contested no-man's zone, front watched over by opposing armies; in practice, area is guarded as much by intuition as arms; for the moment, Kurds think possibility of Iraqi advance is remote; Kurds predict that Hussein faces war; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Utility Expands
abstract: Gaz de France, French utility seeking to offset its embattled domestic business with growth outside France, agrees to pay 1 billion euros for Preussag Energie, oil and gas business of TUI, German conglomerate (S)

headline: ARAMARK IS BUYING FINE HOST FOR ABOUT $100 MILLION
abstract: Aramark plans to buy food service manager Fine Host Corp for about $100 million (S)

headline: Serbia's Runoff Candidates Fight Voter Apathy
abstract: Voter apathy may prevent Vojislav Kostunica, the nationalist who in his job as president of Yugoslavia has criticized free market reforms, from becoming the Serbian president.

headline: Executive Pensions Eclipse Years on the Job
abstract: Array of rules and customs have put distance between retirement benefits of average workers and those of top executives; most rank-and-file workers with traditional pensions receive one year of credit for each year of service, and only their salary counts in determining benefits; many executives can also count their annual bonuses; John W Snow, Pres Bush's nominee to be Treasury Secretary, will receive pension from CSX Corp based on salary, bonuses and also value of 250,000 shares of stock CSX board gave him; if confirmed, Snow would oversee new pension rules announced by Bush administration last week that experts say can be expected to strip benefits from older workers, while benefiting younger workers and saving companies money; experts on executive pension plans say executives are seeking to increase their pensions in part to balance risk they will go unpaid because of corporate failure; note that unlike pensions for ordinary workers, executive plans are not guaranteed by government; photo; graph (M)

headline: Technology News Briefing
abstract: SOFTWARE SHARES IN 2 VIDEO GAME COMPANIES FALL Share prices of two video game companies dropped markedly yesterday, as industry analysts have begun to wonder whether video game sales will be as robust this holiday season as originally expected. Shares in Eidos P.L.C., based in Britain, fell about 15 percent, to 84 pence, after the company said it would delay the release of

headline: A Writer Who Followed His Own Clues to Fame
abstract: Profile of and interview with Italian writer Andrea Camilleri; photo (M)

headline: To Be Rich, Chinese and in Trouble: 3 Tales
abstract: Chinese government is selectively enforcing tax, securities and zoning laws on handful of businesmen and celebrities known for flaunting their wealth and proclaiming their independence; is sending clear signals that capitalists should not act like rogues; has arrested Liu Xiaoqing, actress and businesswoman who proclaimed herself China's first female billionaire, and Yang Bin, troubled orchid tycoon who tried to transform himself into North Korea's capitalist ambassador; Yang Rong, automobile executive who sought better official treatment by threatening to move operations, had to flee to Los Angeles; photos (M)

headline: Private Sector; Governance Issue Takes a Trip Abroad
abstract: Class-action plaintiffs seek to recover and return to Tyco International shareholders $4 million that former chairman L Dennis Kozlowski made to Cambridge University to endow chair to promote research into corporate governance; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Food Company Bid Challenged
abstract: World Business Briefing: Australia: Fo

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: No Time for TiVo.

headline: Microsoft to Invest $400 Million in India
abstract: Moving to expand Microsoft's market share in one of the world's largest emerging markets, Bill Gates said the software giant would spend $400 million in India over the next three years.

headline: A Test of Synergy; A Film May Not Need a Media Conglomerate To Ensure the Widest Exposure
abstract: How successfully moviegoers are drawn to new James Bond and Harry Potter films will serve as test of whether combining Hollywood studios, television networks, magazines, cable systems and other disparate media businesses can create whole greater than sum of its parts; Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, stand-alone studio, is counting on 007's astonishing allure to enlist other marketers in promoting its film and eventually to win broadcast and cable audiences as well, whereas Warner Brothers can count on other media divisions of AOL Time Warner to help launch and maximize profits on Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets; Alex Yemenidjian, MGM chairman and chief executive, believes 'synergy' like AOL's is overrated; photos (M)

headline: Private Sector; A Canadian Oilman Gives In
abstract: Talisman Energy chief executive James W Buckee discusses decision to sell company's stake in Sudanese oil project, which human-rights advocates say has propped up one of most repressive regimes in world and prolonged civil war; still believes that Talisman was positive influence in Sudan; says he had to consider employee morale in face of quite hysterical antagonism; photo (M)

headline: Aide Says Korean Economy Could Weather Most Crises
abstract: Senior South Korean economic advisor, Hyun Jung Taik, says country is all but immune to any repeat of late-1990's economic crises; cites its $117 billion in foreign exchange reserves, $89.9 billion current account surplus and 115 million barrel stockpile of oil; major corporate earnings reports suggest uneven revival of national economy and portend danger in some sectors of economy (M)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Figure In 1971 Massacre Dies
abstract: Alfonso Martinez, former mayor of Mexico City and prominent figure in 1971 massacre of 29 student protestors, dies leaving unanswered questions regarding incident; photo (S)

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: Student Leaders Released
abstract: Four student protesters arrested after demonstrations supporting reformist scholar Hashem Aghajeri are released; are expected to appear in court to answer variety of charges, including creating unrest at universities and debasing government and religious leaders (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Pipeline Is Planned
abstract: Petroleo Brasileiro SA plans to build 450-mile, $1.1 billion pipeline linking offshore oil wells to onshore refineries (S)

headline: Germany Muffs Israeli Tank Sale: Is Fax Blurry?
abstract: Germany, in embarrassing mixup, may rescind plan to sell Fuchs tanks to Israel; Chancellor Gerhard Schroder approved sale of tanks equipped to detect chemical, nuclear and biological arms, which he described as primarily defensive; Israel sought standard version of tank, which analysts say is ideal for urban military incursions; officials say letter containing Israeli request was faxed and refaxed as it made way up chain of command and was hard to read by time it reached Defense Min Peter Struck's office; Struck apologizes for misunderstanding (M)

headline: Major Suspect in Bali Bombing Is Arrested in Indonesia
abstract: Authorities arrested a man who they say was behind a series of terrorist attacks, including the bombing of a disco.

headline: Business; In Every Building, Turn, Turn, Turn
abstract: New turnstiles have been installed in many high-rise office buildings accross nation since Sept 11; security devices are equipped with sleek metal casings and optical sensors which allow entry only to those with identity cards; photo (M)

headline: Helping Children Learn, but Not Forgetting the Fun
abstract: Teacher Alice Keim offers her suggestions of best educational programs for children to use at home, blending fun with learning; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Mazda's Profit Rises
abstract: Mazda Motor Corp reports first-half profit of 5.6 billion yen ($47 million), compared with 1.3 billion yen year earlier; says that Gideon Wolthers will succeed Bob Shanks as chief financial officer (S)

headline: A Nomadic Way of Life Is at Risk in Afghanistan
abstract: Nomads known as Kuchi have lived in Afghanistan for centuries; Kuchi have special place in Afghan life; they are both feared and romanticized, and have always been powerful within tribal system as country's main providers of meat, sheepskins and wool; because of war and drought their numbers have dwindled and those who survive have fallen into penury; situation they face is so bad that Afghan and foreign aid officials have started program to try to save them and their way of life; photos (M)

headline: Iran and Russia Sign Accord to Speed Nuclear Power Project
abstract: Iran and Russia sign agreement to speed completion of nuclear power plant that US fears could help Iran build nuclear weapons; Russia will provide fuel for reactor for ten years; US says Iran's large oil and gas reserves make it unnecessary to develop nuclear energy, but Russian Min Aleksandr Rumyantsev brushes off US pressure, saying cooperation is based on international regulations (M)

headline: Unions and advocacy groups are putting a Madison Avenue finesse on their protest ads.
abstract: Nat Ives column on new marketing acumen shown by advocacy groups in recent advertisements, which have much of same humor, sex appeal and imagery as mainstream consumer advertising; photo (M)

headline: Pouring Paint, Minus a Mess
abstract: Adam Chafe, director for marketing at Dutch Boy Paint division of Sherwin-Williams Co, comments on his work repackaging Dutch Boy in all-plastic gallon container with twist-off lid, side handle and pour spout; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing: Middle East
abstract: SAUDI ARABIA: Deadly Cologne, Down The Hatch; IRAN: Video Dealers Will Be Whipped; TURKEY: Prosecutor Seeks 1,235-Year Sentence;.

headline: A Networked World's Final Frontier: the Airplane
abstract: Some airline passengers defy ban on in-flight use of electronic communication devices that emit radio signal, including cellphones, pagers, personal digital assistants, and laptop computers with wireless Internet connections; whether devices compromise safety is matter of some debate; FCC issued ban not out of concern for passengers' safety, but because using cellphones in air can cause problems with wireless networks on ground, and it does not actually ban devices, but rather prohibit airlines from allowing passengers to use them unless carriers can prove devices do not interfere with communications systems; photo (M)

headline: Chairman of Fiat Wins Fight To Hold Control of Company
abstract: Fiat's board retains Paolo Fresco as c

headline: In Kenyan Elections, Break With the Past
abstract: Daniel arap Moi's decision to step down after 24 years as president of Kenya is seen across Africa as a moment of hope, a sign that a continent too well known for its authoritarian rulers and for the corruption that often flourishes can turn back toward democracy.    The man who expects to become president in elections today, Mwai Kibaki, 71, has made a long journey from a mud hut to a grand home in Nairobi. He emphasizes his decision to break with Mr. Moi a decade ago, and claims credit for helping to build an opposition movement.

headline: CREDIT SUISSE FIRST BOSTON NAMES FINANCIAL OFFICER
abstract: Credit Suisse First Boston hires Barb ra A Yastine as chief financial officer (S)

headline: Technology Briefing: Hardware
abstract: WESTERN DIGITAL RESULTS BEAT ESTIMATES; DELL SAID TO REGAIN NO. 1 SPOT IN PC MARKET; GATEWAY'S RESULTS MEET EXPECTATIONS;.

headline: Business; The Enron Shelf Is More Crowded
abstract: William J Holstein reviews three books about collapse of Enron Corp; they are Pipe Dreams: Greed, Ego and the Death of Enron, by Robert Bryce; Anatomy of Greed: The Unshredded Truth from an Enron Insider, by Brian Cruver; and Enron: The Rise and Fall, by Loren Fox (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: Phone Company Stake Sold
abstract: Taiwan's government sells 13.5 percent of state-owned Chunghwa Telecom Co to consortium of domestic companies for $1.88 billion (S)

headline: On a Plain Vanilla Mouse, Some Decorative Child's Play
abstract: New computer mouse from KidzMouse comes with stickers that can be removed whenever child wants a different look; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Northwest Airlines Reaches Pact With Expedia
abstract: Northwest Airlines reaches accord to sell its tickets again through Expedia, largest online travel agency; specific terms undisclosed (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Japanese yen hits three-month low against dollar after report signals that Japan's economy could contract and Tokyo's market decline; in New York, yen settles at 124.26 to dollar, from 123.22; graph; chart (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Net Up At Electronics Maker
abstract: LG Electronics posts third-quarter profit of $93 million in contrast to loss of nearly $400 million year earlier (S)

headline: Once Again, North Korea Unsettles South Korea's Politics
abstract: Political analysts in Seoul say that with one week to go in South Korea's tight left-right race for president, search and release of North Korea freighter carrying Scud missiles may help conservative candidate Lee Hoi Chang by reminding voters of North Korean military threat; liberal candidate Roh Moo Hyun appears eager to play down incident (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Burberry's Sales Rise
abstract: Burberry Group reports sales for six months ended Sept 30 rose 17 percent; plans to open eight new stores later this year (S)

headline: DOVEBID, AN AUCTION HOUSE, HALTS INITIAL STOCK OFFERING
abstract: Auction house DoveBid scraps $60 million initial public offering (S)

headline: WAL-MART CAUTIOUS ON NOVEMBER SALES FORECAST
abstract: Wal-Mart Stores expects November sales at stores open at least year to rise at low end of its forecast, 2 percent to 4 percent (S)

headline: A Tough Case: How to Convict Hussein
abstract: News analysis of difficulty of verifying suspicions about Iraq's weapons of mass destruction (M)

headline: Bahrain Says 52% Vote Turnout Meets Democratic Goals
abstract: Voters in Bahrain cast ballots to elect parliament for first time in nearly 30 years; government calls election success, pointing to 52-percent voter turnout; government had earlier downplayed expectations for turnout, apprehensive of efforts by political groups to boycott polls; country's largest Shiite organization has denounced country's new Constitution and elections it enshrines as nothing more than show; elections are part of efforts by ruling Khalifa fmily, Sunni Muslims, to appease Shiite Muslims; elections are being watched closely by Bush administration as test of whether democracy and Islam wil provecompatible in Middle East; photo (M)

headline: G.E. Says It Is Dropping 2 Directors From Board
abstract: General Electric Co announces that two directors will step down as it moves to strengthen corporate governance and make its board more independent; they are Scott McNealy and Paolo Fresco (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Financier Sells Chemical Stake
abstract: Martin Ebner will sell his $575 million stake in Lonza, Swiss maker of chemicals, and step down as its chairman in attempt to shore up his ailing BZ Group; likelihood of his divestitures at fire-sale prices unnerves Swiss stock market and companies in which BZ holds shares; photo (M)

headline: O'Neill, in Afghanistan, Promises to Push $2.3 Billion Aid Bill
abstract: Treasury Sec Paul H O'Neill, visiting Afghanistan, says Pres Bush will push Congress to approve $2.3 billion aid bill for nation's reconstruction; visits development projects; meets with Pres Hamid Karzai and Finance Min Ashraf Ghani Ahmedzai; visit helps highlight United States's shift in emphasis from military and emergency aid to reconstruction and economic development (M)

headline: Francisco Zarco Journal; Vino and Vindication: Mexican's Glass Runs Over
abstract: francisco zarco journal: vino and vi

headline: 45 Nations Set to Back Rules On Illicit Diamond Trading
abstract: Representaties of 45 countries that produce, sell or trade in diamonds gather in Interlaken, Switzerland, to endorse beginnings of Kimberley Process, system to prevent Africa's warlords from fueling their conflict through so-called blood diamonds; many of advocacy groups that first inspired debate charge that system of written warranties offered by diamond-cutting and -trading business to complement government effort is critically flawed because it cannot be audited; photo (M)

headline: Priceline Awards Account to Gotham
abstract: Priceline.com in Norwalk, Conn., has awarded its creative account to Gotham in New York, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies. Spending is estimated at $30 million to $40 million.    Priceline, the online seller of discounted airline tickets, hotel rooms and other travel services, had handled creative duties internally since May, when the company parted ways with the New York office of Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos, also part of Interpublic. Ocean Media in Huntington Beach, Calif., continues handling media planning and buying.

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Death Sentence For Nerve Gas Attack
abstract: Seiichi Endo, leader of Japanese cult that killed 12 people and sickened thousands in gas attack on Tokyo's subway system in 1995, is sentenced to death; Endo was so-called health minister of Aum Shinrikyo cult, and admitted producing sarin gas used in attack (S)

headline: Irish Vote on European Union Expansion
abstract: Irish voters apparently give overwhelming endorsement to European Union expansion, which they rejected only last year; photos; expansion would add ten new members, mostly onetime Soviet satellites (S)

headline: Merrill Changes Intel Rating to 'Sell'
abstract: Merrill Lynch & Co analyst Joseph Osha lowers ratings on Intel and five competitors to sell from neutral (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Economic Growth
abstract: British economy grows at annual rate of 1.7 percent in third quarter, slightly faster than second quarter's 1.3 percent increase (S)

headline: SECURITY COUNCIL GETS U.S. PROPOSAL ON DISARMING IRAQ
abstract: United States formally presents full Security Council with draft resolution that includes threat of military action against Iraq, sharply increasing pressure on France, Russia and China to agree to tough measure to force Baghdad to disarm; draft is submitted to all 15 Council nations as means for US to show reluctant allies that it has sufficient support among 10 other members; American diplomats are calculating that neither France, Russia nor China would veto resolution, but latest move forces pace and puts pressure on five to decide soon how they would vote (M)

headline: Glaxo Forms An Alliance In Biotech
abstract: Exelixis Inc enters into broad collaboration with GlaxoSmithKline to discover and develop drugs for cancer, inflammatory diseases and disorders involving blood vessels; deal could result in payments to Exelixis of up to several hundred million dollars; Glaxo will pay Exelixis $30 million up front and will pay additional $14 million to acquire two million shares of Exelixis stock, which represents 3 percent stake, at $7 per share, double market price; will also provide minimum of $90 million in development financing to Exelixis over six years and loan of up to $85 million (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Jobless Rate Falls
abstract: Hong Kong unemployment rate falls to 7.1 percent in period from September through November, fourth consecutive decline; strong exports from mainland China by way of Hong Kong, and influx of mainland Chinese tourists, are creating jobs even as Hong Kong's economy stagnates (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: O'Neill and Lindsey Ousted As Bush Seeks a New Team  President Bush, wrestling with a shaky economy and criticism that his administration projects a muddled message on how to respond, dismissed Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill, left, and the director of his National Economic Council, Lawrence B. Lindsey.    Administration officials conceded that Mr. O'Neill had lost the confidence of the markets and of White House officials, especially his initial champion, Vice President Dick Cheney. In coming months, as the White House rolls out a new tax plan, and other economic measures to show that the president is as focused on the economy as he is on terrorism, the officials said it was crucial that their team speak clearly and with one voice. [Page A1.]

headline: Israeli Army Kills Gaza Woman And Wounds Her 3 Children
abstract: Palestinian woman is killed and her three children wounded by Israeli soldiers near Israeli settlement in Gaza; soldiers fired after spotting six armed Palestinian men approaching settlement; two soldiers are injured by bomb under jeep near Lebanon border; map (S)

headline: Karachi Journal; For a Sickening Encounter, Just Turn on the Tap
abstract: Gen Javed Ashraf is Pakistan leadership's hand-picked managing director of Karachi Sewer and Water Board, given daunting task of solving city's water problems; recent analysis by government water experts finds at least 70 percent of all Karachi water samples fouled by microbes, chemical pollutants, or both; Karachi water has been linked to 50 separate intestinal and skin ailments; even many brands of bottled water are too contaminated for safe drinking; city's main source of water is heavily polluted Indus River; water board chlorinates much of city's water, but constant emptying and refilling of mains strains pipes and creates bacteria-attracting leaks; photo (M)

headline: When the people who make ad decisions gather, they are sitting ducks for hard and soft sells.
abstract: Some of highlights, lowlights and sidelights from annual conference of Association of National Advertisers in Naples, Fla (M)

headline: 2 Afghan Detainee Deaths Investigated
abstract: Two detainees have died in American military custody at the Bagram Air Base, north of Kabul, this month, prompting an army investigation.

headline: Panel to Decide If Schröder Lied On Economy
abstract: Germany's lower house of Parliament creates committee to determine whether politicians lie in an election; opposition Christian Democrats proposed panel to see whether Chancellor Gerhard Schroder and others in governing party inflated economic figures before September federal elections to hide growing budget deficit; Social Democrats responded by insisting on widening panel's mission to include government finances under Christian Democrats in 1990's (M)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Searching For White Militants
abstract: South African authorities search almost 100 rural homes and farms attempting to root out white separatist militants thought to be responsible for several recent anti-government bombings (S)

headline: Out Front in Brazilian Runoff, Leftist Is Wary of a Spill
abstract: Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva of left-wing Workers' Party faces Jose Serra in Brazil's runoff presidential election; da Silva won twice as many votes as Serra in first round, but neither candidate seems to consider outcome of runoff a foregone conclusion, and both are trying to strengthen their bases of support (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Verisign Sees Lower Revenue
abstract: VeriSign Inc's giving up control of dot-org domain is expected to reduce revenue by about $4 million in 2003; Versign is giving up its management of dot-org domain at end of 2002 under deal with Internet Corp for Assigned Names and Numbers and Commerce Department; Icann voted in October to appoint Internet Society to run dot-org database (S)

headline: Eclipse Drops Williams Engine for New Jet
abstract: Eclipse Aviation ends its engine-supply contract with Williams International because Williams failed to deliver engine that is suitable and on schedule for new Eclipse business jet aircraft (S)

headline: Anger Builds and Seethes as Arabs Await American Invader
abstract: Anti-American demonstrations in Cairo, Egypt, seen reflecting deep fear in Arab world that if US attacks Iraq, it will then impose long-term military control; at issue is prospect that American government, backed by its military, may exert daily administrative control over swath of Arab soil for long period; idea summons up angry emotions in region where sensitivities about colonial past run deep; photo (M)

headline: Germany Urges U.S. to Drop Death Penalty Plan
abstract: German Interior Min Otto Schily urges Bush administration to drop its plans to seek death penalty for Zacarias Moussaoui, only person charged in American court with involvement in Sept 11 terror attacks; suggests that move might be only way to end dispute over Germany's failure to provide United States with its intelligence files on terror suspect; Schily says his government maintains 'whole file' on Moussaoui; says German law bars release of intelligence files to United States if American prosecutors continue to press for Moussaoui's execution (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: Chip Company's Profit Misses
abstract: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co's third-quarter net income almost tripled to 3.2 billion Taiwan dollars ($92 million) from 1.2 billion year earlier (S)

headline: I.B.M. Plans To Announce Tiny Transistor
abstract: IBM develops world's smallest transistor, just nine nanometers in length, better than one-tenth size of most advanced transistor currently in production; tiny transistor will allow for high-capacity memory and faster digital logic abilities; will help to ensure that semiconductor industry can fulfill its performance projections through at least 2016 (S)

headline: Asian Companies Relieved over Reopening of U.S. Ports
abstract: Businesses across East Asia express relief after Pres Bush wins temporary court order to reopen 29 West Coast ports in US, although worries persist that underlying labor dispute has not been resolved; 11-day shutdown of ports does not appear to have lasted long enough to inflict serious damage on big exporters like China, Japan and Taiwan (M)

headline: Fox's Program Beats Out 'Larry King Live'
abstract: Fox News Channel's program Hannity & Colmes, politically oriented talks show with Sean Hannity and Alan Colmes as co-hosts, beats out Larry King Live for first time since that program made its debut 16 years ago; Nielsen Media Research says Hannity & Colmes squeaked by Larry King Live with average audience of 1.65 million people this month; King has been watched by audience of 1.58 million people so far this month; reversal of fortune further solidifies Fox News Channel's new standing as most-watched cable news network, title it took from CNN for first time in January (M)

headline: Nokia Shows Way to Profit In an Industry In a Slump
abstract: Nokia reports net income for period ended Sept 30 of 610 million euros ($598.8 million), up from 186 million euros ($182.6 million) year earlier; sales grew 2 percent, to 7.2 billion euros ($7.1 billion); photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Officials Quit After Suspect's Death
abstract: South Korean Justice Min Kim Jung Kil and Prosecutor General Lee Myung Jae resign and apologize for murder suspect's death during Seoul police interrogation; relatives of Cho Cheun Hun hold he was tortured to death; civic groups call for full inquiry; photo (S)

headline: Economic Scene; When it comes to crystal-ball gazing, the Fed trounces the private sector.
abstract: Hal R Varian Economic Scene article on some reasons Federal Reserve's economic forecasts are better than those of private sector organizations; says Fed devotes far more resources to forecasting than even largest commercial forecasters; chairman Alan Greenspan's ability to interpret data discussed; photo (M)/

headline: Fare Idea Returns To Haunt Airlines
abstract: Orbitz, online travel service founded three years ago by airline industry members to counter power of other Internet reservations sites, is compounding industry's falling revenue; fares continue to ratchet lower at time when carriers struggle for greater cash flow; Orbitz, its competitors and Web sites established by airlines themselves combine to insure inexorably lower airfares; photos; graphs (M)

headline: Wall St. and the Nursery School: A New York Story
abstract: Jack B Grubman, former star telecommunications analyst at Salomon Smith Barney unit of Citigroup, told friend in e-mail message last year that Citigroup chairman Sanford I Weill, his boss, helped to secure spots in exclusive nursery school for Grubman's twin daughters after Grubman reversed himself and began to recommend that investors buy AT&T; Citigroup acknowledges that Weill, who was AT&T director, tried to help Grubman's children get into school by making $1 million donation, but denies it was connected to Grubman's upgrading of AT&T shares; circumstances surrounding Grubman's abrupt change in fall of 1999 to upbeat view of AT&T from long-held negative one has come under intense scrutiny from investigators in office of New York Atty Gen Eliot Spitzer and NASD; they are trying to assess whether research practices at Salomon Smith Barney unit of Citigroup were corrupted by firm's investment banking relationships with corporations; soon after Grubman upgraded AT&T, Salomon reaped lucrative fees from offering of shares in AT&T's wireless subsidiary; photos (M)

headline: INVESTING WITH/Colin C. Ferenbach; Tocqueville Alexis Fund
abstract: Carole Gould column on investment strategy and results of Colin C Ferenbach, who manages Tocqueville Alexis mutual fund for Tocqueville Asset Management; photo; statistical table and graph (M)

headline: The Contributors
abstract: Product descriptions for the Holiday Buying Guide were compiled from these contributors:    OUTDOORS -- Ian Austen, J.D. Biersdorfer    CAMERAS -- Ian Austen, David Pogue, J.D. Biersdorfer, Alan Krauss

headline: Netanyahu Vows to Oust Arafat if Elected
abstract: Benjamin Netanyahu vows to expel Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat if he is elected Israel's prime minister, speech to Likud Party convention, Tel Aviv; Prime Min Ariel Sharon casts himself as responsible centrist, winning loudest applause at convention; warns move against Arafat could strain United States ties; Israeli soldiers blow up home of Palestinian leader Muhammad Nayfeh, Shuwaika, West Bank; army says he sent gunman who killed five people at Kibbutz Metzer; Israeli forces backed by dozens of tanks and helicopters reportedly launch predawn raid on Nablus; photos (M)

headline: New Venture Hopes to Offer Some Peace of Mind to C.E.O.'s
abstract: Insurance firm Marsh Inc, accounting advisor FTI Consulting and law firms Patton Boggs and Fulbright & Jaworski join forces to form new consulting venture, Corporate Diagnostics, which review financial records and corporate governance structures, perhaps leading to reduced premiums for officers' and directors' liability insurance (M)

headline: Everybody Ought To Have An Aide
abstract: Abby Ellin column on independent professionals who have personal assistants to take care of everyday minutiae; drawing (M)

headline: World Briefing: Africa
abstract: IVORY COAST: Regional Official Meets Rebels; KENYA: President Dissolves Parliament; CENTRAL AFRICAN REPUBLIC: Gunfire In Capital;.

headline: Kirshenbaum Bond Awarded
abstract: Kirshenbaum Bond Awarded Timex The Timex Corporation in Middlebury, Conn., has awarded its account to Kirshenbaum Bond & Partners in New York, part of the Kirshenbaum Bond Creative Network. Billings were estimated at $6 million to $10 million.

headline: AQUILA, A MIDWESTERN UTILITY, NAMES FINANCIAL OFFICER
abstract: Midwestern utility company Aquila Inc names Rick Dobson interim chief financial officer, succeeding Dan Streek (S)

headline: Trade Groups Agree On Pay Guidelines
abstract: Trade organizations representing agencies and advertisers agree for first time on guidelines for compensation agreements between their members (S)

headline: Two G.I.'s Wounded In Attack in Kabul
abstract: Two American Special Forces soldiers and their Afghan translator are wounded when attacker throws grenade into their jeep at busy downtown Kabul intersection; incident is first direct attack on American soldiers in city since Taliban fell from power; bystanders and police seize attackers, two of whom admit trying to kill Americans (S)

headline: Technology Briefing: Telecommunications
abstract: AIRGATE MAY BE IN DEFAULT AFTER FILING DELAY; CENTURYTEL BID FOR DIGITAL TELEPORT ASSETS; NOKIA TO PROVIDE SERVICES TO FINNISH COMPANY;.

headline: Listen, City Hall
abstract: Sara Nicoll letter comments on Oct 3 article on local government response to e-mail

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Dell Introduces Smaller Server Unit
abstract: Dell Computer introduces smaller model for use in data centers where space is limited; seeks to gain market share from bigger rival Hewlett-Packard (S)

headline: Compressed Data; Enter Maze, and Find the Opt-Out Cheese
abstract: Anti-spam activists criticizes MP3.com, music site, on mechanism it uses to give visitors option of not receiving promotional e-mail; photo (M)

headline: Fated Russian Show Staged in Requiem
abstract: Cast of Russian musical Nord-Ost gives performance as memorial to hostages who died when Russian commandos ended standoff with Chechen terrorists holding them inside Moscow theater; photo; 17 of 76 cast members were among dead (M)

headline: 2 New Partners at Hicks, Muse
abstract: Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst promotes Joe Colonnetta and Andrew S Rosen to partner positions (S)

headline: Article 2002112191542700350 -- No Title
abstract: function pop_me_up(pURL, features) { new_window = window.open(pURL, "popup_window", features); new_window.focus(); } Point and Shoot, Show and Tell A Good Camera Is Just the Start of the Digital Photography Experience

headline: New Kind of Celebrity Promoter Says the Words and Has Her Say
abstract: Some companies that use celebrities to promote products are getting them involved in substantive product and advertising decisions to counter intensifying consumer skepticism about motivations and trustworthiness of celebrity endorsers; among celebrities taking on new responsibilities are Michael Jordan, who oversees design and selling of Jordan line of apparel and footwear sold by Nike, Star Jones, who passes judgment on shoe prototypes being considered by Payless ShoeSource, actresses Meredith Baxter and Victoria Principal, who have created skin-care products, and Jennifer Lopez, who has veto power over design of bottle for her new fragrance, Glow by J.Lo; photo (M)

headline: 14 Die as Bomb-Filled S.U.V. Rams Israeli Bus
abstract: Sport utility vehicle primed with powerful bomb slams into Israeli bus at rush hour in Karkur Junction, igniting bus's fuel tank and killing at least 14 passengers and wounding 50 others; flames turn bus into blackened, contorted skeleton; seven other vehicles are destroyed or damaged by explosion; debris and body parts are blasted over area larger than football field; militant group Islamic Jihad takes responsibility for attack, calling it retaliation for Israeli military operations in West Bank and Gaza Strip that resulted in civilian deaths; Israeli security officials believe two Palestinian terrorists were in SUV when it exploded; say Islamic Jihad's leadership in Damascus, Syria, is ultimately to blame; photo; map (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Bosnia: Policemen Fired For Aiding Sex Traffic
abstract: United Nations, in ongoing effort, dismisses 11 Bosnian policemen for involvement in prostitution; weak law enforcement and permeable borders contribute to rife market in Bosnia for criminals dealing in human trafficking (S)

headline: U.N. Arms Team Taking Up Its Task, a Mixture of 'Hide and Seek' and '20 Questions'
abstract: Success of United Nations inspectors in Iraq in 1990's in uncovering mountains of data and equipment involving development of weapons of mass destruction recalled as new UN team is set to resume task; nuclear inspectors documented major Iraqi push for atomic weapons; International Atomic Energy Agency removed Iraq's supply of highly enriched uranium by 1994 and eventually supervised or verified destruction of Iraq's known nuclear-arms installations and gear; inspectors, even after combing Iraq from 1991 to 1998 and uncovering and destroying tons of forbidden weapons, left with many unanswered questions; new team is armed with smaller, more powerful and easier to use gear and new, more aggressive inspection rules; map and table of likely weapons sites; photo (M)

headline: Personal Business; In a Quest for Travel Deals, to the Flexible Go the Spoils
abstract: Many attractive travel bargains exist for flexible vacationers willing to depart at last minute; some of best discounts, especially overseas, offer both airfare and hotel room; photo (M)

headline: Men and Women And Their Money
abstract: Study by Center for Women's Business Research reveals that wealthy women trust their financial advisors more than wealthy men do, but women spend more time than men making their own investment decisions (M)

headline: World Business Briefing: Europe
abstract: BRITAIN: Executive Moves At Cadbury; ITALY: Job Cuts Approved For Fiat; RUSSIA: Oil Auction; GERMANY: Siemens Unit Posts Profit;.

headline: Venezuela's Oil: Wellspring of Bad Blood
abstract: Vanguard of white-collar rebels in Venezuela vows to remain true to two-week national strike that has paralyzed oil exports from world's fifth-largest supplier; strikers aim to force Pres Hugo Chavez from power, charging that his left-wing government is leading Venezuela to ruin; Chavez's policies have divided Venezuelans as never before, and observers of two-week political standoff now warn that whoever controls $46 billion oil company, Petroleos de Venezuela, will gain upper hand and may well end up controlling country; photo; graph shows value of Venezuela's oil exports compared with other exports (M

headline: Confidence Erodes in Big Swiss Engineering Company
abstract: Shares of ABB Ltú

headline: Miscellany
abstract: American Association of Advertising Agencies presents its first Lifetime Achievement Awards to Philip B Dusenberry and Hal Riney (S)

headline: Indonesians Say They Suspect C.I.A. in Bali Blast
abstract: Many of educated elite in largely moderate Muslim country of Indonesia are blaming Central Intelligence Agency for Bali bombing that killed more that 180 people; reject United States suggestion that it was work of radical Islamic group with links to Al Qaeda; many Indonesians, especially moderate Muslim leaders, cannot accept idea that homegrown radical Islamic organization like Jemaah Islamiyah, headed by frail-loooking cleric Abu Bakar Bashir, could have had hand in terrorist act on its own soil; some Muslim leaders say it is not illogical to blame Washington for Bali violence, given history of US in Indonesia during cold war; photo (M)

headline: Judge Approves Sunbeam Recovery Plan
abstract: Federal bankruptcy judge Arthur Gonzalez approves Sunbeam Corp recovery plan; clears way for company to emerge from Chapter 11 reorganization; plan shows Justice Department investigates company's finances from 1996 through 1998 (S)

headline: ON THE GROUND: In Oakland; Stalwart Anchor City For Bay Area Economy
abstract: On the Ground column on places to stay, eat and visit for business travelers in Oakland, Calif; photo (M)

headline: Europe Strains To Put Laggards Back in Line
abstract: Europe's grand experiment in monetary union tied to euro appears to be fraying; analysts blame union's rule-bound rigidity, unforgiving global downturn and national politicians who still put interests of their own countries before those of united Europe; some member nations exceed budget deficits stipulated in rules made in more robust economic times, and deficits are apt to grow as governments spend more to counter effects of current recession; drawing; photos; table (M)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Guatemala: Deadly Prison Riot
abstract: Eighteen inmates are killed in Pavoncito prison riot for better food and visitation rights; Reuters reports dead inmates were mutilated and prison grounds turned into war zone; officials say they are in control of medium-security facility, but negotiations continue with prisoners (S)

headline: At Home Abroad/ Expat adviser : The dos and don'ts of Japanese etiquette
abstract: Q: I will be going to Tokyo on business this month, and I need some information regarding the cultural differences I may encounter in a professional setting.

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Network Associates Posts 3rd-Quarter Profit
abstract: Network Associates says third-quarter net income was $9.09 million compared with loss of $11.3 million year earlier; sales rose 13 percent, to $232.2 million (S)

headline: LIBBEY'S DECLINE IN PROFIT EXCEEDS FORECAST
abstract: Libbey Inc says third-quarter profit fell more than forecast as sales declined and expenses increased; sales fell to at least $104 million from $107 million (S)

headline: Generic Drug Sales Flourish Thanks to Big Companies
abstract: Pushed by big employers like General Motors and Verizon Communications, as well as health plans and managed care drug plans, sales of low-cost generic prescription drugs are surging to new highs. More than 4 in 10 prescriptions filled at retail pharmacy counters are generic.    Medco Health, the big pharmacy benefit management unit of the drug manufacturer Merck, said retail pharmacists and its own mail-order unit were substituting generics more than 92 percent of the time for brand-name drugs that had lost patent protection.

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Computer Associates Names New Executive
abstract: Computer Associates International names Robert Lamm, Florida lawyer, as director of corporate governance (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Bidding War For Steel Concern
abstract: World Business Briefing: S

headline: Biotech Company Plans Trials on Gene Therapy for Anemia
abstract: Ariad Pharmaceuticals plans clinical trials using gene therapy as cheaper and more convenient way to provide anemia drug erythropoietin (EPO); instead of constantly receiving injections of EPO as current therapy entails, patients' bodies would be able to produce their own (M)

headline: SUNRISE LOOKING TO BUY PROPERTIES FROM MARRIOTT
abstract: Sunrise Assisted Living and unnamed co-bidder seek to acquire Marriott International's senior living division, which supplies assisted-living housing for elderly (S)

headline: He Lit Up HBO. Now He Must Run It.
abstract: Profile of Chris Albrecht, chairman of HBO, and his effort to inject creativity in business side of network, which produced string of hit original series when he was programmer in chief; photos (M)
